Researchers studied how genetic variations in DNA affect gene expression in human lymphoblast cells, which are a type of immune cell. They found that changes in the way genes are processed at the end of their RNA, called polyadenylation, play a significant role in how much of the gene is made. This is different from previous studies that focused on changes in the DNA sequence before the gene is made into RNA. The team looked at how polyaden signals and other elements at the end of genes vary between individuals and found that they predict how much of the gene is made. They tested this in lab and found that changes in polyaden signals affect how much of the gene is made and that elements at the end of the gene control how much is made. They looked at one gene, IRF5, and found that changes in polyaden affect how it responds to antigen. The study shows that polyaden and elements at the end of genes are important in how genes are made and can be used to understand genetic variation in humans.
Researchers have studied the effectiveness of the SIVΔne vaccine, a weakened form of the simian immunodeficiency virus, in inducing protection against the wild-type virus. They used deep sequencing technology to analyze the CD8 T cell response, a type of immune cell that fights infection, in vaccinated animals. The study found that the initial CD8 response targets variable parts of the virus, but the virus quickly mutates and escapes. However, the CD8 cells adapt by targeting conserved parts of the virus and generating new responses to mutated variants. This adaptation correlates with the vaccine's protection. The researchers also found that the vaccine expands the CD8 cell repertoire, increasing its ability to fight the virus. The study highlights the importance of two key principles in vaccine design: anotropic specificity, targeting conserved parts of the virus, and repertoire depth, the range of responses. The SIVne vaccine, a gold standard in HIV research, demonstrates the significance of these principles.
Researchers studied how the body's immune system fights off a common fungal infection called Candida albicans in the mouth. They found that a protein called interleukin-1 (IL-1) plays a crucial role in this fight. IL-1 helps by controlling the number of neutrophils, a type of white blood cell, that attacks the fungus. It does this in two ways: by recruiting neutils from the bloodstream to the infected area and by making more neutils in the bone marrow. Without IL-1, the body can't fight the fungus as well, and the infection spreads. The researchers also found that IL-1 helps make a protein called granulocyte-colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) that helps neutils fight the fungus. G-CS is made by special cells in the mouth called endothelial cells, which respond to IL-1 released by other cells called keratinocytes. This shows how IL-1 talks to different parts of the immune system to fight the fungus. The study found two ways IL-1 helps neutils fight Candida in the mouth, which is important to prevent the fungus from spreading and keep the body healthy.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filari (GPE) delivered over 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals via mass administration of anti-filar drugs in at-risk areas for 4-6 years. The economic benefits of this achievement were calculated by quantifying the number of clinical manifestations averted and associated with disease prevention in the context of direct costs, indirect labor, and healthcare for affected individuals. Reviewing multiple sources, including the World Health Organization, International Fund, and Labour, an estimated $21.8 billion in economic benefits will be gained over the lifetime of 31.4 million treated during the first 8 years of GPE. This includes $2.3 billion from protection of nearly 3 million and individuals from acquiring lymphatic filari as a result of being born in areas freed transmission. Additionally, 28 million infected benefit from GLF halting progression, resulting in $19.5 billion economic benefit. At-risk individuals decreased services with reduced morbidity save health systems $2.2 billion. The Programme offers significant economic benefits, with favorable implementation largely due to donated drugs from the industry, showing a high return on investment.
Scientists have created a new animal model to study a rare genetic disorder called Gaucher disease, which affects the brain and nervous system. Gaucher disease is caused by a mutation in the GBA gene, which leads to a lack of an enzyme called glucocerebrosidase. This enzyme helps break down a fatty substance called glucocerebroside. Without it, the substance builds up in cells and causes problems. The new model, called GBA- medaka, is a type of fish that lacks glucerebrosase activity. Unlike humans and mice without the enzyme, G- medaka lived for months, allowing researchers to study the progression of the disease. They found that G- medaka developed brain problems similar to humans with Gaucher, including brain cell invasion, nerve loss, and inflammation. A key finding was the accumulation of a protein called alpha-synuclein (α-s) in nerve cells. Alpha-s is also linked to Parkinson's disease, another brain disorder. Surprisingly, removing α-s did not improve G- medaka's lifespan, nerve damage, or inflammation. The study shows G- med as a new model for Gaucher disease and how α-s builds up due to lack of glucerebrosase. It also suggests α-s plays a minor role in Gaucher's brain damage. Gaucher patients have higher risk of Parkinson's and α-s builds up in their brains. This study helps understand Gaucher and Parkinson's and may lead to new treatments.
Listeria monocytogen is a type of bacteria that can live inside cells and trigger a strong immune response from the body's immune system. To cause long-lasting protection, the bacteria must escape from a cell's digestive compartment called the phagosome and enter the cell's inner space called the cytosol. Researchers found that the immune system's response to bacteria trapped in the phosome is not weak because it can't present the right signals, but because it's actually suppressed. This suppression not only affects the response to bacteria in the phosome, but also to those in the cytos. When both phosome and cytos bacteria are present, the body can't develop immunity and the number of immune cells that fight the cytos bacteria is reduced. Bacteria in the phosome stop the production of pro-inflammatory signals and create a protein called IL-10, which blocks the immune response. Blocking IL-10 or removing a key protein called MyD restored immunity. The study shows that bacteria in phosome can affect the immune system by blocking signals for inflammation and creating immune cells.
Researchers have identified six genetic variants in the SIX gene associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), a leading cause of blindness worldwide. The variants were found in a study of 262 POAG cases and 256 controls, and included five rare and common changes. One variant, AsnHis (rs12345), was significantly associated with PO (OR=1.27, p=4.2×10-10) in the NEIGH/GLUGEN datasets. The variants were tested in a zebraf (zebrafish) model to evaluate eye and optic nerve structure. Five variants found in PO cases were hypomorphic or null, while one found in controls was benign. One variant increased SIX expression and disrupted its regulation. The study found a feature of PO patients dependent on SIX genotype: those homozygous for the risk allele (His) have a thinner retinal nerve layer than those homozyg for the non-risk (As) allele. This, combined with previous work, suggests SIX variants disrupt retina development, reducing ganglion cells and increasing glcoma risk.
Researchers have discovered a genetic switch that controls the production of flagella and toxins in the bacteria Clostridium difficile, a human intestinal pathogen that causes diarrhea. The flagella, or whip-like structures, help the bacteria attach to intestinal cells, while toxins cause disease. The genetic switch, called the "flagellar switch," is a 154-base pair sequence that can flip between two orientations. When in one orientation, the bacteria produce flagella and toxins, when in the other, they don't. The switch is reversible in the lab and requires a specific factor to degrade early flagella genes when in the "off" orientation. A tyrosine recombinase, RecV, is responsible for flipping the switch in both directions. 

The flag switch affects toxin production by impacting the gene σD, which makes glucyl toxins and cytotoxic C difficile. RecV also controls cell wall protein CV variation. Bacteria with the switch in the "on" orientation are motile, produce toxins, while those in the "off" orientation are not. Mutants with the switch locked in "on" or "off" show similar results. Toxin production is lower in bacteria with the switch in the "off" orientation.
Researchers studied the process of spore formation in the bacterium Clostridium difficile, a pathogen that causes infections in the intestines. This process, called sporulation, involves the creation of a highly resistant spore that helps the bacterium survive. In the model organism Bacillus subtilis, two types of RNA polymerase subunits, sigmaF and sigmaE, control spore development in the forespore and mother cell, respectively. These subunits are replaced by sigmaG and sigmaK at later stages. The researchers found that in Clostrid difficile, the main periods of activity of sigma factors are conserved, but activity of sigmaE is independent of sigmaF, sigmaG is dependent on sigmaE, and sigmaK does not require sigma. They also found that sigmaK is not necessary for spore formation. The study suggests that the level of spore network is conserved in evolution, with sigma factors acting as key regulators, established 2.5 billion years ago at the base of Firmic Phylum.
Researchers have developed a new framework to model the behavior of proteins that are activated by multiple sites, called alloster multisite proteins. These proteins are important in many biological processes, including cell growth and signaling. The model simplifies the complex behavior of these proteins by using a single variable, making it easier to understand and analyze. This is useful for studying systems where many proteins interact at once. The team applied the model to a new pathway in yeast that monitors cell growth and found it forms a "switch" that turns on when growth reaches a certain size. This pathway is made of three parts: a sensor that measures growth, a mechanism that reads the signal, and a response that triggers when the signal is strong enough. The model shows how these parts work together to control growth. The framework can also be used for other types of protein modifications, such as binding or methylation, and is a useful tool for understanding complex biological systems.
Scientists have long known that bacteria can communicate with each other through a process called quorum sensing, or QS, which helps them make decisions as a group. However, the inner workings of this process have been unclear. A team of researchers used a combination of experiments and math to study the QS system in E. coli, a type of bacteria. They broke down the system into smaller parts to understand how signals are sent and received. A new feedback mechanism was discovered and a key player, called Lsr, was found to be important. The team built a model to show how these parts work together, revealing how the "switch" in E. coli's QS system works. This approach can help understand other complex networks in bacteria and guide new uses for QS in technology.
In rural areas of Gabon, where both schistosomiasis and malaria are prevalent, a study investigated the effect of schistosias on Plasmod falcum infection in school-age children. The study found that schosias increased the risk of Plmod infection, especially when combined with Trichuris trichi or hookworm infection. Children infected with schos had a higher incidence of malaria over time, 0.51 per-year, compared to non-infected, with a significant delay in time to first malaria event in those aged 6-10 years. The study suggests that schos enhances susceptibility to malaria in young children, but not older children. This contradicts previous findings on schos-malaria co-infection, which may be due to unaccounted confounding factors. In areas where schos is endemic, its effect on malaria outcome is a concern. The study area is co-endemic for both infections, with up to 30% of children co-infected with Plmod and schos parasites. The results indicate that schos and STH co-infections cumulatively impact malaria in school children, and should be considered in malaria control programs.
Researchers have found that a protein called IRF-5 plays a key role in the body's inflammatory response to the parasite Leishmania infection. IR-5 triggers the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as IL-6 and TNF, which are necessary for a strong immune response. However, the study shows that IR-5 also limits the expansion of CD8 T cells, a type of immune cell that fights infection. IR-5 does this by inducing a protein called HIF-1 in dendritic cells, a type of immune cell that presents antigens to T cells. When H-1 is present, dendritic cells produce less IL-12, a cytokine that activates T cells, and more IL-10, which suppresses them. Without H-1, dendritic cells produce more IL-12 and less IL-10, allowing T cells to expand and fight infection more effectively. Mice without H-1 in dendritic cells had fewer parasites in their spleen, suggesting that H-1 helps Leish establish chronic infection. The study suggests that Leish uses H-1 as a way to evade the immune system.
American visceral leishmanias (VL) is a serious health problem in regions like the Indian subcontinent, North Africa, and South America. It's one of the world's most neglected diseases, linked to poverty, with limited and expensive treatments. In Brazil, the Ministry of Health recommends platelet transfusions for patients with less than 10,000 platelets/mm3. Leishmanias-HIV coinfection is a risk factor for poor VL outcomes, as studies show coinfected individuals have higher risk of poor prognosis.

A review of 14 studies in Latin America found predictors of adverse outcomes: jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age under 5 or over 50, neutropenia, dyspnea, bacterial infections, edema, and low hemoglobin. These were associated with unfavorable outcomes. The main limitation is the lack of validation for prognostic models. Combining results from 10 years identified consistent variables to recognize patients at risk. Developing externally validated models is a priority.

VL is a public health issue, especially in poor areas. Effective treatments are scarce. The Brazilian Ministry recommends platelet transfusions for low platelet counts. Leish-HIV coinfection is a risk factor for poor outcomes, as studies show coinf individuals have higher risk. A review of 14 studies in Latin America found predictors: jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrh, HIV, diarrhea, age under 5 or over 50, neutropenia, dysnea, infections, edema, and low hemoglobin associated with poor outcomes.
Researchers in Algeria studied the susceptibility of Leishmania parasites to antimonial drugs over a 30-year period. The country's treatment for visceral and cutaneous leishmanias has been based on antimonial drugs, but resistance is suspected due to high drug pressure. The study analyzed 106 isolates, including 88 from humans, dogs, rodents, and phleomines, and 18 from dogs in France, collected between 1976 and 2013. The isolates were tested for susceptibility to potassium antimony tarate and sodium stibogluconate. The results showed a trend of increasing susceptibility in visceral leishmanias isolates, but an increase in resistant isolates causing cutaneous leishiasis. The emergence of resistant isolates correlates with Leishmania kili, which causes cutaneous leishias and has emerged in Algeria. The study highlights the need for monitoring ant susceptibility to prevent resistant strains.
Researchers have found a link between acute gastroenteritis and the development of Crohn's disease (CD), a chronic inflammatory condition. They studied mice infected with Salmonella Typhimium or Citrobacterium, bacteria, which are known to cause gastroenteritis, and found that those colonized with Escherichia coli (AIE), a bacteria linked to CD, had a worse outcome after infection. The study showed that IE expanded in the gut tissue, increased inflammation, and delayed healing of the gut lining after infection. This was due to IE's resistance to host defenses and a strong inflammatory response to the pathogen. The results suggest that people colonized with IE at the time of gastroenteritis may be at higher risk for CD. The study also found IE as a potential target for developing interventions after gastroitis in at-risk individuals.
In flowering plants, the female gamet of Arabidopsis is made up of two cells: the egg cell and the central cell, surrounded by five accessory cells. These cells are all important for fertilization, but how they become what they are is not well understood. Researchers looked for genes that control the egg cell's fate and found a mutation called lesis (lis) that makes extra egg cells. In lis mutants, the accessory cells become egg cells, showing that lis is involved in a process that stops accessory cells from becoming egg. Lis is similar to a protein in yeast that helps with cell decisions. This suggests all cells in the gamet are capable of becoming egg, but lis stops it from happening in accessory cells. The central cell in lis gametes also becomes egg, showing another lis process stops it from becoming egg. The lis mutant shows two levels of control: between egg and accessory, and egg and central cells. A marker genes show Arabid cell types are decided after cell formation.
Researchers conducted a study in a rural Ethiopian highland community to understand why people don't wear shoes, which can help prevent Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs). They used the PRECE-PRO model to assess social, behavioral, environmental, and educational factors that influence shoe-wearing. 242 people participated in focus groups, semi-structured interviews, and case studies. The study found that shoe-wearing is changing, going barefoot is seen as shameful, and shoes give dignity and protection against injury. However, practical and social barriers prevent people from wearing shoes. Limited resources mean people can't buy more than one pair, can't afford quality shoes, and shoes are saved for special occasions. Children often don't get shoes until a certain age. Some barriers, like fit and fear of labeling, are specific to certain diseases, but underlying barriers like poverty, price, unsuitability, and low perception are relevant to many NTDs. Using health behavior models, researchers identified barriers to shoe-wearing that can be intervened and will benefit NTD prevention through shoe distribution.

In a community with podoiosis, a NTD caused by soil exposure, researchers found behaviors and practices relevant to other NTDs. In Ethiopia, shoes are distributed to children to prevent podoiosis. Barriers mentioned were financial and suitability of shoes for common activities. Financial constraints influence possession, type, age, consistency, replacement, and activities. Theories suggest targeting beliefs and attitudes about shoe-wearing influence podoiosis risk and effectiveness. The study aimed to understand barriers to consistent shoe-wearing in a rural setting. Respondents aspired to wear, but reality was different. Many had shoes, but not worn regularly. Barriers included financial, access, perceptions, and disease risk. Podoiosis patients faced difficulty finding sizes and stigma.
Pseudorabies virus (PRV) Us protein plays a crucial role in targeting viral capsids and glycoproteins to axons of sympathetic neurons. Without Us, mutants are defective in anterograde transmission in vivo. Researchers wanted to understand how Us promotes axonal sorting of many viral proteins. They found that glyroteins B, C, D, and E are associated with lipid microdomains on infected cells and directed into ax in Us-dependent manner. They discovered Us is associated with lipid rafts and this association is critical for Us-mediated sorting viral proteins. They used non-polarized and polarized PC12 cells, a cell line that acquires sympathetic neuron characteristics in presence of nerve growth factor (NGF). In these cells, Us is highly in detergent-resistant membranes (DR). Reducing Us affinity for lipid ra inhibited antograde transmission from neurons to epithelial cells in vitro. They conclude association Us with ra is key for targeting proteins to axons and consequence for spread PR from pre-synaptic to postynaptic neurons in mammalian nervous system.
Biologists have long known that genetically identical cells can exhibit different behaviors under the same conditions, a phenomenon called nongenic heterogeneity. This has important implications in medicine, as cancer and microbial cells show nenic heterogeneity in growth and response to drugs. Researchers studied the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which shows nenic heterogeneity in growth rate and heat stress. They found that heterogeneity in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels through the Ras/c protein kinase (PKA) pathway and transcription factors M2 and M4 underlies this nenic heterogeneity. Lower cAMP levels correspond to slower growth, and a reporter of this pathway's activity correlates with growth in individual cells. The paralogues M2 and M4 have different roles in nenic heterogeneity, with M2 required for growth and M4 for expression of T1, a subunit of trehalase that contributes to heat tolerance. Perturbing nenic heterogeneity by mutating genes in this pathway or culturing cells with cell-perme cAMP or PK inhibitor significantly impacts survival of heat.
Researchers studied the genetic diversity of the Chikungunya virus (CHV) during its rapid spread from Asia to the Americas in 2013. They analyzed viral samples from infected individuals in Guadeloupe and Martinique, two islands in the center of the outbreak, using deep-sequencing and bioinformatics. They found changes in the virus sequence and a range of minority variants present at different levels in the population. The diversity was reduced after single passages in cell lines. A new 3' untranslated region (UTR) structure was identified, not found in nature, which increased replication in insect cells. This study highlights the need for continued viral surveillance as the epidemic evolves to understand CHV's potential.
Researchers have identified a new gene called UOR that plays a crucial role in regulating cell growth and tumor formation through a key signaling pathway called mTOR. This pathway is involved in many human diseases, including cancer. The study found that reducing UOR in brain cells and nerve cells promotes growth, while overexpressing it suppresses tumor formation in cancer cells. Experiments in zebraf fish and mice showed that UOR inhibits m signaling by stabilizing a component of the mTOR complex, leading to reduced tumor formation. Disrupting the UOR gene increased m activity and worsened cancer in zraf. In mice, UOR depletion also promoted tumor growth and m signaling. The study suggests UOR regulates growth and tumor through m signaling.
Scientists have created a detailed map of the proteins in the parasite Trypanosoma brucei, which causes African trypanosomiasis, a disease that affects humans and cattle. This parasite is difficult to study because most of its proteins are not similar to those in well-studied organisms like yeast and mammals. To understand its biology and how it causes disease, researchers looked at how proteins interact with each other. They used a method called biochemical fractionation to study over 3,500 proteins in the parasite's procyclic stage. This led to the identification of 128 protein complexes, including 635 with unknown functions. These complexes match known pathways and proteins found across the parasite's life cycle, providing clues for many uncharacterized proteins. The researchers also found a protein involved in RNA editing, a process that regulates the parasite's genes. This study provides a new view of the parasite's protein map and a resource for further research.
Lymph nodes are a common sites of prolonged bacterial persistence for Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection in macaques. While tuberculosis is typically considered a lung disease, extrapulmonary infection can occur in any organ. Lymph nodes (LN) are among the most common sites of extrapul Mtb infection, and thoracic LNs are frequently infected in humans. However, the dynamics and effect of Mtb infection on LN structure and function is relatively unstudied. Researchers surveyed thoracic LNs from M-infected cynolg andhes macques using PET scans, bacterial burden, LN structure, and immune function. They found that lymph nodes have different trajectories (increasing, decreasing in activity over time) even in the same animal. Rhes macques are more susceptible to M infection than cynolg macques due to extensive LN pathology. Mtb grows to same level in cynolg andhes mac LNs, but cynolg macques control M at later points post-infection whilehes do not. Notably, compared to lung granulomas, LNs are poor at killing M, even with treatment. Granulomas in L lack B-rich structures, disrupt LN, push out T and B cells, introduce macrophages that serve as niches for M, and destroy vasculature.
Researchers have identified 47 new species of microsporidia, a type of fungus that infects animals, and studied their interactions with the nematode Caenorhabis elegans and other related nematodes. They found that Noc paris is the most common microspor infecting C elegans in the wild and described six new species in the Nemat genus. Phylogenetic analysis identified two subclades distinct from Nematida, named Entersect and Ptospora, which belong to the main clade of microidia that includes human pathogens. All microidia are horizontally transmitted and infect intestinal cells except Ptos, which replicates in the epidermis of C elegans. At the cellular level, Entersect spores show apical distribution and exit via budding, unlike Nematida which exit via exocytosis. Host specificity varies among microidia, some infecting Osche but not its sister Osche, and vice versa. Nauseli fails to induce C eleg transcription of genes induced by Nematida, suggesting evolved mechanisms to prevent host response.
Chemokine receptors, a type of protein receptor, play a crucial role in the human immune system and are involved in cancer and HIV infection. Research has shown that these receptors can form pairs or groups of three or more and this affects their function. Cholesterol also affects how these receptors work. However, little is known about how these receptors pair up and interact with cholesterol. This study used computer simulations to look at how chemine receptors CXCR, CCR, and CCR pair up and interact with cholesterol. The results show that closely related receptors CCR and CCR pair similarly, but differently from CXCR. Cholesterol affects how these pairs in a specific way. Chemine receptors also pair up in different ways, such as CXCR and CCR, and CXCR CCR. Notably, CX and C pair more with cholesterol than CXCR and C. This study provides a detailed look at how chemine receptors interact and how pairing with cholesterol changes their function.
Researchers have identified a new form of systemic leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the Leishmania parasite, which presents with symptoms that are not typical of the classical form of the disease. In addition to fever, hepatosplenomegaly, and wasting, this new form, called "atypical", presents with one or two of these symptoms missing and other symptoms such as lymphadenopathy and anemia. A study of 160 patients with depressed immunity found that 19.4% had normal laboratory profiles but had macrophages laden with Leish parasites. This suggests that systemic lemanias presents a wider spectrum of signs and symptoms than previously thought and is more common than previously diagnosed. The disease is not limited to the pediatric age group, as 31 of the patients were adults. The researchers recommend considering atypical systemic leishiasis in patients with unexplained immunity and no obvious immunologic defect.
Researchers have analyzed millions of genetic mutations and variations in the human genome to understand how they relate to diseases, reactions to medications, and age-related conditions. They found that predicting the impact of a genetic variation on the body is challenging. A new approach is to look at variations in similar proteins, called paralogs, which have the same function but different sequences. This study used a database of known disease-causing variations to identify pairs of variations at the same positions in paralog proteins. The results show that variations in paralog proteins are connected and if one is disease-causing, the other is likely to be too. This information can help identify potential disease-causing variations, improve existing methods, and provide candidates for diagnosis and treatment.

A dataset was created to identify pairs of variations at the same positions in human genes. Variations co-occur at amino pairs more than expected, suggesting similar constraints on paralog sequences result in coordinated distributions of disease and non-disease variants. Data show paralog genes and variantairs can be used for hypothesis generation and clinical research. Extending to paral genes not associated with disease can identify new candidates and uncharacterized variants with phenotyp consequences.

A collection of disease-causing variations was assembled from databases and mapped to genes and sequences. This suggests algorithms based on sequence conservation miss instances. Paralog human might provide additional information for in silico characterization, complementary to approaches like SIFT and PolyPhen. Rare disease variants in paralog tend to pair. Alignments provide a resource for genomics.
Researchers studied the genetic makeup of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falcum in people with severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papua New Guinea. They used a technique called RNA sequencing to analyze the parasite's genes in 44 cases of severe and uncomplicated malaria. The results showed that parasites causing severe malaria had changes in their gene expression, including a decrease in glycolysis, altered chromatin structure, and reduced expression of surface antigens called Pf1. These antigens are targets of protective immunity. The parasites also had down-regulated multiple chaperone proteins. The study found associations between disease severity and Pf1 transcripts, domains, and smaller segments, and confirmed previous associations between expressed Pf1 sequences and disease. The findings can help identify targets for a malaria vaccine and how parasites adapt to the host environment in severe malaria. 

The study differed from previous reports of increased expression of genes involved in Pf1 surface in severe malaria. However, 17 of these genes were down-regulated, including skeleton protein 1, involved in Pf1 expression. Severe patients had lower levels of antibodies to Pf1 and recognized fewer Pf1 than uncomplicated patients. Parasites were older in uncomplicated patients, who had more immunity to Pf1. Severe patients had down-regulated genes in Pf1 expression. Antigens are encountered early and recognized by sera from immune children than uncomplicated. Expression of conserved Pf1 by severe parasites explains rapid immunity to severe than uncomplicated.
Scientists have been exploring a new approach to prevent HIV infection by delivering antibodies that can neutralize the virus directly into the body. In a recent study, researchers used a virus-like particle called AAV to deliver antibodies into rhes macaques, a type of monkey. The goal was to see if these antibodies could protect against a difficult-to-neutralize strain of the virus, SIV239. The results were promising: six out of the seven monkeys that received the antibodies showed protection against the virus, even though the antibodies didn't neutralize the virus on their own. They had lower levels of the virus in their blood, delayed the time it took for the virus to peak, and some even resisted multiple challenges with the virus. One monkey even resisted six challenges, including a high dose of the virus. This approach is promising for preventing HIV in people, but the body's response to the delivered antibodies is a problem that needs to be solved.
Researchers studied the way proteins myosin and kinesin K1 respond to changes in their shape when they bind to or release molecules. They used a simplified model to analyze the proteins' movements and found that the traditional assumption of a linear response to these changes doesn't hold true. This is especially true for kines K1, where the traditional model completely fails to describe how the protein moves. Even though the protein's movements are not random, they can't be explained by a single mode or a combination of modes. The study suggests that the current understanding of protein dynamics may need to be revised. 

The researchers looked at how these proteins change shape when they bind or release molecules. They used a simplified model to analyze the movements and found that the traditional assumption of a linear response doesn't hold. This is especially true for kines K1, where the model completely fails to describe the movements. Even the movements are not random, they can't be explained by a single or combination of modes. The study suggests the understanding of dynamics may need to be revised.
Researchers have found that caveolins, proteins play a crucial role in regulating clathrin-independent endocytosis, a process by which cells take in substances from outside the cell membrane. They discovered that specific caveins, Cavin-1 and Cavin-3, but not Cavin-2 or Cavin-4, inhibit the clath-independent/GPIAP enriched endosomal (CL/GC) endytic pathway. This pathway is independent of cave formation. Caveolin-1 and Cavin-3 also inhibit the CL/GC pathway when overexpressed. Expression of caveolar leads to a reduction in formation of early CL/GC carriers, detected by electron microscopy. The CL/GC pathway is upregulated in cells lacking Cavin-1/Cavin or with reduced Cavin-1 and Cavin. Inhibition by caveins can be mimicked by isolated caveolin scaffolding and associated with perturbed lipid diffusion components, revealed by fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) studies. In absence of caveins and caveol, CAV is endocyted preferentially through CLC pathway but loses polarization and sorting with consequences for membrane and endytic dynamics in migrating cells and muscle tissue.
Researchers have identified a new type of signaling system in bacteria and plants called Aspart-L Receiver (AL) domains, which are different from the typical two-component systems that sense and respond to environmental stimuli. These systems usually have a histidine kinase that phosphorylates a conserved aspartate (Asp) residue on a Receiver (REC) domain. However, some REC domains lack this residue, and it was unclear how many exist, their roles, and how they function without the conserved aspart. The study found that AL domains are common and often attached to rare effector proteins. Analysis of AL structures and data showed that AL have reorganized their active sites to take a constitutive role or accommodate signals other than phosphorylation, while retaining post-phosphorylation mechanisms and dimer interface. This defines AL as an atypical REC subclass and provides insights into shared mechanisms between AL and REC domains.
Researchers have developed a new type of oncolytic herpes virus (OV) that targets cancer cells with a specific protein called HER2, which is found in many types of cancer. This virus is different from others because it is fully virulent, meaning it can cause an immune response in the body. They tested this new virus in mice with cancer and found it was safe and effective. The virus, called R115, was more effective than another version, R113, in stopping the growth of tumors. All mice that survived the primary tumor were protected from new tumors growing in other parts of the body. Some mice were even protected from new tumors for a long time after the virus was gone. The virus changed the environment around the tumor, making it harder for cancer to grow. It also made immune cells that fight cancer, like T cells, increase in the tumor. This showed the virus can be used as a vaccine to help body fight cancer.
A recent study investigated the susceptibility of CD4 T cells induced by different HIV vaccine vectors to HIV infection. The research focused on two vectors: Adenovirus 5 (Ad) and ALVAC, used in clinical trials RV144 and HVT204, respectively. The study found that Ad-specific CD T cells were highly susceptible to HIV, while ALAC-specific T cells were less susceptible. This difference was linked to lower expression of HIV entry receptors CCR5 and CXCR4 on ALAC cells. Phenotypic analysis showed ALAC cells had a strong Th1 profile, producing IFN-γ and CCL4, but little IL-17. In contrast, Ad and ALAC induced distinct CD8 and CD4 responses in PBMC, with ALAC favoring CD8 proliferation and Ad CD4. Depletion of ALAC CD8 cells increased HIV infection of ALAC CD4 cells, suggesting a protective role for ALAC CD8 cells. The study highlights the importance of evaluating vector responses in HIV vaccination, as different vectors induce distinct susceptibility in CD4 cells.
Scientists have studied how female mammals choose which X chromosome to silence in a process called X-inactivation, where one X chromosome is turned off in each somatic cell. The choice of which X to silence varies among species, ranging from strict paternal X-inheritance (PX), where females are haploid for maternal alleles, to random X-inactivation (RX), where both maternal and paternal alleles are equally expressed. The reasons for this diversity are unclear. Researchers analyzed how dominance, linkage, recombination, and sex-differential selection influence X-in evolution. They found that a single interaction between allelic dominance and sex-differential can select a wide range of X-in strategies, including unequal inactivation between maternal and paternal X. RX is favored over PX if alleles are recessive to female fitness, and criteria for RX is more restrictive when variation is sexually antagonistic. Evolution from PX to RX increases female fitness at the expense of male. This provides a framework for predicting X-linked gene expression and leads to predictions for future studies on allele variation.

Species properties and genetic variation predict selection for X-in strategies. Sexual and sex-based mutation rates vary, influencing transmission of deleterious alleles between maternal and paternal X. X-in is female-limited, so selection favors inactivation of the chromosome with more deleterious alleles. An analysis showed evolutionary stability of X-in strategies. Sex-differential selection, where fitness differs between males and females, affects large genomes, influencing X-in diversification. Stronger selection against males decreases paternal X deleterious alleles. Sex-differential might favor biased X-in (unequal expression of maternal and paternal X) and predict biases to evolve. Results suggest conditions for biased-in are permissive.
Researchers have identified a protein called ZAP that can block the infection of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), a type of flavivirus. ZAP is a host protein that restricts many viruses by degrading their RNA, inhibiting translation, and triggering immune responses. However, only one flavivirus, yellow fever virus, was previously known to be resistant to ZAP. The study tested ZAP's antiv potential against three flaviviruses: JEV, dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIK). JEV infection was blocked by ZAP overexpression, but not DENV or ZIK. Depletion of endogenous Z enhanced JEV replication. Z hampered J translation and targeted viral RNA for 3-5' exosome degradation. Zinc-finger motifs of Z were essential for RNA targeting and anti-J activity. JEV 3'-UT, especially region with dumbbell structures and high CG content, was mapped to bind Z and confer sensitivity to Z. The study found JEV as the first Z-sensitive flavivirus. Z may act as intrinsic antiv factor through RNA binding against J infection.
Rift Valley fever virus (RVV) is a highly pathogenic virus that causes severe disease in humans and animals, particularly in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. Researchers studied the response of mice to wild-type and vaccine strains of RVV to understand its pathogenesis. Mice infected with a live-attenuated vaccine strain survived with minimal disease and cytokine response, while the wild-type strain caused severe disease, lymphocyte and platelet depletion, and strong cytokine response. The virus targeted the liver, causing necrosis and hepatitis, but no significant inflammatory response was seen. Instead, a chemokine response was observed, indicating neutrophil infiltration. In the brain, a chemok and cytokine response was seen, but little pathology. The study suggests RVV pathogenesis in mice is liver failure due to necrosis, but long-term disease is neurologic, supported by human and mouse model observations.
Chemotherapy resistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a significant challenge for improving patient survival. Researchers investigated the mechanisms of taxane chemoresistance in TNBC and found that C motif chemokine ligand 20 (C20) is elevated during tax-containing chemotherapy in patients with non-pathologic response. C20 promotes self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCS) through protein kinase Cζ (PKζ) or mitogen-activated protein (MAP)-mediated activation of nuclear factor B (NF-κ) pathway, increasing taxane resistance of BC. C20 also increased ATP-binding subfamily member 1 (ABCB1)/multidrug 1 (DR) expression, leading to extracellular efflux of taxane. A feedback loop between NF-κ and C20 provides impetus for chemoresistance in cancer cells. C20 can be a predictive marker for taxane response, and blocking C or its pathway might reverse tax resistance in breast cancer. Tax-induced C20 promotes self-renew of BC through activation of NFκ, mediated by PKζ and MAP activity. Studies offer a strategy to reverse tax resistance in breast cancer by combining tax treatment with adjuvant pharmacological inhibition of AB1. C20 promotes chemores in BC through positive loop mediated PK/38-NF. Tax-induced C20 activates NF through PKζ or38 and promotes expression of AB, leading to chemores of breast cells. Increase of C20 by tax depends on NF activity, suggesting activated NF regulates C level in feedback to enhance effect on chemores.
Toxoplas gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite, infects virtually all nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. Its ability to infect and manipulate host cells depends on transporting "GRA" proteins from secretory organelles called dense granules into host cells, where they reside. GRA proteins have diverse roles in Toxopla's lifecycle, including hijacking host functions like cell cycle and p38 MAP kinase. Some GRA proteins, like GRA16 and GRA24, are secreted into parasitoph vacuole (PV) where Toop replicates and transported across PV membrane (PVM) into host, but translocation process and machinery not understood. Researchers previously showed TMY1, cleaved by TASP into fragments, localizes PVM and essential for GRA transport into host. To identify additional proteins for effector transport, Toopla mutants defective in cyc-regulation screened for ability export GRA and GRA to host nucleus. Researchers report novel MY2 and MY3 play crucial role in translocation subset GRAs into host. MY2 and MY3 secreted PV, co-localize with PVM and MY1. Consistent predicted transmembrane domains, all proteins membrane-associated, MY3 but MY stably with MY1, N-terminal C-terminal disulf-linked. Results reveal novel complex PVM essential effector translocation into host.
Scientists have studied how a virus called papillomavirus (PV) replicates, or makes copies of itself, inside cells. They found that a protein called E2 binds to a factor called origin recognition complex (ORC) to start the replication process. ORC is a group of proteins that helps initiate DNA duplication. PV has three stages of replication: initial amplification, cell cycle maintenance, and differentiation. The study showed that E2 binds to OR2, but OR2 is not found at the viral origin. Depleting OR2 increased PV replication in some cells, but not in others. This suggests OR2 is not necessary for E2 to start replication, but instead suppresses it. The study also found that over-expressing E2 reduced OR2 at host cell origins, suggesting E restricts pre-OR assembly that competes with viral replication. This implies OR2 restricts viral replication in the maintenance phase and elevated E levels during differentiation subvert OR loading and DNA synthesis at cellular origins.
Researchers investigated the presence of Brucella bacteria in the milk of cows in urban and peri-urban areas of Dush, Tajikistan. They found Bruc DNA in 10.3% of 564 milk samples, which is concerning since unpasteurified dairy products are commonly consumed in the region. Bruc was detected in the milk of all seropositive cows, but also 8.3% of seronegative cows had Bruc DNA. Sequence analysis suggested one cow was infected with B. abortus and another likely infected with B. melensis. The study highlights the need for complementary diagnostic strategies to detect false negatives in Bruc surveillance and control programs. Vaccination of cattle with S19 and small ruminants Rev1 may be necessary to control Bruc infections, but further research is needed to understand Brella circulating in the region.
Researchers studied the role of histone H3 lysine 27 methylation in maintaining chromosome stability in the fungus Zoseptoria trici. This fungus has eight accessory chromosomes that are unstable during meiosis and mitosis, and are transcriptionally repressed, with high enrichment of repetitive elements and heterochromatin marks, such as trimethylation of H3 lysine 9 or lys 27 (HK9me3, HK27me). To understand the impact of heterochatin on genome stability, the researchers deleted genes encoding the methyltransferases responsible for HK9me and HK27, mt1 and mt6, respectively, and generated a double mutant. They used experimental and genomic analyses to determine the impact of these deletions on chromosome and genome stability in vitro and in planta. Whole genome sequencing, ChIP-seq, and RNA-seq were used to compare changes in genome and chromatin structure and differences in gene expression between mutant and wild-type strains. Results showed dramatic chromatin reorganization in HK9-deficient strains, with HK27me mostly localized in regions with HK9 in wild-type. Many rearrangements and formation of new chromosomes were found in absence HK9, accompanied by activation of transposable elements. In contrast, loss HK27 increased stability of accessory chromosomes under normal conditions in vitro, without large changes in gene activity. HK9 is important for maintaining genome stability by disallowing HK27 in constitutive heterochatin. HK27 reduces overall stability of accessory, creating a "metastable" state for quasi-essential genome regions.
Evaluating Cost-Effective Strategies for Rabies Post-Exposure Vaccination in Low-Income Countries

Rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is crucial in preventing the onset of the fatal disease in individuals exposed to rabies. However, life-saving vaccines and biologicals are often inaccessible and unaffordable, particularly to the poorest sectors of society who bear the largest burden of rabies. Increasing accessibility, reducing costs, and preventing delays in delivery of P should be prioritized. Researchers analyzed P vaccination regimens and their relative costs and benefits to victims and healthcare providers, finding P to be an extremely cost-effective intervention ($200 less than $60/death averted). Switching from intramuscular (IM) to intradermal (ID) regimens resulted in significant savings in vaccine volume required to treat the same patients, mitigating shortages and reducing costs. Financing mechanisms to make P more accessible could subsidize costs for those in need and support existing rabies control programs. A universal switch to ID delivery would improve affordability and accessibility of P, reducing human rabies deaths and being economical for providers.
Toxoplas, an obligate intracellular parasite, replicates within mammalian cells in a parasitophorous vacuole (PV) that does not fuse with host organelles. One mechanism for nutrient acquisition is attracting host organelles to the PV. Researchers examined lipid droplets (LD), fat storage organelles, exploited by Toxopla. Toxla replication is reduced in cells depleted of LD or impaired lipolysis or fatty acidolysis. In infected cells, host LD number and LD-associated gene expression (AP, DG2) increase until parasite replication onset. PV are surrounded by host LD. Toxla accesses lipids in LD and incorporates them into its membranes and LD. Exogenous oleic acid stimulates LDogenesis in host, resulting in neutral lipid accumulation in large LD inside parasite. Tox intercepts and internalizes LD, some associated with Rab7, wrapped in intravacolar network (IV) membranes. Mutants impaired IV display diminished lipid uptake from LD. Parasites lacking IV-localized phospholipase2 are less proficient in salvaging lipids from LD in PV, suggesting IV's major role in LD processing and lipid release. Gavage parasites unveil presence of endytic structures containing lipid material from PV lumen. This study highlights Toxla's reliance on LD for intracellular development and scavenging lipids from LD.
Researchers have been searching for new ways to control a disease called fasciolosis, which affects cattle and sheep, caused by liver flukes Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica. Currently, the main treatment is chemotherapy with a drug called tricendazole, but resistance to this drug has been reported in several countries, making it urgent to find new options. A library of flavonoids, a type of plant compound, were tested for their ability to inhibit key enzymes of the liver fluke, Fasciola hepatica. Chalcones, a type of flavon, were found to be good inhibitors of these enzymes, especially those with phenyl and napht groups. One compound, C34, was found to bind to the enzyme FCL with an IC50 of 5.6 μM, making it a slow-reversible inhibitor that interacts with the enzyme's active site. This compound was also found to reduce the ability of the fluke to penetrate the gut and cause death within a week in vitro, while not being non-toxic to bovine cells. This is the first report of non-peptide inhibitors of Fasciola catheps in vitro and opens new avenues for developing novel agents to control fluke infection and other helminthic diseases.
Researchers have discovered how the visual system processes fast and slow changes in light intensity through separate neural pathways. They used a technique called in vivo imaging to study how bipolar cells send signals to the retina. They found that the size of the terminal, a part of the cell, affects how it transmits signals. Cells with smaller terminals transmit faster and respond to higher frequencies, while larger ones respond to lower frequencies. This is because smaller terminals release more vesicles with higher gain, followed by more adaptation. Larger terminals transmit lower frequencies more effectively. The size of the presynaptic compartment, a part of the cell, contributes to these differences in response. This shows how neurons can transmit different temporal components of the signal through terminals with varying properties.
Researchers have developed a new method to detect and analyze individual synapses in the brain using fluorescence microscopy images. Synapses are the tiny connections between brain cells that allow them to communicate with each other. Current methods to study synapses have limitations: fluorescence microscopy is fast and cheap but hard to distinguish between real and fake signals, while electron microscopy is accurate but slow and expensive. The new method uses a combination of fluorescence and electron microscopy to create detailed images of individual synapses. It uses a computer algorithm to identify synapses in the images and produces a map of the probability of each point being a synapse. The researchers tested the method on images and found it worked as well as human annotators and accurately reproduced known features of synapse distributions. This opens the door to discovering new types of synapses and their density. The method can also be applied to other types of microscopy images where electron microscopy is not practical.
Zinc is a vital element for many cellular functions, including DNA synthesis, gene expression, cell division, and immune system, and wound healing. Impairment of zinc homeostasis leads to various pathologies. Mammalian zinc transport occurs via two families, ZnT and ZIP. However, the mechanism of Zn2, responsible for vesicular zinc accumulation and secretion during lactation, is unknown. Researchers modeled Zn2's action computationally and experimentally and found it to be a proton-coupled zinc antiporter. Bafomycin A, a vacuolar ATPase inhibitor, abolished Zn2-dependent transport into vesicles. Lyso Red and Ly-pfluorin showed ves pH alkalization upon Zn2 overexpression and zinc addition. TP, a zinc chelator, reversed this effect. Computational calculations propose Zn2 as an antiporter with 2H+/Zn+ stoichiometry. Zn2 is a motive-driven, electrutral ves zinc exchanger, concentrating zinc in vesicles at the expense of proton extrusion to cytoplasm.
Researchers have found that a group of proteins called 14-3 proteins play a crucial role in maintaining the stability of the genome by helping to fix errors that occur during DNA replication. They do this by interacting with a protein called Exonuclease 1 (Exo), which is responsible for processing stalled replication forks. In cells without 14-3 proteins, Exo becomes overactive and creates gaps in the DNA, leading to persistent activation of the cell's error-checking mechanism and defects. The researchers also found that 14-3 proteins promote the progression of replication forks under low nucleotide conditions. They propose that 14-3 proteins control the activity of Exo and other targets, ensuring fork stability and restart in response to DNA stress. This study sheds light on processes at stalled forks and suggests 14-3 as central regulators of stability and processing. Further research is needed to identify other proteins involved and how 14-3 modulate Exo activity.
Researchers studied the role of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) in human immunodeficiency virus 1 (HIV) infection and pathogenesis using a humanized mouse model. They found that pDC are critical in producing type I interferons (IF-I), which suppress HIV-1 replication. However, p also contribute to HIV-induced immunopathogenesis by promoting death of human leukocytes, including CD4 T cells. A monoclonal antibody was developed to deplete p in lymphoid organs of humanized mice. When p were depleted before HIV-1 infection, IF-I and interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) were abolished, and HIV-1 replication increased. In chronic infection, p depletion reduced IF-I and IS, but increased HIV replication. Surprisingly, p depletion reduced death of human cells in lymphoid organs, but not blood, despite increased replication. p play opposing roles in suppressing HIV replication and promoting immunogenesis. Findings suggest p-depletion and IF blockade as novel strategies for treating HIV non-responsive patients with immune activation despite antiretroviral treatment.
Researchers have discovered that sulforaphane (SF), a compound found in cruciferous vegetables, can block the infection of HIV in macrophages, a type of immune cell, but not in other cells. This is the first time this has been shown. SF works by activating a protein called nuclear erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2), which is also used by other viruses like Marburg, Kapos's sarcoma herpes and Dengue. When Nrf is activated, it changes gene expression in the cell, making it harder for HIV to infect. Experiments showed that blocking Nrf with siRNA increased HIV infection in macroages, and reduced the effect of SF treatment. This suggests that SF's anti-viral activity is through Nrf. SF blocks HIV infection after reverse transcription, but before 2-L circle formation, similar to other proteins induced by type I interferon. However, these proteins were not upregulated. This is the first time Nrf has been shown to block HIV infection, and a new way to trigger this inhibition has been found.
A study in rural western Kenya found that 76.2% of pregnant women had at least one geohelth infection, with 52.3% having Ascaris lumicoid, 39.5 hookworm, and 29% Trichuris trichi. Infections were associated with using an unprotected water source (OR 1.8, 95% CI 1.1-3) and not treating drinking water (OR 1.8, 95 CI 1.1-3). Geelth infections were not linked to symptoms or low body mass. Hookworm infection was linked to lower upper arm circumference (mean -0.7 cm, 95 CI 0.3-1). Women with hookworm egg count 100/gram had lower hemoglobin (mean -1.5 g/dl, 95 CI 0.3-2). Pregnant women 2 and 3 with Ascaris lumic were less likely to have malaria (OR 0.4, 95 CI 0.2-0.8) compared to those without.
Mycolone, a compound produced by the bacterium Mycobacterium ulcerans, has been found to have anti-inflammatory effects on the nervous system. Research has shown that mycolone blocks the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by immune cells, leading to its analgesic and immunomodulatory properties. This study investigated myone's effects on the inflammatory responses of nervous cells involved in pain perception and transmission, as well as neuroinflammation associated with chronic pain. Sensory neurons, Schwann cells, and microglia were isolated from mice to assess myone cytotoxicity and immunomod activity. Results showed that prolonged exposure to myone induced cell death at concentrations >10ng/ml, but nanolar concentrations suppressed production of pro-inflammatory mediators without affecting viability. Notably, myone prevented pro-inflammatory polarization of microglia, which contribute to neuroinflammation. In a rat model of neuropathic pain, myone injected in the spinal canal decreased local production of inflammatory cytokines without cytotoxicity. This study provides evidence that myone suppresses inflammatory responses of neurons, Schw cells, and microia without affecting viability, supporting previous studies suggesting myone analgesia is partially due to anti-inflammatory properties.
Researchers studied how genetic variations in human genes affect the outcome of African trypanosomiasis, a deadly disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei gambense, in West Africa. They collected blood samples from 425 people in Guinea, including 232 with the disease, 79 with long-term carriers, and 114 without the disease. They looked at 28 genetic variations in 8 genes and found that one, IL6 rs1819, was linked to a lower risk of progressing from latent to active disease. Another, MIF36071, was linked to higher risk, but not after adjusting for multiple tests, it was not significant. MIF12459 was linked to latent infection. They confirmed earlier findings that AP1G2 was linked to higher risk and AP1 to lower risk. No links were found with other genes. The study shows genes play a role in controlling the parasite and may lead to new control tools.
Researchers have conducted a study on the genetic diversity of South Asians by whole-genome sequencing 38 individuals from Singapore, descendants of immigrants from Dravid-language-speaking states in south India. The results show that these individuals have greater genetic diversity and higher heterozygous-to-homozygous ratio compared to other Asian populations. When compared to a panel of well-defined Indians, the genetic makeup of these samples is closely related to South Indians, but distinct from Europeans. However, some samples were assigned to mitochondrial haplogroups predominantly present in Europeans and had higher European admixture. Analysis of relatedness to archaic humans Denisovan and Neanderthal found higher ancient admixture in East populations than these samples. The study provides a valuable resource for understanding South Asians in the 1,000 Genomes Project. 

The Singapore Sequencing Indian Project sequenced genomes of 36 South Asians at 30X coverage, complementing 96 Southeast Malays and 1,092 samples from 1,000 Genomes. Principal component analysis revealed greater heterogeneity in Indians from northern India, while southern were more homogeneous. An independent analysis with Gujarati Indians found a third clustered with Singapore Indians. The majority of Singaporeans are descendants of south Indians who settled after Singapore became a trading center in the 19th century. The project aims to sequence 38 healthy Indians for insights into genetic diversity.
Researchers studied the molecular basis of antibiotic resistance in Burkholderia pseudalle isolates from Thailand. They found that most isolates are resistant to aminoglycos and macrolides due to the AmABpr efflux pump. However, three isolates 708, 218, and 9 were susceptible to aminogcos and macides. RT-PCR showed that isolate 708 had no Amr transcripts, while 218 and 9 had reduced levels. When exposed to gentamicin, 218 and 9 became resistant to other amincos and macides, but 708 did not. Transcript analysis showed that resistance in 218 and 9 was due to upregulation of Ampr expression. PCR revealed that the Ampr operon was missing in 708, associated with a 70kb deletion. Rescue of the Ampr region from a fosmid and sequencing showed a 131kb deletion in 708 compared to K43 and 10. This deletion removed not only Ampr but also genes for malleactin and cobal synthesis, and anaerobic arginine deiminase. Whole genome sequencing confirmed absence of these genes in 708. Despite missing virulence genes, 708 was virulent in a murine model.
Researchers studied how CD4 T helper cells, a type of immune cell, differentiate into two distinct types: Th1 and Th2. They found that these cells can express both Th1 and Th2 markers at the same time, not just one or the other. This is different from previous studies where cells were forced to choose one type. The team looked at individual cells and found that some express Th1 cytokine, but not Th marker, and vice versa. This variation is more common in early stage of differentiation than when cells are fully formed. When they blocked signals from outside the cell, Th1 and Th markers became exclusive, showing that signals from outside control what happens inside. This suggests that cells can have mixed Th1/2 state early on, influenced by signals from outside. The study shows how signals from outside and inside interact to decide cell fate, a common strategy for cells to handle variable signals.
Researchers have identified a protein called PAQR-2 in the nematode worm C. elegans that plays a crucial role in adapting to cold temperatures. PA-2 is similar to a protein in mammals that helps regulate insulin and fat metabolism. To understand how PA-2 works, the researchers looked for mutations that suppress its function and found genes involved in phospholipid synthesis and fatty acid metabolism. They discovered that PA-2, phospholip, and a type of enzyme called Δ9 desaturase form a pathway that increases unsaturated fatty acids to keep membranes fluid at low temperatures. This pathway is important for C. elegans to survive at 15°C, a temperature that's usually too cold for it. The researchers also found that PA- suppressors normalize saturated fatty acid levels and detergents that increase membrane fluidity can rescue PA-2 mutants. This suggests that PA-2 is a transmembrane protein that regulates fatty acid metabolism during cold adaptation.
Researchers have used electron microscopy to study the structure of the Herpes Simplex-1 virus, a common human pathogen that causes cold sores and other diseases. They found a previously unknown feature at the top of the virus, a "tail-like" structure that connects the virus to the cell membrane. This structure is similar to that found in a different type of virus that infects bacteria, suggesting it may play a role in releasing the virus's genetic material into the cell. The study suggests this structure is important for the virus's shape and how it enters the cell.
Researchers studied how the parasite Schistosoma mansoni egg antigen (SEA) affects HIV-1 infection in the body. They found that SEA can block HIV-1 from entering cells by binding to a protein on the surface of immune cells called DCIGN. They also found that when immune cells are exposed to SEA, they become less susceptible to HIV-1 infection, but not to a different type of HIV called HIV-4. This is because SEA reduces the production of a protein called IFN-γ, which helps fight off infection. Additionally, SEA reduces the expression of a protein called CCR5 on the surface of immune cells, which HIV uses to enter. A similar effect was seen with a protein called recombinant omega-1 (r-1), which is similar to SEA. This suggests that SEA and r-1 can modulate HIV-1 infection and potentially influence the course of the disease in people co-infected with the parasite.
Researchers have found that when neurons are stimulated, the space between neurons and surrounding cells called astrocytes in the brain shrinks by about 30%. This phenomenon is important for understanding how potassium and astrocyte function, but was not fully explained. A new model was created to explain the shrinkage in normal and gene-deficient individuals. The model shows that release of potassium and sodium from neurons, uptake of potassium and sodium by astrotes, action of the Na/K pump, and osmotically driven water transport through the astrote membrane are enough to cause shrinkage. However, taking into account the concentrations of ions and astrotes with stimulation, the actions of the NK and NBC transporters are key to achieving the observed levels of shrink. The model is detailed and constrained to guide future experiments and pave the way for comprehensive astro-glia-neuron models in normal and pathological situations.
Scientists have long known that certain types of DNA, called transposons and repetitive elements, can be detrimental to an organism's health if expressed. In plants like Arabidopsis, these elements are silenced by a process called RNA-mediated transcriptional gene silencing. This process involves a protein called Argonaute (AGO) and a type of RNA that guides it to chromatin, where enzymes establish repressive modifications. But how these enzymes are recruited to chromatin was unknown. Researchers found that a protein called SPTLTF1 binds to chromatin at locations where transcription is silenced. This binding happens after an enzyme called RNA polymerase V, but not because of a specific type of RNA called siRNA. They also found that AGO and SPTL1 are recruited to chrom together, but independently of each other. Experiments showed that both AGO and SPT1 are needed for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications at certain locations. The study suggests that AGO and SPT create a platform for chrom modifying enzymes to be recruited.
Researchers have studied how the bacteria Borrelia burgdorferi, which causes Lyme disease, spreads from ticks to mammals. They found that the Rpo regulon, a set of genes, is crucial for the bacteria to move through the tick's digestive system. Without Rpo, the bacteria get stuck in the midgut and transform into unusual round bodies. These round bodies are reversible and seem to be caused by low levels of an enzyme that helps the bacteria make energy. The study shows the bacteria have a backup plan to form round bodies when they can't get enough energy to spread to the mammal. This is a new role for Rpo in the tick phase of the disease cycle. The researchers also found that Rpo is needed for nymphs to transmit the disease, but not larvae. The findings suggest that the bacteria adapt to survive in the tick by forming round bodies when it's hard to spread to the mamm.
Scientists have long known that two plant hormones, gibberellin (GA) and jasmonate (JA), play a crucial roles in flower development, particularly in the male part of the flower called the stamen. However, the relationship between GA and JA in stamen development was not well understood. Researchers found that three genes, MY21, MY24, and MY57, are controlled by GA and are important for stamen growth. Without these genes, the stamen is short and the plant is sterile. They discovered that GA promotes JA production, which in turn controls the expression of MY21, MY24, and MY57. This is a key step in normal stamen development. The team also found that GA triggers the degradation of proteins that suppress JA production, allowing JA to be made. Without JA, the stamen does not grow properly and the plant is sterile. The study shows that GA and JA work together to control stamen development, with GA being a necessary for JA production. This is a new understanding of how GA and JA interact in plant development.
Researchers have found that a protein called hypoxia inducible factor-1 (HIF-1) plays a key role in extending lifespan in the worm Caenorhabditis elegans. H-1 is a transcription factor that helps regulate oxygen levels, cell growth, and metabolism, and response to stress. The study shows that H-1 deficiency leads to longer lifespan, similar to the effect of inhibiting the target of rapamycin (TOR) pathway. TOR is a protein that regulates growth and metabolism in response to nutrients. H-1 is one of the targets of TOR in mammalian cells, but its role in lifespan was unclear. The study found that H-1 modulates lifespan in a nutrient-dependent manner, extending lifespan under rich conditions but not under dietary restriction. A mutation in egl-9, which increases H- activity, diminishes lifespan under dietary restriction. This effect is rescued by expressing egl- in specific neurons and muscles. Increased lifespan by H- is dependent on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress regulator inos-requiring-1 (I-1) and associated with lower ER stress. The study suggests a tissue-specific role for H- in lifespan involving the I-ER stress pathway.
Researchers have discovered that human skin cells called keratinocytes can change their behavior in response to different situations, such as when they differentiate or migrate. They found that these cells have unique groups of enhancers, which are like switches that turn on specific genes, for each state. These enhancers are also linked to genetic variations that cause skin diseases. A protein called GR3, which promotes differentiation and migration, binds to different enhancers when keratinocytes differentiate, but to promoters when they migrate, it suppresses genes that inhibit migration. GR3 is located within enhancers and binds to regulate them, and also suppresses formation of non-keratinocyte enhancers in differentiating keratinocytes. This study shows how a single protein can control different gene programs in the same cell type by changing where it binds on chromatin. GR3 regulates divergent expression in differentiating and migrating keratinocytes by switching chromatin binding in distinct enhancer landscapes. The research highlights the relationship between protein GR3 and chromatin, including enhancers, which applies to cell specification and reversible state. GR3 is essential for normal keratin migration in eyelid closure and wound healing, modulating programs that promote movement and suppress progenitor differentiation.
Researchers studied the relationship between endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) and exogenous retroviruses in sheep. ERVs are remnants of ancient retroviral infections that are passed down from generation to generation. Some ERVs may help the host fight off pathogenic retroviruses by interfering with their replication. However, it's been hard to find evidence of this happening. Sheep are a good model to study retroirus coevolution because they have both exogenous (horizontally transmitted) and endogenous retroviruses. The team isolated and studied 27 endogenous retroviruses (enRVs) in sheep, which have been in the host for 5-7 million years. Two enRVs, JS56 and JS-20, got into the genome 3 million years ago and gained a defective gag protein that blocks exogenous retrovir replication. These dominant proviruses became fixed in the genome before sheep domestication 9,000 years ago. A new enRV emerged recently, likely in the last 200 years, that escapes dominant enRV. This study shows sequential events of evolutionary antagonism between endogenous and exogenous retroviruses. It suggests hosts use ERVs as restriction factors to fight retroiral infections.
Researchers have developed a new method to diagnose schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease caused by Schistosoma worms, using real-time PCR (polymerase chain reaction). This method is more sensitive than traditional microscopic examination of stool or urine samples. The study tested 412 samples from patients suspected of having schosomiasis, including urine, stool, biopsy, and serum samples. Compared to traditional methods, PCR increased sensitivity from 4.5% to 10.5% and 33.7 to 48.8% in urine and stool samples respectively. In serum samples, PCR sensitivity was 72.7% and 94.1% in patients with positive microscopy. Specificity was 98.9%. After treatment, PCR positivity declined from 93.8% at 30 days to 8.3% at 360, while antibodies remained positive for a year. The new method outperforms traditional microscopy in stool and urine and can be used with serology, the gold standard for diagnosis. When serology is positive and microscopy is negative, PCR provides information for further exploration.
Researchers have used machine learning to estimate the energy of different shapes of a complex molecule called Archaz A, which is a powerful inhibitor of a type of enzyme found in a certain bacteria. This approach can speed up simulations of the molecule's behavior, which is important for understanding how it works and how it interacts with other molecules. The team used a method called Gaussian process regression, a type of machine learning, to predict the energy of different shapes of the molecule based on previous calculations. They tested the accuracy of the predictions by comparing them to more detailed calculations at a higher level of theory. The results showed that the predictions were very accurate, with an average error of less than 1 kilocalorie per mole. This demonstrates that machine learning can be used for complex and important molecules, potentially speeding up simulations of larger structures. The team used a simple way to represent the molecule's shape, focusing on charges and distances between atoms, which worked well for finding relationships between shape and energy. This is similar to how experimentally determined properties are estimated in chemistry. Machine learning has been used in other areas of quantum mechanics, such as predicting atom energies and transition states, and has been around since the 1990s. This study is a step towards using machine learning with molecular dynamics to simulate long-term behavior of complex systems.
Researchers have developed a new method to detect Ebola virus in wild apes in Africa, where the disease is a major public health concern. They tested fecal samples from gorillas and found that 10% of them had Ebola antibodies, showing they had been exposed to the virus. This is important because it means Ebola is not always deadly for gorillas. The team also found antibodies in gorillas that were thought to be protected from the virus by natural barriers. This new method can help protect apes by detecting early exposure, identifying at-risk populations for vaccination, and tracking vaccine effectiveness. Since humans get Ebola from contact with infected ape carcasses, controlling ape outbreaks can impact human health in local communities where the virus kills up to 88% of people. The study is the first to detect Ebola antibodies in ape feces and has implications for ape management and survival. It's relevant because strategies to protect apes from Ebola are being explored, as vaccines have shown to work in lab monkeys. The team developed a non-invasive assay to detect Ebola in ape feces, allowing insight into ape infections and surveillance. This may aid in epidemiological studies in wild ape populations. The method is sensitive and specific to detect multiple Ebola species with few false results. It's the first to screen large ape populations for Ebola exposure and estimate prevalence.
Researchers have discovered a new type of bacterial protein, called Xop, from the plant pathogen Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicator, that can manipulate plant cells and evade the immune system. This protein, known as a type III effector, is delivered into plant cells by a nanomachine and has E ubiquitin ligase activity. Ubiquitin is a protein that marks other proteins for destruction. Xop's E ubiquitin ligase activity is associated with its C-terminal region, which interacts with plant enzymes and creates K-linked ubiquitin chains. The structure of Xop's C-terminal revealed a novel fold, called XL-box, not seen in any other E ubiquitin ligases. Mutations in the XL-box disrupt its activity and prevent plant cell death. Xop's N-terminal has a leucine-rich repeat (LRR) domain, which may recognize protein targets for ubiquination. While E ligase is needed for cell death, suppression of immune responses depends on N-terminal RR. This unique fold highlights bacterial pathogen's ability to mimic eukote activity.
Researchers studied how the immune system responds to HIV in the early stages of infection and how antiretroviral treatment (ART) affects it. They focused on a specific type of immune cell called follicular helper T cells (cTfh) that helps B cells produce antibodies to fight the virus. The study used a group of people with HIV at different stages of infection: early (stage 1 and 2) and late (stage 3). They found that cfh function was impaired in stage 3 compared to stage 1 and 2. This meant that cfh cells couldn't help B cells produce antibodies as well, and there was more inflammation and less B cells. The study also found that higher viral load in stage 3 was linked to lower cfh-mediated antibody production. This suggests that high virus levels of HIV can damage cfh function and the body's ability to fight it. The researchers also saw changes in the B cell compartment, with fewer memory B cells in stage 3 compared to stage 1 2. This was linked to higher viral load. The study suggests that starting ART early in HIV infection can prevent immune problems and preserve cfh function and B memory.
