Researchers have developed a miniaturized screening method to identify new treatments for the parasitic disease schistosomiasis, which affects over 200 million people worldwide. Current treatment relies on a single drug, praziquel, but it has limitations. The team pharmacologically profiled a schistosome serergic protein-coupled receptor (Sm.5TR), a potential target for new anthelmics. They used a high-throughput screening approach with a luciferase biosensor to measure cellular cAMP levels in intact cells. The study found a divergent pharmacological signature between the paras serergic receptor and its human homolog (H.5TR), supporting the development of parasite-selective ligands. New compounds with potency and selectivity for Sm.5TR over H.7 were identified and validated in vitro and in vivo against schistosules and adult worms. Sm.5 also displayed irreversible inactivation, a phenomenon also seen in H.7, making it a promising target for anthelmic design. The study highlights the feasibility of profiling flatworm GPCRs in high-throughput format and the potential of Sm.5 as a chemotherapeutic node for next-generation anthelmics.
During embryonic development, the formation of the three primary germ layers - ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm - is crucial for the organization of the metazoan body. In some organisms, such as flies, fish, and amphibians, the ectoderm layer not only separates the germ layers but also serves as a substrate for meserm migration. Researchers have found that the separation of these layers is not solely due to differences in adhesion between cells, but rather to contact-induced detachment signals at the boundary between ecterm and meserm. This process involves Ephrin/Eph signaling, where multiple Eph ligands and receptors are expressed on each side of the boundary and tissue separation depends on forward signaling in both directions, involving redundant ligands and receptors and activation of Rac and Rho. This mechanism differs from a simple adhesion-based layer formation and involves localized responses to signals at the boundary and an attachment/detachment cycle allowing cell migration across a substrate.
Researchers analyzed blood samples from 83 children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and 76 age-matched neurotypical peers to identify biochemical markers of the disorder. They used multivariate analysis to classify participants as ASD or neurotypical, achieving 96.1% accuracy for neurotyp and 97.6% for ASD. Additionally, they used partial least squares to predict adaptive behavior, measured by Vineland Adaptive Composite score, with 5 metabolites from folate one-carbon and transulf pathways, achieving R2 of 0.45 after cross-validation. This level of accuracy exceeds previous approaches in the field, indicating strong correlation between metabolites and ASD diagnosis. The study used advanced statistical tools to examine metabolites of folate one-carbon and transulf pathways in neurotyp and ASD children, as well as their siblings. Children aged 3-10 were assessed for oxidative stress, with ASD defined by Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for Disorders, Autism Observation Schedule, and Childhood Rating Scales. Folate metabolites from 83,47,76, and 47 ASD, sibling, and age-matched neurotyp children were used for classification. The multivariate analysis provided unprecedented classification separating ASD and neurotyp cohorts based solely on biochemical data.
Researchers used a statistical method called Bayesian geostatistical modeling to study the spread of Leishmanis in Brazil. Leishias is a disease that affects 350 million people in 98 countries and causes 2 million cases annually. Brazil is one of the most affected countries. The study looked at data from 2001 to 2010 and found that precipitation and socioeconomic factors were important for both cutaneous and visceral leishias. The models predicted 30,189 cases of cutaneous leias and 4,889 of visceral leias in 2010. Maps showed the highest numbers of infected in Minas Gerais and Para states. The study identified areas where leias control efforts should be targeted to reduce the disease. 

The researchers used data from the Ministry of Health in Brazil and a method called INLA to fit the models. They looked at climate, environmental, and socioeconomic factors that affect leias. This is the first study to use this method for leias in Brazil. Previous studies mapped leias at state level but didn't use statistical models that account for space and time. The study found that precipitation and socioeconomic factors were important for both types of leias.
A large study in Vietnam looked at the differences in symptoms and complications of deng between adults and children. The researchers compared 647 adults and 881 children who were hospitalized with deng at the same hospital. They found that children had more severe signs of bleeding and shock, while adults had more bleeding and organ problems. Adults also had lower platelet counts, which is a type of blood cell that helps with clotting. This was true even after they recovered from the illness. The study suggests that adults and children have different patterns of complications from deng due to their age. This is important for understanding how the disease works and creating treatment guidelines for different age groups.
Researchers studied the infection of sooty mangabeys, a type of monkey, with a virus called SIVm, which is similar to HIV in humans. They found that despite the virus replicating well in the monkeys, it doesn't cause disease. They discovered a new mutation in the CCR5 gene, a protein that helps the virus enter cells, which is present in 26% of the monkeys. This mutation makes a non-functional protein that doesn't appear on the cell surface and can't support virus entry. 8% of monkeys are homozygous for this mutation and 41% are heterozygous. The mutation is also found in wild monkeys in Africa. CD4 and CD8 T cells show a gradient of C5 expression across groups, more in CD8 cells. Surprisingly, the prevalence of SIVm infection is not different in monkeys lacking C5 compared to heterozygous and wild-type. Monkeys lacking C5 have robust viral loads, only modestly lower than wild-type. SIVm isolates infect both homozyg mutant and wild PBMC in C5-independent manner in vitro and Envs from C5-null and wild animals use CX6, G15 and G1 in addition to C5 transfected cells.
Researchers have been trying to understand how a protein called MEF2 contributes to the development of tumors, but its role has been unclear. A new study found that M2 can both promote and suppress tumor growth depending on the partners it interacts with. When M2 works with certain proteins, it helps turn on or off genes by changing histone marks like H3K methylation and H3 acetylation. In a type of tumor called leiomyosarcoma (LMS), M2 has two faces: it can be good or bad. In 22% of MS, class II HDs are overexpressed, and high levels of M2, HD4, and HD9 are linked to poor survival. Knocking out HD9 in MS cells makes them less cancerous by restoring M2's ability to turn on genes. HD9 also removes H3me3 from M2's target genes. Surprisingly, class II HDs don't bind M's regulatory elements, so M2 can turn on and off genes at the same time. Repressed M2 genes are ready to be turned on in chromatin. The study suggests class II HDs and HD9 are potential targets for treatment in MS.
Researchers have studied the structure and formation of hydrophins, proteins produced by the fungus Trichoderma rei, using a combination of protein docking, molecular simulation, and cryo-electron microscopy. The study focused on two types of hydrophins, HFBI and HFBII, and found that they form a unit cell composed of six proteins with a hexagonal symmetry. However, experimental results showed a unit cell with three proteins and a smaller size of 56 angstroms. Computational simulations suggested an alternative structure with three proteins and a smaller size, which was tested using a Monte Carlo model. The model showed that this structure could increase the rate of hydroph film formation, indicating a possible mechanism for both biological and technological applications. Hydrophins are important for fungi to interact with their environment and have various uses in industry. The study used cryo-EM, protein docking, and dynamics to get a detailed view of the hydrophin film at the air-water interface. The structures of HF and HII were studied at high resolution. The experimentally, the unit cell size matches a hexagonal arrangement of proteins, but would be seen as a uniform sheet by AFM. The unique properties of hydroph films come from interactions between proteins in the surface network. Hydrophins have been used in industry and biology, and similar models have been used to study self-assembly. The study aimed to understand the role of P3 symmetry in film formation and designed a Monte Carlo algorithm to mimic protein motions. The first high-resolution structure of hydroin was HII, found to be cross-linked with disulfide bridges and 2nm diameter, with an amphipathic structure.
Researchers have identified a potential new target for treating leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the parasite Leishmania donani. They studied the enzyme aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase, LThr, which is essential for protein synthesis in the parasite. Recombinant LThr was expressed and purified, and its kinetic parameters were determined. Immunofluorescence analysis showed LThr is localized in the cytosol and mitochondria. Heterozygous mutants of LThr in Leish promastigotes showed restricted growth and reduced infectivity, and were more susceptible to the inhibitor borid. Several attempts to create Thr homozyg null mutants failed, indicating its essentiality for the parasite. Borid showed strong affinity for LThr and inhibited its activity. The study suggests LThr is a potential target for drug discovery.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA is recognized as non-self by the protein RIG-I through the presence of a 5- triphosphate (5-pp) on viral RNA associated with a 3 poly-UUC tract. Researchers have defined the HCV pathogen-associated molecular pattern (PAMP) and criteria for R-I non-discrimination of HCV by examining RNA-function attributes that impart PAMP to the poly-UC tract. They found that the 34 nucleotide polyuridine core of the sequence was essential for R-I activation and interspersed ribosine nucleotides between poly sequences in RNA were required for optimal R-I induction. 5-pp poly-UC variants stimulated R-I efficiently in vitro and interaction with the repressor and helicase domain of R-I was required for signaling. When appended to 5-pp RNA lacking P activity, the polyUC-core sequence conferred non-recognition of RNA and innate signaling by-I. Importantly, H polyUC variants strongly activated-I triggered anti-H responses in vitro and hepatic immune responses in vivo using a mouse model of P signaling. These studies define a multi-mot P signature of non-recognition by-I that incorporates 5-pp with polyuridine composition and length. The H P motif drives-I to induce the immune response to infection.
Researchers have found that eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, play a crucial role in supporting the growth of a parasitic worm called Trichella spiralis in the host's skeletal muscle. Eosinils produce a protein called IL-4, which helps the worm grow by enhancing glucose uptake in the host cells. This process occurs without the involvement of the immune system's adaptive response. In fact, the presence of eosils suppresses inflammation and maintains nutrient balance in the infected tissue. The study suggests that the worm has evolved a strategy to co-opt the host's innate response to facilitate its growth. Further research is needed to confirm this mechanism.
Researchers studied how DNA replication occurs in human cells, specifically in a type called HeLa cells. They found that DNA replication origins, where replication starts, are spaced about 40,000 base pairs apart and fire in clusters. As the cell replicates, more origins in a cluster fire at the same time, increasing the number of replication forks. The speed of replication remains constant, about 0.7 to 2 kilobases per minute, throughout the process. Analysis of the entire genome shows that replication timing is not uniform, with some regions taking less than 2 minutes and others more than 10 minutes to replicate. This suggests that forks do not move in a single direction, but rather in both forward and backward directions. In fact, most of the genome is replicated by activation of multiple origins, not a single fork. The study also found that the speed of replication depends on the number of forks moving forward and backward, not just the speed of a single fork. The results provide new insights into how mammalian genomes replicate and a model for their replication.
Researchers investigated how the brain's ability to recognize objects despite changes in context, such as lighting or perspective, is achieved. They proposed that this is done by exploiting the fact that object identities change slowly over time, while context changes quickly. The study explored how this "temporal stability" or "slown" approach can be implemented in biologically realistic learning rules. A slow analysis algorithm, based on slown, was implemented in a continuous model using a modified Hebbian rule, linking it to the trace rule, another slown learning implementation. For linear neurons, slown was shown to be implemented by spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) with a specific window. Analyzing STDP, it was found that the window alone is not relevant, but its convolution with the postsynaptic potential (EPSP) is. This led to STDP windows that implement slown and the trace rule, compatible with physiological data in shape and timescale. The analysis showed the window can be split into reversible and irreversible components, sensitive to input statistics. Irreversible statistics generate oscillatory weight dynamics. The study offers a new interpretation of ST's role in neurons.
Researchers have discovered a new way that cancer cells in non-small lung cancer (NSCL) tumors work together to become resistant to chemotherapy. This is called cooperative adaptation to therapy (CAT). Normally, when cancer cells are exposed to treatment, they become resistant due to genetic and phenotypic heterogeneity. However, this study found that cells can induce resistant phenotypes in neighboring cells, even if they don't have the same genetic or phenotyp features. This is called cooperative adaptation to therapy (CAT). The researchers used a CRISPR/Cas toolkit to create diverse NSCL cells with mutations in Dicer, a gene involved in non-coding RNA. They grew cells in a 3D culture system and monitored their growth under drug pressure. Mathematical modeling and flow cytometry showed that co-cultures of wild-type and mutant cells allowed sensitive cells to grow despite drug pressure. This was due to a game-theoretic change in fitness. The study also used an ex vivo model to predict clinical response to drugs and found that cellular heterogeneity correlates with failure of multiple drugs in NSCL patients. This suggests that targeting druggable mutations alone may not be enough for effective therapy.
A study in the Mbeya region of southwestern Tanzania found that 67.9% of the population above the age of 5 had IgG antibodies against Spotted Group (SFG) rickettsiae, a type of bacteria that causes spotted fever. The study involved 1,228 participants from nine communities, stratified by age, altitude, and ownership of domestic mammals. Higher temperatures and lower elevations were associated with higher seroprevalence. Male gender and lower population density were also associated with higher seropval. Cattle density was associated with higher seropval at higher elevations. The study suggests that SFG ricketial infection is common in the rural population of Mb Region and spread is limited by temperature and elevation. Further research is needed to determine the contribution of SFG to febrile illnesses and estimate the disease burden in the population.
Researchers have discovered a new role for a type of fatty acid called oleate in the immune system of a tiny worm called Caenorhabditis elegans. This fatty acid is important for the worm's ability to fight off infections. The scientists found that the worm needs oleate to turn on its immune genes to defend against bacteria. Without oleate, the worm is more likely to get infected by different types of bacteria. However, adding oleate back to the worm helps it fight off the infection. But oleate alone is not enough to activate the immune system. This study adds to what is known about the benefits of a certain types of fatty acids and suggests a link between how the body uses fatty acids and its ability to fight off infections.
Scientists have discovered a new way to create antibiotics that target a specific type of molecule in bacteria, called guanine riboswitch, which is involved in making the building blocks of DNA and RNA. These molecules, called riboswitch ligands, can be designed to bind to guanine ribwitch and prevent it from working, stopping the bacteria from growing. Researchers found a pyrimidine compound, called PC1, that binds to guanine ribwitch and kills certain types of bacteria, including some that are resistant to antibiotics. This compound only works when a specific gene, guA, is controlled by gu ribwitch, showing it targets a different pathway. In a mouse study, PC reduced Staphylococcus aureus infection in mammary glands, showing its potential as a new antibiotic. Guanine ribwitches are part of the purine class, which also includes adenine and 2-deoxyguanine, and regulate transcription at high guanine levels in Bacillus subtilis. The guanine aptamer is a three-way junction of helices with a critical nucleotide in Watson-Crick pair with the ligand. Break group used purine derivatives to target guwitch and found molecules that inhibited growth, but only one repressed expression of guwitch-controlled gene, suggesting different mechanisms.
Researchers studied how macaque monkeys navigate a virtual reality maze to find a reward. They looked at how their behavior, visual exploration, and brain activity in the hippocampus. The hippocampus is a part of the brain that helps with memory and navigation. The researchers found that some cells in the hippocampus responded to one or more things like direction, point of gaze, or task. These cells fired when the monkey saw a landmark and in a specific way that depended on the task. They also encoded the monkey's situation within a set of actions to reach the goal. Overall, hippocampus activity was best described by a fine-grained space of current position, view, and context. The study shows that primate place cells embody multidimensional, task-situated knowledge to the target of gaze, supporting self-awareness in space construction. This type of coding is common in mammals, similar to rodents. The study shows space in primates self-position with respect to target gaze and carries cognitive information to current trajectory to goal. The researchers probed the nature of hippocampus coding in a goal task, separating goal and landmarks, and how cells code position, direction, and gaze. They found that task context modulated activity of cells. Previous studies in primates, including humans, showed hippocampus encoded spatial views, place, or a mix of place and view. The study shows hippocampus display fine tuning to one landmark being viewed and self-position to landmark. The results give a comprehensive analysis of variables controlling hippocampus cells, bridging rodent and primate studies in real and virtual environments.
Researchers have studied the development of the midbrain and hindbrain in vertebrates, focusing on the midbrain boundary (MHB), where a specific pattern of gene expression is established and maintained by a network of regulatory interactions between transcription and secreted factors. They used a computational approach to analyze the spatial expression patterns at the murine MHB, revealing key interactions in the network. The study found that fibroblast growth factor 8 (Fgf8) maintains, rather than induces, wingless 1 (Wnt) expression, a previously unclear issue. Experiments on mouse neural plate explants showed F8 only maintains, but does not induce ectopic Wnt expression. The researchers constructed a regulatory network of key transcription and secret factors at the M and analyzed it using Boolean equations and reaction-diff models, confirming it explains the maintenance of M and expression patterns in wild-type and knock-out conditions. The study demonstrates that spatial expression patterns can provide information about regulatory networks, helping to understand the maintenance of M on a systems level.
A parasite called Theileria annulata infects host cells, causing them to multiply uncontrollably. After the parasite enters the cell, the host's cell membrane dissolves and microtubules (MTs) surround it, forming a structure called a schizont. Instead of invading other cells, the schizont stays attached to the host MTs and uses them to divide the cell during mitosis and cytokinesis. To do this, it interacts with the host's astral and central MTs. Scientists wanted to know how the schizont recruits and stabilizes host MTs. They focused on the plus ends of MT, which are dynamic and constantly growing or shrinking. They found that the schizont recruits a protein called EB1, which regulates host MT dynamics. EB1 binds to a parasite protein called p104, which is on the schizont's surface. This binding depends on a specific sequence in p104. The interaction is regulated by the cell cycle. This is the first time a pathogen protein has interacted with EB via a specific sequence. The study shows how Theileria interacts with the host's cytoskeleton.
In yeast cells, broken replication forks can lead to DNA breaks that are normally repaired through a process called homologous recombination or break-induced replication (BIR). When the enzyme replicase Cdc9 is deficient, cells accumulate DNA damage, likely due to broken forks, and activate a DNA damage checkpoint, leading to longer telomeres. Telomere length requires telomerase, the DNA signaling cascade Mec1-Rad-Rad53, and BIR pathway components Rad51, Rad52, 32, and P1. The phosphorylation of P1 by Mec-Rad53, necessary for inhibiting telomerase at double breaks, is also crucial for P1's role in BIR and telom elongation in c9 cells. Two other mutants, c44 and r3, similar to c9, have long telomeres dependent on P1 phosphorylation. We propose that B forks passing through telomeres promote telerase activity, leading to telom lengthening.
Researchers have developed a new tool to diagnose Onchocercias, a disease caused by the filarial nematode Onocerca volulus, which is a major public health concern due to its debilitating symptoms and resurgence in areas where control measures have been implemented. The tool, called luciferase immunoprecitation system (LIPS), is a rapid, specific, and standardized assay that can differentiate between infected and uninfected individuals with 100% sensitivity and 100 specificity. Four recombinantly produced Onoc volulus antigens (OvAR-1, API-1, A-MS-1, and CPI-1) were tested on a large cohort of sera from uninfected controls and patients with proven infection, including Onoculus, Wucher bancfti, Loa loa, Strongloides storal, and other cross-reactive infections. Antibody responses to the four antigens allowed unequivocal differentiation between infected and uninf with 100 sensitivity and specificity. Analysis of antibody titers to each antigen in infected sera revealed they were different and did not correlate with each other. Compared to infected, patients with W, L, S, and other conditions had lower mean antibody titers to each antigen. The method using a mixture of four antigens in standard or 15-minute format showed 100 sensitivity and specificity distinguishing infected from uninf. The 15-minute format had best performance with sensitivity and specificity for distinguishing from W, L, and S-infected. The multi-antigen IPS can be a rapid, high-throughput tool to diagnose individual infections and sensitive point-of-care for early detection in areas control and mapping.
Researchers conducted a 54-month study in rural Vietnam to evaluate the effectiveness of weekly iron-folic acid supplementation and deworming in reducing anemia, iron deficiency, and soil-transmitted infections in women of reproductive age. The study found that 76% of participants took the ironolic supplement and 95% received dewing treatment. Hemoglobin levels rose from 122g/L to 131/L and anemia prevalence fell from 38% to 18. Iron deficiency decreased from 23% to 8 and iron deficiency anemia from 4%. Hookworm infection dropped from 76 to 11 and moderate or heavy infestation to less than 1%. The study suggests that population-based interventions can efficiently reduce anemia and eliminate iron deficiency and moderate to heavy soil-transmitted infections below public health concern levels.
Researchers have discovered a new way that the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) evades the immune system. EBV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause life-threatening reactivations in people with weakened immune systems. To avoid being detected by the immune system, EBV produces a protein called gp150. This protein forms a shield on the surface of infected cells, making it harder for the immune system to recognize the virus. The shield is made of sugar molecules that cover the protein, making it invisible to the immune cells. This is a new way for EBV to escape the immune system, different from other herpesviruses. The protein gp150 does not break down the molecules that help the immune recognize the virus, nor does it need a part of the protein inside the cell to work. The study found that cells infected with a mutant EBV without gp150 had higher levels of surface molecules that help the immune recognize the virus. This suggests that immune cells other than T cells, like B cells, play a role in fighting EBV infection. The results also show that EBV gp150 helps the virus survive at a vulnerable stage of its life cycle.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called Tarp plays a crucial role in the invasion of certain bacteria called chlamydia into host cells. Tarp is found in all pathogenic chlamial species and helps the bacteria to bind to actin, a protein that makes up the cell's skeleton. The team created an antibody that specifically targets the actin binding part of Tarp and found that it prevents the bacteria from entering host cells. They also found that different chlamial species have different numbers of actin binding sites on T, but all can still form actin filaments. This suggests that T mediated actin binding is a conserved among diverse chlamial species and plays a key role in bacterial invasion. The study shows that the actin activity of T is necessary for the bacteria to enter host cells.
Researchers have developed a new method to accurately count Schistosoma japon eggs in animal feces, a parasite that causes schistosiasis in humans. The method, called formalin-ethylate sediment-digestion (F-SD), removes most debris in feces, making it easier to see eggs under a microscope. This is important because debris often hides eggs, making it hard to determine how many animals are infected and how severe the infection is. The new method was tested on water buffaloes in China and carab water buffalo in the Philippines, showing it's effective and accurate. It's also cheaper than another method, real-time PCR, and can be used in areas with low infection rates or after control efforts to eliminate schosiasis. The FSD method is a tool to track animal reservoirs of S japon, particularly in areas with low to high infection.
Researchers have long known that mutations in the genes encoding cartilage protein (CRT) and proly 3-hydroxylase 1 (P3H1) cause a rare genetic disorder called osteogenesis imperfecta (OI). These proteins, along with cyclophilin, form a complex that 3-hydroxylates a single proline on the α1(I) chain of collagen, which is essential for its proper folding. Recent studies suggest that this 3-hydroxylation is not crucial for collagen's structural stability, but its absence may disrupt protein interactions that help collagen fold properly, leading to overmodification. A new study created mice with a single amino acid substitution in PH's catalytic site, which abolished its 3-hydroxylase activity but not its ability to form a complex with CRT. These mice lacked 3-hydroxylation at Pro986 of α(I) and α(II) collagen chains but showed no overmodification at other residues. They were normal in appearance, had no growth defects, and normal cartilage plate histology but decreased trabecular bone mass. This model recapitulates some of OI's bone but not cartilage phenotypes caused by losing the 3-hydroxylation complex. The study suggests different tissue consequences from inactivating PH's 3-hydroxylase versus ablating the 3-hydroxylation complex.
Scientists have discovered that a genetic element called the P-element has invaded a species of fruit fly called Drosophila simulans, causing a condition called hybrid dysgenesis, which leads to abnormal phenotypes such as sterility. This is similar to what happened in a closely related species, Drosila melanogaster, where the P-element spread rapidly in just a few decades. Until now, D simul was P-element free. Researchers found that around 20% of D simul strains induce dysgenesis and used genomic and transcript data to show this is linked to the P-element invasion. They surveyed 631 simul strains on three continents over 27 years and found the P-element invaded rapidly and simultaneously in regions. Strains with P-elements were rare in 2006 but common by 2014. Strains from the latter phase of invasion have adapted to suppress the P-element's effects, showing resistance to dysgenesis.
Researchers have developed a new method to mark and track male Aedes aegypt mosquitoes using a fluorescent dye called rhodamine B. This dye is given to the mosquitoes through sugar, which they eat, and stains their bodies and seminal fluid. The study tested different concentrations of rhamine and found that 0.4% and 0.8% were the most effective and longest-lasting. Importantly, the marking did not affect the males' ability to mate with females. In field tests, marked males were released and recaptured, and their seminal fluid was found in the females they mated with. This shows that rhamine can be used to evaluate the success of male-based control methods to reduce mosquito populations. It's also a cheaper and faster alternative to other methods like genetic analysis and isotope labeling.
Bacterial superantigens, a family of toxins, induce an inflammatory cytokine storm that can lead to lethal shock. Researchers found that superigens bind directly to the CD28 homodimer, a protein on T cells, to elicit cytokine expression and toxicity. Preventing superigen access to CD28 blocks lethality. Mice were protected from superigen challenge by peptides mimicking the CD28 interface and competing with superigen for binding. Superigens use a conserved β-strand/α-helix domain to engage CD28. Mutation of this domain abolished cytokine induction and lethality. Structural analysis showed superigen binds to T cell receptor and MHC on antigen-presenting cell, CD28 accommodates as third receptor in complex with CD interface towards β-str/and/α-helix. Findings identify CD28 interface as critical target for superigens, broadening pathogen recognition mechanisms.
Researchers have discovered that the Wnt/β-caten pathway plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle and proliferation of embryonic stem cells (ESCs). Unlike somatic cells, ESCs have a fast cell cycle with a short G1 phase due to the lack of cell cycle inhibitors, which maintains their pluripotency and prevents differentiation. The Wnt/β-caten pathway controls pluripotency through the W-effector T3, but its effect on the cell cycle of ESCs was unknown. The study found that W-eff T1 is recruited and triggers the transcription of the Ink/Ar tumor suppressor locus, restoring G1 phase and reducing proliferation of ESCs without affecting pluripotency. T1, not T3, is recruited to palindromic motifs in promoters of cycle repressors, such as p15k, p16, and p19, mediating W-dependent anti-proliferation in ESCs. Ablation of β-caten or T1 impairs W-dependent cell regulation. Activation of W results in downregulation of differentiation genes while plurotency remains unpert. Cell effects depend on βaten and T1, but not T3, indicating non-overlapping functions of T/L factors in ESCs. T1 is enriched at promoters of cycle genes like Ink/Ar locus. Data show GSK inhibition βaten transcriptionally regulates expression of Ink and Ar members in T3-independent manner. T1 KD ESC lines show decreased T1 levels, but not impaired plurotent markers. W pathway induces expression of negative cycle regulators, such as tumor suppressors p16, p19, and p15. Results show W/βaten triggers anti-proliferative effect in ESCs via T1 activity, contrasting its mitogenic effect in somatic cells.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection can cause a wide range of symptoms, from mild to severe and even fatal, and can lead to plasma leakage and hemorrhages due to a cytokine storm caused by monocytes and dendritic cells during DENV replication. Plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) are innate immune cells that respond to virus exposure by secreting IF-α and expressing membrane TRAIL (mTR). Researchers aimed to characterize DC activation in deng patients and their function under DENV-2 in vitro. Flow cytometry analysis revealed that pDC of mildeng patients exhibit higher frequencies of mTR compared to severe or healthy controls. Plasma of IF-α and TR are increased in mild compared to severeeng patients, correlating with DC activation. Experiments showed that in vitro exposure to D-2 induced mTR expression on p. Microscopy highlighted TR was relocalized from intracellular to plasma membrane. Chloro treatment inhibited D- inducedTR localization and IFα by p. Endosomal degradation by chloro allowed viral antig detection inside p. Data suggest endocyt pathway activation by D in p. Coculture p/D- infected monocytes revealed dramatic antigen reduction by. This was also observed after exogenous IFα treatment, indicating DC effect on viral load dependent on IFα production.
Researchers studied how the role of tumor necrosis factor (TN) in fighting Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection. TN helps the body defend against TB in both active and latent phases of infection. However, TN-neutralizing drugs used to treat inflammatory diseases have been linked to increased risk of TB in animal studies. This study used a computational approach to understand TN's role in TB. They extended previous models to investigate soluble (sTN) and transmembrane TN (tmTN). Analyzing anti-T therapy in clinical trials, they simulated two common treatments, anti-T antibody and TN receptor, to predict differences in TB reactivation rates. The study found that TN availability after anti-T therapy is the main cause of latent infection reactivation and that even low levels of TN are essential for control. Using a model, they distinguished anti-T treatment mechanisms and TN's role in TB control and pathology. The study suggests a TN-modulating agent could balance reduction of inflammation with resistance to infection. Alternatively, anti-T therapy timing and dose could be modified.
Researchers have found that genetic variations in the human genome, known as retroduplication variations (RD), can lead to differences between individuals. These variations occur when a copy of a gene is either present or absent in a person's genome. A study used data from the 100 Genomes Project to investigate how often these variations occur in different human populations. They also looked at how often these variations are expressed in the body's cells. The researchers developed a new way to detect variations not listed in the human genome and confirmed their presence in 17 populations. They found 193 variations, mostly from gene deletion. Most were not previously known. Some variations were expressed in certain individuals, but not others were not. The frequency of deletion was low, except for one. The remaining variations' low expression and deletion rate suggest they may have a function. The study also found differences in expression levels between populations, with 9 variations expressed differently.

A new approach was developed to detect undiscovered variations in the genome. Previous studies found 208 variations in populations, but many questions remained. This study found 193, more than previous studies individually, but less than all together. It focused on variations from deletion, not recent events. Many were missing in some genomes. The study used 4,927 variations and genomic data from 1,092 individuals. It found 214 variations affected 190. The variations can provide insight into human history and ongoing processes. RNA data from the Geuvis Consortium allowed studying changes and implications.
Inflammation caused by praziquel treatment depends on the location of Taenia solium cysts in porcine neurocysticosis. Researchers studied the effect of the location of cysts in the brain on inflammation after treatment in pigs. They used histological specimens from naturally infected pigs to investigate the characteristics of the inflammatory reaction around Taenia solium cysts according to their location in the brain tissue, meninges, or both, and the effect of anthelmintic treatment on these variables. 

The study found that cysts located in the parenchyma (brain tissue) provoked a higher level of inflammation after treatment compared to those in the meninges (tissue surrounding the brain and spinal cord) and those partially in contact with both. Inflammation in meningeal cysts was not affected by treatment, but increased in corticomeneal cysts correlated with the extent of cysts adjacent to the parenym. Disruption of the blood-brain barrier was associated with treatment in parenym tissue. Inflammatory response to cysts in meninges was decreased compared to parenym cysts. The study suggests that suboptimal inflammatory response to cystidal drugs may be the reason subarachn neurocysticosis is refractory to treatment compared to parenym.
Researchers conducted a study in Ghana to investigate the presence of yaws, a disease caused by Treponema pallidum s. pertue, in two districts where azithrom was previously distributed to control trachoma. They found no evidence of ongoing transmission of y in these areas, but detected Haemophilus duyi DNA in some lesions. The study suggests that H. duyi may be associated with some skin lesions, but most cases remain unexplained. The researchers recommend integrating diagnostic testing into pre- and post-treatment surveillance to inform y control programs. The study found no active or latent y in the Northern Region of Ghana, with all patients having negative treponal and non-treponal serology, indicating they had never been infected with y. The districts had completed several rounds of azithycin MDA for trach in the past decade. The study's findings have implications for the WHO's y eradication campaign, as Ghana is a major focus of y worldwide. A range of organisms can cause ulcerative skin lesions, including Mycobacterium ulcer, which is endemic in Ghana. Accurate data on y epidemiology is needed to guide eradication efforts.
Researchers have been trying to find ways to get rid of the HIV virus that stays in the body even after treatment. This virus hides in a type of immune cell called memory T cells. A pathway called Jak-STAT helps keep these cells alive and active. Two drugs, tofacitinib and ruxitin, block this pathway and were tested to see if they could get rid of the virus. They worked in lab tests and showed that blocking Jak-STAT reduced the number of cells with the virus. The drugs also stopped the virus from making more copies of itself and spreading to other cells. This could be a way to prevent the virus from coming back. The study also looked at people on treatment and found that blocking Jak-STAT was linked to the virus staying in the body.
Researchers studied the immune response of Spodoptera exigua larvae to two different types of baculoviruses, SeNP and AcNP. Contrary to the expected "host shut-off" of gene expression, the larvae showed a balanced mix of up- and down-regulated genes in the first 36 hours after infection. Many immune-related genes, including pattern recognition proteins and signaling pathways, were down-regulated after baculirus infection. This down-regulation was also seen in the larval gut, where immune-related genes affect the status of gut microorganisms responsible for growth and development. The researchers wondered if this down-regulation affected the amount of gut microbiota. They found an increase in bacterial load and hypothesized it as a consequence of viral infection. Experiments showed that gut bacteria enhanced baculirus virulence and pathogenicity. The study discusses host response pathways affected by baculiruses and the role of microbiota in infection.
Scientists have made a breakthrough in understanding of apomix, a type of asexual reproduction in plants, by creating a new genotype called Mi that replaces meiosis with mitosis. Meiosis is a process where cells divide to produce gametes with half the number of chromosomes, while mitosis is a process where cells divide to produce identical copies. In Mi plants, meiosis is replaced by mitosis, resulting in diploid gametes that are genetically identical to the mother plant. This is a significant step towards understanding and engineering apomix, which could be useful in agriculture.

The researchers isolated a gene that controls entry into second meiotic division and combined it with two other genes that affect meiotic processes to create the Mi genotype. They tested it in plants and found that meiosis was completely replaced by mitosis. The plants produced functional diploid gametes that were genetically identical to the mother. This is different from previous attempts where only 0.2% of gametes were viable, making it unusable for apix engineering. In contrast, Mi plants produced wild-type levels of viable gametes and pollen.

The Mi plants underwent mit-like division instead of normal meiotic division without affecting sexual processes. Gametes retained the mother's heterozygosity for genetic markers, confirming mitosis instead of meiosis. When meiosis is replaced by mitosis, ploidy is expected to double with each generation.
Researchers have developed a new method to identify genes that cause diseases by looking at how they interact with other proteins in the body. Current methods use a general map of protein interactions, but this doesn't account for how different tissues in the body work. The new method uses data on how genes are expressed in specific tissues to create a map of interactions for each tissue. This improves identifying disease-causing genes and predicts new associations between diseases and tissues. 

The researchers tested the method on 60 human tissues and found it worked better than the general map. They also found that most disease-causing genes are expressed in the tissue where the disease occurs. By adding tissue information, they were able to identify more disease-causing genes and new tissue associations. The method was tested on different ways to create tissue maps and found some worked better than others.
Researchers have developed a two-locus model to study the spread of insecticide resistance in mosquitoes that transmit diseases such as malaria. The model accounts for differences in male and female mosquitoes' exposure to high or low concentrations of insecticide and varying selection pressures depending on the concentration. They tested the model by comparing sequential use of insecticides versus deploying them as a mixture to minimize resistance spread. Results showed mixtures outperformed sequential use in 56% of runs, while 44% favored sequential. Mixtures are favored when insecticides are highly effective and exposure is low. If insecticides don't kill homozygous mosquitoes, sequential use is more robust. Resistance spreads slower with mixtures, but may not always outperform sequential. For example, a mixture may last 5 years while individual insecticides last 3-4, giving 7 years total lifespan. The model can identify control strategies to minimize resistance spread, not advocate for mix or sequential as a policy. Results depend on insect attributes, application, behavior, and genetics. Mixtures are favored with effective insecticides, which may be the case with new ones under development.
Researchers have studied the saliva of Rhodnius neglectus, a type of kissing bug that transmits Chagas disease. They used next generation sequencing and mass spectrometry to identify the proteins in its saliva. They found 636 proteins that are likely secreted by the bug, 73 of which were confirmed by proteomic analysis. The saliva contains serine proteases, lipocalins, serine protease inhibitors, antigen-5 metalloproteases, disins, and odor binding proteins. These proteins are similar to those found in other kissing bugs that transmit the disease. The study improves understanding of how these bugs interact with their hosts and how they transmit the disease. It also opens up new possibilities for finding new molecules in the saliva of blood-sucking insects that could be used to fight the disease. The researchers cataloged the proteins in the saliva of Rhnius neglect, highlighting the presence of serine proteases. Other proteins predicted to be secreted by the bug include metalloprotease, antigen-5, serpin, and trypsin-like protease.
Researchers used the nematode Caenorhabdis elegans to study how nematodes interact with bacteria in soil. They exposed C. elegans to different types of bacteria found in grassland soils and used a technique called transcription profiling to see which genes were turned on or off in response. Many genes related to metabolism and immunity were affected, suggesting they play a role in nemode community dynamics in natural systems. The researchers then disabled 21 of these genes and found most affected lifespan and fitness in specific bacterial environments. Even though these bacteria aren't a natural food source for C. elegans, changes in food source due to environmental disturbance had a big impact on gene expression and fitness. They used analysis to show that the degree of gene difference between environments predicted the effect of gene loss on life traits in those environments. C. elegans is not found in abundance in grass soils but is related to relevant nemodes, making it a good model for studying nemode-bacteria interactions.
Scientists have studied how the early stages of mammalian embryo development, specifically the formation of the inner cell mass surrounded by the trophoblast, a layer of cells that forms extra-embryonic structures. They used multi-scale modeling to investigate the principles behind this process. The study made three predictions, supported by quantitative imaging. First, gene expression noise promotes cell plasticity and plays a crucial role in organizing the mouse blastocyst. Second, asymmetry in levels of Cdx2 and Oct4 noise variation provides a means to benefit from noise plasticity while reducing detrimental effects of stochasticity. Third, the embryo controls timing and pace of cell specification to modulate plasticity, creating a window for cells to read environment and adjust fate. Results suggest noise is crucial in maintaining plasticity and organizing the blastocyst.
Researchers have discovered that germline-encoded antibodies, which are antibodies produced by the immune system before exposure to antigens, can bind to multiple antigens with high specificity. This is different from mature antibodies, which are produced after exposure to antigens, that typically bind to one specific antigens. The team used a computational tool called Rosetta to design antibodies that can bind to multiple antigens or a single antigen. They found that designing antibodies to bind multiple antigens resulted in sequences similar to those encoded by germl genes, while designing to bind a single antigen resulted in sequences similar to mature antibodies. This suggests that germl-encoded antibodies have flexibility that allows them to bind diverse antigens. The team also found that certain positions in the germl gene, such as CDR1, CDR, and immunoglobulin framework, contribute to polyspecificity. Designing antibodies that can bind multiple antigens may allow for rational design of antibodies that retain polyspecific for diverse epitope binding. The study demonstrates that Rosetta design captures aspects of antibody-antigen recognition and provides a step towards rational antibody design without prior knowledge of germl or mature sequences.
Locusts exhibit two main behavioral phases: solitary and gregarious. Solitary locusts are repelled by other locusts, while gregar insects are attracted to conspecifics and form large aggregations like hopper bands. Research has shown that crowding converts locusts to the gregar form. To understand hopper band formation, scientists studied phase change at the collective level. A mathematical model was created to predict the dynamics of hopper formation at the population level. The model reveals conditions for an outbreak, characterized by a large transition to the gregar phase. It also predicts the proportion of the population that will gregarize and the time for this to occur. Numerical simulations show aggregation's structure and traveling clumps of gregar insects. The model suggests possible future biological experiments.

The problem was addressed by creating a mathematical model to describe collective gregar, a key process before destructive locust outbreaks. It linked individual phase change and interactions to the gregar hopper band. The onset of an outbreak was studied by constructing a behavioral model for gregar and solitary locusts. Dynamics were classified in wide parameter space, a challenging by numerical techniques alone. For low densities, both phases are spread and solitary dominates. For large populations, a dense gregar patch emerges and solitary locs become scarce. Clustering at high densities is the hop band. The model calculates the critical density for gregar forms and the ratio gregar to solitary. Behavioral is plastic and dependent on density: gregar to solitary in sparse and vice versa in crowded. This is summarized in a figure. Analysis yields the most unstable spacing from the number of modes. Simulations show rapid transitions once gregar is initiated. Dense gregar packs form and sweep solitary in vicinity.
Scientists have been trying to understand how viruses fuse with host cells, a process called membrane fusion, for a long time. Viruses have proteins on their surface, called fusion proteins, that change shape to trigger fusion. However, it's hard to capture the middle stages of this process because they are short-lived. Researchers studied tick-borne encephalitis virus, a type of flavivirus, to see how it fuses with cells. They found that by changing the pH, or acidity, of the environment, they could trap the virus in a middle stage where the fusion proteins break apart and attach to the cell membrane, but don't merge. When they changed the pH back to normal, the virus fused with the cell. This shows that there are two steps in the fusion process: first, the proteins break apart and attach, then merge. This helps us understand how viruses work and how they infect cells.
Scientists are concerned that we are experiencing an extinction event on a scale similar to the mass extinctions seen in the fossil record, with present-day extinction rates estimated to be several orders of magnitude higher than background rates and projected to increase if current trends continue. While research has focused on vertebrates, such as body size, fecundity, and geographic range, as predictors of vulnerability, knowledge of plant extinctions and vulnerabilities is lagging. This study focuses on the Cape of South Africa, a global biodiversity hotspot, comparing Red List data for British and South African floras to demonstrate that taxonomic distribution of extinction risk differs between regions, inconsistent with a trait-based model of extinction. A phylogenetic tree for the Cape reveals phylogenetic signal in the distribution of plant risks, but most threatened species cluster at the tips of the phylogeny, opposite to trends in mammals. Analyzing 11 exemplar clades, mode of speciation explains the phylogen structure of extinction risks in plants of the Cape. Results show that extinction risk is higher for young and fast-evolving plant lineages, not explained by correlations with simple traits, and most vulnerable species are marching towards extinction at a rapid pace, independently from anthropogenic effects. This has implications for conservation and casts doubt on the utility of Red List criteria for regions with rapid speciation, aiming to preserve the tree-of-life.
Researchers have identified two new proteins, Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase (TK) and Vav, that contribute to the immune system's ability to engulf and destroy the fungal pathogen Candida albicans. This process, called phagocytosis, is crucial to prevent infection. The proteins interact with the major phagytic receptor Dectin-1, which plays a key role in anti-fungal immunity. TK and Vav are recruited to phagytic cups containing C. alb yeast or hyphae, but are absent from mature phagosomes. They localize to regions surrounding the hye, while Dect-1 lines the length of the phosome. TK and V colocalize with lipid (3,4,5)P3 and F-act at the phytic cup, but not diacylglycerol (DAG) which marks mature phagomal membranes. Using a TK inhibitor, researchers show TK contributes to DAG synthesis at the phytic cup and subsequent recruitment of PK. TK or V-deficient peritoneal macrophages display defect in C. alb phocytosis. Bone-derived macrophages lacking TK or V1 show reduced C. alb uptake, comparable to Dect1-deficient cells. TK or V-deficient mice are more susceptible to systemic C infection than wild-type mice.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a vector-borne disease that affects ruminants and humans. Madagascar was heavily affected by RV in 2008-2009, with a large spread of the disease. To optimize resources for RV surveillance in Madagascar, identifying at-risk environments is essential. This study aimed to identify factors favorable to RV transmission in cattle and humans and human behaviors in Malag contexts. We characterized Malag environments using Multiple Factor Analysis (FA) and analyzed cattle and human serological data using Generalized Mixed Models. Cattle and human seroprevalence were associated with humid environments and high cattle density. Areas with high cattle density were at risk. Frequent contact with raw milk contributed to human infection. Our study highlighted eastern, western, and northwestern parts as high-risk for RV transmission in cattle. Analyzing environmental and human datasets brought new insight on RV transmission patterns in Madagascar. Association between serreval, humid, and cattle density suggests conitant and direct transmissions critical to RV enotic transmission. In at-risk environments, western, northwestern, and eastern areas, suitable Cx and Anophe mosquitoes transmission occurs in cattle and human.
Researchers studied how a type of protein called a prion, which is a self-propagating protein conformation, is transmitted between identical and non-identical proteins. They used a yeast-based system to explore the nature of transmission barriers between prions. Prion Rq, a common in wild and laboratory yeast, has a prion domain with four Q-rich regions. The study found that Rq has multiple prion determinants that can drive amyloid formation in vitro and transmit the prion state in vivo. Analysis of transmission between Rq fragments with different pr determinants showed that one Q-rich region is required and sufficient for transmission, but barriers of different strength exist despite identical sequences. This indicates that multiple prion determinants act cooperatively to attain the pr conformation and transmission is determined by this fold.
Researchers have developed a new method to analyze genetic data from multiple individuals using a technique called deep learning, a type of machine learning. This method uses multiple layers of neural networks to learn from input data, such as summary statistics, and output genetic parameters of interest. They applied this method to a challenging problem of inferring natural selection and population size history in Drosila melanogaster, a type of fruit fly. The method can separate selection from demography, or population size change, without needing to do them step by step. This is important because selection can confound demographic analysis. They applied the method to 197 Drosilaogaster genomes from Zambia and found many regions of the genome have experienced strong selection, soft, or balancing selection. Soft and balancing selection occur more often near the center of chromosomes. Demographic inference suggests previous bottlenecks for Dilaogaster were too extreme. This work shows the potential of deep learning for population analysis, which is still in its infancy. It can distinguish between informative and uninformative statistics. Deep learning has been used in other fields like neuroscience and biology, but not genetics. It can accommodate complex models and provide a new approach to likelihood-free inference. It can be used with other methods like ABC or SVM. Other approaches are possible and it's unclear which will be most accurate.
High-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) oncogenes disrupt the Fanconi anemia (FA) DNA repair pathway by impairing localization and deubiquination of FANCD2. Persistent expression of high-risk HPV oncogen is necessary for the development of anal and oropharyngeal cancers. Researchers found that E6/E7-expressing cells are hypersensitive to DNA-damaging agent cisplatin and have defects in repairing interstrand crosslinks (ICL). The study reveals how E/E7 attenuates the FA DNA repair pathway. E7 activates the pathway by increasing FAN2 monoubiquination and foci, but inhibits completion of repair by multiple mechanisms. E7 impairs FAN2 localization with double-strand breaks (DSB), hindering recruitment of downstream protein Rad51 to DS in E cells. Further, E expression delays F2 deubiquination, an important for ICL repair. Delayed F2 deubination is associated with chromatin retention of F2, hindering US1 deubiquinating activity and persistently activated ATR/CHK-1/p565F signaling. Emediated p53 degradation does not hamper cell cycle process F2 modifications but abrogates repair by disrupting F deubination. E reduces and foci formation of Pal2, a repair protein downstream F2.
Researchers in Mexico's Southern Chiapas region have made significant progress in reducing the transmission of Onchocerca volulus, a parasitic worm that causes river blindness and skin disease. Since 1998, 559 communities in the area have received semi-annual treatment with ivermectin, a medication that kills the parasite. In 50 of these communities, the treatment frequency was increased to four times a year in 2003, and 113 more communities were added to the quarterly regimen in 2009. To assess the impact, researchers collected black flies and tested them for the parasite DNA. None of the 67,924 flies collected in 2011 had the parasite, indicating an infection rate of less than 0.06 per 1,000 flies. Blood tests on 4,230 children under 5 years old showed only 2 were exposed to the parasite, a rate of 0.05%. These results meet the criteria for interrupting transmission set by the World Health Organization.
Listeria monocytogen is a type of bacteria that invades mammalian cells and escapes from membrane-bound vacuoles to replicate in the host cytos. To grow and spread to adjacent cells, it uses a transcription activator called PrA. However, the signal that triggers PrA activation was unknown. Researchers found that L monocytogen secretes a small peptide pherone, pA, which helps the bacteria escape from vacoles and may activate PrA. The pA pherone is made by cutting a protein called PAlipop, which is not needed for pathogenesis. Without pA, bacteria are less virulent in mice and less likely to escape vacoles of non-phagocytic cells. Mutating PrA restores virulence and eliminates pA need. The pA peptide may signal monocogen its presence in the vacole, turning on genes for escape and PrA to grow in the cytos.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Vibrio cholera, which causes cholera, adapts to the hostile environment of the human intestines during infection. They found that Vibrio cholera uses a strategy to overcome the high levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by the host cells. The scientists used a technique called whole-genome transposon sequencing (T-seq) to identify the genes involved in this process. They compared Vibrio cholera's ability to colonize the intestines of mice with and without the antioxidant N-acetyl cystine, which reduces ROS levels. The results showed that mutants of the methyl-directed repair system, such as MutS, had an advantage in untreated, ROS-rich mice but not in N-treated mice. Further analysis suggested that accumulation of catalase-producing mutants and rugose variants in N- mice was the cause of Mut mutant enrichment by oxidative stress during infection. Rugose variants could revert to smooth colonies in vitro. The mutation rate of wildtype colonized in N- mice was higher than in N+ mice. These findings support a paradigm that Vibrio employs a temporal strategy to battle ROS during infection, resulting in enriched phenotypes.
Researchers studied the role of the Mlh3 protein in baker's yeast, a type of fungus, in meiotic recombination and DNA repair. Meiotic recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between chromosomes during reproduction. Mlh-M3 is an enzyme that helps resolve Holliday junctions, a type of recombination intermediate, into crossovers. It also plays a minor role in mismatch repair, fixing errors in DNA. To understand how Mlh-M3 works in both meiotic recombination and repair, scientists analyzed 60 new Mlh alleles. Five disrupted mismatch repair, one disrupted meiotic crossover. They purified and characterized Mlh-M representatives from each class. Both displayed wild-type endonuc activities in vitro. M2sh, a protein that acts with M-M in repair, stimulated enduc activity of M-M but not M, suggesting M is defective in interactions. Whole-genome recombination maps were constructed for wild-type, mismatch, crossover, mismatch, enduc defective, and null M mutants. Compared to wild-type, all M mutants showed increases in non-crossover events, consistent with recombination intermediates being resolved through alternative pathways.
When antibiotics are used to treat diseases like tuberculosis, malaria, and Staphylococcus aureus, or gonorrhea, the bacteria can quickly become resistant to the medication. This leads to a switch to new drugs and discontinuing the old ones, but resistance often persists or declines slowly. Researchers thought this was due to the low fitness cost of resistance in the bacteria. However, a new study shows that the structure of the host population, specifically the number of contacts, also plays a role in reversion dynamics. During treatment, host structure leads to non-random distribution of resistant bacteria among the population, and after treatment stops, it affects competition, reducing fitness advantages. This results in lower reversion rate and probability on the population level after treatment is stopped. Simulations show the impact of heterogeneity in host structure is largest in biologically plausible range when fitness costs are small.

The study confirms contact heterogeneity lowers reversion to sensitivity even when a fraction of bacteria is sensitive when treatment is stopped. Large differences between sensitive and resistant strains cause non-trivial distribution of infections over the network, influencing reversion once treatment is stopped. Since costs are small for many pathogen-drug combinations, the relevant range is where effects are expected to be largest. Fitness variance affects reversion probability and shifts closer to 1 with system size. During treatment, resistant infections increase while sensitive decline. Once resistant has risen to a level, treatment is stopped and dynamics are governed by wild-type and resistant in absence. Modulating host structure on reversion is strongest in relevant when differences are small. This allows studying resistance emergence and competition between strains after treatment.
Researchers studied how genetic variations in the human genome, known as copy number variants (CNVs), contribute to autism spectrum disorders (ASD). They used fruit flies, Drosophila, as a model to examine interactions between genes affected by CNVs in individuals with autism. They found that pairs of genes, affected by the same CNV, interacted synergistically, meaning their combined effect was greater than the sum of their individual effects. This was observed in three out of four CNVs with complete ortholog relationships. The study supports the idea that multiple genes, not just one, contribute to autism. The researchers used Dophila to model the effects of gene changes on neurological phenotypes, like those seen in autism. They focused on genes from CNVs identified in patients, whose products participate in autism networks and neural functioning. Many CNVs affect genes in the same pathway, and 33% affect multiple interacting genes in that pathway, suggesting combined copy change causes autistic phenotypes. Autism is highly heritable, but only 30% of cases have identified genetic cause, suggesting many rare and numerous alleles. Large numbers of autistic individuals with family members have de novo CNVs.
Researchers have long known that a type of immune cell called CD8 T cells plays a key role in the development of a severe form of malaria called cerebral malaria. However, they didn't understand how these cells contribute to the disease. To investigate, scientists used a technique called intravital two-photon microscopy to observe CD8 cells in the brains of mice infected with two different types of malaria parasites. They found that these cells accumulated in the spaces around blood vessels in the brain, but behaved differently depending on the type of parasite. In one type, Plasmodium berghei AN, CD8 cells formed long-term interactions with other cells that present antigens, but blocking this interaction didn't prevent the disease. The cells were also found near dying brain cells, but this didn't cause damage to the blood vessels. The study suggests that CD8 cells getting stuck in these spaces is a sign of severe malaria and important for its development.
A study was conducted in Viga County, Kenya to determine the burden of Tungis, a parasitic disease caused by the sand flea Tunga, also known as jigger. The study involved 437 participants aged 5 and above from 21 villages in 3 sublocations. The overall prevalence of Tungis was 21.5% (95% CI 17.7-25.3%). The disease was more common in areas with low economic status, such as monthly income of Ksh 100 or less, no toilet facilities, and age 14 or less. Wearing closed footwear and resting inside the house also increased the risk of Tis. Tungis is a significant problem in Viga due to the economic status of the affected people. Factors contributing to the disease include poverty. The study suggests the need for cost-effective and accessible strategies to control Tungis.
Researchers have developed a new model to understand how two hormones, auxin and cytokinin, work together to shape the root of a plant, Arabidopsis. Auxin is a hormone that helps roots grow and develop, while cytokinin is involved in cell growth and division. The two hormones interact in a feedback loop, where auxin affects cytokinin and cytokinin affects auxin. The model shows that a pattern of cytokinin levels is not necessary for correct auxin patterning, but rather how auxin modifies cytokinin response. This allows the feedback loop to amplify and stabilize auxin. The study also found that auxin influx, not just efflux, is important for patterning and that pericycle cells on opposite xylem poles compete for auxin, which is why lateral roots are not initiated opposite each other. The model is an extension of previous work on longitudinal auxin transport and considers regulation of transporters under control of aux and cytokinin. It reveals a novel role for aux influx and connection between subcell polarity and tissue robustness. The findings will help construct three-dimensional models of aux transport and growth in Arabidopsis.
Researchers have discovered a key player in the migratory locust's ability to change its behavior in response to its environment. The protein CRE-B acts as a mediator in the NPF/NO signaling pathway, which regulates the locust's locomotor activity between solitary and gregarious phases. CRE-B directly activates the expression of the NOS gene by interacting with its promoter region. Phosphorylation of CRE-B changes in response to population density and is controlled by N2. The involvement of CRE-B in N2-regulated locomotor plasticity is confirmed by RNA experiment and behavioral assay. Protein kinase A transmits the effects of N2 on CRE-B phosphorylation and N transcription. The study reveals a precise cascade underlying environment-induced behavioral plasticity.
Researchers studied the role of the protein Zelda (Z) in the early development of Drosophila melanogaster embryos. Zelda is a protein that helps turn on the expression of certain genes. The team used a technique called chromatin immunoprecipitation with high-through sequencing (IP-Seq) to see where Zelda binds in the embryo at different stages. They found that Zelda binds to thousands of regions in the embryo even before the zygotic genome is active. Most of these regions stay bound until the zyg genome is active. They expected Zelda to bind to promoters and enhancers of genes that are expressed early, but also found it binds to promoters of genes that are not expressed until the zyg genome is active. This suggests Zelda plays a role in activating the zyg genome at the maternal-to-zyotic transition (MZ). The team found that Zelda alone can identify active promoters and regulatory sequences with high specificity and selectivity. This means Zelda is not only needed for early transcription but also plays a role in activating the zyg genome at the MZ.
Scientists have long known that proteins interact with each other to carry out biological processes, but the timing of these interactions is crucial for proper function. The body's internal clock, or circadian rhythm, regulates many physiological processes, but the timing of protein interactions on this scale is not well understood. Researchers identified 109 new interactions between circadian proteins using a two-hybrid approach. One interaction, between phosphatase 1 and CLOCK/BMAL, led to BM1 destabilization. A dynamic circadian protein network was created using circadian data to predict protein timing. Systematic analysis of RNA and overexpression suggested crucial roles for components in interactions. Analysis of a global network in liver showed interacting proteins are expressed at similar times, likely restricting interactions to specific phases. Circadian proteins connect many processes, such as signaling and cell cycle, contributing to temporal organization in a new way.

A previous studies have analyzed protein interactions at specific stages or phases, but this study provides a comprehensive view of circadian dynamics. Modulators of CLOCK/BMAL function were found, indicating phosphatase 1's role in BM1 regulation. The network was expanded with validated interactions from literature, some essential for circadian dynamics. Timing of expression, protein interactions, and post-translational modifications are essential for circadian rhythms. The study focused on CLOCK and BM1, central to the circadian network, whose modulation by proteins is relevant for rhythms. Examples demonstrate timed interactions' importance for the clock, but the network is not comprehensive. The extent of regulation via time-dependent interactions is largely unknown.
Scientists have solved the structure of a protein called ABA-1 from the nematode Ascaris, a parasite that infects humans. This protein, called a nematode polyallergen (NPA), is unusual because it binds to lipids and is found only in nematodes. It's made up of many copies of a small protein unit that are identical or very similar in amino acid sequence. ABA-1 is the most common unit of NPA in Ascar and is similar to another parasite that infects humans, Ascaris lumicoid. Immune responses to NPA are linked to resistance to infection and are controlled by genes. The structure of ABA-1 was determined using a technique called nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. It has a unique fold with a long helix in the middle and two helical bundles on sides. Two distinct lipid-binding pockets are found in the ends, and amino acids that bind fatty acid were identified. Recombinant A-1 has a tightly bound ligand from bacteria in one site. This is the first processed unit of a repetitive protein to be structurally characterized and belongs to a new class. NPA have no counterparts in vertebrates, making them targets for drug or immunological intervention.
Ciguater poisoning is a serious health issue in tropical regions, particularly in Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PITCs). Between 1998 and 2008, there were 39,677 reported cases of cigu poisoning, with an average of 194 cases per 100,000 people per year. This is a 60% increase from the 104 cases per 100,000 reported between 1973 and 1983. Estimated 500,000 Pacific islanders may have suffered from cig poisoning in the last 35 years, making it a major public health concern. Cigu poisoning is often underdiagnosed and underreported, with only 2-10% of cases reported to health authorities.

Cigu poisoning is caused by eating fish contaminated with cigatoxin, a toxin from dinoflagates and cyanobacteria. The toxin builds up in the food chain, from herbivorous fish to carnivorous fish. Symptoms include severe neurologic, gastrointestinal, and cardiac issues, and in some cases, chronic neuro symptoms lasting weeks to months. Diagnosis is difficult as it can only be detected in specialized labs and is based on symptoms after eating contaminated fish.

Factors associated with cig poisoning include the presence of cigato dinlagates, climate change, coastal degradation, and exploitation of marine resources. The incidence is predicted to increase due to these factors, making it a human and ecological concern.
Researchers studied the impact of benznazole treatment on a specific type of immune cells called CD4CD+8 T cells in patients with Chagas disease, a parasitic infection caused by Trypanosoma cruzi. These cells play a key role in fighting off the parasite, but are impaired in chronic disease. Thirty-eight patients with Chagas, 20 asymptomatic and 18 symptomatic, and 12 healthy donors were studied. Blood cells were stimulated with parasite antigens to analyze cytokine and cytotoxic molecule production before and after treatment. Benznazole reduced CD4CD+ T cells and improved their function, increasing IL-2 and TN-α production. Inhibitory receptors on these cells were higher in Chagas patients, especially in severe cases. Treatment reduced these receptors and improved multifunctional capacity. CD+8 T cells produced effector molecules to control parasite. Benazole partially reversed exhaustion caused by T cruz infection, improving CD4CD+ T response.
Researchers have identified a key enzyme called Arabidopsis phosphoinide-specific phospholipase 2 (AtPLC2) that plays a crucial role in the breakdown of phosphoinides, a type of lipid involved in plant development and stress response. Phosphides are important signals that help plants grow and respond to their environment. However, multiple forms of the phosphide biosynthetic genes make it hard to understand which enzymes are involved in each step of the pathway and their roles in plant growth. The study found that AtC is the primary phospholase in phosphide metabolism and involved in seedling growth and endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress in Arabidopsis. Lipid profiling of multiple mutants showed that plc-1 had higher levels of its substrates phosphidylinositol 4-phosphate and phosphidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate, suggesting the phosphide metabolic pathway is impaired. At displayed a distinct expression pattern and localized at the plasma membrane in different cell types where phosphide signaling occurs. Seedlings of plc- showed growth defect that was complemented by heterologous expression At, suggesting phosphide-specific phospholase activity by At is required for growth. Moreover, plc- showed hypersensitive response to ER as evidenced by changes in phenotypes and gene profiles. The study revealed primary enzyme in phosphide metabolism, involvement in seedling and emerging link between phosphide and stress.
Researchers challenge the idea that causation in the world only occurs at the microscopic level, known as reductionism. They use a measure called intrinsic-effect power-integrated (Φ) to show that macro-level systems can have more causation power than their microscopic parts. This was tested on various systems of different sizes and time scales, considering all possible combinations of micro and macro elements. The study found that macro systems can have more inputs and outputs than their micro parts, revealing new mechanisms and constraints not seen at the microscopic level. This means macro systems can have more causation than their parts, especially when they are more interconnected. The researchers also found that for a given system, there can be multiple maxima of Φ across space and time. This was demonstrated on a biological system, the fission yeast cell cycle, where local maxima were found during its function. These max correspond to levels where emergent properties appear and provide a new perspective for scientific inquiry. The study uses intrinsic power as a measure of causation and shows examples of macro systems with more causation than micro. This refutes the idea that causation is only at the microscopic level. Evaluating macro systems across space and time shows there can be multiple maxima of causation, where integrated information decreases to zero. Local max capture emergent roles of macro elements, corresponding to system descriptions as NOR, OR, AND, or MAJ. The study assesses causation explicitly as intrinsic power and determines space-time levels where new properties emerge.
Scientists have studied how reactive oxygen species (ROS) are produced in the mitochondrial respiratory chain, which is crucial for energy production in cells.
