A low-mic affinity between NS C18 and nuclear receptor importin-alpha (Imp) was purified and visualized at 2.2 Å resolution using x-ray crystallography. Structure-guided mutational analysis revealed important residues for NS subcell localization. Notably, a proline 884 allows Imp binding, and mutating it to threonine in D1 NS results in mislocalization to cytoplasm without affecting virus fitness. In contrast, mutating arginine 888, conserved in all flaviviruses, to alanine results in non-viable virus, while R888 mutation leads to attenuated phenotype, though NS is in nucleus. R forms hydrogen bond with Y conserved in alliviruses. Data suggests conserved function C18, possibly in RNA interactions critical for replication, independent of subcell localization.
Researchers have developed a new method for mapping neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) that can be used by health ministries in endemic countries to determine when to start public health interventions. The Integrated Mapping (IT) Methodology combines data for lymphatic filariasis (LF), trachoma, schistosomiasis, and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) and is designed to be efficient and practical. It uses World Health Organization (WHO) recommended indicators for each disease in specific age groups. The study tested the protocol by comparing it to current mapping methods for each disease in one district in Mali and Senegal. Results showed IT reached the same conclusions as WHO for trach, LF, and STH, but more targeted recommendations for schosiasis. IT was practical and saved costs compared to standard, non-integrated WHO methods. This tool can help implement much-needed programs in endemic countries.
In the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the phosphatase C14 plays a crucial role in the exit from mitosis. It is anchored to the nucleolar chromatin by the C1/Net protein until anaphase, at which time it is released into the nucleoplasm. Two pathways, the FEAR (C fourteen early release network) and MEN (mitotic network), promote C14 release. Researchers found that histone H2 ubiquitination by the Bre1 ubiquitin ligase is necessary for C14 release from nucleolar chrom when MEN is inactivated. This is mediated by histone H3 methylation on lysines 4 and 79, but not histone deacetylase (HD) Sir2, which associates with C14 onolar chrom as part of the RENT complex. Defects in C14 release were also seen in cells lacking H3 lys 36 methylation and in cells with HD recruited by this modification. These histone modifications are new factors for the FEAR network to act on nucleolar chrom.
Researchers have developed a new computational method called GeneProgram to identify groups of genes that work together to perform specific functions in the human body. These groups, called programs, can be involved in normal processes or disease. The challenge in finding these programs is that human cells and tissues are different, and data is collected at different times and in different ways. GeneProgram uses a new approach to organize genes and tissues into groups that work together, and assigns a score to each group based on how often they work together. The method was tested on synthetic and real data and outperformed other methods. It was then applied to a large dataset of human gene expression data to see how cells respond to infections and immune molecules. Gene found 104 programs, many of which are involved in key pathways and signaling. It also discovered new pathways involved in response to infection, including Wnt and neurotransmitter receptors. The map of programs will help guide future experiments, genes with low scores may be new targets and genes with high scores may be common in disease states. The method is general and can be applied to other biological data.
Researchers have discovered that a specific type of immune cell, called NKGChi NK cells, plays a crucial role in fighting off a common virus called cytomegalovirus (CMV). These cells can remember past infections and respond quickly to future threats. Scientists found that NKGChi cells in people who have been infected with CMV have a specific epigenetic mark on the IFNG gene, which helps them produce a key protein called interferon-gamma (IF-γ). This mark is similar to what's seen in memory T cells that help fight off infections. The researchers showed that this mark is necessary for NChi cells to produce IF-γ when triggered by a specific receptors. This epigen mark is a hallmark of NChi cells that have been exposed to CMV and helps them remember past infections. It's not clear how often this happens in healthy people with CMV, but it's a key part of how NChi cells adapt to fight off the virus.
Researchers have discovered a new mechanism by which the bacterium Legionella pneumophila regulates its effectors within host cells. An effector proteins are molecules secreted by the bacterium to manipulate host cellular processes for infection. Temporal regulation of these effectors is crucial for distinct activities at different stages of infection. The study found a protein, Lub, an E3 ubiquitin ligase, hijacks the host proteome to target another effector, Sid, for degradation. Delayed delivery of Lub to the cytoplasm leads to shutdown of Sid in host cells at later stages. This shows a sophisticated co-evolution between host and bacterium involving an effector as a key regulator of cognate effector function. Lub acts as a negative regulator of Sid within host cells, the first example of an effector targeting a cognate eff within host. The study proposes the term "metaeffector" for this class of bacterial effectors. Determinants of susceptibility are encoded in effectors themselves. Lub controls Sid instability in host cytoplasm by targeting for ubiquination. Lub is a bona fide metaeff, regulating another eff function within host. Targets of bacterial E ligases are largely unknown, previous studies aimed at host proteins. Sid is first target of bacterial E ligase effector. Future studies will reveal bacterial effectors manipulating ubiquitin system functions as metaeff coordinating effector expression spatiemporally.
Researchers studied the early stages of HIV-1 infection in 81 individuals to understand how the virus evolves and adapts to its new host. They found that some parts of the virus's genetic code changed rapidly, more than expected, which could be due to the host's immune system trying to fight it off or the virus adapting to its new environment. The team identified 24 sites that changed quickly, 14 of which were in areas targeted by the immune system's T-cells or in specific to the host's genetic makeup. Some of these sites were also changed due to a process called APOB, which helps the virus escape the immune system. The study also found that insertions and deletions in the virus's genetic code were due to selection, not random mutations. This research provides insight into how HIV-1 evolves in new hosts and how the immune system and virus interact in early stages of infection.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to understand how epigenetic silencing works in yeast. They focused on two key chromatin marks, H4 acetylation and H3 methylation, and found that both are essential for stable epigen states. The model shows that having both modifications leads to a robust epigen silencing and a new state with both active and silenced marks under certain conditions. This bivalent state appears under perturbations and results in patchy silencing. The study also found that limited supply of silencing proteins can cause counterintuitive responses. The researchers investigated the design of the silencing system and compared it to experimental observations. They looked at the behavior of Sir protein, spreading of silenced regions in mutants, and the role of Dot1 in yeast silencing. The model can be extended to include other silencing and active marks and inform which are essential for epigen fate.
Researchers in Uganda studied the gut microbiota (GM) of children hospitalized with severe acute malnutrition (SAM) to see if it differed between those with edemat and non-edemat forms of the condition. Edemat malnutrition, also known as kwashiork, is the most severe form of SAM. The study included 87 children aged 6-24 months, with 62% having edemat malnutrition and 66% being boys with a mean age of 16.1 months. Fecal samples were taken at admission, DNA extracted, and analyzed using two methods: Denaturing Gradient Electrophoresis (DGGE) and high-throughput sequencing. Results showed GM composition differed between the two groups, with non-edemat children having lower diversity. However, beta diversity analysis did not reveal differences between edemat and non-ed SAM. The study suggests non-ed children have lower GM diversity, but no clear compositional differences were found. A link between GM and malnutrition has been reported, with pathogenic bacteria found in malnour children. Transplanting fecal samples from Malian twins with edemat malnutrition into germ-free mice showed a direct relationship. GM dysbiosis is associated with mal, but unknown if it differs between edemat and nonemat SAM. The study justifies further research on probiotics for SAM in developing countries, where mal remains a major problem, accounting for 12.6% of deaths in children under 5.
Researchers studied the variation in telomere length in 112 wild-type yeast isolates of Saccharomyces sensu stricto. They found extensive variation in telom length, with European strains having extremely short telomeres (<150bp) and American isolates having telom approximately three times longer (>400bp). Inserting a URA gene near telom allowed analysis of individual telom lengths and telomere effect (TPE). Crossing American and European strains resulted in F1 spores with a continuum of telom lengths consistent with multiple quantitative loci (QTL) involved in length. Variation in T is quantitative but weakly correlated with telom length. Genotyping F1 segregants indicated several QTL associated with telom length and silencing variation, including candidate genes and regions with no known telom properties. Transgressive segregation was detected for both phenotypes, validated by reciprocal hemizosity that YU and TLC are telom-length QTL in S paradox subpopulations. Sequence divergence within Kuod generates negative epistasis in allelic combinations (American-YU and European-YU) resulting in short telom.
Researchers have been trying to understand how people make decisions, but also when they decide to make them. Traditional models, called sequential sampling models (SMs), assume decisions come from a process that builds up over time, making response times (RTs) predictable. However, these models don't work when people are not forced to respond right away, but can take their time. A new study shows that people can choose to delay and stop the process, a scenario not accounted for by SMs. The researchers developed SMs using brain data from electroencephalography (EEG) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies, where participants bought or rejected stocks based on cues and could respond at any time. Standard SMs didn't fit the data well, but adding a mechanism for delaying decisions improved the fit. Time analysis of EEG data showed states of increasing and decreasing power in beta frequencies (14-30Hz), indicating responses were prepared and inhibited, supporting the idea of a decision to not decide. The model also explained results from a version of the study where participants pressed a button for more information. The study shows computational modeling supports understanding of hidden dynamics in cognition.
Researchers identified a genetic mutation in the SUVH2 gene as the cause of hereditary nasal parakerosis (HN) in Labrador Retrievers, a rare skin disorder causing crusts and fissures on the nasal planum. A genome-wide association study of 13 HN cases and 23 controls found a strong association on chromosome 2. Resequencing of one case's genome revealed 3 non-synonymous variants in the SUVH gene, with one perfectly associated with HN in a cohort of 500 dogs. The candidate variant is a missense in SUVH, a histone lysine 9 (H9) methyltransferase, mediating chromatin silencing. The variant c.972G>T changes a conserved asparagine to lysine in the catalytically active domain. Histopathological studies suggest HN is not due to hyperproliferation but delayed differentiation of kerocytes. SUVH is involved in epetic regulation of kerocyte differentiation, ensuring proper stratification and sealing of mammalian epidermis.
Researchers studied how the mixing of avian and swine influenza viruses in pigs can lead to the creation of new, potentially pandemic-causing strains. They found that when pigs are infected with both avian and swine flu viruses, genetic mixing occurs in the lower respiratory tract, and the type of virus that is shed is influenced by the type of cells in the pig's nose. The study showed that pigs can serve as a "mixing vessel" for creating new viruses that can be transmitted to humans. By housing pigs infected with both avian and swine viruses, the researchers found that many new viruses were created in the lower respiratory tract, but only a few were shed. The type of cells in the pig's nose helped select which virus was shed. The study suggests that tissue type is a key factor in selecting which virus is transmitted.
Researchers studied the effect of maternal Schistosoma mansoni infection and prazantel treatment during pregnancy on Schistoma mans infection and immune responsiveness among offspring at five years old. They found that offspring of infected mothers in schistosia-endemic areas may be sensitized in utero, which can influence their immune response to schistosome and schosiasis morbidity. However, the effect of prazant treatment of S mans during pregnancy on risk of S mans infection among offspring and their immune response when exposed to S is unknown. The study examined prazant treatment of S mans during pregnancy on prevalence of mans and immune among offspring at five years in a trial in Uganda. Offspring of treated or untreated mothers were examined for mans infection and cytokine and antibody responses to SW and SEA, as well as T cell expression FoxP at five. Of 134 children, 2.4% had mans at five based on single sample. Infection did not differ between treated or untreated. Cytokine IF, IL-5, IL-10 and IL-13 and antibody IgG, Ig4 IgE responses to SW and FoxP expression were higher among infected than uninfected. Prazant treatment S during pregnancy had no effect on responses, except IL-10 to SW which was higher in offspring of women received prazant than did not. No evidence found that S mans infection and treatment during pregnancy influence prevalence or intensity mans infection or immune response among offspring five, but IL-10 to SW suggest maternal mans and treatment may affect immunoreg responsiveness in schos.
Scientists have discovered a new way that the body's immune cells, called macrophages, can quickly get rid of harmful invaders like bacteria and viruses. Normally, macrophages use a process called phagocytosis to engulf and digest invaders, but this process is slow. Researchers found that when macrophages are activated by inflammation, they switch to a faster process called macinocytosis. This allows them to quickly transfer the invaders to lysosomes for destruction. The key to this switch is a protein called coronin 1, which is activated by a chemical signal when macroages are inflamed. When coron 1 is activated, it turns on an enzyme called PI-3-kinase, which helps with macinocytosis. Even without inflammation, a modified coron 1 protein can still trigger macinocytosis. This means macroages can get rid of invaders quickly, even when not inflamed.
Researchers conducted a study in Arua District, North Uganda to assess the acceptance of tset baits (insecticide-treated targets) in areas where they had not been used before. The study involved 16 focus group discussions with male and female participants in 8 villages across the district. Results showed that villagers who had never seen baits before expressed fear and anxiety, associating them with witchcraft and "ghosts from the river", which are linked to illness, death, and misfortune. In contrast, villagers in areas where ba had been used previously had positive attitudes and were aware of their purpose and benefits. They reported similar negative perceptions when tse control started a decade ago. The study suggests acceptance varies between villages and is related to duration with tse programs. Success of community-based interventions against tse will depend on engagement and sensitization that reaches all communities, especially new areas. 

The study is part of efforts to eliminate neglected diseases, including sleeping sickness (African trypanosomias or HAT) and develop cost-effective tse control methods. In West Uganda, new ba are being deployed over 500km. The area covers villages where tse control has not been conducted. Effectiveness of ba depends on acceptance by the community. 

In other areas, negative attitudes towards ba led to damage, vandalism, and operational failure. Community acceptance is vital for effective tse control. The study was in an area where ba have been used in government programs against H. Examples of community participation in tse ba range from encouraging to active construction, deployment, and maintenance. In all, acceptance was crucial for success. Three years before the study, 70 ba were deployed per parish, but efforts did not result in sustainable tse control.
Scientists have long known that recombination, a process that shuffles genetic material during reproduction, plays a crucial role in evolution. However, understanding its impact has been limited due to lack of detailed data on recombination rates across and within species. Researchers studied Drosophila melanogaster, a fruit fly species, to better understand recombination. They analyzed 5,860 meioses and genotyped 139 million SNPs, mapping 106,964 recombination events at 2-kilobase resolution. This allowed them to create whole-genome recombination maps and describe variation among individuals. Results show recombination rates vary greatly, with hotspots and coldspots on chromosomes. Gene conversion, a type of recombination, is more evenly distributed than crossing over, another type. At local level, recombination linked to sequence motifs and occur in transcript regions, suggesting chromatin structure affects breaks. These findings highlight need to be considered for accurate re rate estimates and population models of selection and linkage.
Researchers have identified a protein called ID2 (ID2) that plays a crucial role in a process called RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdM) in plants. They found that ID2 forms a complex with two other proteins, ID1 and ID2, which are similar to ID2 but have different functions. ID1 is needed for making new DNA methylation, RNA accumulation, and gene silencing, while ID2 has some of the same roles as ID1. ID and ID2 can't bind to double-stranded RNA, suggesting their roles are different from ID2 in the complex. The researchers also found that ID2's coiled domain helps it bind to itself, but not ID1 or ID2, and ID's X domain is needed for the complex to work. They tested ID2 with mutations and found that its X domain is essential for its function in RM and gene silencing. ID2 is similar to another protein, SGS, which helps silence genes after they're made. Both have zinc finger and coiled domains, but only ID's X domain is conserved. The study shows ID2 forms a complex with ID1 and ID2 for RM, which is needed for the process.
Exposure to Leishmania braziliensis triggers neutroph activation and apoptosis. Neutrophils, the first line of defense against invading pathogens, are rapidly recruited to the site of Leishmanial inoculation. During Leish braziliensis infection, depletion of neutrophils significantly increases the parasite load, whereas co-culture of neutils with L braziliensis has an opposite effect. The co-culture of infected macrophages and neutils induced parasite killing, leading to the question of how neutils respond to L brazili exposure. Here, we focused on the interaction between neutils and Lili, exploring activation and apoptotic fate. Inoculation of serum-opsonized Lili promastigotes mice neutroph accumulation in vivo, peaking at 24 hours. In vitro exposure of thioglyateelic inflammatory bone neutils to Lili modulated expression of surface molecules such as CD18 and CD62, and induced oxidative burst. Using mCh-expressing Lili, effects were mainly observed in infected and not bystander cells. Neutil activation with Lili was confirmed by release of TN-α and neutilase. Neutils with Lili displayed markers of early apoptosis. We show Lili induces neutroph recruitment in vivo and neutils exposed to the parasite in vitro through activation and release of inflammatory mediators. This may impact parasite elimination, particularly at early stages of infection.
Researchers explored the potential benefits of vaccination as a supplementary control measure for bovine tuberculosis (TB) in cattle. Currently, vaccination is not used in international control programs and is banned in the EU. Candidate vaccines, based on Mycobacterium bovis BCG, interfere with the tuberculin skin test, used to determine if herds and countries are TB-free. New diagnostic tests, Differentiated Infected from Vaccinated Animals (DIV), can introduce vaccination into existing eradication programs. Using herd models from Britain, they estimated the feasibility of supplemental vaccination. The economic impact of TB on farmers is dominated by testing costs and restrictions. Farmers will adopt vaccination if it reduces burden and restrictions. In Britain's testing sequence, the DIV test's specificity, not sensitivity, is the barrier to herd benefit. Relaxing testing could mitigate negative effects, but increase hidden infection in officially free herds. Models explored DIV characteristics for a protective benefit. A specificity of 99.85% and sensitivity >40% is required. Data from infected animals suggest a cocktail of three DIV antigens can achieve 99.85% specificity and 73.3% sensitivity relative to post-mortem detection.
Researchers have identified a new class of compounds called dihydrobenoxazepones that can kill the parasitic worm Trichis, which infects over 500 million people worldwide, causing growth and educational problems. Current treatments are limited and ineffective, so new options are needed. Using a mouse model of the parasite, they screened 480 small molecules and found dihydroazepoxones with anthelmint activity. Further screening and synthesis led to 20 active dihydroazepones, a new class not previously implicated in nematode control. The most active compounds killed adult Tris with an EC50 of 25-50μM, comparable to existing levamisole. They showed low toxicity to mouse gut cells, demonstrating selectivity for the parasite. Developing a treatment for a neglected disease is challenging, but dihydroazone O029 reduced embryon Tris eggs' ability to infect mice in vivo. This suggests an alternative strategy to develop a therapeutic that acts in the environment, interrupting the parasite lifecycle. The dihydroazones are a new anthint active against both egg and adult stages of Tris, showing selectivity and potential for further optimisation to improve potency and pharmacokinetics for a clinical agent.
Researchers have re-examined the concept of "date" and "party" hubs in protein-protein interaction networks, where "date" hubs have low expression with their partners and "party" hubs have high expression. They found that the importance of "date" hubs to network connectivity can be attributed to a small number of extremely central hubs that don't display low expression, contradicting the idea of a link between quantity and function. The "date/party distinction was motivated by a bimodal distribution of hub-expression, but this feature isn't robust to method changes. Topological properties don't correlate with expression, but centrality does with functional similarity of interacting proteins. They suggest thinking in terms of "date/p dichotomy is not meaningful, and it's more useful to consider roles of protein-protein interactions than individual.
Researchers have been using whole-genome sequencing to track the spread of infectious diseases, but a major limitation of this approach is that it requires genetic changes to occur over a short period of time to identify the source of an outbreak. To address this, the concept of "transmission" was introduced, defined as the number of mutations between two pathogen sequences from the same transmission event. Using data from the literature, simulations were run to estimate transmission for 10 major pathogens and found that it is generally low, with many pairs having identical sequences. This limited the ability to reconstruct outbreaks, especially for pathogens with low transmission like Streptococcus, Shigella, and Clostrid. In contrast, rapidly evolving pathogens like RNA viruses provided valuable information on individual transmission events. The study highlights the limitations of genetic data in certain scenarios and the need to expand tools to include other types of epidemiological data. Accurate transmission trees are not available for most pathogens, so a simulation approach was used to estimate transmission using parameters like genome length, mutation rate, and generation time. The limited diversity had a significant impact on reconstruction and identified transmission as a limiting factor for many pathogens. The diversity depends on genomic and epidemiological factors and can be quantified by transmission, defined as the number of mutations between pairs. This may be problematic for methods relying on phylogenetic trees and the impact on reconstruction remains to be investigated. The study introduced transmission as a measure of informativeness of WGS for reconstructing chains and estimated for 10 pathogens using a simulated approach.
Researchers studied how genes on the X chromosome that escape inactivation in female mammals, a process that silences most genes on one of the two X chromosomes in females. They analyzed gene expression and chromatin structure of X-linked genes in mouse tissues and cells with different X inactivation patterns based on single nucleotide polymorphisms. They found a continuum between complete silencing and expression from the inactive X chromosome, with few genes escaping in most tissues but more in embryonic-kid-derived cells. Alle-specific RNA polymerase occupancy and DNase hypersensitivity at gene promoters correlated with escape levels, suggesting open chromatin structure. Alle-specific CTCF binding on the inactive X was denser in brain compared to embryonic cells, possibly due to compartmentalized structure and fewer escape genes. A minority of genes escaped X in tissue and cell-specific manner, indicating X and escape are tightly controlled in vivo. The probability of bi-allelic versus monoallelic expression was calculated using a new algorithm applicable to any gene. Surveys in human/mouse cells showed 8-15% consistently escape, 10-13 variable, and 10-20 between cell/individuals. Escape results in sexual dimorphisms and bi-alle expression is important for normal females. Mouse 3-7 genes may be exceptional compared to other mammals. Escape were distributed along the X, not influenced by distance from the X center, and play roles in regulation and are dosage-sensitive. Tissue-specific genes will help understanding sex differences.
Researchers have identified a new cystine protease enzyme in the Plasmod viv, a parasite that causes malaria, which affects hundreds of millions of people worldwide. This enzyme, called VX-4, has unique properties that allow it to break down different proteins in different environments within the cell. It is most active at acidic pH 5.5, where it breaks down a protein called Z-Arg-MCA, and at neutral pH 6.5-7.5, it breaks Z-Arg-MCA. VX-4 prefers positively charged amino acids at the first position and less specificity at third and fourth positions. Three amino acids in its pocket are different from similar enzymes VX-2 and VX-3. Replacing one of these amino acids abolishes activity at neutral pH. VX-4 is found in the food vacuoles and cytoplasm of the erythrocyte stage of P. viv. It breaks actin at neutral pH and P. viv plasmin 4 and hemoglobin at acidic pH. VX-4 has pH-dependent switching, allowing it to break different substrates in different environments. It might break hemoglobin in acidic food vacu, P viv plasmin at neutral or acidic, and cytoskeleton in erythrocyte.
Scientists have created a new model to better understand how a type of microbe called Clostridium ljungahli works. This microbe can turn many different substances into useful products, making it a good candidate for sustainable production of chemicals. However, scientists didn't know much about its biology and couldn't predict its behavior. The new model, called iL965ME, includes all major pathways for making proteins, amino acids, nucleotides, lipids, and vitamins, as well as RNA and protein synthesis. It's the first model of its kind for a Gram-positive bacterium and makes predictions more accurate. The model shows how protein and media composition affect metabolism and energy in this microbe. It also predicts overflow metabolism, which is useful for designing new products, like glycerol, a new product for Clostridium ljahli. The model also shows how changing metal availability affects secretion, opening up new ways to optimize fermentation and understand how the microbe uses carbon and proteins.

The model includes all major metabolic, amino, acid, nucleotide, lipid, and vitamin synthesis pathways, as well as RNA and protein synthesis necessary for reactions. It also includes cofactors and mechanisms for energy conservation. The model predicted secretion of acetate, ethanol, and glycer during carbon and metal availability, and how protein and media influence metabolic and energy in this microbe.
Researchers used a panel of human osteoblast cells to study the genetic control of transcript variation, similar to previous studies in lymphoblast cell lines. They found that osteoblast and lymphlast cells have distinct gene expression patterns, with some genes specific to each cell type. By analyzing genetic variants, they found that some transcript forms of genes in osteoblast are controlled by genetic variants, and these variants can be tissue-specific or not. The study also found that multiple transcript forms of a gene can be present in both tissues and genetic variants can affect the expression of one form over another, not just an all-or-nothing effect. Examining top genetic associations from a bone density study, they found overlap with their results. One gene, FAM118, was tested in additional studies and a new transcript variant was found. This approach to studying transcript variation in multiple tissues is useful for detecting genetic variation between cell types and identifying specific variants that may be important.
Scientists have discovered a new way to make yeast, called Saccharomyces eayan, use a type of sugar called maltotose. This sugar is important for brewing beer production, but Sacomy eayan can't normally use it. Researchers took a gene from another yeast, Saccharces cerevisiae, that can use maltose, and combined it with a gene from Sacomy eayan that can use maltose. This created a new gene that allows Sacomyayan to use maltose. They tested this new gene in a lab and found it worked. They also looked at the structure of the new gene and found it's similar to another gene from a different yeast that can use maltose. This suggests that the ability to use maltose may have evolved in a similar way in different yeasts.
Researchers have found a link between the severity of the flu and how much the virus has changed from previous strains. They used a new model to show that the more the virus has changed, the more deaths it causes. This helps them develop a way to quickly estimate how many deaths a new flu strain will cause. This is important for planning and preparing for flu outbreaks, as it can help balance public health and economic costs. The study used a simplified model to look at how the virus interacts with the body and found a direct link between how much the virus has changed and how many deaths it causes. They tested this method on the H1N1 flu virus and found it worked well. This method can be used to predict the impact of future H1N1 flu strains and with some changes for H2 and B viruses. The researchers used a simplified model to look at how the virus interacts with the body and found a direct link between how much the virus has changed and how many deaths it causes. They tested this method on H1 flu and found it worked.
Researchers have identified a protein from the Asian soybean fungus Phakora pachyri that suppresses the plant's immune system. This protein, called PEC23, is a small, cysteine-rich protein that is secreted by the fungus. It interacts with a soybean transcription factor called GmPL12, which is a negative regulator of the plant's immune response. When GPL12 is silenced, the plant becomes more resistant to the fungus. The study suggests that PEC23 is a virulence factor, meaning it helps the fungus infect the plant, and that it interacts with GPL12 to suppress the plant's immune response. The protein has a unique feature, a repeat of 10 cysteine motifs, which is also found in other rust fungi. This suggests that PEC23 may be part of a conserved protein platform that fungi use to manipulate the plant's immune system. The researchers tested PEC on soybeans with silenced G12 and P23, but found no change in disease symptoms, possibly due to redundancy of other fungal proteins. The study shows that G12 acts as an immune suppressor, ensuring plant growth without infection. The cystine motif is found in other rust species, indicating a possible conserved interaction.
Researchers have discovered that the EphA receptor, a protein on the surface of host cells, plays a crucial role in the invasion and replication of the bacterium Chlamydia trachatis. Chydia invades host cells and replicates inside a membrane-bound vacuole called an inclusion, where multiple host proteins are recruited to support its development. The researchers found that EphA activates the PI3 signaling pathway, necessary for efficient replication, by interacting with the bacterium's serovar L2 protein. Interfering with this interaction, downregulating EphA, or inhibiting its activity reduced infection. During replication, EphA accumulates around the inclusion and interacts with the PIK regulatory subunit to activate the PIK/Akt pathway. Overexpressing full-length EphA, but not a mutant lacking the cytoplasmic domain, enhanced PIK activation and infection. Despite depleting EphA from the surface, infection upregulates it through the ER pathway, keeping infected cells resistant to apoptosis. The study shows EphA is both an entry and intracellular signaling receptor for Chydia. Engagement of a surface receptor at the membrane is a new mechanism by which Chy subverts the host and induces resistance.
Researchers have long known that neurons have active channels in their dendrites, the branching parts of the cell that receive signals from other neurons. These channels allow dendrites to be excitable, meaning they can generate electrical impulses. However, the role of this excitability in dendritic computation has been unclear. A new study shows that the output of a model of an active dendritic tree is highly dependent on the rate of signals it receives, with a large dynamic range of over 50 decibels. This means it can amplify weak signals and saturate strong ones. The model also predicts that neurons with larger dendritic trees will have a larger dynamic range and blocking active conductances will decrease it. The researchers propose that dendrites amplify weak signals and saturate strong ones, solving the problem of sensitivity and saturation in signal processing. This is important for individual neurons, neural networks, sensory organs, and organisms. The study suggests that dendritic spikes are not just a result of excitability, but also a way to increase dynamic range. The neuron function is not a simple Hill-like curve, but a double-sigmoid, as seen in retinal ganglion cells.
Researchers studied how to improve the accuracy of models that infer gene regulation from time-series data. Current methods assume mRNA levels represent protein concentrations and changes in gene expression are solely due to transcription factors, neglecting other effects. They investigated this bias using a combination of experiments and models on the Fli-FlM module in E. coli. coli, measuring protein and physiological effects with kinetic models. Results show correcting these assumptions improves model quality, especially for systems with longer protein half-lives and varying expression machinery activity. A new approach is proposed for using time-series data to learn regulatory networks, demonstrated on Fli-FlM, highlighting global effects and regulation of Fli and FlM halfives for promoter dynamics. 

To address bias, they used constitutively-expressed genes, mathematical models, and procedures to reconstruct protein concentrations and integrate physiological effects. A reporter gene driven by a constitutive promoter was used to measure global effects, but model fit was only marginally improved. Concentrations of Fli and FlM were estimated from promoter activities and physiologically plausible halfives, providing a data set to test mRNA and protein influences on inference. They inferred regulatory and quantitative function of a Fli-dependent gene, not regulated by other factors, from reporter data. Estimating protein concentrations from promoter activities and physiological halfives improved inference of interactions and regulation. A model with Fli and FlM as regulators and expression activity was compatible with data.
Researchers studied the spatial and temporal distribution of Oligyomys fulcens, a rodent species that carries diseases, in the Agua region of Panama. They collected data from 2006 to 2009 and analyzed it using maps and statistical tests. The study area was 6.43 square kilometers and divided into four periods: dry season, rainy season, and two transition months. The population of O. fulcens varied across seasons and years, typically absent in late transition months and re-established in subsequent years. Spatial analysis showed that populations were around 300-600 meters apart, with sharp borders between suitable and unsuitable habitats. The species showed a changing pattern over time, with shifting hotspots of abundance. This was due to seasonality and human activities like agriculture. These factors define the occurrence, timing, and duration of rodent populations affected by humans, and possible human exposure.

The study found multi-annual dynamics of O. fulens populations, with seasonal and yearly heterogeneity in abundance and distribution. This variation in zoon reservoirs makes pathogen identification challenging. Results provide a spatio-temporal characterization of hotspots of rodent habitation and persistence. Populations are subject to fluctuations within and among years, and geographically restricted, even in their range. Suitable habitat change, but dynamics on the landscape is poorly understood. Rod-borne zoon are sensitive to population size, demographic, persistence, and changes in host distribution, determinants of pathogen establishment and transmission.
Researchers have developed a new method to understand how genetic changes in the influenza A (H3) virus affect its ability to evade the human immune system. This is crucial for creating effective vaccines. The method, called "antigenic tree," assigns weights to each change in the virus's surface protein to show how much it impacts its ability to evade the immune system. It was tested on data from 1968 to 2003 and found known and new sites that affect the virus's ability to evade the immune system. This method can be used for other viruses and systems where genetic and phenotypic data is available. 

The researchers applied this method to the major protein of the influenza A (3) virus over 35 years. Branches on the tree represent the impact of changes on the virus's ability to evade the immune. This method is faster and less expensive than lab experiments to determine the impact of changes. It was tested on data from 1968 to 200 and found areas of the tree that correspond to known changes in the virus's ability to evade the immune. This can be used to identify changes that need to be updated in vaccines. The method can be used for other viruses and systems with genetic and phenotypic data.
Researchers used a large-scale RNA interference (RNAi) screen to study how human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV16) infects cells. They found that a group of genes involved in cell division, or mitosis, are necessary for the virus to enter the cell's nucleus. Normally, the cell's nuclear envelope blocks the virus's DNA from entering, but during cell division, the envelope breaks down, allowing the virus to enter. The virus then attaches to the cell's DNA on the division plate. The study suggests that HPV needs the nuclear envelope to break down for its DNA to enter the cell's nucleus. This research highlights the power of RNA screens in studying virus-host interactions and provides a list of genes involved in HPV infection for future studies.
Black Sigat or black streak disease, caused by the Dothideomyc fungus Pseudocospora fiji (previously Mycoserella fiji), is a major threat to global banana production. The disease requires frequent fungicide applications, which increase economic and environmental costs, and lead to rapid evolution of fungicide-resistant strains. To combat this, two strains of P. fiji were sequenced and assembled with a new genetic map. The 74b genome of P. fiji is expanded by LTR transposons, making it largest in Doideomycetes. Electrophoretic karyotyping and molecular markers showed chromosome polymorphisms and genetic diversity. Genetic differentiation was detected using neutral markers, suggesting selection and limited gene flow. Frequencies of fungicide in fung-treated plantations were higher than untreated P. fiji populations. A homologue of Cladospor fulum Avr effector Pf4 was identified in P. fiji genome. Infiltration of Pf4 into leaves of resistant banana variety Calcut 4 resulted hypersensitive response, suggesting Cal 4 carries unknown gene recognizing Pf4. The P fiji genome will aid fung treatment and banana breeding programs.
Scientists have long believed that changes in the way genes are turned on and off play a key role in the evolution of species-specific traits. However, most studies focus on highly conserved sites and rely on comparing sequences between species. A new method uses a "birth-death" model to track changes in transcription factor binding sites without comparing sequences. This method was applied to six transcription factors in humans and mice and found that 58-79% of binding sites in humans are new since they diverged from mice. Over 15% of sites are unique to humans and are near genes related to specific pathways and have more genetic variations than older sites. This method can identify lineage-specific elements and help understand their role in gene regulation variation between species. Unlike other approaches, this method uses specific binding sites or their rate of creation along a lineage. For five of six factors, the produced the most significant prediction using this method. Previous methods rely on cross-species alignments which are often low quality, especially in non-coding regions. This method can determine lineage differences in evolutionary rates of a motif along a branch in the phylogeny. Results support that this method can identify lineage regulatory elements, a step towards understanding their role in gene regulation variation.
Researchers studied how light affects the circadian clock in zebraf fish, a vertebrate model that responds to light in most of its tissues. They found that light induces expression of certain genes, including clock genes, in zraf cells in vivo and vitro. However, the mechanism linking light to gene expression was unclear. To understand this, they focused on how light regulates the zraf period2 (per) gene. Using transgenic fish and stably transfected cell-based assays, they defined a Light Module (LRM) within the per promoter. The LRM is necessary and sufficient for light-driven gene expression and circadian regulation. Curiously, the LRM is conserved in vertebrate per genes, even in species lacking light-sensitive clocks. They also found that human LRM can substitute zraf LRM to confer light-regulated transcription in zraf cells. The LRM contains E and D-box elements, critical for its function. E-box directs circadian regulation by mediating BMAL/C activity, while D-box drives light expression. The zraf homolog of thyroid embryonic factor binds to L-box and transactivates expression. They showed t mRNA levels are light-inducible and knockdown of t attenuates light transcription from per promoter in vivo. Their results support a model where light-dependent crosstalk between E and D-box factors is central to per expression. This extends understanding of how light entrains the clock and regulates gene expression in vertebrates.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called coronin plays a crucial role in the motility of Plasmodium sporites, the highly motile forms of a rodent malaria-causing parasite transmitted by mosquitoes. These parasites need to migrate to penetrate tissue and enter host cells. Without coronin, the parasites show motility defects that impair colonization of the salivary glands but not migration in the skin, resulting in decreased transmission efficiency. The study found that extracellular ligands trigger intracellular calcium release followed by actin-dependent localization of coron to the rear of the gliding sporite, initiating motility. Mutational and imaging analysis suggest coron organizes actin filaments for motility. Using coronin-Cherry as a marker for actin filaments, protein A contributes to actin disassembly. Calcium and cAMP signaling regulate a switch from parasite motility to host invasion by influencing actin dynamics.
Researchers have identified a new mechanism of resistance to a key drug used to treat leishmaniasis, a disease caused by Leishmania parasites. The drug, amphotin B, is a crucial in reducing the global burden of this disease, but resistance to it is a growing concern. Four lines of Leish mexicana, a type of Leish parasite, were found to be resistant to amphotin. They had altered sterol synthesis and were more sensitive to another drug, pentidine. Genome sequencing showed a mutation in a sterol biosynthesis gene, ster C-desaturase, in one line. However, in three lines, RNA sequencing revealed loss of expression of ster C-methyltransferase (SMT), responsible for resistance and altered sterol synthesis. Loss of milteine transporter was also found in one line. MT is encoded by two genes, with different expression levels. Reduced expression was associated with loss of 3 untranslated region of dominant gene, due to structural variations at locus. Regions of homology between genes and presence of SIDER retrotranson elements promoted these variations. In one case, loss of MT was not associated with loss of virulence in macrophages in vivo.
Researchers investigated how attention and prediction interact to modulate information processing in the brain. They used electroencephalography (EEG) to record neural activity in humans performing a simple visual task. Participants either attended or ignored a stream of gratings with predictable, surprising, or unpredictable orientations. The study found that surprising stimuli evoked responses were encoded as the difference between predicted and observed features, and attention increased the encoding of this information in the brain. This supports a predictive coding theory that attention optimizes expectations by increasing the gain of prediction errors. The theory suggests attention should increase selectivity for mismatch information in response to surprising stimuli, which is called the "mismatch model". An alternative theory proposes attention modulates predictions, not errors, which are propagated through the hierarchy and modulated by attention. The study found a significant effect of attention on mismatch responses to surprising but not unpredictable stimuli, starting 150ms after onset and reaching significance at 350ms. This shows attention boosts prediction errors evoked by surprising stimuli, consistent with predictive theory. The study aimed to determine what type of information is modulated between attention and prediction. They used forward models to quantify selectivity for orientation and mismatch in responses to surprising and unpredictable stimuli in the oddball paradigm.
Trypanosoma brucei, a parasite found in sub-Saharan Africa, is divided into three sub-species: T. b. brucei, T. rhodesense, and T. gambense. T. b. brucei cannot infect humans due to sensitivity to trypanolytic factors (TLF) in human serum, while T. rhodense and T. gambense are resistant. T. gambense has two sub-groups that differ genetically and in human serum resistance phenotypes. Group 1 T. gambense has an invariant phenotype, while group 2 shows variable resistance. Previous research suggested group 1 T. gambense is resistant to TLF due to reduced uptake of TLF mediated by reduced expression of TLF receptor, the haptoglobin-hoglobin receptor (HbHR) gene. This study investigates if true for group 2 parasites. Isogenic and sensitive group 2 T. gambense were compared to T. bruce parasites. Both express HHR at similar levels and internalize fluorescent labeled TLF like T. bruce. Both resistant and sensitive group 2, as well as group 1 T gambense, internalize recombinant AP1, but only sensitive 2 are lysed. Data indicate group 1 T gambense avoiding TLF is resistant to main component AP1. Group 2 T gambense is innately resistant AP1, possibly same mechanism. However, group 2 Tense variably displays phenotype and does not correlate with HHR expression change. Differences in human resistance mechanisms between T gamb groups 1 and 2.
Researchers have found that DNA methylation of the HIV virus's 5' long terminal repeat (LTR) plays a role in controlling the virus's latency, or dormant state, in the body. This is a mechanism that helps the virus evade the immune system and antiretroviral drugs. However, the role of DNA methylation in HIV-1 latency has not been clear, unlike other factors like transcription and chromatin structure. The study used an in vitro model and patient samples to show that CpG methylation of the HIV-1 5LTR is an epigenetic restriction that prevents reactivation of latent HIV-1 and determines its stability. Methylation is a late event in latency establishment and not required for initial silencing. Latent reservoirs with unmethylated 5LTR are more easily reactivable. In patients without detectable viremia, HIV-1 promoters are hypermethyl and resistant to reactivation, while those with vire have hypomethyl 5LTR. Methylation does not confer complete resistance to reactivation with some drugs, but dense methylation is reactivated in absence of T cell activation. This has implications for strategies to eradicate HIV.
Researchers have created a comprehensive catalog of genetic variations in the fruit fly Drosoph melanogaster, including single nucleotide, multi-nucleotide, and structural variants. They used a new approach to identify over 3.6 million distinct variations, with more than 800,000 insertions, deletions, and complex variants up to 6,000 base pairs long. While single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) are more common, they found that other types of variations are not more likely to cause mutations. Instead, the high density of SNPs is due to population-level processes. The study also looked at how genetic variations affect gene expression in adult flies by mapping over 2,000 genes. Insertions and deletions make up 10% of these variations and have larger effects than SNPs. They found more associations in males than females and that most variations are specific to each sex, showing a difference in genetic architecture between sexes and importance of factors mediating sex-based expression. Additionally, they analyzed gene expression in offspring of sequenced lines and found that most variations can be seen in heterozygous individuals. This study expands the catalog of variations in Dophila and shows high density of polymorphisms compared to humans and mice.
Researchers investigated how the relationship between the amplitude of the rectified electromyogram (EMG) signal and the neural drive to the muscle. The rectified EMG is commonly used to estimate the neural drive to muscles, but its accuracy can be distorted by the overlap of motor unit potentials, known as amplitude cancellation. The study used analytical and computational models to analyze the impact of cancellation on the correlation between the rectified EM and neural drive. The results showed that the ideal rectified EM without cancellation (EMnc) is a better estimator of the neural drive than the actual rectified EM. Simulations confirmed this, with a strong correlation between the neural and EMnc at low cancellation levels (less than 40%) and low contraction (less than 5% of maximum voluntary force). However, this correlation decreased with increasing cancellation (r=-0.83) at high levels (more than 60%) and contraction (more than 15%). The study also found that stronger neural drive resulted in a stronger correlation between rectified EM and neural, but cancellation mainly distorted low-frequency components (less than 5 Hz) of the neural drive. The findings indicate that amplitude distorts the rectified EM signal, making it less reliable as an estimator of neural drive, especially at high contraction levels or weak synaptic input to motor neurons.
Scientists have discovered a key player in how plants respond to aluminum stress: a protein called YCCA. When plants are exposed to aluminum, YCCA regulates the production of a hormone called auxin in the root tip of the plant. This hormone is responsible for slowing down root growth. Researchers found that YCCA upregulates certain genes that produce auxin, leading to its accumulation in the root tip and growth inhibition during stress. This process is dependent on another hormone called ethylene, which is involved in plant growth and development. Disrupting ethylene signaling either enhanced or reduced YCCA expression in the root tip in response to stress. Inhibiting ethylene also alleviated root growth under stress in plants lacking YCCA or treated with a chemical that blocks Y activity. Another protein, EIN3, is involved in regulating Y9 transcription in this process. PIF4, a protein, acts as a transcription activator for Y5 and 8, promoting root growth inhibition by regulating auxin in the root tip. Al-induced P4 expression in the tip acts downstream of ethylene signaling. The study reveals a cascade of Y-regulated auxin biosynthesis in the root tip mediating growth in response to stress.
Researchers have found that certain peptides from the simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) can suppress the activity of natural killer (NK) cells in primates by binding to a major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecule, Mam-A*002, on the surface of infected cells. This interaction stabilizes the binding of Mamu-K3DL05, an inhibitory receptor on NK cells, preventing them from killing the infected cells. Twenty-eight out of seventy-five SIV peptides bound to Mam-A002 suppressed the cytolytic activity of Mam-K3+ NK cells, including three immunodominant CD8 T cell epitopes. Substitutions at the C-terminal end of inhibitory peptides changed them into disinhibitory, and vice versa, without altering binding to Mam002. The effects of these variants on NK cell responses corresponded to their effects on Mam002 tetramer binding Mam-K05. In mixtures of inhibitory and disinitory peptides, low concentrations of inhibitory dominated to suppress cell responses. Consistent with inhibition of Mam-K cells by epitopes presented Mam002, SIV replication was higher in Mam002 CD+ lymphocytes co-cultured with Mam-K NK than Mam-K cells.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Haemophilus influenzae, a common cause of ear infections, adapts to changing environments. They found that when nutrients are scarce, the bacteria evolve to survive and thrive. This adaptation helps them colonize and persist in the body. In a study, they looked at how the bacterium's response to nutrient limitation and found a mutation that reduced its ability to break down a molecule called cyclic adenosine monophosphate. In a model of ear infection, this mutation led to less fluid buildup in the ear, a sign of disease resolution. However, the mutated bacteria formed more communities inside ear cells than the original strain, suggesting a reservoir for future infection. This is the first look at how Haemophilus influenza adapts to nutrient limitation and shows the presence of these communities in a model of chronic infection.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Burkholderia pseudalle, which causes melioidosis, interacts with its host's iron levels during infection. Iron is crucial for the bacterium's growth and the host's immune response. The study found that B. pseudalle downregulates the host's iron exporter ferroin, making more iron available to the bacterium. Supplementing iron with ferric ammonium citrate increased bacterial growth, while iron chelating with deferoxamine reduced it. Infected mice had lower ferroin expression, higher liver iron, and lower serum iron levels. Administering ferric ammonium citrate promoted bacterial growth and inflammation, while limiting iron availability improved clearance, reduced cytokines, and survival. The study suggests B. pseudalle modulates iron homeostasis to acquire iron and evade the host's immune response, promoting intracellular growth.
Researchers have developed a new technique called "functional mode analysis" to identify the specific movements in proteins that help them perform their biological functions. These movements are often involve many atoms working together, making it hard to pinpoint which ones are crucial. The new method uses a "functional quantity" that measures the protein's state and finds the movement most related to it. This quantity can be anything relevant to the protein's function, such as shape, charge, or chemical properties. It also estimates which motion is most likely to change the quantity. Two measures are used: the Pearson coefficient for linear correlation and mutual information for any kind of dependence. This helps create a model for the protein's function in terms of a single movement. The technique was tested on several proteins: polyalanine helix, T lysozyme, Trpase, and leucine-binding protein.
Researchers studied the order of intron removal from transcripts of the tubA and gap genes in Euglena gracilis, a type of single-celled organism. These genes contain two types of introns: conventional and nonconventional. Conventional introns are found in most eukaryotes, but nonconventional are unique to eugids and diplonids. Nonventional introns don't have the same borders or sequence as conventional introns and form a different secondary structure. The study found that noncon introns are removed before conventional introns. This suggests a gap between the two types of splicing processes. The study used PacBio Next Generation Sequencing to analyze intermediate products of splicing. Nonconventional introns insert at new positions, while conventional introns are conserved or lost. Only 100 nonconventional introns have been described so far, mostly in eugids. They form a stable structure with exon/intron junction, but not like self-splicing tRNA introns. Intermediate introns have features of both conventional and nonconventional introns. Few genes have been annotated, but confirmed on genomic level. A whole-genome survey of noncon intr is needed.
Researchers studied the effects of Coxsackievirus B (CV) infection on the development of the heart in young mice. CV is a common virus that causes mild fever in infants, but can lead to severe heart problems in some cases. The study looked at what happens when young mice are infected with a low dose of the virus and don't show symptoms, but then face stress as adults. They found that infected mice developed heart problems, such as thickening and dilation, which can lead to heart failure. The virus infected cells that help make new heart cells, called cardiac progenitor cells, were reduced in the hearts of infected mice. This means the heart may not be able to make new cells to adapt to stress. The virus infected these cells, but not the rest of the heart, and was cleared from the heart over time. The study suggests that a mild CV infection in young can lead to heart problems later in life.
Researchers studied how the bacterium Burkholderia pseudalle, which causes meloidosis, interacts with immune cells called macrophages. They found that the bacterium activates a protein called caspase-1 through a receptor called NLRC, but not NLR3, in the early stages of infection. Caspase-1 is involved in a process called pyptosis, where the cell breaks down and dies. Later in infection, casase-1 activation is independent of NLRC. The study identified a pathway involving casases-9 and PAR downstream of NLRC and casase-1. Without casase-1, macrophages undergo apoptosis, or programmed cell death, which is dependent on initiator and effector casases. The bacterium's flagellin and TSS3 protein play a role in casase-1 activation and pyptosis. Infection with a mutant bacterium lacking T3S3 showed reduced casase-1 activation, cell death, and IL-1 secretion. In mice infected with the mutant, mortality was lower, bacterial loads in organs, and IL-β, myeloperoxidase, and neutrophils in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid were reduced. The study suggests a major role of T3 in NLRC-mediated casase-1 activation and pypt and contribution of casase-dependent and independent cell death in Burkia pathogenesis.
Researchers studied the role of Arabidopsis Kβ, a subunit of the SNF1 protein complex, in pollen-stigma interactions during pollination. They found that Arabid Kβ is a cytoplasm and nucleus-localized protein in vegetative cells of pollen grains and is essential for pollen germination on the stigma. In Arabid Kβ mutants, pollen could not germinate on the stigma, but germinated normally in vitro. Further analysis revealed that hydration of mutant pollen on stigma was compromised, but adding water promoted germination in vivo, suggesting defective hydration led to germination. Mutant pollen had destroyed mitochondria and peroxomes and reduced numbers compared to wild type. Arabid Kβ mutants had reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) in pollen. Adding H2O2 in vitro compensated reduced ROS levels, and overexpressing Arabid CATAL 3 reduced hydration on stigma. These results indicate Arabid Kβ regulates ROS by mediating biogenesis of mitochond and peroxomes, required for pollen-stigma interactions during pollination.
In the bacterium Bacillus subtilis, the enzyme RNase III plays a crucial role in protecting the cell from the expression of toxin genes carried by two types of viruses called prophages, Skin and SP. This is done through a process called antisense RNA, where RNase cleaves double-stranded RNA. While many organisms use RNase or its homologs as part of a defense mechanism against viruses, Bacillus subtil requires RNase for survival, making its presence essential. Researchers found that two toxin-encoding mRNAs, txA and yT, from Skin and SP prophages are sensitive to RNase. They explored the mechanism of RNase-mediated decay of txA mRNA paired with its antisense RNA, both in the cell and in a lab dish. The study showed that RNase in Bacillus subtil is not related to its function in RNA metabolism or ribosome maturation, but rather to degrading toxin-encoding mRNAs from viruses. In the absence of these viruses, the RNase gene can be deleted without affecting growth. The researchers also found that other enzymes involved in RNA maturation can function without RNase, and that RNase contributes little to stability of many antisense RNAs. RNase has been shown to be involved in bacterial defense against phages in other species and in eukaryotes, where it plays a role in RNA interference and microRNA generation.
Researchers have studied how the parasitic worm Brugia malayi, which causes Lymphatic Filariasis, releases tiny particles called extracellular vesicles (EVs) that contain proteins and RNA to manipulate the host's biology. They found that EVs are released by all stages of the worm's life cycle, from microfilar to adult, and are taken up by host cells in the same way, suggesting a uniform mechanism for delivering effectors. Proteins in EVs from adult male and female worms differ, revealing sex-specific characteristics. The drug ivermectin inhibits EV release from all worm stages, but not in a drug-resistant isolate, suggesting a potential mechanism for its action and new ways to develop anti-filar drugs.
A recent study in the Western Province of the Solomon Islands found that scabies and impigo are common skin conditions affecting many people, especially children. The study included 190 residents from 10 rural villages and found that 19.2% had scabies and 32.7% had impigo. Scabies was most common in infants under 1 year old and children 1-4 years old, while impigo was most common in children 1-4 years old. Scabies was associated with impigo, with 41% of imp cases also having scabies. The study suggests that controlling scabies could reduce the burden of both conditions and their complications.
Researchers have found a link between the number of new brain cells being created in the hippocampus and a type of immune cells called T cells in adult mice. The hippocampus is a part of the brain that helps with memory and learning. The study looked at 719 mice and found that the more T cells there were, the more new brain cells were being created. This was true even when the mice were not sick or injured. The researchers also found that the genetic makeup of the mice affected the number of T cells and new brain cells. They looked at mice without T cells and found that they had fewer new brain cells. This suggests that T cells play a role in creating new brain cells in the hippocampus. The study also found that genetic variation in mice affected the number of T cells and new brain cells. This means that some mice naturally have more T and new brain cells than others. The study looked at many mice and found that the link between T and new brain cells was stronger than other traits. The study suggests that T play a bigger role in creating new brain cells than thought.
Researchers have developed a vaccine, called TVac, to protect against Chagas disease, a major health problem in Latin America and emerging in the US. They identified potential vaccine candidates by analyzing the Trypanosoma cruzi database and tested TVac in a mouse model. The vaccine consisted of DNA and protein components and cytokines IL-12 and GMF. Mice were immunized with TVac and then infected with Trypanosoma cruzi parasites. TVac induced a strong antibody response and moderate lymphocyte proliferation in mice. Upon infection, TVac-vaccinated mice expanded antibodies and elicited a CD8 T cell response with type 1 cytokines, controlling parasite burden. In the chronic phase, antibody persisted and CD8 cells and type 1 cytokines subsided, while type 2 cytokines became dominant. TVac-vaccinated mice had undetectable parasitism, inflammation, and fibrosis in heart and skeletal muscle. In contrast, mice with vector or cytokines only had a mixed response and persistent parasite burden in myocardium. TVac-induced type 1 and lymphocyte responses provided resistance to acute infection and prevented chronic immunology. This is the first report of a vaccine reducing parasite below detection in chronic animals. TVac elicited a strong antibody response after challenge. The vaccine included antigens were conserved among strains and expressed in infective stages. Immunized mice had significant anti-parasitic responses. This vaccine is a promising approach.
Researchers used a machine-learning approach called Support Vector Machine (SVM) to assess the risk of developing type 1 diabetes (T1) based on genetic data from genome-wide association studies (GWAS). They tested this approach on three large datasets and found that it accurately predicted disease risk with an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.84. In contrast, using only a few known susceptibility loci resulted in poor performance. The study suggests that taking into account many genetic markers can improve disease assessment. The researchers used a dataset from the Wellcome Trust Case Control Consortium (WTCC) and the Genetics of Kidneys in Diabetes (GoD) consortium. They found that the VM algorithm worked well with hundreds of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) but not with just a few. This approach can be applied to other diseases where a significant risk has been captured by arrays. The study shows that genetic risk assessment may be feasible for complex diseases.
Researchers studied how memory CD8 T cells, a type of immune cell that helps fight infection, behave in the skin during a secondary infection. They found that these cells can enter the skin without needing to go through lymph nodes, which are like traffic hubs for immune cells, and provide protection against a virus called Vaccinia. This is different from naive CD8 cells, which need to go through nodes to fight infection. Memory CD8 cells become cytotoxic, meaning they kill infected cells, and then differentiate into CD69+ residents, which stay in the skin and help fight future infections. They also found that these cells use a protein called granzyme to kill infected cells. This study shows how memory CD8 cells work in the skin and how they can be used to make vaccines more effective.
Myosin VI, a type of motor protein, plays a crucial role in the distribution of proteins on the surface of axons in neurons. Axons and dendrites, the two main parts of a neuron, have distinct compositions and functions due to the way proteins are targeted to them. Myosin VI, a minus-directed motor, helps enrich proteins on the surface of axons by stimulating a process called endocytosis, where proteins are taken in from the dendrite membrane to the axon. In experiments, a protein was engineered to bind to Myos VI and was found on the surface of axons in mouse neurons, suggesting it could be used to study neuron function. Myos VI helps shape the distribution of proteins on axons and dendrites, necessary for proper electrical signaling.
Researchers have identified a gene called DmaD1 in the freshwater crustacean Daphnia magna that plays a key role in determining the sex of the organism. This gene is unusual because it is controlled by environmental factors rather than genetics, unlike most other sex-determining mechanisms. DmaD1 is similar to a gene found in insects, which are thought to be closely related to crustaceans. However, the way it is expressed is different. In insects, the gene is spliced differently in males and females, but in Dnia, the amount of transcripts is what differs. The gene is only expressed in males during development and is found in male structures. Disrupting the gene in males results in female traits, while adding it to females results in male-like traits. Another gene, Dma2, was also found but did not have a clear effect on sex. These findings show that Dma1 is crucial for male development and reveal how environmental sex is controlled by a conserved genetic component. This suggests an ancient link between genetic and environmental sex-determin.
A new vaccine against genital herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) is urgently needed to prevent pain and suffering, reduce the incidence of neonatal herpes, and decrease the risk of HIV transmission that accompanies genital infection. Researchers evaluated a trivalent HSV-2 subunit vaccine administered with CpG and alum in rhes macaques and guinea pigs. The vaccine contains glycoproteins C, D, and E (C, D, E) to block virus entry by D and immune evasion by C and E. In rhes macques, the trivalent vaccine induced plasma and mucosal neutralizing antibodies that block C and E immune activities and stimulated CD T cell responses. After vaginal challenge, self-limited infection of brief duration was detected by histology and immunohistochemistry in naïve, but not trivalent immunized macques. Vaccine efficacy was evaluated in guinea pigs. Animals were mock immunized or immunized with D, the trivalent or trivalent followed by booster D. The trivalent and tr groups were 97% and 99% efficacious in preventing lesions and outperformed D alone. As marker of transmission, vaginal swabs were evaluated for HSV-2 DNA and replication between five and seven weeks after. HSV-2 DNA was reduced in all compared with mock. Shedding of replication virus occurred fewer in tr than D immunized animals while tr D group had no shedding replication virus. Overall, trivalent had lesions <1% and shedding replication virus 0.2%. The vaccine has potential for prevention of herpes in humans.
Researchers have developed a new method called Perm-se to map protein-DNA interactions in highly repetitive regions of the genome. These regions are difficult to study because short DNA sequences from these areas can match multiple locations in the genome, leading to incorrect results. Perm-se uses data from other experiments like DNase-seq and histone ChIP-se to improve mapping accuracy. The method was tested on 64 ENCODE ChIP-se datasets and found many new protein-DNA interactions in segment duplications. These interactions are less conserved across species but share characteristics with non-repet regions. 

Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed sequencing (Ch-se) is a way to study protein binding and histone modifications. It generates millions of short DNA sequences. Mapping these to the genome is the first step in analysis. To study repetitive regions, a new method called Perm-se was created. It uses DNase-se and histone Ch-se data to find where reads come from. DNase-se shows open chromatin regions with transcription factors. Perm-se was tested on ENCODE Ch-se datasets and found many new protein-DNA targets in duplications. These interactions share characteristics with nonpet regions. A model was made to use DNase data to map reads in Perm-se. It's versatile and can use other data like histone Ch-se.
Schistosomiasis, a parasitic infection affecting over 218 million people worldwide, particularly in Africa, may increase the risk of HIV-1 acquisition and impair control of HIV-1 replication in those infected. Researchers conducted a nested case-control study in Tanzania to investigate the effects of schistosiasis on HIV-1 susceptibility and viral load at HIV-1 seroconversion. Approximately 40% of the population had Schistoma mans infection and 2% had S. haematium. The study found that women with schist infections had a higher odds of HIV-1 acquisition than those without, with an adjusted odds ratio of 2.8 (1.2-6.6, p=0.019). In contrast, sch-infected men did not have an increased odds of HIV-1 acquisition. The study also found that HIV-1 RNA levels in post-serconversion blood of HIV-1 serconverters with schosias were significantly higher than those without schias, with a median of 4.4 (3.9-4.6) log copies/mL versus 3.7 (3.2-4.3, p=0.017). The study confirms that pre-existing schist infection increases HIV-1 susceptibility in women and raises viral load at HIV-1 serconversion.
Ribosomal DNA (rDNA) is a highly variable region in the human genome, with varying copy number and sequence. Despite its importance for cellular function, little is known about its stability and regulation in mammalian genomes due to analysis challenges. Researchers used computational and droplet digital PCR to measure rDNA in normal and cancer states in human and mouse genomes. They found that number and sequence can change in cancer. Counterintuitively, human cancer genomes show loss of copies, accompanied by global number variation. The sequence is also more variable in cancer genomes. Genomes with lower copies have mutational evidence of mTOR activity. The PTEN phosphatase is a tumor suppressor critical for genome stability and negative regulator of mTOR pathway. Surprisingly, consistent with human genomes, hematopoietic cancer cells from PTEN-/- mouse model leukemia have lower rDNA number than normal, despite increased RNA and protein production. Loss occurs early and is associated with hypersensitivity to damage. Loss is a feature in cancers with m activation. rDNA number may be a simple indicator of cancer sensitivity to DNA treatments.

Researchers used a mouse model for PTEN/- leukemia to assess rDNA in hematopoietic stem cells. Surprisingly, rDNA number is reduced in genomes with m activation, providing that number can be altered naturally. They also found co-occurring number of additional genes and single nucleotide variation in repeats. Number can be estimated from whole-genome and dro digital PCR. The plethora of genome projects allows comparison between number in tumor and normal from individual. They used these to analyze rDNA changes in different and cancer. In summary, rDNA number and sequence change in cancer, with m activity associated contractions and damage. This comes possibility to target loci. Cells with low number may be sensitive DNA agents.
Researchers have developed a new approach to study how bacteria spread and grow inside the body during an infection. They used special strains of Salmonella, a type of bacteria, that are genetically identical but can be distinguished with a test. This allowed them to track the bacteria in different parts of the body and understand how they interact with the immune system. The study found that after infection starts, some bacteria die and multiply quickly, creating separate groups in different organs, controlled by the body's defenses. Later, more bacteria survive and spread to other parts of the body through the blood, with some dying off in the process. This new method provides a detailed look at how Salmonella infections work, showing complex and random events drive the disease. It can be applied to other host-bacteria combinations, giving a complete view of inside dynamics.
Researchers have been trying to figure out how our brains process 3D motion from what we see with two eyes, but existing ideas don't fully solve the problem. A new approach combines velocity, binocular disparity, and other cues to better understand 3D motion. In the "aperture problem", two strategies emerge: (1) preferring slow motion in 3D and (2) cyclopean based on slow 2D motion. Predicting ambiguous motion helps distinguish between these strategies.
