Light and temperature drive different sets of genes, but mostly not the same ones. A gene that helps sense temperature and light is needed for circadian rhythms to work. This study shows C. elegans has a circadian clock and can be used to learn more about its evolution and function.
Scientists have studied a type of yeast called Saccharomyces cerevisae to understand how DNA repair and recombination work. They looked at a gene called RAD3, which is similar to a human gene called XPD. Some versions of RAD3 have problems with DNA repair and cause a lot of recombination. Previous studies showed that this was because of single-stranded DNA gaps that turn into breaks during replication. The researchers used a new method to see the products of recombination and found that RAD3 versions have 100 times more crossovers. They mapped these events and found that 3/4 are breaks in both sister chromatids and 1/4 in single chromatids. This is similar to normal recombination in healthy cells. They looked at 216 changes in the genome, including crosso, conversions, deletions, and duplications and found that some are near areas with a lot of recombination. They also found a hotspot for deletions and duplications near the end of a chromosome. This suggests that some normal recombination in healthy cells might be from incomplete repair and breaks that can't be fixed by sister recombination.
Helicobacter pylori, a gastric pathogen, has a set of simple sequence repeats (SSR) that generate heterogeneous populations through slipped mispairing, allowing adaptation to the changing host environment. Researchers found that an intergenic tract, via slipped mispair, operates like a rheostat to fine-tune expression of the sialic acid adhesin, SabA. They used isogenic strains with varying tract length to show that it affects Sab promoter output, altering H. pylori binding to sial-Lewis receptors on gastric mucosa. Analysis of post-infection clones revealed variable tract length in H. pylori, mirroring host-pathogen interplay where best-fit phenotypes are selected. In silico and in vitro analyzes showed tract length affects DNA structure and RNA polymerase binding, shifting alignment between promoter and UP elements. Additional H. pyl genes with similar tracts show variations modulate cognate output. The study proposes a mechanism mediated by promoter-prox SSR for transcription regulation in bacteria with limited transacting factors.
High-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) must evade the immune system to establish persistent infections and amplify its genome upon cell differentiation. Researchers have found that a protein called STAT-5, part of the JAK/STAT family, plays a key role in this process. STAT-5 is usually involved in regulating the immune response to cytokines and growth factors, but in the case of HPV, it promotes viral replication. The virus activates STAT-5 without changing its overall levels. Inhibiting STAT-5 with a drug called pimide blocks viral genome amplification and late gene expression in differentiating cells, but has no effect on undifferentiated cells that stably maintain the virus. Studies show that a specific version of STAT-5, called STAT-β, is responsible for this activity and it works through the ATM damage response pathway. A protein called peroxisomeator-activated receptor (PARγ) also contributes to this effect. These findings reveal a new mechanism by which the immune regulator STAT-5 promotes viral replication through the DNA damage response.
Researchers in Nepal identified 13 antigens from Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi that are unique to chronic carriers of the bacteria in the biliary tract. These antigens are proteins, lipoproteins, and hemolysin-related proteins that are not found in healthy individuals from a typhoid endemic area. One antigen, YE (ST147), an uncharacterized protein with an ATP-binding motif, showed a strong response in patients with S Typhi in their biliary tract compared to those without. The researchers used an immunoscreen technique called in vivo-induced antigen technology (IVAT) to identify these antigens, which are expressed in the body but not in lab-grown bacteria. The study aimed to understand host-pathogen interactions in the biliary of chronic carriers and develop a diagnostic to identify asymptomatic S Typhi carriers. The identified antigens were found in 70% of chronic carriers, 0% of bile-negative controls, 0 of healthy, and 12.5% with acute tyoid. Further evaluation of these and other antigens could lead to improved diagnostic and therapeutic approaches for S Ty carriage.
Scientists have discovered a new way that genes can be turned back on after being silenced. They found that non-working copies of a gene called "white" can reactivate a working copy of the same gene that's been turned off by a process called heterochromatin. This new phenomenon is called transactivation and relies on the presence of similar RNA molecules from the same gene. It's different from other ways genes are turned on or off, like paramutation, transduction, and transvection. In transactivation, non-working genes that don't make a full protein can still influence the working copy of the same gene that's turned off by heterochatin. The researchers found that non-working white genes increase the amount of another gene called wmh and change the structure of the gene's location. This new way of turning on genes is heritable, meaning it's passed on, and relies on the presence of similar RNA. It's also affected by genes that control how genes are turned off after they're made.
Researchers have discovered a protein called Boophil in the midgut of a tick that helps the tick avoid the host's blood clotting system. Boophil is a multifunctional inhibitor that targets several enzymes involved in clotting and complement cascades, including thrombin, elastase, and kallikrein. The study found that Boophil behaves as a classical non-competitive inhibitor of thrombin, blocking platelet aggregation, fibrin formation, and clot formation in vitro. It also inhibits FXa, preventing activation and kikrein activity, indicating it targets the contact pathway. Additionally, Boophil abates cathepsin G and plmin-induced platelet aggregation and affects elastase cleavage of Tissue Pathway Inhibitor (TFI). In vivo, Boophil inhibits carot artery occlusion and promotes bleeding in mice. This suggests Boophil plays a key role in keeping the midut environment low in clotting and inflammatory response, allowing ticks to digest blood for metabolism and egg development. Boophil is the first midut FXa inhibitor found to also inhibit thrombosis.
Researchers have created a computer model called the Spatially Explicit Model of Enteric Tissue (SEMT) to study how inflammation affects the lining of the intestines. This lining, called the mucosa, is crucial for absorbing nutrients and protecting the body from harm. Its structure and function are closely linked, and changes in its architecture can lead to various diseases. Inflammation is a key factor in many gastrointestinal diseases and affects how the mucosa's structure. To understand its role, the researchers developed SEMT to simulate how enteric epithelial cells behave under different conditions, from healthy to diseased. SEMT reproduces healthy mucosal dynamics and various experiments, revealing mechanisms like the role of PTEN/PIK in inflammation and enterocyte slough in ischemia-reper and colonic metaplas. SEMT can be a platform for studying inflammation in gastrointestinal diseases.
Researchers studied the effectiveness of Wolbachia, a bacterium that reduces arbovirus transmission, in Aedes aegypt mosquitoes in Brazil. Traditional control methods like insecticide spraying didn't work well. Wolia was released in a community in Rio de Janeiro for 20 weeks, but only 40% of mosquitoes were infected after 7 weeks and 65% after 19 weeks. However, when releases stopped, 97% of mosquitoes transmitted Wolia to their offspring. Releasing more mosquitoes with longer wings and lower mortality didn't affect invasion. Investigating lab procedures, pyre resistance in Wol decreased from 68 to 3.5% after 17 generations. Initially, released mosquitoes were resistant to pyreoids due to household use of insecticides, jeopardizing Wolia invasion. A new strain, wRio, was created by crossing WolBr with field males to introduce pyre resistance. It increased survival but negatively affected mosquito traits, reducing egg size and hatch. Despite this, wRio established where Br failed, showing matching local genetics, especially pyre resistance, is key to invasion. Local support was high, 90%, and temperature didn't affect Wol expression on Brazilian background. Wolia should match insecticide profile of wild population to invade.
Researchers studied how the vaccinia virus, a type of poxvirus, uses a complex signaling pathway to evade the host's defense mechanisms and replicate properly. They found that the B protein kinase plays a crucial role in in inactivating the antiviral factor B, and likely orchestrates other pathways as well. By deleting the B gene in the virus, they observed a significant increase in viral titer after several passages. Characterization of the adapted viruses revealed mutations correlating with loss of function of the vaccinia B pseudokinase provided a fitness enhancement to the virus. This suggests that losing the gene can be beneficial for the virus. The study also found that expressing full-length B leads to a reduction in fitness in viruses with a defect in B, but no impact on wild-type or mutant viruses. This indicates that B possesses inhibitory activity masked by the presence of B kinase. Further investigation showed that B localizes to the nucleus, a rare characteristic among poxiral proteins. Surprisingly, B phosphorylation is reduced when B is present in cells without B, suggesting B may enhance antiral activity of B. The study presents novel evidence that a paralog kinase-pseudase pair can exhibit epist relationship in virus, serving to enhance conservation during pox evolution and orchestrate events during infection.
Researchers studied the behavior of two synthetic peptides, LKKKLLKKLL (L) and EAAEAAEAAE (E), with built-in alpha-helix secondary structure, in water and at macroscopic interfaces. These peptides are too short to form stable structures on their own, so their conformation is influenced by environment. Simulations showed they don't form random coils or full alpha-helices, but adopt multiple conformations with short lifetimes. Conformation changes with environment, like pH, salt, or presence of interfaces. At macroscopic interfaces, peptides adopt alphael conformation due to hydrophobic/hydrophobic partitioning. Their response to interfaces depends on surface charge and hydrophobicity.
Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) is a common virus that infects humans in the first years of life and stays in the body for life. It can integrate its genome into the ends of host chromosomes in infected cells, but how it does so is unclear. Interestingly, HH-6 and other similar viruses have sequences at the ends of their genomes that are similar to human chromosome ends. Researchers deleted these sequences in HH-6 and found that they are not necessary for virus replication, but crucial for staying in infected cells. They created a system to test integration and found that without these sequences, the virus is lost quickly. They also found that one sequence is more important than the other for integration. This study shows that HH-6 sequences help the virus stay in infected cells by integrating into chromosome ends. This is a new way the virus maintains itself in the body.
Researchers have discovered the 3D structure of a key protein called D13 from the vaccinia virus, a type of poxvirus. This protein forms a double-barrel shape with two jellyroll domains and a head domain. It assembles into trimers similar to those found in adenoviruses and other icosahedral viruses. When attached to artificial membranes, D13 creates a honeycomb-like structure similar to the virus's immature particles. This suggests that poxviruses use an ancient lipid-remodeling strategy similar to other icosahedral viruses. The protein D13 is essential for the first step of poxvirus formation, as it can create immature particles without other viral factors. Neutralizing D13 with rifampic or mutations stops viral assembly. The study reveals that poxviruses use a common strategy with other icosahedral viruses, and D13 is a target for developing pox inhibitors.
Researchers studied how a plant hormone called auxin affects root growth in a type of grass called Brachyp distyon. Auxin is important for root development in other plants like Arabidopsis, but its role in Brachypton is unclear. They found a mutant with reduced tryptophanminotransferase activity, an enzyme needed for auxin production, but surprisingly had longer roots. This is opposite of what happens in Arabidopsis, where reduced tryophminotransferase leads to shorter roots. The mutant also had elevated auxin levels, not lower as expected. This doesn't seem to be due to alternative auxin production pathways, but increased expression of genes that convert indole-3-pyruvic acid to auxin. Ethylene, another hormone, seems to be involved in this process. Treating the mutant with ethylene precursor 1-aminyclopropane-1-carboxlic acid reduced auxin levels and root growth. Downstream ethylene signaling component, ethylene insensitive 2-like 1, also had increased aux levels. This suggests ethylene inhibits the rate-limiting step of auxin biosynthesis, making aux levels suboptimal for root elongation. The study reveals a delicate balance between auxin and ethylene to control cell elongation in Brach roots, different from Arabidopsis.
Researchers studied how genes in yeast species evolve at different rates and found a link between gene expression and nucleosome organization. Genes without a nucleosome-free region, called OP, vary widely between species, while those with a nucleosome region, DPN, remain similar. They tested if early evolution affects this difference by selecting for high expression of a protein and found both OP and DPN genes increased equally. However, they adapted differently: DPN duplicated regions, while OP favored mutations. When selection stopped, DPN returned to normal, but OP didn't. This suggests organization constrains early evolution and biases long-term path. In yeast, gene divergence is linked to nucleosome organization, connecting evolution with regulation. Genes that diverged quickly lack a nucleosome near start, while DPN remained conserved. When selection stopped, DPN returned to normal, but OP didn't. Results show organization impacts early dynamics and long-term evolution. To test if OP and DPN differ in responding to selection, they selected high expression and examined genomic response. Dozens of proteins increased, regardless of class. They chose 41 proteins with mid-to-high levels, no preference for function or position. Genes were DPN and OP, quantified by nucleosome occupancy. Alternatively, DPN and OP may respond similarly to selection, but easily satisfied by OP due to flexible structure. This supports flexible organization directs evolution's path.
Researchers have found that a protein called Tax, produced by the human T-cell leukemia virus HTLV-1, can cause cells to become senescent. Senescence is a state where cells stop growing and dividing, which can be a protective against cancer. However, Tax also activates a protein called NF-κB, which is involved in cell growth and survival. The study shows that NFκ activation by Tax leads to senesc, and that this is a checkpoint to prevent cancer. The protein p21 and p27, which cause senesc, are upregulated by Tax, and act independently of p53 and pR. Tax also stabilizes p27 by activating the an enzyme called APC, which brings about degradation of Skp and inactivation of SCF. The mRNA of another protein, p21, also increases due to Tax activation and stabilization. The surge in p and p27 leads to p53 and pR-independent senescence, called Tax-induced senescence. The study shows that p and p-mediated senesc induced by Tax is a response to chronic NF-κ hyperactivation. NFκ is constitutively active in many cancers, especially leukemia, and data suggest that changes disabling this pathway accompany NF-κ deregulation in cancers. Impairments of p and p function have been observed in most HT-1-transformed cells. Constitutive IK activation and NFκ hyperactivation cause Tax-induced senescence, and Rel is the major driver of senesc. NFκ acts upstream of APC to stabilize p. Loss of Sk has been shown to facilitate p p p-mediated and Arf-independent senesc in SkpAr-null mice. Induction of p by Tax is due to both promoter activation and stabilization.
Researchers have long understood that the frontal lobe plays a crucial role in decision-making and executive control, guiding goal-directed behaviors. However, current models don't fully explain decision-making in uncertain, changing, and open-ended situations. A new computational model of executive function is proposed to clarify this issue. Experiments show the model predicts human decisions and variations across individuals in natural situations. The model reveals the frontal function monitors up to four behavioral strategies and infers their ability to predict outcomes, choosing the most reliable one to guide action and maximize rewards. If unreliable, a new strategy is formed from stored memory, probed, and confirmed to drive action. The executive has a limited capacity for four strategies, compensated by a binary control structure promoting exploration and new strategies in ambiguous situations. Results support a model integrating reasoning, learning, and creativity in decision-making behavior. 

A key issue is understanding how the executive controls creating new strategies and managing an expanding collection for action. A computational model is proposed controlling creation, learning, storage, and selection of strategies. The PRO model suggests regulating exploration and creativity in adaptive behavior. Results support a model integrating reasoning, learning, and creative in executive control. The model creates an expanding repertoire of flexible strategies in uncertain, changing environments. The frontal function manages task representations in long memory for action. According to reinforcement learning, the actor is adjusted to maximize utility. How do we manage an expanding strategies and create new rather than adjusting or switching, possibly according to cues? Little is known about the executive continuously between adjusting, staying, switching, and creating sets for action.
Researchers have developed a new approach called Analysis of Dynamic Adaptations Parameter Trajectories (ADAPT) to study the long-term effects of pharmacological treatments on diseases. This method uses mathematical modeling to predict how molecular adaptations change over time in response to a treatment. A concept of time-dependent parameters is introduced to describe the dynamics of these changes, making use of experimental data from different stages of the treatment. This approach provides insight into the underlying biological systems and identifies areas to study further to understand treatment outcomes. ADAPT was used to investigate the effects of activating the liver receptor LXR, a potential target for treating atherosclerosis. Unexpectedly, it found that activating LXR reduced the liver's ability to clear cholesterol, despite promoting cholesterol efflux and excretion. This was confirmed by measuring SR1 levels in liver membranes. AD can also identify potential side effects and design new interventions to prevent them.
Researchers have proposed a new hypothesis on how the spinal cord and cerebellum work together to coordinate body movements. They suggest that sensory and motor signals are combined in neurons of the spinal cord's spinocerebell pathways. This allows the cerebellum to approximate spatial and temporal relationships between body parts, necessary for coordination. However, the number of granule cells limits the number of combinations that can be represented. Instead, the spinal cord provides useful combinations, described as linear projections in a multi-dimensional space. Granule cells, with the help of Golgi cells, enhance these projections, allowing Purkinje cells to approximate non-linear functions. This new view shows how the cerebellum's functions are supported by spinal recombinations. 

The spinocbell system avoids superfluous combinations by combining signals in individual neurons. This allows "good" combinations to be formed with high probability. The spinal circuit makes sensorimotor functions available to the cerebell through its projections. The cerebell granule receives this information. The spinocbell network's structure before the granule must be considered to understand how dimensionality can be lifted. A simplified example is controlling a double joint arm. The paper seeks to explain these observations in terms of spinal and cerebell circuitry, providing integration across dimensions for coordination. The cerebell is key for coordination, but little is known about its mechanisms.
Researchers used next-generation sequencing to study the regulation of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the Aedes aegypti mosquito during Chikungunya virus (CHV) infection. They identified 88 known and 79 miRNAs in uninfected and CHV infected mosquito cells, respectively, and nine novel miRNAs in the mosquito. The study found that CHV infection altered the expression of 77 miRNAs, specifically eight of which were upregulated. The researchers predicted the targets of these miRN and classified them into pathways. This study provides insight into the modification of miRN during CHV infection and identifies potential candidates for vector-based antiviral strategies.
Cysticercosis (CE) is a parasitic disease affecting humans and livestock worldwide, with significant medical and economic importance in many developing countries, including Iran. The study aimed to determine the economic burden of CE in Iran. Data on prevalence and incidence of CE in humans and animals were obtained from hospitals, literature, and government reports. Economic data on human and animal disease, including treatment costs, productivity, and livestock losses were from national and international datasets. Monte Carlo methods represented uncertainty in parameters. Estimated 1,295 surgical cases per year 2000-2009, and 635,232 asymptomatic individuals. Annual cost of CE in Iran was $232.3 million, including direct and indirect costs. Human cost was $93.3 million and livestock $132 million. Cost per case was $1,539. CE has considerable impact on Iran, 0.03% of country's gross product. Establishment of surveillance and control are necessary to reduce burden. Cost-benefit analysis of control is recommended incorporating losses due to CE in Iran.
Researchers have conducted a comprehensive analysis of mouse polyomavirus (MPV) infection in mouse cells to understand how the virus interacts with its host and affects gene expression. They used deep sequencing to follow MPV infection in NIH3T cells at various times and analyzed both viral and cellular transcriptomes. The study revealed a dynamic regulation of viral and host gene expression, including widespread RNA editing of viral transcripts late in infection. By 36 hours, 359 genes were upregulated and 857 downregulated. Gene ontology analysis showed changes in translation, metabolism, RNA processing, DNA methylation, and protein turnover were upregulated, while extracellular adhesion, cytoskeleton, zinc binding, SH domain, and GTP activation were downregulated. Noncoding RNAs were also altered, with MALAT1, a marker for late-stage cancer, downregulated and several others upregulated. The study provides new insights into MPV lifecycle and its effects on cell growth and metabolism.
Hundreds of thousands of runners attempt to complete a marathon each year, but many experience severe performance-limiting depletion of physiologic carbohydrate reserves, known as "hitting the wall," and drop out before reaching the finish. Analyses of endurance have suggested that glycogen reserves are insufficient to fuel a marathon, making "hitting the wall" inevitable, or that maximal glycogen loading is required to complete a marathon without "hitting the wall. However, a new study shows that energetic constraints on runners are more subtle and depend on physiologic variables, including muscle mass, liver glycogen, and running intensity. The study estimates the distance at which runners will exhaust glycogen as a function of intensity, providing a basis for ensuring safety and optimizing performance by setting paces and prescribing fuel requirements. The analysis sheds light on standards in marathon that have remained empirically defined, such as qualifying times for the Boston Marathon. Carbohydrate loading influences performance by permitting runners to run at greater speeds without "hitting the wall" due to exhaustion of glyc reserves. Typical levels allow runners to complete a marathon safely between four and five hours. The model incorporates running cost and dependence on exertion, revealing dependencies of distance to glyc depletion and pace.
Researchers studied how different strains of Toxoplas, a parasite that causes toxoplasmosis, interact with mouse immune cells called macrophages. They infected mouse macrophages with 29 different Tooplas strains from around the world and used a technique called RNA-sequencing to see what genes were turned on or off in both the parasite and the host. They found big differences in how the parasite and host interacted with each other. Some Tooplas strains turned on genes that helped them hide from the host's immune system, while others turned on genes that made the host's immune system attack them. They also found new ways that some Tooplas strains regulated the host's interferon response, a key part of the immune system that helps fight off infections. Some Toop strains even made the host cells produce interferon without help from other parts of the immune system. The study shows that different Tooplas strains have unique ways of interacting with host cells, which might explain why some strains cause more severe disease than others.
Researchers have investigated the process of recombination in enteroviruses, a mechanism that allows viruses to acquire new genetic material and contribute to diversity and emergence of new strains. They used a novel approach to isolate chimeric poliovirus genomes with duplicated sequences at the recombination site and found that progeny viruses with imprecise junctions had increased fitness. Mutations affecting polymerase or replication complexes altered recombination yield but not non-recombination, suggesting it's a replicative process. The study proposes a biphasic process: initial recombination followed by resolution of extraneous sequences to optimize fitness. This has implications for understanding evolution in positive-strand RNA viruses.
Researchers have discovered a new route for the body to clear a hormone called norepinephrine (NE) in fat cells, which plays a key role in burning fat and energy. This hormone is important for treating diseases such as obesity and diabetes. Previous studies found that NE is cleared by nerve cells or immune cells in fat tissue, but this process is not efficient. The researchers found that a protein called organic anion transporter 3 (Oct) is highly expressed in fat cells and takes up NE at a high rate, unlike other known routes. Fat cells also have enzymes to break down NE and reabsorb it with the help of Oct. When Oct is blocked, mice have higher body temperature and fat burning compared to normal mice. After cold exposure, fat in Oct-deficient mice have more "brown" fat, a type of fat that burns energy, and express more genes for energy production. This involves a signaling pathway in fat cells. Genes for glucose production are increased to compensate for lack of energy in Oct-deficient mice. Blocking this pathway in Oct-deficient mice abolishes fat burning and energy production. Reduced Oct in humans is linked to higher metabolic rate. The study shows Oct governs NE in fat cells, offering potential for treating metabolic disorders.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called HP1 plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression by interacting with a specific region of histone H3, a protein that makes up chromatin. This region, called the globular domain, is partially hidden inside the nucleosome, a structure that wraps chromatin around. HP1 also interacts with the SWI/SNF complex, a protein that remodels chromatin. The interaction between HP and SW/SNF is antagonistic, meaning they work against each other. In some cases, SWNF acts as a repressor, opening chrom to allow HP to bind, while in others, SWNF acts as activator and HP binds to methylated histone tails. HP uses its chromadow domain to bind to the glob domain of histone H, which is also contacted by SWNF subunits Brg and Brm. This interaction allows HP to detect and block chrom remodeling by SWNF. The study suggests HP benefits from chrom opening to bind and uses this property to prevent unwanted chrom remodeling.
Researchers have discovered a property called "self-containment" in RNA molecules, which refers to their ability to maintain a specific structure regardless of their surrounding sequence context. They developed a method to measure this property, called the self-containment index, and found that microRNAs (miRNAs) exhibit high self-containment, consistent with their need for structural invariance during biogenesis. Most other structured RNAs do not show this property. Analysis revealed a trend towards higher self-containment in conserved miRNAs, suggesting it may be a characteristic of miRN acquiring new genomic contexts. miRNAs display enhanced self-containment compared to other functional RNAs, and a trend towards selection for self-containment in functional classes. The study suggests self-containment arises from selection for robustness against perturbations, invariance during biogenesis, and modular composition of function. Containment analysis is important for RNA annotation and design.
Researchers have identified four transcription factors (TFs) in Arabidopsis that play a crucial role in limiting the spread of necrotrophic fungal pathogens, such as Botrytis cinerea and Plectphaella cucina. Mutants defective in any of these TFs showed increased susceptibility to these pathogens, indicating their importance in disease resistance. Transcriptome analysis revealed a common signature of 77 up-regulated genes in the mutants, including several encoding secreted peptides named PROIR (provirulence factors). Overexpression of PROIR in Arabid increased susceptibility to necrot P cucina, while loss-of-function mutants increased resistance, suggesting their role in fungal pathogenesis. The TF and PROIR identified are novel determinants of plant susceptibility to necrophic fungal pathogens.
Researchers have found that a protein called Forkhead Box 1 (FOX1) plays a crucial role in making the uterus ready for a fertilized eggs to implant. The uterus needs to be in a specific state to allow the egg to attach and grow. If it's not, women may have trouble getting pregnant or carrying a pregnancy to term. Scientists studied mice without FOX1 in the uterus and found they couldn't get pregnant. This was because the cells in the uterus were not working right and the egg couldn't get in. They looked at what was happening in the uterus and found changes in how genes that help the egg attach and grow. They also found that a hormone called progesterone, which helps the uterus get ready, was working differently. Progester was stuck in the cells of the uterus when it should have been in the egg. When progesterone was in the cells, FOX1 was not working. This happened in mice and human uterus too. This means FOX1 and progesterone work together to make the uterus ready for egg to implant.
Researchers developed a statistical model to map the spread of deng cases in Bangladesh, a disease that is often underreported. They used data from 2000 to 2009 and found that temperature and its interaction with daily temperature range, two months prior, were linked to deng incidence. Rainfall, two months prior, was also linked to deng. Densely populated districts and those bordering India or Myanmar had higher incidence. The model estimated that 92% of deng cases occurred between August and September. Cases were reported across the country, with 94 in Dhaka, the capital, located in the middle. Less than half of districts reported cases were from surveillance data. The proportion varied by month, with higher in high-incidence districts, but dropped towards the end of transmission.
Researchers have discovered a new type of preferred places that mice visit in an open environments, called "knots". These places are characterized by high tortuous paths with twists and turns, and are often visited sporadically during a session. Mice perform a behavior called "knot-scribling" while in these places, which involves tracing a winding path with twists and turns. Knots are distinct from "home" places, where mice spend most of their time, and are typically located near the point of entry into the arena. Mice tend to leave knots shortly after being placed there, but return to them sporadically throughout the session. Injecting mice with saline and placing them in an exposed area enhances the establishment of knots, suggesting that stress and arousal create a long-term association between a locale and knot-scribling. In an environment without cues, mice mark a locale with twisting and turning, creating a self-generated landmark. Knot-scribling may help mice obtain an overview of the environment, recalibrate their map and compass, and improve interpretation of the scene through vestibular input.
Researchers have identified a potential new target for antifungal compounds in a protein called Sec14, which is essential for the growth and virulence of the fungal pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans. They found that the compound NG04, an ergoline, inhibits the growth of C. neoans and related compounds have even higher potency against it. NG04 also showed fungicidal activity against a fluconazole-resistant C. neoans strain. Sec14 is involved in lipid transfer and virulence in pathogenic fungi, making it an attractive target. The researchers used high-resolution chemogenomics to identify Sec14 as the target of NG04 and found mutations in Sec14 define compound interactions in the binding pocket of the protein. They also showed that NG04 inhibits growth of two clinical isolates of C. neoans and NG04-related compounds have equal and even higher potency against C. neoans. The study suggests NG04 as a novel antif starting point.
Researchers have found that the antimal drug mefloquine shows promising antischosomal properties in mice. This means it can help treat schistosomiasis, a disease that affects millions of people worldwide and is often linked to poverty. The current treatment, prazantel, may not be effective long-term due to parasite resistance, so new compounds are needed. Mefloquine reduced worm burdens by 72-100% in mice infected with adult Schistoma mansoni and S japonicum. It also worked on young stages of the worms in the mice. Both forms of meflo reduced worm burdens in mice with subpatent or patent infections. This is promising for developing a new schistosomal drug based on aminoal functionality. Further studies are needed to understand how meflo works and its effects on other parasites. It's interesting that meflo, used to treat malaria, may also help with schosias in areas where both diseases coexist.
A study was conducted in Cameroon to map the distribution of podoiosis, a non-filar elephantiasis that causes massive swelling of the lower legs. Podoiosis was identified as a neglected disease by the World Health Organization in 2011. The study used a multi-stage sampling design and surveyed 76 villages from 40 districts in 10 regions of Cameroon. Individuals 15 years old or older were screened for lymphedema, and a clinical algorithm was used to diagnose podoiosis excluding filarial lymphema. Of 10,178 individuals from 4,603 households participated, 83 with lymphema were identified, but none were positive for Wuchereria bancrofti antigen or DNA. 52 cases of podoiosis were identified after applying the algorithm, with a prevalence of 0.5% (95% CI 0.4-0.7). Podoiosis was found in every region except two villages in Adamawa, with 17 districts having no cases, 15 with 0.2-1% and 8 with 1.2-2.7%. The study demonstrates low but widespread distribution of podoiosis in Cameroon. Designing a control program and health response to the burden of podoiosis is important through surveillance and morbidity services.
Notch signaling plays a crucial role in regulating the adhesion of germline stem cells (GSCs) to their niche in Drosophila. As flies age, Notch signaling increases in GSCs, leading to their removal from the niche. Research shows that Gs with low levels of Notch signaling exhibit increased adhesion to the niche, outcompeting neighbors with higher levels of Notch. Adhesion is altered through regulation of E-cadherin expression. Enhancing Not signaling in Gs hastens age-dependent loss from niche, and is partially mediated by lethal. Disrupting Not signaling in Gs does not delay G loss during aging, nor affects BMP signaling, which promotes self-renew of Gs. In contrast, Not activation in niche maintains niche integrity, mediating G retention, is reduced with age, indicating Not regulates niche occupancy both intrinsically and extrinsically.
Researchers have discovered that a group of kinases, called conserved herpesvirus protein kinases (CHPs), share a common function with cellular cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks). These kinases are found in eight human herpesviruses, including human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) and human herpesvirus 5 (HHV-5). They phosphorylate the retinoblastoma (R) tumor suppressor protein and lamin A, which are substrates of Cdks. A functional assay showed that one of these kinases, UL97 from HH-5, has Cd-like activity. To determine if this activity is shared among all CHPs, researchers expressed tagged each protein in human cells to test for R phosphorylation, lamin disruption, and Cd function. They found that beta and gamma-herpesirus CHPs can phosphorylate R and lamin, disrupt the nuclear lamina, while alpha-herpesirus homologs cannot. All beta and gamma CHPs displayed Cd activity in yeast, but alpha did not. These kinases, some of which are targets of antiviral drugs, likely serve overlapping and non-overlapping functions during infections.
A team of researchers conducted a systematic review to understand the global distribution of Burkholderia pseudalle, a bacterium that causes meloidosis, a deadly disease found in tropical regions. The study aimed to update the risk map of meloid and propose guidelines for environmental sampling. A working group, the Detection Environmental Burkholder pseudalle Working Party, was formed during the 2010 World Meloid Congress. The team searched PubMed for studies on pseudalle and meloid from 1912 to 2011. They found that the distribution of pseudalle in the environment is patchy, with many areas lacking studies where meloid is suspected. The methods used to detect pseud were variable and not robust. The team developed guidelines to reduce false results and provide affordable methods for both developed and developing countries. The guidelines provide a basis for a global map of pseudalle.

The study found that 82% of 61 studies detected pseud using culture or PCR, but some isolates may be non-pathogenic. Only 3 studies from Kenya and Australia reported no pseud. A 1977 study in the US identified a pseud-like organism as Bokomens. Meloid is a disease caused by pseud, first described in 1912, with most cases in Thailand and Australia. 50 of 61 studies detected pseud using culture or PCR. Strains in France, Burkina Faso, Madagascar, and Niger were confirmed pseud by genotyping.
Researchers have discovered a new way to stop the dengue virus from entering cells by targeting a specific part of the virus. They found peptides, short chains of amino acids, that bind to a middle stage of the virus's life cycle, when it's preparing to fuse with the cell membrane. This binding blocks the virus from infecting the cell. The peptides work by attaching to the virus before it reaches the cell, and are carried inside with it into a compartment called an endosome, where the virus fuses with the cell membrane. This happens at a specific temperature, 37°C, and not at 4°C. The researchers propose a two-step model for how this works: the peptides bind to the virus and block it from fusing with the cell. This could be a new way to stop deng and other flaviviruses from infecting cells.
Researchers have developed a new method to sequence the entire genome of Vibrio cholera, the bacteria that causes cholera, directly from dried stool samples on filter paper. This is significant because cholera is a major global health concern, causing an estimated 4 million cases and 95,000 deaths annually, with recent outbreaks in Haiti and Yemen reminding us that it's still a pressing issue. The new method is low-cost, safe, and sustainable, and can be used in resource-limited settings. It provides previously unavailable data on circulating cholera strains, which can inform public health policy on control and elimination. The team successfully sequenced the cholera genome from stool samples preserved in alkaline peptone water and culture, both on filter paper, with a minimum DNA concentration of 0.02 ng/μL. The data confirmed the presence or absence of genes of interest, including cholera toxin and pilus loci, and identified co-infecting pathogens that may impact disease severity. The results fit within the global cholera phylogenetic tree, identifying strains as the 7th pandemic El Tor. This method can be used to explore the gut microbiome, identify co-infections, and provide molecular epidemiological information on cholera outbreaks in remote areas.
Researchers have identified a protein called Dyne that plays a crucial role in maintaining the structure of epithelial cells, which are layers of cells that line organs and glands in the body. Epithelial cells need to be organized in a specific way to function properly, but how this organization is achieved is not well understood. A study in fruit flies, called Drosophila, found that Dyne is essential for this organization. Dy works with a protein called Stardust (Sdt) to target a protein called Crumbs to the top surface of epithelial cells. Crumbs is important for cell-to-cell adhesion, sticking cells together. Dy and S work together to move Crumbs to the right place, where it can do its job. The study found that Dy also controls where Stardust mRNA, the instructions for making Stard, is found in the cell. This is important because Stard is only found at the top of epithelial cells early in development, but not in mature cells. This is the first time Dy has been shown to be important for epithelial organization and suggests that where mRNA, instructions, is found in the cell, can affect how cells are organized.
Researchers have found evidence that the parasite Leishmania infantum, which causes leishmaniasis, can exchange genetic material within its own cells, a process called intraclonal genetic exchange. This contradicts the previous belief that Leishmania reproduces asexually. To test this, scientists created transgenic Leish lines that express green and red fluorescent markers, linked to drug resistance. They fed these lines to sand flies, Phlebotus periciosus, and found that the markers were exchanged within the fly's midgut. This shows Leish can recognize and mate with cells of the same genotype. The hybrid offspring were triploid, meaning they had three sets of DNA, and were stable throughout the parasite's life cycle. Infections with the hybrid in mice showed reduced parasite loads in spleen and liver, similar to uninfected mice, and lower arginase activity. This suggests the hybrid is less virulent. The study confirms Leish can mate within its natural vector, the sand fly.
Researchers studied Leishmania donani strains from patients in Ethiopia with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) and HIV co-infections. They analyzed DNA from 63 strains using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) targeting three regions: internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS), cystine protease B (cp), and HASPB. The ITS and cp PCR identified the strains as Leishmania donani. However, the HAS PCR amplicon size varied depending on the patient's geographic location. Most strains from northwestern Ethiopia produced a 290bp product, while a minority gave 410 amplicons, all from HIV-VL co-infections. Southwestern strains produced 450 amplicons, with smaller products observed in three. Sudanese strains had amplicons identical to northwestern, while Kenyan gave larger products 500-650bp. High-resolution analysis distinguished different products. Sequence analysis showed the HAS repeat region in Leish donani comprised polymorphic 13-14 amino motifs. The 13 amino peptide, prevalent in Leish donani, is rare in Leishum. The order of repeats in Leishani varies between regions. The HAS region shows considerable polymorphism among Leish strains from East Africa. This should be considered when designing diagnostic and vaccine assays based on this antigen.
Scientists have studied the diversity of HIV-1, a virus that causes AIDS, to understand how it evolves and spreads. They found that some versions of the virus, called recombinants, have unique properties that help them survive and spread. The researchers created a model to predict where these recombinations occur based on the virus's genetic code and compared it to real-world data. The model worked well for most of the virus, but some areas had more or fewer recombinations than expected. This suggests that natural selection, the process by which the virus adapts to its environment, plays a role in these areas. The envelope gene, which helps the virus enter cells, had fewer recombinations, indicating these versions are less successful. However, areas around the envelope had more recombinations, suggesting they have an advantage. This study shows that only a few recombinations are important for the virus's evolution, despite its diversity.
Researchers in neuroscience rely heavily on computational modeling to understand brain function and behavior. Traditionally, two problems have been addressed separately: estimating individual parameters in a population and comparing candidate models. However, these are interdependent, as population parameters depend on which subjects express the model. A new framework, hierarchical Bayesian inference (HBI), combines approaches to estimate parameters and compare models concurrently. This framework has advantages for both estimation and comparison. Parameters estimated by H show smaller errors compared to other methods. Model comparison by H is robust against outliers and not biased towards simplistic models. The approach enables researchers to make group-level inferences by performing H-tests. 

A challenge is that the best-fitting model may vary subject to subject, but hierarchical estimation assumes the model is expressed all subjects. A new method, hierarchical Bayesian inference, addresses this by using variational techniques. This has consequences for both estimation and comparison. A fully Bayesian approach quantifies uncertainty at group level, enabling statistical tests and errors. Empirical methods play a role in modern statistics. A novel framework, hierarchical Bayesian inference, is introduced for estimation and comparison. H is hierarchical in that individual parameters are regularized across individuals. H is Bayesian that uncertainties both individual and group are represented by distributions. Evaluating a model precedes estimation its values; research used separate tools. However, are interconnected because parameters and depend on subjects that express the model. This is addressed from a Bayesian viewpoint.
Researchers studied how the development of the brain's auditory circuitry in mice, focusing on the role of rhombomeres and Hox genes. Rhomberes are groups of cells that contribute to brainstem development, and Hox genes determine their fate and connectivity. The study found that rhomere 4 contributes to sensory and motor components, including the ventral nucleus of lemniscus, ventral cochlear nuclei, and olivochlear neurons. Assembly of these components is crucial for sound perception and depends on interactions between Hox1 and H2 genes. In mice without H1 and H2, low-level sound transmission is lost, causing hearing impairments. On the other hand, H2 regulates axon guidance and contralateral projections to the trapezoid nucleus, involved in sound localization. Each rhomere and its Hox controls distinct subcircuits in the brainstem. The study also found that a single rhomere contributes to various auditory pathway derivatives across multiple rhomeres. H1 and H2 are crucial in rhom patterning, and ventral4 changes in their absence. The study suggests H genes are key in assembling functional circuits in the developing brain.
Scientists have sequenced the complete genome of a marine bacterium called Saccharagus deans strain 2-40, which can break down complex carbohydrates found in plants and algae. This bacterium is part of a newly discovered group of marine bacteria that recycle complex carbohydrates in the ocean. The genome analysis shows it has many enzymes that can break down different types of complex carbohydrates, some with unique combinations of parts that help break them down complex carbohydrates in the ocean. This is the first time a marine bacterium's genome has been sequenced that can break down plant cell walls, a key part of the carbon cycle not well understood in the ocean.

The study found that the bacterium's enzymes are regulated in different ways, and more complex carbohydrates need more enzymes to break them down. Glucose is a key to regulating the enzymes. The bacterium can grow on plants as its only food and break them down completely, the first time a marine bacterium has done so. It's related to other bacteria that break down cellulose and fix nitrogen, found in shipworms.

The bacterium is likely important in the ocean's carbon cycle, recycling biomass and breaking down complex carbohydrates. It's a "super-degrader" breaking down complex carbohydrates from plants and animals. The bacterium's genome has been fully sequenced and is available online.
Japanese Encephalitis virus (JEV) is a zoonotic flavivirus that causes significant childhood neurological infections in Asia. Over the past 20 years, the dominant genotype has shifted from III (GIII) to I (GI). The reason for this shift is unknown. Culex (Cx) mosquitoes are common in China and play a key role in JE transmission. This study used Cx pipiens mosquitoes from China to explore if they played a role in the shift. Female Cx pip mosquitoes were exposed to GI or GIII JEV strains. Midgut, organs, and saliv glands of infected mosquitoes were collected at 7 and 14 days post infection and measured for infection, replication, dissemination, and transmission. Cx pip mosquitoes were competent for both GI and GIII infection, with similar rates and kinetics. Both genotypes disseminated to secondary organs at similar rates. GI-infected saliv glands were positive at 16.2% at 7 days, while GIII was undetectable. However, 29.4% and 36.3% were positive at 14 days, showing an increase. No difference in transmission rate between GI and G-infected was detected. Data suggests GI and GIII have similar infectivity in Cx pip, suggesting C pip may not play a role in JE shift.
Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral disease that affects people living in tropical and subtropical regions, including Malaysia, where large outbreaks have occurred in recent years. Researchers studied the demographics and clinical characteristics of deng deaths in Malaysia between 2013 and 2014. They reviewed 322 deng deaths, with a mean age of 40.7 years and 72.5% were adults. Diabetes and hypertension were common co-morbidities among adults and elderly. The most common symptoms were lethargy and vomiting, with lethargy more common in children and abdominal pain in adults. 22.4% had no symptoms and 34% were suspected deng at initial presentation. Adults developed severe plasma leakage more often and half suffered multi-organ involvement. Deng deaths occurred at 3 days post-admission. Deng shock syndrome (DSS) caused 70% of deaths, followed by organ involvement 69% and bleeding 29.7%. In Malaysia, deng deaths primarily occurred in adults and SS was leading cause regardless of age. The study suggests early recognition and aggressive intervention to prevent deaths.
Researchers studied how female fruit flies choose their mates and what makes them attractive to males. They found that insulin signaling, a nutrient-sensing pathway, affects female attractiveness in fruit flies. Insulin signaling in the body and ovaries makes females more attractive, while insulin in the fat tissue makes them less attractive. The ovaries are necessary for insulin's effect on attractiveness, and manipulating insulin in ovaries alone has the same effect as global manipulation. Insulin in fat has opposite effect, suggesting a relationship with ovaries. Both tissue-specific insulin manipulations changed fecundity in the same direction, pointing to insulin as link between fecundity and attractiveness cues. Cues, cuticular hydrocarbons, responded differently to body and ovary manipulations, indicating independent activity from two tissues. The study describes a system where attractiveness comes from connection between cues and organism's state of fecundity, both created by insulin in fat and ovaries.
During the 2013-2015 Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic in West Africa, the virus spread unevenly across the hardest-hit countries Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. To understand how the disease spread, researchers estimated the basic reproduction number (R) for each district and country using weekly case numbers. They found that R ranged from 0.36 to 1.72 in Guinea, 0.53 to 3.37 in Liberia, and 1.14 to 2.73 in Sierra Leone. At the national level, R was estimated at 0.97 for Guinea, 1.26 for Liberia, and 1.66 for Sierra Leone. The study suggests that urbanization, such as high population density and wealth, contributed to the spread of EVD. The researchers used district-level data and a statistical approach to model the growth of the epidemic at country and district level. They estimated transmissibility of EVD as R for Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra, and their 53 districts. The study found a relationship between R and socio-demographic variables, such as urbanization, as drivers of E transmission at population level.
Scientists have long debated what determines a protein's rate of evolution. Two main factors are at play: intrinsic properties of the protein itself and its age. Researchers studied the interplay between these two factors using a large dataset of human and mouse proteins with known structures. They found that previously reported relationships between protein structure and evolution still hold within each age group, but age also plays a role. Younger proteins, despite being less designable, evolve faster than older ones. Age affects the relationship between structure and evolution, making older proteins more stable and robust to mutations. The study suggests both intrinsic and historical factors interact to determine protein evolution rates.
Polycomb-like 3 (P3) is a component of the Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) that promotes embryonic stem cell (ES) self-renewal. Researchers identified P3 as a binding partner of Suz12, a core component of PR2, using mass spectrometry and co-immunoprecipitation. Knocking down P3 in ES cells increases spontaneous differentiation, but not early differentiation, indicating P3 has a specific role in self-renew. P3 promotes PR2 function by increasing histone 3 lysine 27 trimethylation (H3K27me3). Chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-q) shows P3 co-localizes with Suz12 and depletion of P3 decreases Suz binding at 60% of PR2 targets. Mutation of conserved residues in the P Tudor domain of P3, which recognizes methylated histones, compromises H3me formation. P3 and its paralog P2 exist in different PR complexes but bind many of the same targets, particularly Cp islands regulated by P3. P3 is critical for ESC selfnew, histone methylation, and PR2 recruitment to a subset of genomic sites.
Researchers studied how the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans changes its chemosensory behavior in response to food availability. They found that a specific gene, sr-234, in the AD sensory neuron, is regulated by the transcription factor MEF-2 and basic helix-loop-helix (bHL) factors. MEF-2 and bHL work together to control the expression of sr-234 as a function of feeding state. A cis-regulatory M2 site is necessary for starvation-induced downregulation of sr-234, while an E-box binds bHL factors to drive expression in AD neurons. HL-2, HL-3, and HL-4 act in AD neurons to regulate sr-234. MX-3 and HL-30 in the intestine regulate sr- levels in AD neurons, dependent on insulin signaling in AD neurons. Intestine-to-neuron regulation of sr- involves insulin-like peptides. These results show that chemore gene expression is regulated by cell-autonomous and non-autonomous mechanisms mediated by MEF and bHL, allowing animals to fine-tune chemens responses to feeding changes.
Researchers studied the connection between mosquitoes and Buruli ulcer (BU), a skin infection caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium ulcerans, in southeastern Australia. They trapped mosquitoes in seven towns on the Bellarine Peninsula, Victoria, from 2004 to 2009, and tested them for M. ulcer using real-time PCR. The number of confirmed BU cases in residents during the same period was counted to find the average incidence in each town. A strong link was found between M. ulcer in mosquitoes and human disease risk (r, 0.99; 95% CI 0.92-0.99; p<0.001). This supports the idea that mosquitoes spread M. ulcer to humans in Australia. This has implications for controlling and preventing BU. Mosquitoes may play a role in spreading M ulcer in other areas like Queensland and Africa, where most cases occur, but more research is needed.
Researchers have identified a genetic mutation in the MRS2 gene, which codes for a magnesium ion channel in the mitochondria, as the cause of demyelination in rats. Demyelination is a condition where myelin breaks down in the central nervous system after normal myelination is complete. The mutation creates a new splice site that inactivates the gene, leading to a loss of function. Transgenic rats with the wild-type MRS2 gene validated the findings. M2 is essential for magnesium influx in mitochondria in yeast and human cells. Rats with the mutation have mitochondrial deficits, high lactic acid, low ATP, and swollen mitochondria in oligodendrocytes. M2 is mainly in neurons, not oligodrocytes, and in the inner mitochondria membrane. Observations suggest demel is due to mitochondrial disease and myelin maintenance is different from production. Mg2 homeostasis in mitochondria is crucial for myelin maintenance.
Researchers analyzed eight clinical microarray studies to evaluate the consistency of gene expression signatures in diagnosing and predicting diseases. They found that current documentation methods often lead to different diagnoses when applied to external patients, hindering their use in clinical practice. The team proposed a new documentation strategy that includes quantitative information, reducing discrepancies to 1%. This approach improves the process of bringing gene expression signatures to clinical practice, making it more reliable.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called curli, produced by certain bacteria, helps them stick to surfaces and form communities called biofilms, making them resistant to stress. They found that curli's structure is similar to human amyloid, a protein linked to Alzheimer's disease. Two peptides designed to stop human amyloid formation also stopped curli from forming and reduced bacterial biofilm in Salmonella. This suggests a new way to fight bacterial infections by targeting amyloid biofilms. The study also showed that cur can seed human amyloid formation, supporting the idea that amyloids can interact across species. Curli is made in a specific process and helps bacteria stick to cells, activate the immune system, and form biofilms. Amyloids are found in all life forms of life and play a role in many processes. A similar to cur, another protein in bacteria changed shape from a ball to a sheet-like structure when forming a biofilm. Cur's two main parts, Csg and Csg, work together to form fibrils, with Csg starting the process by interacting with unstructured C monomers. Two compounds also stopped a yeast protein from becoming a prion, a misfolded protein. This study offers a new way to stop curli formation and suggests that anti-amyloid drugs could target amyloid biofilms.
Japanese Encephalitis (JE) is a significant cause of encephal in Asia, with high fatality rates and neurologic sequelae among survivors. In the Philippines, the epidemiology of JE is not well defined. A systematic review of literature and surveillance data from 2011-2014 was conducted to support consideration of JE vaccine introduction into the national schedule. The review found 29 reports on JE in the Philippines, including 5 serologic surveys, 18 clinical cases, and 8 animal studies. Clinical studies reported 257 laboratory-confirmed JE cases from 1972-2013, with JE virus as causative in 7-18% of meningitis and encephalitis and 16-40% encephal cases. Predominantly affected children under 15, with 6-7% resulting in death. Surveillance from 2011-2014 identified 73 laboratory-confirmed JE out of 497 tested. The review demonstrates endemicity and geographic range of JE in the Philippines, supporting vaccine use in the country. Continued surveillance and laboratory confirmation is needed to quantify the burden, guide prioritization of high-risk areas, and age and schedule of vaccine introduction, and measure preventive measures against this public health threat.
Scientists have long debated the origins of genetic robustness in bacteria, which is the ability to withstand genetic mutations and environmental changes. Two main theories exist: it arises from environmental pressures or intrinsic factors, such as metabolic needs, or adaptive selection of genes that allow species to endure disruptions. To study this, researchers analyzed the robustness of metabolic networks in hundreds of bacterial species across various environments. They found that variations in robustness reflect ecological adaptations. Robustness was divided into two components: environmental, responsible for 20% of non-essential reactions, linked to species' lifestyle (specialized or generalist), and environmental-independent, linked to intrinsic capacities (0.6 correlation) of species, with higher robustness in fast growers or producers of secondary metabolites. Reactions uniquely susceptible to disruptions were identified in pathogens, potential drug targets.
Researchers conducted a study in Uganda to investigate the effect of Schistosoma mansoni infection on the immune response to measles vaccination in pre-school children. They found that children infected with S. mansoni had lower levels of antibodies against measles after vaccination compared to those who were not infected. The study also showed that treatment with prazantel, a medication used to treat S. mansoni, improved the immune response to measles vaccination in infected children who received it before or at the time of vaccination, but not after. At 24 weeks after vaccination, antibody levels did not differ between groups, but were lower in those who remained infected. The study suggests that S. mansoni infection may reduce the effectiveness of measles vaccination and that treating the infection with prazantel may help. This could be important in areas where schistosomiasis is common, as it may also affect responses to other vaccines.
Scientists have made significant progress in understanding how bacterial populations evolve by analyzing large-scale DNA samples. To get a clear picture of a population's genetic structure and ancestry, researchers need DNA sequences from many genes and a broad sampling of the population. However, traditional methods like phylogenetic analysis struggle with large samples, especially when recombination is common. To address this, researchers introduced statistical tools to detect and represent recombination between populations and a model population's shape in sequence space. They used extensive data from the Neisseria genus to demonstrate combining these tools with phylogen analysis. The tools are available in BAPS 5.2 software, downloadable from http://web.ab.fiak.fi/matec/software/baps.

A population of 508 Neisser strains was analyzed, assuming a simplified evolutionary model with a common local ancestor and global ancestor. Traditional genetic tools are not suitable for bacterial data, and phylogen analysis can be distorted by recombination. The new tools in BAPS enable large-scale population analysis, previously not possible with standard Bayesian methods. Neisser was chosen due to frequent recombination and horizontal gene flow between species.
Researchers have long believed that brain rhythms play a crucial role in our ability to focus and pay attention. A specific rhythm in the beta band, around 20 Hz, has been linked to attention in previous studies. This rhythm is thought to be generated in higher areas of the brain and sent to lower areas to help us focus. To understand how this works, scientists built a computer model of brain areas. Their results show that this rhythm can activate connections from lower to upper layers, helping us focus on one thing over another. They also found that certain cells in the brain, called inhibitory neurons, resonate at 20 Hz and control activity in upper layers in a way that helps us focus. This could explain how a chemical called acetylcholine helps us choose what to pay attention to.

The researchers tested how this rhythm affects cells in lower layers. They found that these cells can modulate activity in upper layers by sending signals to them. Specifically, they found that two types of connections from lower to upper layers are associated with this rhythm. This matches what happens in the brain when we pay attention to something inside our field of vision, but not outside. The rhythm enhances activity in upper layers, reduces in lower, and makes cells in upper fire more. This is consistent with how attention works in the brain.

The model shows that top-down signals, or from higher to lower, can bias competition in the brain. This is consistent with other models, but adds a new idea that interaction between layers, regulated by rhythm, helps us focus. Attention control is not fully understood, but competition has been thought to be a key. Recent studies link beta rhythm to top attention. This study used a model to see if rhythm can bias competition and how it does. They tested if rhythm reproduces what happens in the brain when we pay attention.
Researchers have developed a new method called Multiple Shooting for Stochastic Systems (MSS) to calibrate and predict the spread of epidemics using real-time data. Stochastic models are useful for studying the emergence of new diseases when the number of infected individuals is small, but current methods for estimating and predicting these models are limited. M uses a linear approximation to describe the size of fluctuations and updates the belief about the epidemic state with each new observation. The method was tested on simulated outbreaks of a viral pathogen and showed accurate estimates of key parameters such as duration of infectiousness, R0, and Reff, and the number of unobserved individuals during the epidemic. It also accurately predicted future hospitalizations and attack rate. M outperformed three state-of-the-art methods: likelihood with Poisson assumption, particle filtering, and Kalman filter in most scenarios. This method may improve current approaches for calibrating and predicting stochastic models of epidemics.
Researchers have discovered that our perception of the world around us is influenced by two opposing forces: one that pushes us away from what we've seen before and another that pulls us towards what we've decided in the past. In a series of experiments, they used multiple modeling and validation approaches to investigate how previous stimuli and decisions affect our perception. The results showed that our perception is shaped by a hierarchy of processes: low-level adaptation repels us from previous stimuli, while decisional attracts us to the past. This hierarchy is consistent with a two-process model where decision persistence compensates for adaptation, leading to biases in perception. The study proposes a unified account of dependence where distinct mechanisms at different stages promote differentiation and integration of visual information over time.

The research used multile modeling and cross-validation to investigate the impact of previous stimuli and decisions on behavioral reports in adjustment and forced-choice tasks. They found that perceptual reports are permeated by biases from a hierarchy of serial dependent processes. Low-level adaptation repels perception away from previous stimuli, whereas decisional attracts percept reports towards the past. This is consistent with a two-process model of dependence where persistence in decision compensates for adaptation, leading to attractive biases in perception.

The study aimed to determine whether dependence in perception depends on past stimuli or decisions. Recent work has shown that past stimuli bias decisions about present sensory input. However, the history of decisions itself is a source of perceptual bias that combines or outweighs the impact of previous stimuli. The results provided strong evidence for a hierarchical view of dependence and showed decisional affect percept even when interleaved with new stimuli. The study presents a unified account of concatenated perceptual and decisional processes, proposing a hierarchical model of dependence where adaptation and decisional forces interact shaping experience and reactions to stimuli.
Researchers studied the role of a protein complex called CLK-CYC in the fruit fly Drosila's internal clock, which regulates daily rhythms. CLK-CYC is a key component of the fly's circadian system, but its function was not fully understood. They created a modified version of the protein, CY-VP16, by adding a potent transcription activator from a virus to see if it would enhance CLKYC's activity. The results showed that CY-VP increased CLKYC's ability to turn on genes involved in the circadian rhythm. This was seen in both in cells and flies expressing CY-VP. These flies had higher levels of CLKYC target genes and a shorter circadian period, indicating that transcription plays a role in period determination. Further analysis showed that the shorter period was due to faster activation of transcription, not just higher levels of a protein. The study suggests that the timing of transcription, not the activation itself, is key to the observed effects in CYVP-expressing flies. The findings indicate that circadian transcription contributes to the fly's circadian function.
Scientists have long believed that horizontally acquired genes, or genes passed from one species to another, can function independently and confer new traits. However, a new research suggests that pre-existing proteins in an organism can limit the functionality of a horizontally acquired gene if it operates on an ancestral pathway. Researchers studied the horizontally acquired pmr gene in Salmonella, a type of bacteria, and Escherichia coli, a closely related bacteria. They found that the pmr gene activates the PA/PB system in Salmonella but not in E coli. coli. The pmr protein in Salmonella binds to phosphorylated PA, protecting it from dephosphorylation by PB, resulting in transcription of PA-dependent genes, including polymyxin resistance. In contrast, E coli pmr protein cannot activate PA/PB in E coli. coli. The researchers discovered that E coli pmB has higher phosphatase activity towards PA than Salmon pmB and identified a specific domain responsible for this property. Replacing E coli pmB with Salmon homolog restored E coli resistance to polymin in low Mg+ conditions. This study shows that differences in biochemical activities of ancestral proteins can dictate the ability of horizontally acquired gene to confer species-specific traits.
Researchers have developed a new method to identify genes involved in the early stages of cell differentiation, a process by which cells become more specialized. This method, called Differentiation-Test, analyzes gene expression data from a mixture of cells without separating them into different types. Previous methods often included genes that respond to differentiation, not regulate it. The team applied Different-Test to mouse embryonic stem cells and found Smad1, a new regulator of pluripotency and self-renew. They used short RNA to study two regulators detected by Different-Test, Smad1 and P2, and found lower expression in differentiated cells. The researchers separated regulators into two modules: upregulated during differentiation and downregulated, associated with pluripotency.
Researchers have developed a new method to analyze genetic data from next-generation sequencing studies, called unbiased clustering of gene variants with phenotypic-link network. This method aims to identify functional associations between genes and their roles in diseases. Traditional methods use large-scale data, such as protein-protein interactions and gene-expression networks, but can be affected by bias, leading to false findings. The new method controls for a known bias in gene length, where longer genes tend to cluster together, leading to exaggerated results. It uses over 100,000 human genotype-phenotype relations and semantic similarity to enhance the network. The researchers tested the method on different data and networks and found that disease-associated genes cluster more in the phenotyp-link network than other networks. This method can identify functional genes in the same disease, even after accounting for sequencing bias, and is suitable for polygenic disorders.
Mexico implemented an 8% tax on non-essential foods with energy density ≥275 kcal/100g and a peso-per tax on sugar-sweet beverages (SBs) in January 2014 to prevent obesity and diabetes. This study examined changes in volume of taxed and untaxed food purchases in response to these taxes, stratified by socioeconomic status (SES). Data from 6,248 households in Nielsen's Mexico Consumer Panel (2012-2014) showed taxed food purchases declined by 5.1% in 2014 compared to expected trends, with no change in untaxed foods. Low SES households purchased 10.2% less taxed foods, medium SES 5.8% less, while high SES didn't change. The study's limitations include inability to infer causality due to national implementation and lack of control group, and only representing urban areas. Purchases of non-essential foods declined in the first year after taxes. Future studies should evaluate taxes' impact on energy intake, quality, and food patterns.
Researchers have developed a new model to explain the behavior of a specific type of neuron in the locust's brain called the Lobula Giant Detector (LG). This neuron is sensitive to objects approaching objects and responds best when they are on a collision course with the locust's compound eyes. A previous model, called η, used a power law to scale inhibitory input, but was not biologically plausible. The new model, n-ψ, is more realistic and assumes each channel is noisy and has a threshold. By pooling these channels, an approximate power law is obtained. This model can predict many characteristics of the LG neuron, including its response to approaching objects. The results depend on noise in the inhibitory pathway but are robust against noise in the excitatory pathway. The model shows that a power law alone is not enough, as it would distort the LG's response to approaching objects. The new model, nψ, is based on biophysical principles and describes the membrane potential of the LG neuron. It receives input signals and integrates them through the dendritic tree. The conditions for each channel are noise and a threshold.
Cameroon has been endemic for Buruli ulcer (BU) since 1969, but a national control program was only established in 2002. From 2001 to 2014, the number of cases dropped from 3.89 to 1.45 per 100,000 inhabitants, and the number of endemic districts rose from 2 to 64. Five diagnostic and treatment centers are now functional, with two more planned for 2015. The health system has been strengthened and research has gained interest in Cameroon. However, a reduction in resources and activities led to a drop in performance since 2010. The program aims to detect cases early, confirm 70% by PCR, treat all according to guidelines, and heal 95% without joint limitation. BU is expensive and occurs in poor, remote areas.
Researchers investigated how people's confidence in their choices affects their learning and decision-making in situations where they gain or lose something. They found that people are more confident in their choices when learning to gain something compared to avoiding a loss, even if they perform equally well in both situations. A computational model showed that this bias is due to "context-value", an estimate of the average value of options, which is different in gain and loss domains. This bias is the first found in a learning context and is general, meaning it has important consequences. It shows that people's flexibility in learning changes when outcomes are framed as gains or losses. A previous study showed that stakes can also bias people's confidence in choices, with gains increasing and losses decreasing it. Confidence is crucial in learning and decision-making, as it affects subsequent processes and strategies. The researchers hypothesized that people would be less confident in choices to avoid losses compared to gains, despite equal performance and difficulty. They found that this bias is generated by learned-value, a variable in some learning models. The study investigated behavior and confidence in a task where outcomes were manipulated (gains or losses). People performed equally well in gain and loss contexts.
Researchers have studied the role of a protein called ns3 in the replication of alphaviruses, a type of virus that causes diseases such as chikungunya fever and sindbis fever. Ns3 is part of the virus's replication complex and has a conserved amino-terminal domain that helps with RNA synthesis and a poorly conserved carbox-terminal region.
