They found that a carbox-terminal proline-rich sequence in ns3 is a target for a protein called amphiphin, which is found in host cells. Amphins bind to ns3 of three alphaviruses, including semli forest, sind, and chikunya, and this interaction is important for viral replication. When cells are infected with alphavirus, amphins move to where ns3 is located. Disrupting ns3's ability to bind amphin or silencing amphin expression impairs viral replication in cells. In mice infected with alphavirus that can't bind amphin, the virus is less deadly. This study shows that ns3's interaction with amphin is crucial for alphavirus replication.
Researchers studied 123 strains of a disease-causing fungi in Brazil, known as chromoblastyc, to understand its diversity. They used DNA sequencing to identify the species. The fungi were divided into three groups, with Fonca being the most common, followed by Rhinadiella and Cyellophora. Fonca pedso was the most prevalent, found in 80% of cases, followed by 13% for monora, 3 for nica, and 1 pnius. Two new species, Rhinadi and Cyello, were also found, making up 3 and 1% of cases, respectively. The study found that Fonca pedso and nica are associated with the disease, while monora is not. Cladiophora was not found, likely due to climate, as it thrives in arid conditions.
Listeria monocytogenes, a type of bacteria, infects host cells and causes DNA damage, but surprisingly, the host's DNA damage response is only moderately activated. Researchers found that the bacteria's toxin, listeriolysin O (LO), blocks the host's DNA damage response by degrading a key sensor protein, Mre11. Without this protein, the bacteria can replicate more easily, showing the importance of this mechanism in controlling infection. The study reveals that dampening the host's DNA response is crucial for the bacteria's success. This is the first time it's been shown that the DNA response can be a negative regulator of bacterial infection. Other bacteria, like Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Neisseria gonorrhoe, also cause DNA damage, but it's not been studied during Lister infection. Lister's LO degrades M11 through proteasome degradation, and dampening the response is important for infection, as blocking proteins in this pathway increase bacteria. The study uncovers Lister's subversion of the DNA response and its role in blocking bacterial proliferation.
Researchers have identified a protein called BRD4 as a key player in the infection of two common viruses, HSV-1 and HSV-2, which cause diseases in humans. They tested a library of chemicals that regulate gene expression and found that blocking a part of BR4, called the BD domain, increased infection. Using a specific chemical called JQ, they found that JQ acts by blocking BR4, as knocking down BR4's expression stopped JQ's effect on infection. BR4 regulates virus replication by forming a complex with proteins CD9 and RNA polymerase II, while JQ promotes infection by directing the complex to viral gene promoters. Suppressing BR4 or blocking CD9 activity hindered infection. The study suggests JQ enhances infection by switching BR4 to regulate viral gene expression by targeting chromatin.
Researchers studied the microbial communities in the mouths of children with a devastating illness called noma cancrum, which causes severe facial disfigurement and affects over 140,000 malnourished children every year. The cause of noma is still unknown, but a mix of infection, poor oral hygiene, and weakened immune system likely contribute to the development of oral lesions. These lesions are entry points for microorganisms that trigger gangren facial infections. The team sequenced 16 rRNA gene fragments from 60 samples of gingival fluid from 12 healthy children, 12 with noma lesions, and 12 with Acute Necrotizing Gingitis (AN) lesions and healthy sites. Compared to healthy individuals, samples from diseased mouths were enriched with Spirocha and depleted Proteobacteria. Samples from healthy sites of diseased had similar proportions of Spiro and Proteobacteria to healthy controls. Samples from n mouths did not have higher Fusobacter abundance, casting doubt on its causative role. Microbial communities from n and AN lesions were dominated by Prevotella intermedia OT, less abundant in healthy sites. Multivariate analysis confirmed different bacterial communities in healthy and lesion sites. Several OTUs in Erysotrichales, Cloidales, Boid, and Spirotales were identified as indicators of n, suggesting one or more microbes within these orders associated with noma development.
Bacillus thuringis, a bacterium that infects insects, uses a communication system called quorum sensing to adapt to its environment and decide whether to form spores or survive in the insect cadaver. Researchers studied the role of quorum sensing in this bacterium and found that a protein called Npr plays a key role in this process. Npr is activated by a signaling peptide called Npr and acts as a transcription factor, turning on genes that help the bacteria survive in the insect cadaver. However, in the absence of Npr, Npr has a different function: it inhibits sporulation, the process of forming spores. Npr does this by preventing a protein called SpoA from being activated, which is necessary for spore formation. This is similar to how other proteins called Raps work, which don't bind DNA but control gene expression through protein interactions. The structure of Npr shows it has a flexible shape similar to Raps. The researchers propose that Npr has two functions: binding Npr makes it an inhibitor of sporulation, while binding N makes it a transcription activator of necrotrophic lifestyle. This coordination of sporulation and necrotism ensures the bacteria's survival and spread during infection.
Researchers have developed a new way to predict which HIV treatment will work best for an individual patients by combining genetic and chemical information. Current treatments for HIV can't cure the virus, but can control it with multiple drugs. Each patient has a unique viral type, making it hard to choose the right treatment. With genetic and chemical data, models can predict the best treatment. Previous models only used genetic data, not chemical similarity of drugs. The new method, called proteochem, combines genetic and chemical properties in one model. A large database of 300,000 data points was used, including 4 types of drugs and 10,700 mutants. The new models were accurate, with an error rate below 0.5.5. They also did better than previous models in predicting resistance, 0.76 compared to 0.91. Known and new resistance-causing mutations were found, such as K102 and Q18. The models were applied to a public database and correctly predicted 84% of resistance, compared to 80%. This method can predict resistance for new mutants and mixtures and inform users about reliability.
Researchers have proposed an alternative mechanism for chemotaxis, the process by which cells move towards chemical attractants. They suggest that pseudopods, formed by a self-generated cycle, are modulated by chemotactants rather than directly causing actin polymerization. A computational model based on pseudod autocatalysis reproduces a wide range of existing data on cell movement and chemaxis. It simulates cell polarization, persistence, and pseudod selection in chemactant gradients, and predicts pseudod position and initiation in gradients. The model predicts that the angle between pseudods at the front of the cell increases with the difference between the cell's direction and the gradient. Experiments on Dictyostelium cells confirm this prediction. The model and data suggest that rapidly moving cells like Dictyostelium and neutrophils have an intrinsic pseudod cycle at the heart of their motility. This implies that chemaxis relies on modification of pseudod behaviour, not generation of new pseudods or actin polymer by chemactants. The model is robust to changes in parameters and emerges two mechanisms of chemaxis, pseudod selection and orientation, from simple pathways. Actin polymerization and depolymerization following stimuli are also observed without multiple pathways.
Researchers studied how fleas transmit the bacterium Yersinia pestis, which causes plague, to rodents. They found that fleas can transmit the bacterium in two ways: early-phase transmission (EPT) and bio-dependent transmission (BDT). However, the efficiency of transmission varies among flea species and rodent blood sources. To understand EPT, they fed fleas bacteremic blood from mice, rats, guinea pigs, and gerbils. They observed that 10-28% of fleas fed rat or guinea blood regurgitated a portion of the infected meal into the esophagus within 24 hours. This phenomenon is called post-infection esophageal reflux (PIER). In contrast, PIER was rare in fleas fed bacteremic mouse or gerbil blood. PIER correlated with accumulation of dense aggregates of Y. pest, red blood cells, and hemoglobin in the proventulus. At next feeding, fleas with PIER were 3-25 times more likely to be blocked, with blood retained in the esagus, than fleas without P. Three days after feeding on bacteremic rat blood, Oropsa montana transmitted significantly more CFU than groups using mouse blood, and this transmission was bio-dependent. Data support a model where EPT results from regurgitation of Y. pest from obstructed foregut and E and BDT can overlap.
Researchers have found that positive correlations between the activity of neurons in the brain can actually improve the accuracy of coding, rather than hinder it. Contrary to previous studies, which showed that correlations were either detrimental or marginally beneficial, this study shows that they can enhance performance by astronomical factors. The probability of error can be suppressed by many orders of magnitude and the number of stimuli encoded, or capacity, can be increased more than tenfold. These effects don't require unrealistic correlation values and can occur in populations with just a few neurons. The study also found that heterogeneity in activity is beneficial and that both error suppression and enhancement depend on a specific pattern of correlation. Tuning one or several parameters can lead to perfect coding. The pattern of positive correlation leads to a "locking" of response that eliminates variability in the space relevant for stimulus discrimination. The researchers suggest that this pattern is a key to high-fidelity coding and propose tests to identify it.
Researchers have developed a new vaccine against cholera, a severe diarrhea caused by Vibrio cholera bacteria. The vaccine combines a specific part of the bacteria's outer shell, called OSP, with a fragment of tetanus toxin. They tested the vaccine in mice and found it induced strong immune responses, including antibodies and memory cells that can fight the bacteria. The vaccine also protected mice from cholera in a challenge test. The researchers varied the amount of OSP in the vaccine and the ratio of OSP to tetanus fragment, as well as the adjuvant used and route of immunization. They found similar immune responses in mice with different variations, but lower responses in those with the highest dose. The vaccine worked with or without adjuvant. Administering the tetanus fragment resulted in 55% protection against cholera in mice. This new vaccine could be beneficial, especially for young children who don't respond well to the bacteria's outer shell.
A study was conducted in Cameroon to investigate the effectiveness of immunochromatographic test (ICT) in mapping lymphatic filariasis (LF) in areas with contrasting levels of Loa loa and Mansonella perans endemicity. The study assessed the prevalence and intensity of Wuchereria bancrofti, Loa loa, and Mansonella perans in 42 villages across three regions of Cameroon's rainforest domain. Blood samples were collected for circulating filarial antigen detection by ICT and microfilaria assessment. Clinical manifestations of LF were also evaluated. Overall, 219 individuals participated, with 24 testing positive by ICT, ranging from 0% in South-west to 2.1% in North. Lymphedema was diagnosed in 20 individuals, mostly in North, with none testing positive by ICT. No microf W. bancfti were found in blood of individuals with positive ICT or lymphedema. Positive ICT was associated with high Loa intensity, with 21 having over 8,000 Loa/ml (odds ratio 15.4; CI 6.1-39; p<0.001). A strong association was observed between Loa prevalence and ICT area, with 1% or more positive results in areas with Loa above 15%. No association was found between ICT and M perans prevalence or density. The study confirmed association between ICT and Lo intensity, and demonstrated strong association with Lo prevalence. Results suggest main confounding factor for positive test results are high Lo levels. Findings indicate W. bancft less prevalent in Central region than assumed, accurate re-mapping useful for shrinking LF distribution map.
Scientists have studied how the SARS-CoV virus replicates, or makes copies itself, inside host cells. They found that it uses a network of modified endoplasmic reticulum, a type of cell membrane, to do so. This network is made up of convoluted membranes and double-membr vesicles (DMVs) that are about 200-300 nanometers in diameter. These DMVs are not just floating vesicles, but are part of the network. The virus uses this network to make its RNA, the genetic material it needs to replicate. The virus also uses this network to hide from the cell's defense mechanisms that try to fight it off the virus. The researchers used electron tomography to see the network in 3D at high resolution. They found that the convol membranes, not the DMVs, have viral replicase subunits, the proteins that help make the virus copy itself. The DMVs have double-stranded RNA, the virus's genetic material, inside. But the researchers couldn't see how the DMs connect to the cell's cytoplasm. This raises questions about how the DMs form and where the virus makes its RNA. The study shows how the virus reorganizes the cell's membranes to replicate and hide from the immune system. This will help scientists understand the early stages of the virus's life cycle and how it interacts with the host.
Scientists have long believed that a substance called suberin plays a crucial role in helping plants absorb water and nutrients from the soil. However, there was no direct evidence to support this idea until now. Researchers studied a plant called Arabidopsis thaliana and found that when suberin is present in the roots, it helps control how water and nutrients move into the plant. They created a mutant plant with more suberin in its roots and found that it had less water loss and more efficient water use during growth. The plant also had less calcium, manganese, and zinc, and more sodium, sulfur, selenium, and molybdenum in its leaves. This shows that suberin in the roots helps control water and nutrient transport to the leaves. The team also found that suberin acts as a barrier to water and mineral transport in the plant. When suberin is high, it reduces water movement to the shoot and loss from the root to soil. They tested this by measuring water loss in plants with more suberin and found it was 15% of normal plants. This supports the idea that suberin is a barrier to water and nutrient transport. The study suggests that increasing suberin could help develop drought-resistant crops with better water use.
Researchers investigated the dynamics of rhodopsin deactivation and its role in regulating the reproducibility of the single photon response (SPR) in vertebrate phototransduction. They used a Continuous Time Markov Chain (CT) model based on the biochemistry of rhodin activation and deactivation, interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction. The model reproduced both wild-type (WT) and mutant responses with variable numbers of phosphorylation sites. The sources of variability were dissected into components: random number of turn-off steps, random sojourn time between steps, or both. Results showed that only randomness of soj times in phosphorylated states contributed to coefficient of variation (CV) of response, while randomness of number of turn steps had negligible effect. This contradicts the view that larger number of decay steps makes response more stable. Rhodin shutoff is responsible for variability, while diffusion of second messengers acts as suppressor.
Researchers have developed a new mathematical framework to analyze complex networks within cells that are affected by external factors outside the network, such as fluctuations in the number of ribosomes in a gene network. These external factors can make it hard to model the network's behavior. The new framework separates the network from its environment by incorporating the environment's effect into a new model. This allows for a "self-contained" model that summarizes all possible behaviors under external fluctuations. The model can be used to analyze a network subject to external noise without considering the noise.

The study shows that models of biochemical networks need to account for both internal and external noise caused by variations in the cellular environment. This is done by extending the model's state with environmental species whose dynamics are described along with the system of interest. The decoupled dynamics provide a tool to study how stochasticity is propagated through reaction networks. The environmental noise is split into two terms: one that is suppressed and one that is sensed by the network.

The decoupled process can reduce computational effort in Monte Carlo simulations, especially if the environment is costly to simulate. This highlights the framework as a tool to split biochemical networks into parts that are easier to simulate. The time evolution of a reaction network is described by a continuous Markov chain with species and channels. The state at time is denoted and its path on intervals.
Researchers have developed a new brain-machine interface (BMI) system that allows people to control devices with their thoughts at a faster and more precise scale than current systems. The system uses two main components: an infinite-hor feedback model of the brain's behavior and a point model of neural spikes. The feedback model infers the user's intention during control and is used for training and adaptation. The point model enables processing and adaptation with every spike at a time, unlike current decoders that use batch adaptation on slower time scales. Experiments in a non-human primates showed that the system improved performance compared to current techniques and allowed consistent control. Spike-based adaptation was faster and more consistent than batch methods and robust to initialization. The system also controlled tasks beyond those used for training. This has implications for developing clinically viable neuroprosthetics.
Researchers studied how the retina responds to different types of visual stimuli, such as movies and white noise patterns, to understand how it processes information. They found that the retina doesn't completely eliminate redundancies in responses, but reduces them to a lower level, similar to responses to white noise. The amount of correlation varies between stimuli, but is less than predicted by a non-adaptive model. Experiments showed the retina doesn't fully decorrelate its input, even with least correlated stimuli, some correlations are present between ganglion cell spike trains. Results are consistent with previous studies on LGN and visual cortex, which differ in structure when probed with natural versus random stimuli. Gain of ganglion cells responding to correlated stimuli changes with effective contrast, i.e. standard deviation of input to nonlinearity in linear model. The retina may adjust its coding strategy to represent new stimulus efficiently.
Researchers have developed a new approach to predict genetic interactions between genes, called synthetic lethality, which occurs when a combination of mutations results in a surprising effect. This is important for understanding how proteins work together in pathways and the causes of diseases. They used data from various sources to create a large number of features characterizing relationships between genes. These features were independent of known interactions, unlike previous methods. A non-parametric multi-classifier system was developed to predict interactions using these features. Experiments showed improved performance compared to current method. The approach was used to create a yeast transcription factor genetic network, supported by literature, and predicted interactions between non-essential genes. This method is expected to uncover new interactions in yeast and higher organisms like mouse and human, where few have been identified.
The BRCA Challenge is a global data-sharing project that aggregates BRCA1 and BR2 data to support collaborative research. It aims to understand how genetic variations affect cancer risk in these genes. Initially, variants from public databases were integrated into a single site, www.brca.org. The BR Exchange provides a reliable and accessible record of interpreted variants for high-risk phenotypes. Over 20,000 variants have been aggregated, three times the number in the next-largest database, with 7,250 classifications. Data comes from clinical databases like BIC, ClinVar, and LOVD, and population databases linked to one access. The BR Challenge brought together experts, clinicians, researchers, and providers to advance understanding BR1 and BR2 variation. Ongoing work includes sharing data with centers, developing methods for genetic variation extraction, and engaging communities for clinical significance.

The scope of BR1 and BR2 testing is larger than other cancer genes, but data has not been coordinated. Multiple databases and proprietary testing have hindered linking well-annotated variants for interpretation. The BR Challenge shares and annotates variants to advance health globally. BR1 and BR2 are a compelling case for sharing to improve variant interpretation, enabling clinicians and patients to decide. The BR Exchange is an open portal to improve sharing and classification, improving care for clinicians, patients, and families. The Challenge brings clinicians, researchers, scientists, patients, and advocates to a new data-sharing model.
Malaria, a disease caused by the Plasmodium parasite, remains a significant threat to human health, resulting in over one million deaths annually. To survive and thrive, Plmod undergoes a complex life cycle in humans and mosquitoes, requiring adaptation to various environments. To manage oxidative stress and maintain redox processes, Plmod relies on a delicate balance. Researchers have mapped the subcellular localization of antioxidant and redox proteins in Plmod falcum for the first time. They found that two Plmod peroxiredoxins and a putative glyoxal system are targeted to the apoplast, a non-photosynthetic plastid, similar to plant chloroplasts. A complete picture of thioredoxin and glutaredin-like proteins was also obtained. Notably, Plmod uses alternative translation initiation (ATI) to target two major antioxidant enzymes, glutathione reductase and thioreductase, to different locations. This dual localization by ATI may occur in other Apicomplex parasites, opening new avenues for intervention.

The study provides the first comprehensive picture of cellular redox metabolism in malaria. The apoplast, a non-photosynthetic plast of Plmod, contains plant-like metabolic pathways, including fatty acid and hem biosynthesis. Until now, no data existed on antioxidative capacity of the apoplast. Two major antioxidants, catalase and glutathione peroxide, are absent in the parasite. This offers potential for therapeutic agents disrupting redox balance in Plmod. Many redox enzymes contain targeting sequences, but localization has not been demonstrated. Plasium has two NAD-dependent red systems with broad antioxidant mechanisms. The study maps the red system of malaria, understanding cellular functions and interactions. ATI exists in Apicom parasites, translating isoforms with subcell localization from one gene.
Researchers studied how a protein called PUM binds to its partner Mcl-1. PUM is a type of protein that doesn't have a fixed shape on its own, but folds into a specific shape when it binds to M-1. They used a computer model to see how electrostatic interactions, or charges, affect this process. The model was tested with data on how much of the protein was folded and how well it bound to M-1, and matched what was already known about how binding changed with salt levels. They found that the protein's own electrostatic interactions didn't much affect its shape before binding. However, electrostatic interactions between PUM and M-1, especially non-native ones, helped form the initial complex. The model showed the binding process in more detail than experiments alone, revealing the role of non-electrostatic interactions. The study highlights the importance of electrostatic interactions in binding of proteins that don't have a fixed shape. This approach can be used to predict how mutations affect binding.
Researchers studied how Polycomb proteins, which help silence genes during development, move in fruit fly embryos. They found that these proteins form structures called Polycomb bodies, which contain silenced genes, and move in the nucleus. Using a combination of techniques, they tracked the formation and movement of these bodies during embryogenesis. They found that Polycomb bodies correspond to 3D structures of genomic domains identified in previous studies. During early development, Polycomb and Polyhomeotic proteins accumulate in these bodies, which form on euchromatin domains with histone H3-methylated on K27. Time-lapse analysis showed two types of motion: long-range movement of bodies and chromatin domains, and fast movement of individual bodies and chromatin. Both types move within smaller volumes than chromosome territories, limiting interaction with other nuclear structures. Fast motion decreases in late stages, suggesting chromatin dynamics in gene silencing maintenance.
Researchers used ultra-deep sequencing to study mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) mutations in mice that age normally and prematurely. They found that mice with a proofreading-deficient mtDNA polymerase, called mt mutator, have 10 times more mutations than their normal siblings. These mice also have more linear mtDNA fragments and less complete DNA in some areas. In contrast, large DNA deletions are rare in these mice and don't seem to cause premature aging. Analysis shows that most mutations in these mice come from their mothers, suggesting they are inherited. The study found no increase in mutations or deletions in normal mice as they age, questioning their role in aging. Oxidative damage is also not a main cause of mt mutations. The study suggests most mt mutations occur during development, not from damage later in life.
Researchers have discovered a new type of sodium-driven ATP synthase membrane motor in the anaerobic bacterium Fusobacterium nucleatum that uses glutamate decarboxylation to generate a transmembrane gradient of sodium ions. This ionotive force is directly coupled to ATP synthesis via an F1-ATP synthase with a novel sodium recognition motif shared by other human pathogens. Molecular modeling and free energy simulations of the rotary element of the enzyme, the c-ring, indicate sodium specificity in physiological settings. Consistently, activity measurements showed sodium stimulation of the enzyme, either membrane-embedded or isolated, and ATP synthesis was sensitive to sodium ionophore monens. Furthermore, sodium has a protective effect against inhibitors targeting ion-binding sites, both the complete ATPase and isolated. Evidence of sodium coupling is provided by two crystal structures of the c-ring solved by X-ray crystallography at 2.2 and 2.6 resolution at pH 5.3 and 8.7, respectively. Sodium ions occupy binding sites, each coordinated by four amino acids and a water. Intriguingly, carboxylates mediate ion binding. Simulations and experiments demonstrate this implies a proton is bound to all sites, although sodium alone drives the rotary mechanism. The structure reveals a new mode of ion coupling in ATPases and provides a basis for drug efforts against opportunistic pathogen.
Researchers studied how the immune system's T cells, called T cells, recognize and respond to foreign substances on the surface of other cells. This recognition is a key step in fighting off infections and diseases. In the lab, it's known that strong and long-lasting interactions between T cells and these substances, called major histocompatibility complex (MHC), lead to strong T cell activation. However, the study found that in the body, T cells respond best to substances with medium-strength interactions with M, not the strongest. In fact, the strongest interactions led to weaker cell responses and less ability to fight off infections. This challenges the idea that stronger is always better when it comes to T and M interactions. The study suggests that vaccine design should consider how substances interact with T in the body, not just in the lab, to be effective.
The fungus Nect haematocca, also known as Fusarium solani, is a member of a group of over 50 species called the Fusarium solani complex. This group has diverse properties, including causing disease in over 100 plant genera and opportunistic infections in humans. Researchers studied the most known member of this group, N haematocca mating population VI (MP). They found that genes controlling its ability to colonize specific habitats are on extra chromosomes, called supernary. These extra chromosomes have unique genes not found in other fungi, including its closest relative Fusarium gramineum, and multiple copies of genes found in other fungi. Some genes may have come from duplication, while others from horizontal transfer. Three extra chromosomes, 14, 15, and 17, were confirmed absent in some isolates lacking specific sequences on their ends. These extra chromosomes have more repeats, unique genes, and lower G content compared to others. The origin of extra genes and chromosomes is unknown, but expansion and large size match species' diverse habitats. Unique genes on extra chromosomes might explain isolates having different niches.
Researchers have developed a new method to study how herpesviruses, a type of virus that causes cold sores and other diseases, leave infected cells. They used a special microscope to watch live cells and see how the virus particles move and leave the cell. The method, called total internal reflection fluorescence microscopy, lets them see the virus near the cell membrane. They also used a special tool to see when the virus leaves the cell. The study found that virus particles travel in small, acid-filled vesicles to the cell membrane, where they leave the cell. Three proteins, Rab6, Rab8, and Rab11, help the vesicles move to the right place. The vesicles then dock and fuse with the cell membrane, releasing the virus. After leaving the cell, the virus stays on the surface. This study helps understand how herpesviruses leave cells, which is important for understanding how they spread and cause disease.
Researchers studied the impact of Enterobius vermicularis infection and mebendazole treatment on the intestinal microbiota and immune response in 109 primary school children in Taiwan. They found that Enterobias increased gut diversity and peaked after meendazole treatment. At the phylum level, pinworm and meendazole were associated with decreased Fusobacteria and increased Actinobacteria. The probiotic Bifobacterium abundance increased after Enterias and meend treatment. Intestinal SIg levels were lower in the pin-infected group and higher in the meend-treated group. A higher pre-treatment Salmonella proportion was linked to increased SIg after meend dewing. The study suggests that exposure to pin and meend is associated with increased diversity, Actinob, and probiotic Bifobacterium, and decreased Fusob. SIg levels were lower in pin-inf and higher in meend-treated. 

The study found that Enterobias and meend dewing altered the intestinal microbiome, consistent with previous helminth-infected microbiota studies. Further metabolomics studies are needed to evaluate if pin and meend alter commensal metabolism and host immune. The change in microbial composition after meend in pin-inf children may be confounded by late effects of Enterias. More experiments, including animal studies, are needed to understand relationships between pin, microbiota, and immune. The immunomodulatory effect of pin may depend on individual microbiota interaction.
Researchers studied the genetics of root length in Arabidopsis thalian, a plant species, and found that most of the genetic variation in root length was not due to individual genes acting alone, but to interactions between genes. This is known as epistasis, where two or more genes work together to affect a trait. They used a method called genome-wide association analysis to identify genes involved in root length and found four pairs of interacting genes that explained a large part of the variation in the population. These genes were not detected in a standard analysis that only looked at individual genes. The researchers estimated that half of these interactions were real, not false positives due to the small population size of the study. They found functional genes in three of the pairs that affect root development. The study shows that epasis can explain why some traits have low heritability, or genetic variation, and why some genes are not found in standard analysis. It also highlights the importance of accounting for epasis in genetic studies.
Researchers analyzed 30,506 mitochondrial DNA (mt) sequences from around the world to understand how genetic background influences the occurrence and severity of disease-causing mt mutations. They found that the likelihood of having two or more disease-causing mutations was 6 times lower in certain mt haplogroups, suggesting that the background plays a role in acquiring or retaining disease-causing mutations. The study also showed that disease-causing mutations were more frequent in younger sequences and genomes, and that some mutations recurred within the same phylogenetic cluster. This implies that natural selection may have purified disease-causing mutations in older populations, explaining why they are less common in specific ethnic groups. The researchers also found that 43% of recurrent disease-causing mt mutations were associated with specific haplogroups, but not necessarily disease-causing, and that the dataset was representative of global populations, not enriched with rare variants or mutations from patients with mitochondrial diseases. Overall, the study suggests that mt background influences the occurrence and severity of disease-causing mt mutations, not just a few examples.
Researchers have developed a computer model to study how cells move and interact with each other on a surface with tiny patterns. This is important for understanding how cancer spreads, how embryos develop, and how wounds heal. The model includes how cells change shape and how they stick to each other. It shows that a balance between how cells stick to each other and how they move is key to what happens when they collide. The model can reproduce different outcomes of cell collisions, such as changing direction, sticking together, or passing by each other. It suggests why different types of cells behave differently and how interventions can change outcomes.

The model is more detailed than simple models that just look at how cells move together. It shows that cell shape and adhesion can have a big effect on how cells move. This is different from what would be expected from simpler models. The model also shows that combining cell shape and adhesion can lead to new effects not seen before.

The model was applied to neural crest cells and cancer cells. It can reproduce four types of collisions seen in these cells. This would not happen with a simpler model. The model shows that detailed interactions and cell dynamics are needed to understand how cells interact. It shows that combining cell shape and biochemistry can lead to unexpected effects, such as adhesion not always making cells walk past each other.

Collective cell movement is important for many biological processes, like the immune system, development, and cancer. Cell interactions drive new dynamics not seen in single cells.
Researchers have been trying to figure out how thioredoxin (Tr) breaks down its mixed disulfide complex for over 20 years. A mixed disulfide is a type of chemical bond between two sulfur atoms. Thiorexin is a protein that helps convert oxidized proteins back to their normal state. To study this process, scientists looked at a complex between thiorexin and a protein called arsenate reductase (Ars). They found that a sulfur atom in thiore (CysTr) attacks another sulfur in Ars (CysArs) to form a disulfide. Then, another sulfur in thiore (CysTr) attacks the disulf to break it apart. This sulfur in thiore (CysTr) is more reactive than the other sulfur in Ars (ysArs). The study used computer simulations and experiments to see how thiore breaks down the disulf. They found that the sulfur in thiore (CTr) changes shape to make it easier for it to attack the disulf and break it apart. This helps us understand how thiorexin works to convert oxidized proteins back to normal.
People's preferences are not fixed and can change based on what others' choices. Researchers tested this idea in a study of 700 14-24 year olds. They found that people are uncertain about their own preferences and can learn from others' choices. This uncertainty is reflected in their choices before and after seeing others' preferences. A model, called the taste-uncertainty (K) model, showed that people update their preferences based on new information. The study found that people's variability in choices is due to uncertainty, not just random noise. When people see others' choices, they update their beliefs about their own preferences. This is a new way of learning, called Bayesian updating. The study suggests that people are uncertain about their own preferences and can change based on others' choices. This has implications for understanding brain development and decision-making.
Scientists have been trying to understand how different signals in a cell come together to create a single response. In yeast, multiple pathways control a complex process called filamentous growth, which happens under specific conditions. To study this, researchers used a new method called secretion profiling to measure the release of a protein called Ms2, which is involved in filament growth. They found that many pathways that regulate growth were also required for the Ms2 pathway to work. This made the pathway more sensitive to signals and connected it to the cell's global network. Several regulators were needed for Ms2 expression, showing it's a key point where signals meet. The promoter of Ms2 was also controlled by a protein called HDAC, which helped the pathway and growth. This study shows how pathways that control growth are connected and work together to create a complex response.
Researchers studied how changes in gene expression contribute to the evolution of different body shapes in filamentous fungi. They grew five species of fungi, Sordomycetes, in a common environment and measured gene expression at five stages of development. They found genes that increased in expression led to changes in fruit body shape. Knocking out these genes in two species showed altered fruiting body development. This approach was more efficient than studying whole genomes or gene families. Combining gene expression with knockout helped refine networks of genes controlling fruit body development, a complex process in multicellular organisms.

Fungal fruiting bodies have similar stages but different shapes. This makes them ideal for studying how common and different developmental sources of similar traits and how new traits arise despite existing networks. The researchers found key genes in Neurospora and Fusarium for sexual development and reproduction. They used a systematic approach by comparing gene expression across species. Mapping variations in developmental processes is key to understanding evolution.

Bayesian networks based on gene expression are hypothetical until verified by specific studies. Combining with knockout helps understand relationships among genes in a process and how they evolved. Estimating expression in ancestral lineages identifies changes that may lead to new traits. If complex traits depend on gene changes, morphology should map to expression changes.
Scientists have found a new way to introduce genetic material into the eggs of a parasite called Schistosoma, which causes a disease in humans. This parasite has a high ratio of germ cells to non-germ cells, making it a good target for genetic modification. The researchers used a technique called electroporation to deliver genes and molecules into the eggs. They tested it with fluorescent RNA, messenger RNA, and a virus. The results showed that electrop was more effective than just soaking the eggs in the material. The virus was detected in the eggs and the larvae that hatched from them. The virus was also found in the germ cells of the larvae, which is important for genetic modification. The study suggests that electrop is a good way to introduce genes into Schosoma eggs.
Researchers have developed a new approach called Perturbation Markov Transmission (PM) to study the dynamic behavior of large molecular assemblies in cells. These assemblies are crucial for various biological processes and signaling between different parts of the cell. Previous studies have looked at the topology and fluctuations of these networks, but not the time-dependent behavior. The PM model monitors responses of over 8,000 residues across 6 decades of time after a perturbation, using a method called Klov subspace projection. It can identify key residues for movement, signaling, and binding. The team applied this to the Gro-Gro chaper system and found 71-84% accuracy with experimental studies. This method is general and can be used for other assemblies like viruses and ribosomes.
Researchers have discovered that a type of carbohydrate-binding protein called galectin from a mushroom, Coprinopsis cinerea, is toxic to the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans. When fed to the nematode, the galectin, called CGL2, inhibited its development and ultimately led to its death. The researchers found that the toxicity depends on the interaction between the galectin and a specific sugar-containing molecule on the nemode's surface. They identified the sugar molecule as a Gal1,4Fuc1,6 modification of the nemode's N-glycan core. The study suggests that fungal galectins play a role in defense against predators by binding to specific sugar molecules on their prey. To test the galectin's toxicity, researchers fed nemodes with E. coli bacteria expressing the galectin or a defective version that can't bind carbohydrates. They found that nemodes lacking a specific sugar on their surface were resistant to the galect's toxicity. Another galect from a different mushroom, Agaricus bisporus, was also toxic to nemodes. This led researchers to the hypothesis that galectins help fungi defend against predators like nematodes. They found that C. cin galect C2 was toxic to C. elegans and identified the sugar it binds to as Gal1,4uc,6 modification of the nem's N-gcan core. This modification is also found in other animals like octopus and squid. The researchers found a gene that may be involved in making this sugar modification, which could shed light on its function.
A long-lived reservoir of latently infected CD4 T cells is a major barrier to curing HIV and has been extensively studied, but its effect on the virus's evolutionary dynamics has received little attention. Researchers developed a within-host quasis model that incorporates a long-lived reservoir and nested it into an epidemiological model of HIV dynamics. They found that the presence of a reservoir severely delays evolutionary dynamics within a host, with longer delays associated with larger reservoir sizes and homeostatic proliferation of cells within the reservoir. These delays change the dynamics of the virus at the epidemiological scale. The delay in within evolutionary can be sufficient for the virus to evolve intermediate loads consistent with maximising transmission, as observed, not the high loads previous models predicted. This effect can be enhanced if viruses similar to those initiating infection are preferentially transmitted. The results depend on within characteristics such as reservoir size, with evolution observed only when dynamics are sufficiently delayed. The reservoir has an underappreciated role in both within and between-host evolution.
Researchers studied how the Coxsackievirus B3 (CV3) virus evades the immune system by looking at how it affects the presentation of antigens to T cells. Antigens are proteins on the surface of infected cells that T cells recognize to fight the virus. They used special T cells that can detect specific antigens to see how CV3 affects antigen presentation in the body. They found that CV3 almost completely stops the presentation of antigens to CD8 T cells, which are a type of T cell that kills infected cells. However, it doesn't stop presentation to CD4 cells, another type of T cell that helps other cells. CD4 cells can still recognize CV3 and fight it, and even remember it for later to fight again. This is important because it shows how CV3 avoids being detected by the immune system.
Researchers conducted a study to compare the effectiveness of high-dose intravenous methylprednisone and oral prednisone versus intravenous saline and oral prednisone in treating leprosy Type 1 reactions and nerve function impairment. Forty-two individuals were randomly assigned to receive methylprednisone followed by predone or predone alone. There were no significant differences in the rate of adverse events or improvement at the end of the study. However, those treated with methylprednis were less likely to experience deterioration in sensory function between day 29 and 113. The study also found that 50% of individuals with Type 1 reactions and nerve impairment required additional predone despite 16 weeks of corticosteroids. This supports the use of prolonged corticosteroid treatment for Type 1 reactions and investigation of factors for recurrence after corticoid treatment.
Researchers studied how regulatory T cells (Treg) affect CD8 T cells in people with chronic HIV infection. They found that Treg cells from HIV-infected individuals (Treg/HIV) did not suppress autologous CD8 T cell function as well as T cells from HIV-negative individuals (T/H-). However, T/H inhibited IFNγ expression of autolog CD8 cells stimulated with CMV/EBV/Flu (CEF) antigens, but not HIV-specific CD8 cells. In cross cultures, T/H suppressed differentiation of CEF or HIV-specific CD8 cells from infected patients. PD-1 and PD-L expression was higher on HIV-specific CD8 cells compared to CEF CD8 cells, and did not change after T depletion or co-culture with T/H. The study shows T/H defect in modulating differentiation and PD-1/P-L expression on HIV CD8 cells. This defect might contribute to exhaustion of HIV-specific T responses. Treg mostly suppressed differentiation of effector-memory CD8 cells in HIV-infected patients. HIV-specific CD8 cells were less sensitive to Treg suppression than recall-specific CD8 cells. HIV-specific effector CD8 cells were resistant to Treg modulation of exhaustion molecules PD-1/PDL. Results suggest CD8 cells are defective in IFγ production and sensitivity to Treg, or T could be less suppressive. In HIV infection, T exert subset-specific inhibitory effects on CD8 cells. Failure to contain HIV-associated activation is due to impaired T function and decreased responsiveness of effector clones, associated with high PD-1/P-L levels.
Researchers have evaluated Wuchereria bancrofti's glutathione-transferase (GST) as a potential vaccine candidate for lymphatic filariasis. The parasite's GST helps it survive in the lymphatic system by countering oxidative radicals produced by the host. Previous studies have shown GSTs from other parasites can be used as vaccines, but not from lymphatic parasites. This study cloned the GST gene from Wuchereria bancroft's third larval DNA, expressed and purified the recombinant GST (rWGST). Serum from individuals living in an endemic area showed significant levels of anti-WGST IgG antibodies compared to those with microfilaria or clinical symptoms. Isotype analysis showed IgG and Ig3 antibodies in endemic individuals. Functional analysis showed rGST retained enzymatic activity and antibodies inhibited it. Similar results were seen with anti-rGST antibodies in mice. Brugia mal GST and Wucher bancroft show sequence similarity. To evaluate rGST's potential, Brug mal was used as a challenge. Results showed 61% protection in jirds immunized with rGST. The study suggests rGST is a potential vaccine against lymphatic filariasis.
CRISPR-C9 technologies have revolutionized genome editing of experimental organisms and hold great promise for therapy. Despite advances in understanding the CRPR-C9 system, concerns remain about potential off-target effects. Recent studies used whole-genome sequencing of edited embryos to find new mutations that might be caused by poor editing. However, these studies used strain-matched but not pedigree-matched controls, making it hard to tell if changes were due to editing or other factors. This study used a trio design, sequencing parents and 19 embryos, 10 of which were edited with well-characterized gRNAs targeting the coat color gene. Detailed analysis found that if CR9 editing caused mutations or off-target changes, the number was not different from background mutations caused by other factors. This supports using CR9 as a therapeutic tool.
Scientists have discovered two new players, Hypersensitive to Red 1 (HR1) and Phosphatase 7 (PP), that help control the opening and closing of stomata, tiny pores on plant leaves, which regulate carbon dioxide uptake and water loss. Stomatal aperture affects photosynthesis, water efficiency, and crop yields. Blue light is one of the signals that regulates stomatal opening and is perceived by blue/UV light-absorbing cryptochromes phototropins. The researchers found that mutations in HR1 or PP lead to misregulation of stomatal aperture and reduced water loss under light. Both HR1 and PP are expressed in guard cells in response to light-dark or dark-light transition. HR1 interacts with PP through its N-terminal zinc finger motif and requires PP for stomatal response. HR1 is phosphorylated in vivo and PP dephosphylates HR1. In the dark, HR1 is dephosphylated in a 193kDa complex, while light increases to 285Da. In PP mutant, this shift is impaired and HR1 is predominantly phosphorylated. The study proposes that HR modification by PP under light is essential for proper HR1 conformation and assembly.
Researchers have identified a key component of the Mediator complex, a protein called MDT-15, in the nematode worm Caenorhabditis elegans that plays a crucial role in adapting to the materials ingested by the worm. MDT-15 is a subunit of the Mediator, a complex that helps regulate gene expression by interacting with various transcription factors. The study found that MDT-15 is involved in detoxifying certain toxins and heavy metals, making the worm more sensitive to exposure. However, it does not affect other stress responses such as heat tolerance. MDT-15 also regulates genes involved in fatty acid metabolism and nutrient availability. The researchers propose that MDT-15 integrates multiple pathways to monitor the quality and availability of ingested materials, including nutrients and toxins. The study used microarrays to identify MDT-15 targets and found it interacts with at least two metabolic factors, NHR-49 and SBP-1. MDT-15 was previously found to regulate genes in fatty acid metabolism and fasting response. The study suggests MDT-15 is part of a system that ensures health and longevity by adapting to ingestion-related stress.
Researchers have long believed that the hippocampus, a brain region responsible for spatial navigation, encodes geometric information such as distances and angles. However, since it consists of patterns of spiking neurons, downstream regions must translate these patterns into accurate information about an animal's environment. The researchers hypothesized that the pattern of neuronal firing, particularly co-firing, is key to decoding spatial information and since coiring implies spatial overlap of place fields, a map by coiring will be based on connectivity and adjacency, a topological. They tested this hypothesis with a model of hippocampal activity, varying parameters firing rate, place size, and number of neurons in simulations of rat trajectories in topologically and geometrically distinct environments. Using computational tools from algebraic topology, they found that patterns of coiring convey topological information in biologically realistic time. Simulations revealed a "learning" region where interplay between parameters produce hippocal states more or less adept at map formation. For example, lower number of neurons can be compensated by adjustments firing or place size, but beyond point formation fails. They propose this region provides a lens to view conditions impairing spatial by altering cell rates or specificity.
Researchers have been trying to understand how the hepatitis C virus (HCV) is released from infected cells, but the process is not fully understood. They used a technique called RNA interference (RNAi) to identify host genes involved in HCV release and combined it with live cell imaging to track the virus's movement. The study found that HCV uses the cell's secretory pathway to exit, which is also used by other viruses in the same family. This pathway involves the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), Golgi, and vesicles, and recycling endosomes. The researchers identified several proteins that help HCV move through this pathway, including those involved in vesicle formation, sorting, and transport to the plasma membrane. They also found that HCV interacts with apolipoprotein E and VAMP vesicles. To understand how HCV moves, they created a tagged version of the virus and tracked its movement. The core protein moved to the cell's periphery and interacted with microtubules, but was blocked by a drug. Some core also went to the Golgi and interacted with recycling endosomes. Silencing a recycling component caused core to accumulate in the Gol. The majority of core interacted with apolipop E and VAMP vesicles. This study reveals new proteins involved in HCV release and shows how it moves in infected cells.
Researchers have found that the loss of a specific gene called Grb10 can contribute to the formation of tumors in mice with a weakened immune system. Gr10 is an imprinted gene, meaning it is expressed from only one parent and loss of the expressed allele leads to complete loss of protein. The study used mice with a weakened immune system, called NF1, to model tumors that arise in people with this condition. Analysis of tumor cells from these mice showed Gr10 was not expressed. Further analysis found that the expressed allele of Gr10 is commonly lost in NF tumors in these mice. The researchers tested if restoring or losing Gr10 would change tumor growth features. Restoring Gr10 in weakened tumors decreased growth, reduced colony formation, and downregulated Ras signaling. Conversely, silencing Gr10 in normal cells increased growth and Ras levels. Expression of a constantly active MEK rescued cells from Gr10 reduction in colony formation. This study shows Gr10 loss can occur in tumor formation and affects normal cells. In weakened mice, Gr10 loss promotes Ras hyperactivation, a feature of tumor development. This work identifies a new role for an imprinted gene in tumor formation and suggests considering imprinted genes' origin in disease.
Researchers investigated how humans learn to predict threats from environmental cues, a fundamental skill found in many species, through Pavlovian fear conditioning. This process involves associating neutral cues with aversive events. Despite many studies on neural mechanisms, computational understanding is fragmented, with different models giving opposing predictions for trial-by-trial dynamics of learning, such as autonomic nervous system (ANS) activity. The team used a statistical framework for psychophysiological modeling to obtain precise, trial-by-trial, single-subject estimates of ANS responses. They considered non-probabilistic, probabilistic, and non-learning models, as well as different functions to link models with AN activity. Across three experiments, skin conductance (SCR) and pupil size (PS) responses were measured. A probabilistic model best explained ANS responses, with SCR tracking expected uncertainty and outcome, and PS tracking outcome alone. Combining psychophysiological with learning theory, the team found Pavlov threat in humans relies on probabilistic inference and uncertainty estimation. This could inform neural implementation of aversive learning theories.
Researchers have identified a new regulator of fungal reproduction in the fungus Aspergillus nidulans, called Pom, which suppresses the septation and conidiation process. Septation is the process of cell division in fungi, while conidiation is the production of spores for reproduction. Without Pom, the fungus has defects in septation and conidiation, and overexpressing Pom stops septation. Normally, the protein Sep promotes the phosphorylation of Hog, a protein involved in stress response, while Pom reverses this process. Under stress conditions, Hog is phosphorylated and can bypasses the need for Sep, but not the entire septation process. The study shows interaction between the septation and stress pathways, with Pom and Sep regulating Hog phosphorylation through upstream kinases. 

In normal conditions, Sep promotes Hog phosphorylation, while Pom reverses it. Under stress, Hog is phosphorylated and can bypasses Sep, but not the entire septation process. The study shows interaction between septation and stress pathways, with Pom and Sep regulating Hog phosphorylation through kinases. The researchers found that Sep, a kinase, promotes septation, while Pom suppresses it. Sep promotes Hog phosphorylation, while Pom reverses it. Under stress, Hog is phosphorylated and bypasses Sep, but not septation. The study shows interaction between septation and stress, with Pom and Sep regulating Hog phosphorylation through kinases.
Researchers investigated the association between Leish RNA virus 1 (LRV1) and mucosal manifestations of tegumentary leishmaniasis (TL) in 156 patients in Brazil. TL is endemic in Latin America and causes 20,000 cases per year, but its pathogenesis is not fully understood. Clinical manifestations vary from cutaneous leishias (CL) to severe disseminated leishias (DL), mucosal leishias (ML), and diffuse cutaneous leish (DCL). LRV1 was previously linked to severity in animal models. The study found 5 Leishmania species: 121 (77.6%) Leishmania (Viann) brazili, 18 (11.5%) Leish (V) guyensis, 3 (1.8) Leish (V) laini, 2 (1.3) Leish (Le) amazonensis, and 2 (1.3) Leish (V) shawi. LRV was detected in 6 (3.9%) samples. Patients with CL+ML and DCL were excluded. Among 147 remaining patients, 71.1% (n=27) mucosal lesions were LRV+ and 28.9% (n=11) LRV-, while 36.7% (n=40) cutaneous lesions were LRV+ and 63.3 (n=69) LRV-. The ratio LRV+/LRV- was 2.93 (CI 1.57-5.46, p<0.001), indicating LRV association with mucosal leishias. LRV was not the only factor contributing to disease.
Type I interferon (IFN) plays a crucial role in protecting against pneumocococcal disease by preventing bacteria from migrating from the lungs into the bloodstream. Researchers found that mice lacking the type I interferon receptor (Ifnar−/−) or treated with a neutralizing antibodies against type interferon had more bacteria in their blood after being infected with pneumocococcus, while having similar amounts in their lungs. In contrast, treating mice with interferon or a synthetic RNA that induces interferon reduced bacteria in the blood after pneumococcus infection. Interferon increased tight junction proteins and decreased the pneumococcus receptor platelet activating factor (PAF) receptor. This led to reduced pneumoc invasion and migration across epithelial and endothelial layers, and increased lung permeability in Ifnar− mice. The study identifies interferon as a key component of the immune system that regulates two mechanisms involved in pneumoc invasion: PAF-mediated transcytosis and tight junction-dependent pericellular migration, limiting lung infection progression to invasive disease.
Researchers have developed a neural network with multiple layers that can learn and solve complex tasks, such as foraging, by combining two types of plasticity: rewarded and non-rewarded spike-dependent plasticity (STDP). The network consists of three layers: an input, hidden, and output. The hidden layer uses non-rewarded STDP to respond to specific combinations of inputs and classify patterns, while the output layer uses rewarded ST to learn and make decisions. This combination allows the network to learn without labeled data and distinguish between rewarding and punishing patterns. Synaptic noise enables trial-and-error learning to identify effective strategies for solving the task. The study shows that a set of properties of spiking networks with ST can solve complex tasks involving pattern recognition and decision-making.
A protein called ELF5 plays a key role in the development of a type of breast cancer called luminal breast cancer. In this cancer, ELF helps the cancer cells grow and spread to other parts of the body, such as the lungs. ELF does this by recruiting a type of immune cell called myeloid-derived suppressor cells. These cells are immature neutrophils that help the cancer grow and spread. When these cells are removed, the number of lung metastases decreases. In a mouse model of luminal breast cancer, ELF was found to increase the number of immune cells in the tumor and blood vessels, making it easier for cancer to spread. This was also seen in human breast cancer, where high ELF levels of the protein were linked to shorter survival and faster disease progression. The study suggests that ELF is a factor in the spread of luminal breast cancer.
Recent research has shown that the interaction between chromatin loops plays a crucial role in determining the level of cell-to-cell variability in gene expression. Chromatin loops are characterized by three factors: connection pattern, distance between regulatory elements, and communication. To understand how these factors affect gene expression, a model was developed that maps three patterns of interacting DNA loops into a 4-state model of transcription. The study found that nested loops enhance mRNA expression and reduce noise, while alternating loops have opposite effects. Comparing facilitated and direct looping on gene expression, facilitated performs better in controlling mean and tuning noise, but control is distance-dependent, with a limit to loop length where the difference between forms disappears. The results support the chromatin-looping hypothesis.
Researchers have developed a new way to design a type of RNA called riboregulators that can control gene expression without the need for extra proteins. These riboregulators, called translation inhibiting RNAs (tiRNAs), work by blocking translation initiation, the first step in gene expression. To design them, they analyzed 12 features related to thermodynamics and structure that affect translation. From a library of 12,000 tiRNAs, 18 were selected and tested with two target genes. Results showed repression of up to 60% of original protein levels, which was partially explained by a statistical model. A model was built to link tiRNA properties to repression, showing both structure and thermodynamics are important for efficient repression. This approach allows for more reliable design of effective ribg, expanding the toolbox for gene modulation.
Researchers studied how groups of neurons in the brain's cortex communicate with each other to create memories and behaviors. They recorded electrical activity from multiple points in the brain of awake monkeys and lab-grown-up brain tissue. They found that when a group of neurons gets too active, its activity spreads quickly to other parts of the brain through electrical signals. These large electrical signals, called coherence potentials, last for hundreds of milliseconds and carry information like single-cell signals. However, they have a unique shape, allowing them to encode and identify specific connections. This behavior is similar to how ideas spread in social networks.

Previous studies used similar changes in electrical signals to identify connected groups of neurons. They also found waves traveling between brain areas. This raises questions about how signals spread across brain regions and interact. The study's data showed that coherence preserves the pattern of activity, suggesting it carries meaningful information. The shape of the signal is a better predictor of behavior than single-cell signals, supporting this idea. Researchers looked for the underlying pattern of activity associated with coherence. Their recordings represent many neurons, but only a few near the electrode can be seen, a small sample of the activity.
Scientists have long known that the size of a cell's nucleus is related to its overall size, but the exact mechanism behind this relationship is unclear. To investigate this, researchers conducted a genetic screen in yeast to identify essential factors involved in controlling nuclear size. They found 25 factors that affect nuclear size and discovered that RNA processing and LINC complexes play a crucial role in this process. The study revealed a wide range of nuclear sizes, from small to large, and pinpointed specific cellular processes and structural components important for size control. 

The researchers used yeast to generate cells with varying sizes, observing a consistent ratio of nuclear to cell volume. They found that nuclear size increases with cell volume during the cell cycle, maintaining a constant ratio. However, there's a sudden increase in size during DNA replication. Yeast Schizoscharomyces pombe is a useful for studying nuclear control due to its simplicity and closed mitosis. A screen of non-essential mutants implicated nucleocytoplasmic transport and lipid biosynthesis in size control. This suggests regulation of global processes, nucleoplasmic transcription and cytoplasm translation, and specific nuclear components are important for size. In multicellular organisms, the ratio varies between cell types but is generally within a narrow range. There's evidence that volume is determined by volume or related to it, not directly by DNA. Volume correlates with across a range in both budding and fission yeasts.
Deep brain stimulation (DB) is a treatment for neurological disorders like Parkinson's disease and essential tremor (ET). Current DB involves delivering constant pulses through electrodes implanted in the brain, but "closed-loop" approaches adjust stimulation based on brain activity, potentially improving efficiency and reducing side effects. Success depends on devising a strategy that minimizes neural oscillations associated with symptoms. A step towards this is creating a mathematical model describing how oscillations change with stimulation. Our work uses coupled oscillators to represent neurons generating pathological oscillations, analyzing how patients respond to stimulation with given phase and amplitude under certain conditions. We predict the best strategy is phase-specific and stimulation has more effect when oscillation amplitude is lower. This is compared with ET patient data. We propose a new strategy combining phase-locked and adaptive DB.
Researchers have developed a new test, called Biom-LAMP, to detect a parasite called Schistosoma mansoni in a type of snail called Biomalaria glabrata. This parasite causes a disease called schistosias, which affects over 230 million people worldwide. The new test is a rapid and simple way to detect the parasite in snails, which can help control the spread of the disease. It uses a technique called looped isothermal amplification, which makes many copies of the parasite's DNA, making it easier to detect. The test was tested on snails infected with different amounts of the parasite and was able to detect it in all of them. It can be used on individual snails or groups of snails, making it suitable for large-scale surveys in areas where schosias is common. The test is specific, sensitive, and cost-effective, and can be used in areas with basic laboratory facilities. This is important for controlling the spread of schias in areas where it is common.
Dengue, a mosquito-borne disease, has been a major public health concern in Sri Lanka since the 1960s. The Ministry of Health is responsible for controlling deng and other outbreaks, and providing care to those affected. Controlling deng and treating patients in hospitals is a significant burden on the public health sector. This study estimated the costs of deng control and hospitalizations in Colombo, the most urban district in Sri Lanka, in 2012 from the Ministry's perspective. The total cost of deng control and hospitalizations was $3.45 million, or $1.50 per capita. Personnel costs made up 79% of deng control and 46% of hospital costs. The average cost per deng control was $0.42. Hospital costs ranged from $216 to $609 for pediatric and $196 to $866 for adult cases, depending on severity and treatment. This study is the first to assess the economic burden of deng on the public sector in Sri Lanka. The results suggest deng is a significant burden on the health sector.
A new study has re-examined the origins of the most common European Y-chromosome lineage, Haplog Rb1b2 (R-M269), which is carried by 110 million men. Previous research suggested it originated in the Paleolithic era, but this study shows its distribution is best explained by a single source in the Near East during the Neolithic period. This means most European Y-chromosomes come from the Neolithic expansion. This pattern contrasts with maternally inherited DNA, which suggests males played a unique role in the transition. The Neolithic expansion brought significant cultural and technological changes, and this study shows Y-chromosome lineages often accompany these changes. Other European lineages, such as Hg1b1 (E35) and J, also show Neolithic origins, indicating most European Y-chromes come from this period. The study used microsatellites to analyze diversity within the lineage, showing it spread from a single source in Anatolia during the Neolithic. This challenges previous findings that suggested a Paleolithic origin based on high frequency in the west. Mitochondrial DNA shows a different picture, with no east-west line and most lineages having Paleolithic signatures.
Researchers have explored the relationship between movement variability and motor learning, suggesting that increased variability can speed up the learning process. However, a computational model of motor adaptation shows that variability can have both positive and negative effects on learning. Experiments also found decelerating effects, and a meta-analysis of published papers found no statistical relation between variability and learning rate across a wide range of experiments. Motor learning is a complex process that can be modeled, but further research is needed to understand the importance of involved factors.

 Simulations showed that increased variability does not typically enable faster learning and sometimes slows it down, but doesn't preclude a possible positive correlation between variability and learning rate. Factors can affect learning and variability in distinct ways, leading to positive, negative, or zero relations between them. It's hypothesized that variability is correlated with learning in a task-specific way, depending on which factor affects performance. Computer simulations of error-based learning with an optimal model showed variability as a problem for motor control and received attention. Studies on variability and learning are sparse, except that reduction is a characteristic of learning.

Simulations suggest the relation between variability and rate varies in adaptation, depending on which factor dominates performance in a task. Divergent results can be explained by uncertainty or noise. People converge to solutions where variability minimally impacts accuracy. A study showed initial variability predicts learning in reinforcement and motor tasks, the first to show facilitatory effect for error-based adaptation.
Scientists have studied how a protein called RelA interacts with another protein called CB/p300 to help turn on genes involved in the immune response and inflammation. Rel is part of a family of proteins called NFκ that helps cells survive and grow. To turn on genes, Rel interacts with CB/p300 and other proteins on DNA. The Rel:CB/p300 complex is made of two parts: Rel's DNA part binds to CB300's K domain, and Rel's activation part to CB's T1 domain. A specific event, Rel's Ser276 being phosphorylated, is needed for this to happen. The role of this interaction in turning on Rel's genes was unclear. Researchers used NMR to see the structure of the Rel:CB complex and found that Rel's activation part folds when binding to CB's T1 through hydrophobic sites. They also made Rel mutants to block the interaction and found that many more genes turned on by Rel are affected than thought. This interaction controls NF's response through a feedback loop and CB/p300 is already on Rel's target gene promoters.
Researchers have developed a new method called Time-course Gene Set Analysis (TSA) to analyze gene expression data from repeated measurements over time. This method is an extension of gene set analysis, which considers groups of genes together in analysis. Unlike previous methods, TSA can use all available measurements, even if some are missing, and accounts for differences within gene sets. It identifies significant changes in gene expression over time and compares patterns between conditions. The method was tested on two real datasets: an HIV vaccine trial and a study on influenza and pneumocococcal vaccines. In the HIV trial, TSA found significant changes in 69 gene sets over time, while other methods failed to detect any pattern. In the influenza study, TSA identified 4 gene sets linked to the vaccine, but not previously associated with pneumococcal vaccine. Simulations showed TSA has good statistical properties and increased power compared to other methods. The method is available as an R package.
Researchers have created a detailed map of the global distribution of Plasmodium vivax, a parasite that causes malaria, to help control and eliminate the disease. Current understanding of P. vivax was limited compared to P. falciparum, making it hard to develop strategies for control. The team used data from 9,970 surveys from 1985 to 2010 and a statistical model to estimate the parasite rate in every 5x5 km square. They also included data on Duffy negativity, a trait that affects P. viv transmission. The map shows P. viv is present in a narrow range worldwide, with high areas mostly in the Americas, Africa, and Asia. The Americas have 22% of the risk area but only 6% of the 2.5 billion people at risk. Africa has 3.5% of risk due to Duffy negativity. Asia has 82% of risk with high areas in India and Myanmar. East Asia has the highest risk in Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. This map will help plan P. viv control and elimination.
Staphylococcus aureus, a common bacteria that causes skin and soft tissue infections, has a protein called clumping factor B (ClB) that helps it stick to host cells and evade the immune system, making it more virulent. Previous research showed ClB helps S. aureus colonize the nose by binding to a protein called loric in the nasal tissue. However, its role in skin infections was unknown. This study found ClB plays a crucial role in skin infections, affecting abscess formation and bacterial load early on. It interacts with loric, a protein in abs tissue. A vaccine targeting ClB induced both antibody and cell responses, protecting against S. aureus skin infection. This study identifies Cl as a key antigen for future skin infection vaccines.
To achieve the UNAIDS goal of reducing new HIV infections to 500,000 by 2020, pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a key strategy. Truv, a medication currently approved for EP, is costly and requires daily dosing. To improve EP, next-generation regimens, including long-acting formulations, are being investigated. However, preclinical testing often fails to translate to clinical efficacy, and quantifying prophylactic efficacy in the clinic is ethically problematic. To prioritize and design EP regimens, tools are needed that integrate pharmacological, viral, and host factors. A stochastic approach was developed to predict prophyl efficacy, using dolutegravir (DT) as an example. Combining DT's population pharmacokinetics with the framework, predicted plasma concentrations of 145.18 and 722.23nM prevent 50 and 90% transmissions respectively. Daily EP with 50mg DT prevented 99-100 infections, and 85 when 50% of dosing events were missed. EP 'on' prevented 79-84 infections and P >80 when initiated within 6 hours and continued. The framework can be adapted to other EP candidates, indicating oral 50 DT is inferior to Truv. Predicted 90 concentrations guide release kinetics of DT nano-formulations.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) uses autophagy to enhance its replication, but how it regulates the autophagy pathway is unclear. Researchers found that HCV induces the expression of Rubicon and UVR, which inhibit and stimulate the maturation of autophagosomes, respectively. Rubicon is induced early, while UVR is delayed, leading to accumulation of autagosomes in early in infection. Rubicon inhibits maturation of autag in H-infected cells, confirmed by siRNA knockdown and overexpression. Rubicon enhances maturation of autag. Rub plays a role in H replication, suppressing its expression reduces H replication and overexpression enhances. In contrast, overexpression UVR facilitates maturation autag and suppresses H replication. The H subgenomic RNA replicon, expressing nonstructural proteins, induces Rubicon and autag accumulation. Analysis shows NS4 protein induces Rubicon and autag. Results indicate H, by inducing Rub and UVR, temporally regulates autagy to enhance replication.
Cyclin-like 1 (Cny1) is a newly identified member of the cyclin family that is highly similar in protein sequence to Cyclin (Cny). However, its function is poorly characterized in any organism.
