A study was conducted in a protected area in southeastern Brazil to investigate the transmission of visceral leishmaniasis (VL), a disease caused by Leishmania parasites. The area, known as Campinas, initially reported a case in 2009 and since then cases were restricted to dogs living in two contiguous condominiums. The study found 1.5% and 1.2% seroprevalence in dogs in 2013 and 201, respectively. Six species of sand flies were identified as vectors or potential transmitters of Leishmania, including the main vector in Brazil, Lutzia longalipis. Two specimens were captured in the area. Infection was recorded in two wild animals, Pomy monticola and Expillatai firm. Infection was also detected in two white-eared opossums, a known reservoir of VL. Coordinates of infected animals were plotted on a map, showing proximity to human residences and infected dogs. The area has an active focus of VL. The risk of transmission in similar areas with environmental modifications is evident. Different epidemiological profiles must be considered for prevention and control measures.
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a cancer-causing virus linked to nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), a highly aggressive type of cancer common in Asia. While some viral proteins have been shown to promote cancer cell migration and invasion, not all tumors express these proteins, suggesting other mechanisms are at play. Researchers found that EB virus-encoded microRNA miR-B9 is highly expressed in EB-positive NPC tissues. They investigated miR9's effect in EB-negative and EB-positive NPC cells and found it promotes cell migration and invasion in vitro and metastasis in vivo. Computational analysis showed miR9 targets E-cadher, a protein crucial for cell-cell junctions and epithelial phenotype. Biochemical assays confirmed mi9 inhibits Eadher to induce mesenchymal phenotype and promote NPC migration. This suggests mi9 is a promastatic viralRNA and high levels in EB-positive NPC may contribute to aggressive tumor behavior.
Researchers have developed a new software tool called gashimi for visualizing splicing events in RNA-seq data. Unlike existing tools, gimi is annotation-independent and can handle large genomic regions by scaling down segments between splice sites. It's available on GitHub and implemented in Python, generating R code for plotting. The tool was initially part of the MISO suite, which quantifies and compares splicing from RNA-seq data. Current implementations include a standalone utility for MISO-indexed splicing and IGV's built-in visualization. Visualizing splicing is challenging as events occur between non-contiguous regions, distant in space. Gimi aggregates samples and shrinks intron lengths for better visualization. The sash representation is a standard for splicing, but current implementations have limitations. Gimi addresses these by eliminating annotation needs and supporting hundreds of samples. It draws a connective element illustrating splice junctions between sites.
Researchers have developed a new model to predict and align cis-regulatory modules (CRMs) across species, which are crucial for gene regulation. Current methods struggle with aligning non-coding sequences and don't account for CRMs' special properties. The new model captures evolution modes of transcription factor binding sites and background sequences. A key feature is a probabilistic model of site gains and losses, a significant in regulatory evolution. A computational framework uses this model to solve alignment and prediction problems. The method is similar to statistical alignment but uses conserved sites to improve alignment. It deals with uncertainties of site annotations and sequence in a probabilistic framework. Simulated and real data show it outperforms state-of-the-art methods. Alignments were used to study genome-wide binding of key factors in Drosophila blasterm, revealing: factor-bound sequences are constrained even if neighboring genes aren't expressed, and distal sites are more conserved than proximal. The approach is implemented as software, EM (Evolutionary Model cis-regulatory Module) for broad application.
Researchers studied the role of the piRNA pathway in Drosophila, a type of fruit fly, in maintaining genome integrity and telomere protection. They found that mutations in genes arm, aub, ago3, and rhi led to extensive fragmentation of the zygotic genome during embryonic cleavage divisions. Additionally, aub and arm showed defects in telomere resolution during meiosis and cleavage divisions, while mutations in lig-IV, which disrupt non-homous end joining, suppressed fusions. By contrast, lig-IV mutations enhanced chromosome fragmentation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation studies showed that aub and arm mutations disrupted telom binding of HO, a component of the telere protection complex, and reduced expression of a subpopulation 19-22-ntelom-specific piRN. Mutations in r and ago, however, did not block HO binding or production of theseRNAs. These findings uncovered separable functions for the Dophila pi pathway. The a, arm, r, and ago genes silenced transons and maintained chromosome integrity during cleavage embryonic divisions, while a and arm had an additional function in assembly of the telere complex.
Researchers have identified a new Ebola virus responsible for a hemorrhagic fever outbreak in Uganda. The virus, called Bundibugyo ebolavirus, is closely related to another Ebola virus found in Côte d'Ivoire, despite being from a different part of Africa. This discovery is important for creating tests to detect Ebola in humans and animals, and developing treatments and vaccines. The new virus was found in 29 suspect blood samples using standard and a new DNA sequencing method. The outbreak in Uganda's Bundibyo District started in November 2007 with 7 cases, and spread to 149 cases and 37 deaths by December 2007. The new virus is less deadly than two other known Ebola viruses, with a 36% fatality rate compared to 80-90% for one and 50-55% for the other. More studies are needed to see if current vaccines protect against this new virus and to test its effects in animals. To control the outbreak, rapid tests were sent to Uganda to quickly identify cases. The outbreak ended in December 2007.
Researchers have found that Alzheimer's disease (AD) progresses at varying rates among patients, with some declining quickly and others slowly. To understand this variation, scientists analyzed data from 648 patients with an average 4.78-year follow-up period. They used the Global Deteration Scale (GDS) and Functional Staging (FAST) procedures, which break down AD into seven stages from normal to severe dementia. Each stage has a published average duration, but the variation was unknown. The study found that the standard deviations for stages 4-6 are similar to their means, indicating significant variation in decline among patients. This suggests that AD is a heterogeneous disease with different subgroups of patients experiencing different patterns of decline. A large dataset revealed significant variation in lengths of DS/FAST stages 4-6, with standard deviations similar to their means, indicating varying cognitive and functional decline. This supports the idea that AD is a complex disease with multiple factors contributing to its progression. The study used a 23-year dataset with patients at stages 4-7 of AD, showing large heterogeneity in DS/FAST durations consistent with previous reports. The DS and FAST procedures describe a continuum of 16 stages from normal to severe AD, with some differences between them. A 5-year follow-up study found association between frontal lobe involvement and rapid AD progression, and a 15-year study examined patterns of AD progression.
Researchers studied how the hippocampus, a part of the brain involved in memory, adapts to changing environments. They created a simplified model of the hippocampus to see how it encodes and decodes memory patterns. They found that adding new neurons, a process called neurogenesis, was more effective than changing existing neurons or their connections, called synaptic plasticity. This allowed the model to adapt to new environments while keeping old memories. They extended the model to include grid cells in the entorinal cortex, which provide spatial information. Compared three strategies: synaptic plasticity, where connections change but not number of neurons; turnover, where neurons die and are replaced; and neurogenesis, where new neurons are added. Neurogenesis outperformed the others. A more realistic rule that includes cell death and plasticity of new neurons performed better than each alone. This rule can be tailored for short or long-term memory. They also studied neurogenesis over an animal's lifetime under different conditions, showing distinct features that can be tested. Place cells emerged in a realistic way in the model due to dentate gyrus sparsification.
African trypanosomes, a type of parasite that causes sleeping sickness in humans and animals, have a special enzymes called peroxides that protect their cells from damage. These enzymes, called Px I and II, are found in the cell's liquid (cytosol) and mitochondria, a part of the cell that produces energy. Without these enzymes, the parasite's cells die quickly. Researchers found that the mitochondria is not the main source of damage, but the lysosome, a part of the cell that breaks down waste, is. The lysosome is damaged when the parasite takes in too much iron from its host, a process called endocytosis. The lysosome's damage leads to cell death. The enzymes Px I and II protect the lysosome from iron-induced damage. This process is linked to the parasite's high rate of taking in iron from its host. The study shows that the lysosome, not mitochondria, is the main site of damage in African trypanosomes.
Researchers have studied the role of a protein called PMEL in melanocytes, cells that produce melanin, the pigment responsible for skin and hair color. They created mice without the PM gene, called P−/−, and found they were viable and fertile with no developmental defects. However, their melanosomes, the structures where melanin accumulates, were spherical instead of the usual elongated shape. This was seen in skin and eye melanocytes. Inactivating PM had a mild effect on coat color in different genetic backgrounds, but reduced melanin content in hair, showing PM's role in maintaining epidermal pigmentation. The study suggests PM is essential for normal melanos shape but not survival of melanocytes.
A systematic review and meta-analysis of environmental methods for deng vector control was conducted to evaluate their effectiveness in preventing deng infections. Nineteen studies were eligible, with sixteen contributing to the meta-analysis. The methods evaluated were: container covers with and without insecticides, waste management and clean-up, and elimination of breeding sites. Quality was highest for container covers with insecticides, followed by waste without direct collection and elimination. Both review and meta showed a weak effect on larval populations, with no differences between results. For the meta, container without insect (BI: -7.9, DOE-5) and waste with collection (BI: -8.83, DOE-6.2) achieved strongest reductions for BI, while pupal results were opposite, with covers (P: -0.83, 0.09) and elimination (P: -0.95, -0.83) showing strongest. Each method showed effectiveness in reducing Aedes larval and pupal densities. However, more high-quality studies are needed to strengthen evidence. A previous studies concluded environmental management was effective, and community-based interventions reduced deng risk. This study aimed to review and meta environmental methods' effectiveness. Searches were finished in 2017, but no further studies altered results. All methods showed effectiveness in reducing Aedes densities, partly due to study design issues and linking control and transmission.
Researchers have identified small molecules that can selectively stall protein synthesis by the ribosome, a key to developing new treatments for diseases. These compounds, like PF-06303, inhibit PCSK9, a major regulator of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, reducing LDL in preclinical models and affecting few off-target proteins. However, their impact on cell physiology and ribosome control pathways is unknown. A genome-wide CRISPR screen was used to identify proteins and pathways that modulate growth in presence of high doses of PF-03. The most potent genetic modifiers of fitness were ubiquitin binding protein ASC2 and helicase ASC3, which bind to the ribosome and protect cells from PF03's toxic effects. Surprisingly, quality control proteins Pelota and H1 sensitize cells to PF03 treatment. Genetic experiments showed ASC3 acts with ASC2 and downstream of H1. These results connect ribosome control pathways and provide insights into selectivity of compounds that stall translation, aiding next-generation compounds to treat diseases.
Researchers have discovered that a protein from the Kaposi's sarcoma herpesvirus (KSH) called SO induces widespread destruction of cellular messenger RNA (mRNA) in host cells. This is a way for the virus to evade the immune system and block host gene expression. The mechanism behind this process was unknown, as SO doesn't have an enzyme that breaks down RNA. The study found that SO stimulates RNA turnover through a unique process called polyadenylation, where RNA gets an extra tail. Cells with SO express this protein have longer tails on their RNA and it gets broken down faster. Inhibiting this tail formation blocks SO's activity. Both nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins are important for SO's function and it moves to the nucleus. This is a new way for the virus to shut down host and a new way to study how RNA is broken down in cells.
Researchers studied how the immune system responds to bacterial infections in the lungs. They found that a type of interferon, called IFλ, plays a key role in this response. IFλ is a protein that helps fight off viral infections, but its role in bacterial infections was unknown. The study showed that two types of bacteria, Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, trigger IFλ production in the lungs. Mice without the receptor for IFλ, called IL-28, cleared the bacteria better and had less lung damage. This was linked to lower levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines in the airways. In human cells, IFλ blocked a microRNA called mi-21, leading to more of a protein called PDC4, which promotes inflammation. In mice without IFλ or PDC, bacterial clearance improved and lung damage reduced. The study suggests IFλ promotes inflammation by blocking mi-21 regulation of PDC.
Researchers at the National Center for African Trypanosomiasis in the Democratic Republic of Congo studied mortality trends and risk factors in 781 patients with advanced stage-2 sleeping sickness between 1989 and 2012. They found that 17.2% of patients died in the standard melarsol treatment group, 12.1% in the short melarsol group, 5.4 in the eflornine group, 9.1 in the NECT regimen, and 36% in the group given efline due to severe clinical status. After adjusting for treatment, the odds of death were higher for patients with severely impaired clinical status, high protach, parasites in CSF, and cyach. Multivariate analysis showed clinical status and protach as predictors of death in some groups. The study's clinical assessment tool may help develop standardized tools for H management and epidemiological reports.
Researchers have developed a new method to study the effects of isolation on social behavior in fruit flies, specifically Drosophila melanogaster. They created a system to track and analyze the behavior of many flies at once, and used it to see how isolation affects their social interactions. The team found that isolation changes social behavior and the way flies interact with each other, and that these changes happen quickly. They also looked at the genetic changes in the flies and found that some genes related to metabolism are affected. Isolated flies have more lipids, a type of fat, in their bodies. The researchers used this method to study the effects of isolation on social behavior and found that it changes the way flies move and interact with each other, and that these changes last. They also found that some genes related to metabolism are affected. The study shows that isolation has a big impact on social behavior and physiology in flies.
Researchers conducted a pilot study in rural Bangladesh to evaluate the impact of a smartphone adaptation of the World Health Organization's (WHO) diarrhea management guidelines, including a tool for age-based weight estimation. The study took place in two hospitals that lacked scales, necessitating weight estimation. The study consisted of a 6-week pre-intervention and 6-week intervention period with a 10-day post-discharge follow-up. The primary outcome was adherence to guidelines for intravenous (IV) fluids, antibiotics, and zinc. A total of 841 patients were enrolled (325 pre-intervention, 516 intervention). During the intervention, the proportion of prescriptions for IV fluids decreased at both hospitals (p < 0.001) with risk ratios (RRs) of 0.5 and 0.2, respectively. However, when IV fluids were prescribed, the volume adhered to recommendations. The proportion of prescriptions for the antibiotic azithromycin increased (p < 0.001; p= 0.035) with RR of 6.9 and 1.6, while prescriptions for other antibiotics decreased; zinc adherence increased. The study found that a smartphone tool can improve guideline adherence.
Scientists have long struggled to predict how host-parasite systems will respond to climate change due to the complexity of their interactions. A key factors like host survival and parasite virulence have different temperature dependencies that need to be included in disease models. Researchers used data from Daphnia and a microidian parasite to create a mechanistic model of within-parasite dynamics. The model accounted for host mortality, parasite growth, and infection cost across temperatures with fewer parameters than traditional models. The study shows that linking metabolic theory with a host-parite framework can predict parasite population responses at the within-host level.

The researchers analyzed data on host and parasite across a temperature range using a model to capture thermal dependencies of aging and virulence, growth, and abundance. They fitted a model to data on Daph and its parasite to examine temperature effects on traits, interactions, and dynamics. Over nine temperatures, they measured lifespan of exposed and unexposed D and parasite abundance. Accurate predictions of climate change on host-parite and disease require models that integrate thermal dependencies of host and parasite traits. Development, survival, and movement can be described by formula from metabolic theory. These inform classical host-parite models to estimate temperature effects on prevalence and severity.

The study demonstrates the power of linking metabolic relationships for host and parasite in mechanistic models to understand temperature impacts on disease. The framework is simple and general, making it a valuable approach for predicting outcomes and consequences of infections under climate change.
Scientists have long known that a type of brain cell called GABAergic interneurons play a crucial role in controlling the activity of another type called excitatory pyramidal cells. However, how different types of inhibitory neurons contribute to information processing is not fully understood. Researchers propose a new role for a network of three types of inhibitory neurons: parvalbum, somostatin, and vaso intestinal peptide. They suggest that these neurons control the distribution of inhibition onto pyramidal cells, and that mutual inhibition between two of them translates weak inputs into large changes in inhibition. Using a computer model, they show that properties of the circuit support this idea. They also show that this network allows inputs to switch between two modes of processing, either integrating or canceling top inputs onto dendrites of pyramidal cells.
Researchers have found that interactions between different microorganisms in the microbiome can create false associations between specific microbes and host phenotypes, making it difficult to determine which microbes are directly linked to a disease. They developed a method, called Direct Association Analysis, to remove indirect associations and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease. The method corrected inflated p-values in association tests and showed only a small subset of associations are directly linked to the disease. Direct associations had higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate and brain-gut axis as factors in inflammatory disease. Microbial interactions produce a large number of spurious associations between members of the microbiome and phenotypes, many of which can be removed by a procedure based on maximum models from statistical physics. Traditional association studies lost power to identify the link between phenotype and microbiota in the dataset. The number of detections increased for real data, suggesting many reported associations between microbi and IBD could be indirect. The researchers estimated the contribution of indirect associations and isolated direct from associations, showing interactions are strong enough to generate detect changes in abundance of microbes not linked to host.
Researchers compared two ways of infecting mosquitoes with Wolbach, a type of bacteria, to see how it affects the spread of two viruses: dengue (DENV) and West Nile (WNV). They used two methods: stably infecting mosquitoes with Wolbach, which means the bacteria is passed on to their offspring, and transiently infecting, where the bacteria is only in the mosquito for a short time. The study found that Wolbach blocked both viruses in both types of infections, but the effect was stronger in stably infected mosquitoes. They also found no evidence that Wolbach helped the viruses spread, which suggests it could be a safe way to stop them from being transmitted. This is important because some mosquitoes are hard to infect with Wolbach, making it hard to study how it affects viruses. The study looked at how Wolbach density, or amount, in mosquitoes and found it was lower in transiently infected ones, which could explain why the weaker effect. They repeated the study with another virus, WNV, and got similar results.
Researchers studied how cilia are organized in the roundworm C. elegans. Cilia are microtub-based organelles that help cells sense the environment. They are divided into three parts: the basal body, transition zone (TZ), and shaft. In mammals, a protein called Inversin localizes to a part of the shaft near the TZ, called the Invers compartment (Inv). The mechanisms that create and maintain Inv are unknown. In C elegans, the shafts of sensory cilia are divided into two regions by microtub structure: proximal doublet near TZ and distal singlet. It was thought Cans cilia have an Inv like mammals. The study explored ciliogenesis, structure, and Inv in Cans. They found Inv is distinct from the double region. Two genes, n-2 (Invers homolog) and ar-13,lp-11, and unc-119, are needed for cili. Inv and double region can be grouped into two modules: n-2lp-11 and ar-13-119, which are opposed by hd-6 deacetylase. Glutamylation, a tub modification, is not needed for Inv and double region targeting; rather, it's modulated by n-2, ar-13, and-119. C targeting and localization of N-2, A-13, and UNC does not require TZ, double region and Inv genes. N-2 needs its calcium binding domain for Inv. C elegans Inv is distinct from double region, and components interact to regulate cili via placement, microt structure, and localization.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called Scribble plays a crucial role in the formation and repair of myelin, the fatty insulation that surrounds nerve fibers in the central nervous system. Myelin is formed by oligodendrocytes, specialized cells that change shape to create the myelin sheath. Scribble is present throughout oligodrocy development and becomes more active in mature oligodcytes, where it is found in both developing and mature myelin sheaths. Without Scri, oligodrotes fail to initiate myelinate, and myelin formation is disrupted in the central nervous system during development and after damage. Scri also regulates myelin thickness by suppressing a signaling pathway called ERK/MAP and is located at the node of Ranvier, where it helps axon-glial adhesion. This study shows that Scri is essential for myelination and remyelination, a process conserved across evolution.
Researchers have discovered a new insights into the pathogenesis of several Gram-positive bacteria, including Listeria monocytogen, Staphylococcus aureus, and Clostridium botulin. Until now, modified virulence peptides have been rarely reported and S-like cytolyins have been associated with Streptoccus sp, including group A and G streptocci and S.iae, a fish pathogen. However, this study found that a number of related clusters can be identified in other Gram pathogens, including L. monocogen, S. aure and C. A focus on the L. monocogen cluster revealed it encodes an inducible cytotoxic and hemolytic peptide, Listerin S, which plays a role in survival of the path in PMNs and contributes to virulence in mouse model. Notably, Listerin-associated cluster is variable, present in subset isolates from lineage I, evolutionary associated with majority of epidemics with this fatal path. In silico analysis demonstrates gene clusters encoding S-like factors present in notorious Gram pathogens, including L. monocogen, S. aure and C. botulin. A focus on L. has established S biosynthetic enzymes, SagD, function analogous to microcin B modification machinery, Sag can substitute for Mc with respect modification micro B structural in vitro. Each cluster contains gene encoding S-like peptide, designate Listerin (LS), Stolys (ST), and Botin (BTS).
Researchers studied the role of interleukin-17 (IL-17) and matrix metalloprotease-9 (MMP-9) in mycetoma, a type of granulomatous inflammatory disease caused by fungi or bacteria. They found that IL-17 and MMP-9 were present in myet lesions, with IL-17 mainly in Zones I and II, and MMP-9 in Zones II and III. MMP-9 levels were higher in lesions caused by Actinomura pelletii and Streptomyces somensis compared to Madure mycatis. There was a direct correlation between MMP-9 and IL-17 levels, and MMP-9 levels were higher in lesions with longer disease duration. The study suggests IL-17 and MMP-9 play a role in myet granuloma formation, but more research is needed to determine their exact function.
Researchers have been trying to understand how certain proteins, called intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs), recognize and bind to other molecules. IDPs are unique because they don't have a fixed shape and can change depending on what they interact with. Some IDPs stay disordered even when bound to a target, a phenomenon called "fuzziness". Scientists studied the transcription activation domain of the Ewing Sarcoma oncoprotein (E) family, an ID that exhibits fuzziness. They hypothesized that E-target binding involves interactions between E's aromatic side chains and the target's basic residues. To test this, they looked at E variants with different sequences, aromatic density, and charge. Results supported the cation-π model. A coarse-grained model and analytical model also captured the trends. E-target binding is driven by balance between E conformation entropy and cationπ contacts. This versatile recognition mode offers a framework for promiscuous target by polyent IDPs.
Researchers studied the functions of two ATP-dependent proteases, Lon-1 and Lon-2, in the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi, which causes Lyme disease. This bacterium is transmitted to humans through tick bites. Previous work showed that Lon-1 is upregulated when exposed to blood, while Lon-2 is not. The study aimed to clarify the roles of these proteases in B. burgorferi. Phylogenetic analysis showed that Lon-1 and Lon-2 are different due to differences in their substrate binding domains. Recombinant Lon-1 showed properties of an ATP-dependent chaper-protease but did not complement E. coli mutant, while Lon-2 corrected Lon-mut phenotypes. The study concludes that B. burgorfer Lon-1 and-2 have distinct roles. Lon-2 functions like a canonical Lon, in cellular homeostasis, while Lon-1, induced by blood, may be important for host adaptation from arthropod to warm-blood host.
Researchers studied how the role of antibody-dependent phagocytosis (AD) in preventing HIV-1 infection. AD is a process where antibodies help white blood cells engulf and destroy viruses. They found that HIV-1 virions (virus particles) are not easily engulfed by antibodies, but when coated with a specific protein called gp41, antibodies can mediate phagocytosis. A few hundred gp41 molecules are needed for successful phagytosis, similar to the number of spikes on other viruses like influenza. Using a technique called fluorescence spectroscopy, they found a link between virus aggregation and AD. In contrast, HIV-infected cells are targets for phagocytosis in the presence of antibodies. The study suggests AD may not play a role in preventing HIV infection due to lack of trimers and inability of antibodies to cross-link receptors on white cells. However, phagocyt of infected cells could play a role in clearing cells on verge of infection.
Hookworm infection is a widespread in many countries around the world, but its economic and health impact is not well understood. To determine how much time, energy, and resources to invest in controlling the disease, researchers created a model to estimate the economic and health burden of hookworm in every country, region, and globally in 2016. From a societal perspective, globally, hookworm resulted in 2,126,280 Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALYs) using 200 disability estimates and 4,087,803 DALs using 201 estimates (excluding cognitive impairment). Including impairment did not increase DALs worldwide. Productivity losses varied with anemia and calculation method, from $7.5 billion to $138.9 annually using Gross National Income (GNI) per capita, and from $2.5 to $43.9 billion using minimum wage. Hook is classified as a neglected disease, but its burden exceeded estimates of diseases with more attention, such as rotavirus. Countries transitioning to higher income, like Brazil and China, still face significant hook burden. A study reported 3,230,800 DALs annually due to hook among all ages in 21 regions, but did not include cognitive impairment. Assuming median anemia and NI, hook infections resulted in losses $11.1 billion (95%: $5.5-18.5) using Method 1, $87.9 (95:1.7-302.3) Method 2, and $23.1 (11-38.4) Method 3. Using minimum wage, global burden was $3 billion.
Researchers studied how oxygen deprivation, or hypoxia, affects the developing brain in vertebrates, such as zebraf fish. They found that hypox disrupts the pathfinding of forebrain neurons, leading to errors in commissural axons failing to cross the midline. This happens due to the activation of the hypia-inducible transcription factor (h1) pathway, which can be mimicked by chemical inducers of h1 or expression of constitutively active hα. Blocking transcription activation of hα prevented the defects. EphrinB2 was identified as a target of the h pathway, and its knockdown rescued the errors. The receptor EphA4 is expressed in a pattern to the misrouting axons. Targeting a constitutive form of EphB to neurons showed EphB mediates the errors via reverse-signaling. Magnesium, used to improve neurodevelopment in prebirths, protects against errors by preventing upregulation of EphB.
Researchers studied how a fungal infection called paracidiomycosis affects the lungs in mice using a new imaging technique called high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) and compared it to traditional tissue analysis. Paracidiomycosis is a disease caused by a fungus that affects the lungs, skin, and other parts of the body, and can be hard to treat. The researchers infected mice with the fungus and took pictures of their lungs with HRCT every four weeks to see how the infection spread. They also looked at the lungs under a microscope to compare the results. Three types of lung damage were found: nodular, diffuse, confluent, and pseudo-oral. The damage was mostly around the lung's center and affected the left lung more often. After four weeks, 80% of infected mice had a type of damage called consolidation, which made the lung denser. After eight and 12 weeks, the damage spread to other parts of the lung. Microscopic analysis showed that the damage seen on HRCT was the same as a type of reaction, while nodules were small groups of immune cells. After 16 weeks, the damage formed large masses that blocked airways. Researchers found that HRCT is a good tool to see and measure lung damage in this infection. This method can help reduce the number of animals needed for study and monitor treatment.
Researchers have developed a new test to detect infection with Leishmania donovirus, a parasite that causes visceral leishmaniasis. The test, called Interferon-gamma Release Assay (QuFERON), measures the body's immune response to the parasite. They tested the test on blood samples from people with active, cured, and healthy individuals living in areas where the parasite is common. The test used five different parts of the parasite: H2, H2-PS2, H-Le12, crude antigen, and soluble Leish antigen (SL). The test based on SL had 80% sensitivity and 100 specificity. This means it correctly identified 80% of people with the infection and 100% of those without. The study found that people with active infection had a different immune response than expected, producing interferon-gamma when exposed to the parasite. This is opposite of previous findings that showed no response. The test could be used to measure immune response to the parasite.
Researchers have found that a toxin called CNFY plays a key role in making the bacteria Yersinia pseudotuberculosis persistent in the body. This bacteria can cause gastrointestinal infections that can lead to relapsing enteritis and autoimmune disorders. To establish a persistent infection, the bacteria must navigate through the intestinal lining and colonize the underlying lymphatic tissues, but how they evade the immune response is not well understood. The study shows that CNFY toxin enhances the transfer of antiphocytic effectors, leading to inflammation and tissue destruction of the intestinal microbiota and bacterial clearance. However, suppressing CNFY function increases interferon-mediated responses, non-inflammatory activities and tolerogenesis. This leads to a preprogramming of the pathogen's transcription towards persistence, giving the bacteria an advantage against host responses and establishing a commensal lifestyle.

The study demonstrates that removing a single virulence factor, CNFY, is sufficient to dampen inflammation and evade host defense, favoring Yers persistence. The mechanisms are unclear, but the impact suggests a set of immune responses, such as IL-6 levels, modulators, bacteridal activities, and anti-inflammatory factors, contributing to the process. The CNFY process is a double-edged sword. The toxin constitutively activates Rho GTPases deid and improves Y translocation into host, enhancing inflammation and tissue damage. Suppressing CN function shifts the balance towards immune suppression, promoting asymptomatic infection. Several enteric pathogens, including Yersiae, persist in the tract and lymphatic tissues, promoting chronic arthritis and ileitis.
Researchers have identified a new gene called DES1 in the fungus Magnaporthe oryza that helps the pathogen to overcome the plant's defense system. This gene is necessary for the fungus to successfully colonize and reproduce in the plant. To find DES1, scientists looked at pathogenic-defective mutants in a library of T-DNA insertions. They found that DES1 encodes a protein rich in serine with unknown properties, and its homologs are conserved in filamentous Ascomyc. Deleting DES1 had no effect on growth, conial germination, appressium formation, and penetration, but conial size was smaller. The mutant was sensitive to oxidative stress and had less extracellular enzymes. In interaction with rice, cells inoculated with DES mutant showed strong defense responses, brown granules, ROS, autofluorescent materials, and PR gene induction. The mutant had reduced infectious hyal extension and pathogenicity. Suppressing ROS with DPI, an inhibitor of NAD oxidases, reduced defense in plant tissues with mutant. DPI-treated tissues allowed mutant to grow normally. This suggests DES1 regulates fungal proteins, compromising plant defense by ROS.
Researchers in Ghana used a statistical model to predict where Schistosoma haematium, a parasitic worm infection, was most prevalent in the country. They compared these predictions to actual data from school surveys to see how accurate the model was. The study found that using the model alone, 21 out of 25 schools with high infection rates would not receive treatment and 20% of schools with no infection would be treated. This would mean 28% of children would not receive treatment and 12% would receive unnecessary treatment. The model was not accurate enough to guide the national program, but can be a tool when combined with actual assessments. Predictive mapping should not be a one-time exercise, but an ongoing process that incorporates testing and refining to meet needs of disease control managers.
Researchers have discovered that a mixture of prostaglandins, a type of hormone, guides sperm in the reproductive tract of Caenorhabditis elegans, a type of worm. They found that the worm's oocytes, or egg cells, synthesize prostagland from fatty acid precursors in yolk protein complexes. The team used genetics and mass spectrometry to study prostland metabolism and found that omega-6 and omega-3 fatty acids are converted into over 10 structurally related prostland, which work together to promote sperm guidance. Disrupting omega-3 fatty acid synthesis triggers prostland production from omega-6 acids. The worm's prostland synthesis is different from mammal pathways, yet still produces PG2 stereomers. A conserved enzyme, cytochrome P450, regulates prostland synthesis. The team found a cons enzyme that inhibits prostland metabolism, possibly diverting precursors to alternative pathways. Results support that multiple prostland function together promote sperm motility for fertilization.
Researchers have developed a new method to design proteins that are less likely to trigger an immune response while keeping their function intact. This is a challenge in creating medicines that use proteins to treat diseases, as the body's immune system often rejects them. The team used a computer program to find the best balance between making the protein less recognizable to the immune system and keeping it working well. They found that there is no single "best" design, but a range of options that trade off between these two goals. Eight of these designs were made and tested, and the results matched the computer predictions. This is the first time a systematic look at the trade-offs between making a protein less immunogenic and keeping it functional. The new method could speed up and improve the development of medicines that use proteins to treat diseases.
Researchers studied how temperature affects the process of meiosis in plants, specifically Arabidopsis thaliana. Meiosis is a crucial for sexual reproduction and involves the exchange of DNA between chromosomes to ensure proper chromosome segregation. The frequency and distribution of these exchanges, called crossovers (CO), are regulated by internal and external factors, but more is known about the internal mechanisms than external. The study found that higher temperatures increase meiotic recombination in Arabidopsis and used genetic analysis to show that the extra crossovers come from the Type I pathway, which is sensitive to interference. They also found that heat-induced crossovers are not due to increased DNA breaks and the hyper-recombinant phenotype is specific to thermal stress, not a general response. This provides insight into how environmental cues affect meiotic recombination and may have practical applications.
Researchers have developed a new computational tool, called Hanalyzer, to help scientists navigate the vast and rapidly evolving field of molecular biology. This tool combines reading, reasoning, and reporting methods to analyze experimental data from various sources. It extracts information from structured and unstructured data, tracks provenance, and enriches knowledge by noting relationships between genes and databases. Hanalyzer was tested on a large gene expression dataset related to craniofacial development, revealing new roles for four previously uncharacterized genes, validated by further experiments. The tool allows users to trace provenance links and access underlying data sources. To present relevant knowledge, sub-networks are selected and presented in a comprehensible way, either by visualizing or creating a quantitative network based on experimental data. Combining the two networks highlights supported and unsupported linkages, facilitating explanation and hypothesis generation. This approach can be applied to any dataset.
Helminth parasites, such as Fasciola hepatica, secrete extracellular vesicles (EVs) that can be internalized by host cells, modulating the host's immune response. While the cargo of EVs has been characterized in many parasites, little is known about the surface-exposed molecules that participate in ligand-receptor interactions with the cell to initiate vesicle docking and internalization. Researchers used a membrane-impermeable biotin reagent to capture proteins on the outer surface of two subpopulations (15 and 120 EV) released by adult F. hepatica, describing 380 proteins including virulence factors, membrane proteins, and molecules involved in EV biogenesis/trafficking. Proteomics and immunohistochemical analysis showed 120 EV have endosomal origin and may be released via the protonephial excretory system, while larger 15 EV are from gastrodermal epithelial cells lining the gut. Lectin microarray strategy profiled surface oligosaccharides of intact fluorically labelled EVs displayed to host. Lect profiles of 15 and 120 EV subpopulations are identical but distinct from parasite tegument, predominated by mannose sugars. EV were resistant to exo and endoglycosases, but glycosidase remodelled surface and blocked uptake by macrophages. Pre-treatment with antibodies from infected hosts or purified against EV surface proteins significantly enhanced internalization.
Researchers have discovered a key player in the regulation of microRNAs (miRNAs) in plants, called Arabidopsis CDF2. miRNAs are crucial for plant development and are first transcribed as stem-loop primary miRNAs (pri-mi) by RNA polymerase II, then cut into mature miRN by Dicer 1 (D1). CDF2 interacts with D1 and regulates a group of miRN. It acts as a transcription activator or repressor for some mi genes and binds directly to their promoters. C2 also binds to pri-mi regulated by itself and affects D1 processing of these prii. Genetically, C2 works in the same pathway as mi156 or mi172 to control flowering. C2 regulates a group of prii at both transcription and post-transcription levels to maintain proper levels of mature mi to control plant development.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called geranylgeranyl diphosphate (GG) plays a crucial role in the communication between oocytes and granulosa cells in the ovaries. This communication is essential for the development of follicles, which provide eggs for reproduction. GG is involved in a process called protein geranylation, which helps cells talk to each other. The study found that GG levels increase in oocytes during early follicle development. When GG was removed from oocytes, granosa cells didn't proliferate, and follicles didn't transition to the next stage, affecting female fertility. Mechanistically, GG blocked a protein called Rho, which helps cells stick together, and another called Rab, which helps send materials from o to granosa cells. Restoring GG in oocytes fixed these issues. The study shows GG's role in o-granosa communication and follicle transition, a key step in female reproduction.
Researchers have created a detailed model of an enzyme called RNA polymerase II, which is responsible for creating messenger RNA from DNA. Despite previous studies, it was unclear how a molecule called NTP (a building block of RNA) reaches the enzyme's active site. The model reveals that the secondary channel is the main route for NTP to enter the enzyme, but the main channel is still a possibility. This is because the non-DNA part of the transcription bubble, which overlaps with the main channel, is crucial for studying NTP routes but its shape is unknown in available structures. The researchers built a model of RNA polymerase II with a complete bubble by combining existing data and simulations. They found that the secondary channel has more space for NTP than the main, and simulations showed that N through the main is hindered by electrostatic repulsion between N and negatively charged DNA. This suggests the secondary channel is the main route for N during transcription.
Dengue is a significant public health problem in Thailand and Cambodia, particularly among children under 15 years old. Despite being a reportable disease, the true burden of deng is unknown due to underreporting. Researchers used data from laboratory-confirmed outpatient and inpatient cases in prospective studies to estimate the magnitude of underreporting and establish accurate burden estimates for these countries. Two cohort studies were conducted among children under 15 in a deng field site over two deng seasons. Age-specific multiplication factors (MF) were calculated by comparing cohort data to national surveillance in the same province and year. In Thailand, 14,627 person-years of cohort data were obtained in two provinces and 14,493 from one in Cambodia. Average incidence of laboratory-confirmed deng was 23/1,000 and 25/1,000 in Thailand, and 41/1,000 in Cambodia. Calculated MF varied by age and year (0.4-29). Average age-specific MF were applied to country data indicating in Thailand 229,886 (210,612-331,236) deng cases annually 2003-2007 and 111,178 (80,452,357,135) in Cambodia. Underreporting total inpatient deng cases was 8.7 and 2.6 in Thailand, and 9.1 and 1.4 in Cambodia. In 2007, over 95,000 children in Thailand and 58,000 in Cambodia were estimated hospitalized due to deng. Calculating MF by cohort data to surveillance is one approach to assess burden. Data indicate deng reported in many countries underreport true burden.
Researchers have discovered that natural killer (NK) cells play a crucial role in promoting the immune response to cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. They found that NK cells help accelerate the development of CD8 T cells, a type of immune cell that fights off the virus, by controlling the production of immunosup cytokines. These cytokines can suppress the immune response and make it harder for the body to fight off the infection. By limiting their production, NK cells create an environment that allows CD8 cells to develop and attack the virus effectively. The study used mice with and genetically modified viruses to understand how NK cells interact with CMV. They found that without NK cells, CD8 cells were delayed in responding to the infection. Administering interferon-alpha, a cytokine that suppresses immune response, also delayed CD8 cell activation. This shows that NK cells not only directly fight the virus but also regulate the immune response to prevent overreaction and promote CD8 cell development.
Scientists have discovered that a protein called nucleolin plays a crucial role in controlling the expression of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes in Arabidopsis thalian, a type of plant. rRNA genes are arranged in arrays of hundreds to thousands of copies in plants, but not all are transcribed under normal conditions. Researchers found four rRNA variants in Arabid thalian, with one induced and others repressed or unchanged in plants with disrupted nucleolin protein (At-L). The most represented rRNA variant, inactive in normal plants, is reactivated in At-L mutants. The study shows pre-rRNAs originate from RNA I transcription and are processed. Disruption of At-L gene causes loss of symmetrical DNA methylation without affecting histone marks on r genes. This reveals a new mechanism for r gene regulation, where nucleolin controls active and repressed r variants.
Researchers have found that a protein called UL29 from the human cytomegalovirus virus interacts with a complex called NuRD, which is involved in regulating gene expression. This interaction is important for the virus to replicate efficiently. The Nu complex is made up of several proteins, including HDAC1, RBP, and CHD4. When these proteins are knocked down, the virus's immediate-early RNA and DNA accumulation is reduced. This suggests that multiple components of the Nu complex are necessary for the virus to replicate. The researchers also found that the UL29 protein enhances the activity of the virus's major promoter, regardless of the presence of another protein UL38. However, this effect requires the Nu components of the complex. When the Nu components are knocked down, the virus's immediateearly RNA accumulation is inhibited. The researchers propose that UL29 modifies the Nu complex to stimulate the accumulation of immediateearly RNAs.
Researchers studied how the immune system responds to Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) in young children and adults. They used a technique called whole-genome-fragment display libraries (GFPDL) to identify the specific parts of the virus that the immune system targets. Before and after infection, they found that the immune response to the fusion protein (F) didn't change much, but the response to the attachment protein (G) increased 100-fold. The immune system targeted the N and C-terminus of G and a central part called the conserved domain (CCD). They made synthetic peptides and proteins to test the immune response in children, adolescents, and adults. The response to F increased with age, and new targets were found in the pre-fusion form of F. Antibodies to pre-fusion were 2-3 times stronger than post-fusion. For G, the response was high in children but decreased in adults. This study shows the immune response to F and G evolve differently and supports the idea that the virus adapts to the immune system. These findings can help develop effective countermeasures like vaccines.
Emodeide, a veterinary drug used to treat nematode infections in cats and dogs, has been shown to have macrofidal effects on adult Brug mal, a parasite that causes lymphatic filariasis. Researchers studied how emide works on Brug mal and found it potently inhibits motility by activating voltage-gated potassium channels, with males being more sensitive than females. They discovered that emide targets S-1 channels, a type of potassium channel, and that has different forms due to alternative splicing in the R1 region. The slo-1 isoform found in males is more sensitive to emide than the slo-1 isoform found in females. Knocking down the slo-1 isoform in females increased emide potency. Onchercavolus, another parasite that causes blindness, has two forms of slo-1 in females with different R1 domains. Modeling showed emide binds to the same R1 region in different species of filaria, affected by splicing variations. This study shows emide has potent macroidal effects and splicing in R1 affects potency. Evaluating sex-dependent effects of anthelmint compounds is important to prevent underdosing one gender of nematodes given to patients.
Scientists have been trying to eliminate lymphatic filariasis, a disease caused by the parasite Wuchereria bancrofti, using rapid tests that detect the parasite's protein in the blood. However, these tests also react with another parasite, Loa loa, causing false positives. To understand why, researchers used a special antibody to purify Loa antigens from people with Loa infections. They found many Loa antigens that react with the same antibody, and identified several Lo proteins in the blood of people with Loa infections. These proteins are made by the parasite and released into the blood when it dies. Unlike Wuchereria's protein, which stays in the blood for a long time, Loa antigens are only present in some people's blood for a short time. This difference can help tell the two parasites apart and make better tests for Loa.
Researchers have identified a new protein called RAB-28 that plays a crucial role in the development and function of cilia, tiny hair-like structures on the surface of cells that help with sensing and signaling. Defects in cilia cause inherited disorders such as retinitis pigmentosa and Bardet-Bied syndrome, which affect multiple organs and developmental processes. To find new cilia-associated genes, scientists used the nematode C. elegans, where cili form quickly during a short period in late embryogenesis. They analyzed RNA libraries and found a signature profile of known ciliary proteins, including FAM161, CC104, and RP1. From a list of 185 candidates, they found orthologues of MAP, YAP, CC149, and R28 as conserved ciliary components. Further analysis of C. elegans R-28, linked to autosomal-recessive cone-rod dystrophy, showed this GTPase is expressed in ciliated neurons and associates with intraflagellar transport (IFT) in a Bardet-Bied syndrome (BBS)-dependent manner. Inactive R-28 has no IFT and diffuse localization, while active GTP-bound R-28 concentrates at the periciliary membrane and undergoes bidirectional IFT. Overexpression of predicted or locked GTP variants of R-28 disrupts cilium and sensory morphogenesis. This study presents a new approach for identifying ciliary proteins and unveils R28, a GTP closely related to B protein R4/IFT, as IFT-associated with BBS-dependent cell and non-autonomous functions at the ciliary base.
Scientists have long wondered how the brain represents the world around us, despite relying only on neural responses and no direct access to external stimuli to understand what those responses mean. Researchers investigated how much can be learned about the space of stimuli using the action potentials (spikes) of cells with stereotypical receptive fields. They used hippocampal place cells as a model and found that knowing which groups of cells fire together reveals a surprising amount of structure in the underlying space, enabling the brain to construct its own representations.

The study showed that knowing which hippocamp cells fire together is enough to extract global features of the environment and reconstruct an accurate representation of physical space, including the animal's position. This is different from previous approaches that reconstructed position from place activity, which required knowing place fields or other neural responses related to position. The researchers found that simple knowledge of cell groups is enough to infer topological features of two-dimensional environment and geometric reconstruction of space, without assuming place fields or prior measurements of position.

In the case of hippocamp cells, global features of environment and accurate reconstruction of space, including animal's position, can be inferred from spikes alone. No prior knowledge of place fields or independent position is needed. Previous approaches to reconstructing position from place activity required knowing place fields, which is not the case here.
Researchers studied a severe liver disease called viral fulminant hepatitis (FH) in mice infected with a virus called murine hepatitis virus-3 (MH-3). They found that mice with high levels of a protein called IL-1β in their liver and blood had severe disease and high mortality. Mice without IL-1 receptor (IL-1-) or treated with IL-1 antagonist (IL-Ra) had less virus replication, disease, and lower mortality. IL-1 receptor deficiency blocked a protein called fibrinogen-like-2 (F2) in macrophages and neutrophils in the liver, and reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) by macrophages activated NLR3 inflamome. Mice without NADPH oxidase subunit p47 showed reduced NLR3 inflamome and IL-β during infection, making them resistant to FH. Mice without NLR3 and caspase-1, inflamome components, had less IL-β and reduced hepatitis. The study shows that ROS/NLR3/IL-β is a key pathway causing severe liver disease during viral infection, and may lead to new treatments for FH and other inflammatory diseases.
Hookworm infections are a major cause of severe anemia and iron deficiency in children in tropical regions. Researchers used a new diagnostic tool called multiplex real-time PCR to study the prevalence and impact of two types of hookworm species, Ancyoma duale and Necator american, on anemia and iron deficiency in pre-school children in Malawi. The study found that 34.1% of severely anemic children and 27.0% non-severely anemic children had hookworm infections, while microscopy detected only 5.6%. The prevalence of A duale and american was 26.1% and 4.9% respectively. Moderate to high A duale infections were associated with severe anemia and iron deficiency, with odds ratios of 2.49 and 9.04 respectively. Iron deficiency was also associated with intensity of Aale infection, with odds of 3.63, 16.98 and 44.91 for low, moderate and high loads. This is the first study to assess hook load and species with anemia and iron deficiency. The results show a higher than expected prevalence of Aale and its association with severe anemia and iron in pre-school children in Malawi, highlighting the need for species-specific screening. Multiplex real PCR is a powerful tool to combat anemia and iron deficiency in resource-poor settings.
Researchers have identified a protein called COM-1 that plays a crucial role in the process of meiosis, a type of cell division that occurs in reproductive cells. During meiosis, DNA is broken into pieces called double-strand breaks (DSBs), which can be repaired in two ways: homologous recombination (HR) or non-homous joining (NHE). HR is the only way to create inter-chromosome crossovers (COs) needed for proper cell division. Without COM-1, cells repair DS via error-prone NHE, resulting in lack of CO, chromosomal abnormalities, and near-complete embryonic lethality. COM1 is not required for DS initiation but promotes meiotic recombination by counteracting NHE complex. In fact, animals lacking both COM1 and Ku are viable and proficient in CO formation. COM acts parallel to nuclease EX-1 to promote interolog HR at early meiotic stage and safeguard CO formation. Both nucleases are dispensable for RAD-51 at late stage when hom-independent pathways predominate.
Researchers studied the immune response of goats to Burkholderia pseudallei, a bacteria that causes meloidosis, a severe pneumonia and sepsis in Southeast Asia and Australia. They used an aerosol infection model to mimic the disease in goats, which is more similar to human infection than previous mouse models. The goal was to identify proteins that trigger an immune response, which could lead to new diagnostics and vaccines. The study found that goats developed a strong immune response to several proteins, including GroEL, EF-T, and Dna, which were present in all samples after infection. Heat shock protein GroEL elicited the strongest response. Most antigens showed peak IgM reactivity at day 14, while IgG increased as disease progressed. A comparison with human sera showed many common reactive proteins between goats and humans with meloidosis. The study found a diverse and increasing antibody response over disease in goats, with IgG and IgM responses in individual serum samples using 2D electrophoresis and western blots. ELISA and 2D gel electrophis were used to analyze antibody concentration to whole lysate and individual antigens. Total reactive IgM was stable with most antigens throughout 7-14. The response was similar to human meloid patients, with many antigens eliciting comparable antibodies. The study suggests goats have a complex immune response to multiple antigens during meloidosis, similar to humans.
Cyclin B-Cdk Activation Continues after Centros Separation to Control Mitotic Progression

A key event that initiates mitosis is the activation of cyclin B-cyclindependent kinase (Cdk), triggered by a positive feedback loop at the end of G2. This activation is followed by the metaphase/anaphase-promoting complex-dependent destruction of cyclin B, which inactivates Cdk, allowing mitotic exit and cell division. However, experimental data on Cdk activation in mitosis have been lacking. Researchers used a novel approach to determine the temporal development of cyclin B-Cdk activity in single cells. By quantifying dephosphorylation of C and phosphorylation of the Cdk target anaphase-promoting complex, they disclosed cyclin B-Cdk continues to be activated after centros separation. Importantly, cytoplasmic cyclin-Cdk activity can be maintained when cyclin B translocates to the nucleus in prophase. These data are fitted into a model describing cyclin-Cdk activation in human, revealing a resemblance to a bistable circuit. Cyclin-Cdk levels required to enter mitosis are lower than the amount needed for mitotic progression. Gradually increasing cyclin-Cdk activity after centros separation is critical to coordinate mitotic progression.
HIV-1 vaccines have failed to elicit neutralizing antibodies (Nabs) that can protect against diverse HIV-1 subtypes. One way to develop a strong, cross-reactive response is HIV-1 superinfection (SI), defined as sequential infections from different partners. SI has led to a broader and more potent response than single infection, but it's unclear if SI impacts epitope specificity. This study examined post-SI responses from 21 Kenyan women exposed to subtypes A, C, and D, and superinfected after 1.07 years. Plasma samples were analyzed at 2.72 years postSI. Previous studies showed broad and potent responses targeted 4 main HIV-1 envelope epitopes: CD4 site, V1/V glycan, N332 in V3, and gp41 proximal region. Epitope mapping and computational analysis found no dominant response to these epitopes in 21 women. Data suggest SI promotes a polyclonal response, supporting vaccine designs using multivalent immunogens to elicit diverse Nabs.
Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is a leading cause of neurological disabilities in children worldwide, but the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. CMV has been shown to dysregulate the Notch signaling pathway in neural progenitor cells (NPCs). Hairy Enhancer of Split 1 (Hes) is essential for NPC fate and brain development as an important downstream effector of Notch signaling. Researchers found that CMV downregulates Hes protein levels in infected NPCs. The CM 72Da immediate-early 1 protein (IE1) is involved in Hes degradation by assembling a ubiquitination complex and promoting Hes ubiquination as a potential E3 ubiquitin ligase, followed by proteasomal degradation of Hes. SpA, a component of PML bodies, is another target of IE-mediated ubiquination. The C-terminal region of IE, amino acids 451-475, is required for IE/Hes interaction and IE-mediated Hes ubiquination but not for IE/SpA interaction and ubiquination. This study reveals a novel mechanism linking Hes downregulation to neurodevelopment disorders caused by CMV infection and identifies IE as the first CM-encoded E3 ubiquitin ligase.
Researchers studied how gene expression changes in fruit fly embryos from four different species of the Drosophila genus, which diverged 40 million years ago. They looked at how transcription factors, proteins that control gene expression, bind to DNA and compared it to gene expression levels. They found that gene expression is more conserved than transcription factor binding, and changes in gene expression are not explained by changes in binding. However, sites bound by multiple factors and near genes are conserved more than others, suggesting weak or non-functional binding not subject to selection.

They compared binding across species and found it decreased with phylogenetic distance. Few regions were bound by all four species. Quantitative and qualitative comparisons showed transcription binding diverged in Dophila. They compared divergence to divergence and found only 3-7% of variance explained by binding, 21% if phylogenetic not considered. mRNA-seq from embryos at end of cellularization showed highly correlated between species, decaying with distance. Divergence was lower than TF binding.

They found two sources of binding divergence: BCD, HB, GT, and KR motifs drive a portion, and ChIP log-transformed values normalized for comparisons. mRNA levels were highly correlated between species, decaying with distance. Divergence was lower than TF binding along Doph tree. On a gene-by-gene basis, they matched genes to regions bound by most TFs and focused on 4,846 annotated in all species.
Researchers conducted a large-scale study in two primary health centers in Thanjav district, India, where eight rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) for lymphatic filariasis had been completed. The study aimed to assess the effectiveness of MDA and identify potential "hotspots" of transmission. They tested 50,363 people, mostly children, for microfilaria (M) and antigenemia (Ag) levels. Results showed 0.2% prevalence of M and 0.004 intensity in 60µl blood, and 2.3% and 17.3 Ag-units, respectively. Ag prevalence ranged 0.7-0.9% in children 2-10 years and 2.7-3% in adults. Despite M levels <1% and Ag <2 in sentinel sites, "residual" M-preval ≥1 was found in 7 children and "transmission" at least one Ag-positive child during MDA. Antigenemic persons clustered at household and site levels. An Ag-preval ~1% in children equivalent 0.4 M-preval as possible threshold for stopping MDA. The study indicates need for good surveillance strategies to detect "hot" and evidence-based sampling and evaluation size for transmission assessment surveys.
Researchers conducted a systematic review to assess the effectiveness of temeph, an organophosphate laricide, in controlling deng vectors and deng transmission when used as a single intervention or combined with other methods. They searched six databases and screened grey literature for relevant studies, extracting data and assessing methodological quality. 27 studies were included, 11 single intervention and 16 combined. Single intervention studies showed temeph reduced entomological indices, while 11 of 16 combined studies showed tem with other chemical methods reduced entom indices, but not sustained over time or failed to reduce immature stages. Effectiveness depended on factors like delivery quality, water rate, type, debris, temperature, and sunlight. Timing, reapplication, reluctance, cost, supplies, time, and labor were limitations. As a single intervention, tem was effective in suppressing entom indices, but not when combined with other methods. No evidence suggests tem reduces deng transmission.
Researchers have discovered that two proteins, Ctf19 and C3, play a crucial role in holding sister chromatids together during cell division. C19 is found along the length of chromosomes, but is most abundant at the centromere region, the pericentere. The study found that C19 directs the association of C with the perentere, while C3 ensures its functionality in holding sister chromatids together. Without C3, cells show defects in combination with mutants of C19. Delaying DNA replication rescues the defect in C19 components, but not C3. The researchers propose that C19 loads C at the centere before replication, ensuring its incorporation through C3. Two C19 proteins, I3 and Ch4, direct C association with the perentere during mitosis and meiosis. Without I3 and Ch4, C binding at perere is reduced, affecting chromatid cohesion and segregation. A pathway of C loading is essential for C to be in place before replication. C3 is crucial in ensuring the replisome's integrity and association with cohesion as it traverses the protein-DNA barrier surrounding the centere. The study also found I3 and Ch4 localized at the centere, despite influencing C in perentere. C19 plays a similar role in perent cohesion during mitosis and meiosis. C19 and C3 are conserved. The study suggests a mechanism of kinetore-driven cohesion may operate in organisms with perent heterochatin.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a widespread arbovirus that infects an estimated 100 million people every year, mainly in tropical and subtropical areas. Dengue fever (DF) and deng hemorrhagic fever (DHF) are major health concerns. To understand the underlying mechanisms of deng pathogenesis, researchers studied the serum metabolome and lipidome of adult patients at three stages of infection: early fever, defervescence, and convalescence. Using liquid chromatography and mass spectrometry, they identified 60 differential metabolites, mainly fatty acids, acylcarnines, phospholids, and amino acids, in a large sample of 44 patients. The main pathways affected were fatty biosynthesis, β-oxidation, phosphid catabolism, and steroid. These changes suggest a multifactorial host response. Analysis of phospholids and sphingolids showed association with lymphocytes and platelets, which normalized at convalescent stage. These metabolites may be prognostic markers. DENV causes distinct serumome and lipidome changes, with many involved in inflammatory responses. The study reveals early anti-inflammatory responses modulating pro-inflammatory processes, preventing excessive inflammation. This is the first omic approach to show concurrent and dynamic host responses to DENV, offering physiological insights on why DF is self-limiting.
Research on neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) has increased in recent years, but significant gaps in diagnostic and treatment remain. Analyzing bibliometric data from research is a powerful method to reveal research efforts and partnerships. This study aimed to map NTD research in Germany and its partners to enable informed evaluation of German contributions. A Scopus database search for articles with German affiliations published between 2002-2012 was conducted for kinoplast and helminth diseases. From 26,833 publications, 1,187 (4.4%) had at least one German affiliation, and 972 were processed for five most published diseases. Co-author networks were constructed with 4,007 authors and 863 institutions. Most co-authors outside Germany were from high-income countries, Brazil. Collaborations with African countries were scattered. NTD research in Germany was distributed among 220 institutions. Strong performers were identified on individual level using parameters (publications, h-index) and social analysis (between centrality). The network varied between diseases. The share of NTD publications with affiliations is half of other medical fields. This underlines the need to identify and expand Germany's strong research towards NTD. Spatial analysis of collaborations abroad can support decisions to strengthen low and middle-income countries involved less than high-income. Identifying knowledge within networks complements traditional indicators for opportunities.
Haiti has made significant progress in controlling neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) such as lymphatic filariasis (LF) and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) since 2000 through a mass drug administration (MDA) program led by the Ministry of Health and its partners. By 2012, the program had reached national scale with good epidemiological coverage, allowing treatment for almost all of the country. Key to this success were the details of how MDAs were implemented, including community awareness through evidence-based education, community trust in drug distributors, directly observed treatment, easy access, and quality data collection. These strategies were effective, with 100% coverage in 201, above targets for LF and STH, and a 45% reduction in infection burden. Haiti's campaign, with international support, resulted in steady progress toward LF elimination and a strong foundation for STH control. 

The likelihood of taking treatment was associated with community knowledge, disease, transmission, strategy, and side effects, perceived risk, and history. In Haiti, knowledge was low and not associated with MDA. In Grand Anse, with 72% prevalence in 2001, decline was less than others, remaining at 55. Results show progress addressing STH, but question how to continue after MDA ceases. A successful campaign was launched in 200 with high rates, steady toward LF elimination, with more rounds in high prevalence and fewer low. A foundation for STH control was established. Factors determining treatment were knowing M was to take and ease of access. Direct observation increased participation. Now, Haiti turns to morbidity control for LF, building on surgery and patient groups implemented.
Researchers studied the role of the master regulator Ctr in controlling the cell cycle of Sinorhizob meli, a type of bacteria that forms a symbiotic relationship with legume plants. In this relationship, S. meli undergoes significant changes, including genome amplification, cell elongation, and loss of reproductive capacity. The researchers found that depleting Ctr causes similar changes, suggesting it's essential for differentiation. They also discovered that Ctr is regulated by proteolytic degradation, a possible mechanism for its depletion during symbiosis. By analyzing gene expression and protein interactions, they found Ctr regulates different processes than in S. meli than in another similar bacteria, Caulob cresus. For example, it doesn't control the F complex for cell division timing, but instead regulates the septum-inhibiting system. This study provides insight into how conserved genetic networks can adapt to diverse lifestyles. The model of Ctr regulation in S. mel will help understand how the bacterial cycle is modulated by plant factors during symbiosis.
Francisella tularens is a highly infectious bacterium that causes tularemia, a zoonotic disease. To survive and multiply inside host cells, it needs to evade the immune system. Researchers found a gene, FTL_6, that helps Francisella use glutathione (GSH) as a source of cystine, an essential amino acid. This is the first time a nutrient system is shown to be crucial for Francisella's growth inside host cells. SH is the most abundant cystine source in host cells. Francisella adapted to use SH as cystine source in host cells, a key example of bacteria-host interaction.

 Francisella's FTL_6 gene encodes a glutamyl transpeptase (GT) that breaks down glutam peptides. GT allows Francisella to use glutam peptides as cystine source during growth and is critical for virulence. Without GT, Francisella is resistant to serum. Researchers tested if GT helps Francis use glutam peptides as amino acids and cystine, essential for Francis. They grew Francisella with and without cystine in minimal medium. Francis growth was severely impaired without cystine. Adding cystine relieved growth defect, suggesting GT provides cystine to bacteria by breaking down glut peptides.

Francisella uses SH and glutam-cystine as cystine sources. GT breaks glut-cystine bond. Francisella GT complements E. coli GT deficient strain. Francis GT breaks glu bond in glut-cystine dipeptide, like E. coli. Francis uses SH and glut-cystine as primary cystine sources. Without GT, Francis can't obtain cystine from surroundings, adding cystine compensates deficiency.
Researchers studied how two types of Leishmania parasites, Leishmania amazonensis and Leish major, interact inside host cells. These parasites have different forms: flagellated promastigotes in insects and round amastigotes in host cells. Leish amazon amastotes occupy large vacuoles with many parasites, while Leish major amigotes are in small, tight vacoles that divide. To see if these vacoles can fuse, scientists infected mouse cells with non-fluorescent Leish amazon amastotes, then superinfected with fluorescent Leish major amastotes or promigotes. They used time-lapse imaging and found that Le major promigotes fused with established Leish amazon vacoles, but Leish amastotes did not. In chimeric vacoles, Le promigotes remained motile and multiplied, but did not turn into amastotes. In contrast, in separate vacoles, Le promigotes were destroyed or differentiated into amastotes. This shows that Leish vacoles differ in their ability to fuse and that species-specific mechanisms are required for differentiation.
Scientists have been trying to develop a vaccine against HIV-1, a virus that causes AIDS, for a long time. One goal is to create antibodies that can neutralize the virus, or stop it from infecting cells. To do this, they need to understand how the virus's outer layer, called Env, works. Env is made of two parts, gp120 and gp41, and is heavily covered in sugar molecules called glycans. These glycans make it hard for antibodies to bind and neutralize the virus. Researchers created a vaccine using a piece of the virus, called a trimer, and tested it in rabbits. They found that some rabbits developed strong antibodies that could neutralize the virus. These antibodies targeted gaps in the glycans near the CD4 binding site, a spot where the virus attaches to cells. The researchers also found that removing some of these glycans made the virus more susceptible to the antibodies. This is a new way to create antibodies that can neutralize HIV-1. The study shows that holes in the glycans can be used to develop antibodies that can neutralize the virus. It also shows that antibodies can neutralize the virus even if the glycans are present. This is a step towards creating a vaccine that can protect against HIV-1.
Researchers investigated how to monitor wound healing in patients with Buruli ulcer (BU), a bacterial infection common in rural Africa. Traditionally, surgery was the main treatment, but a combination of antibiotics rifampicin and streptomycin improved outcomes and reduced recurrence. However, managing extensive lesions after treatment remained a challenge, especially in areas with high disease burden. Immunohistochemistry was used to identify markers for wound progression. Specimens from 8 patients were analyzed before and after treatment for connective tissue, remodeling, and epidermal activation markers. Suitable markers were found to monitor healing. α-smooth muscle actin myofiblasts emerged during healing, producing extracellular matrix proteins like pro-collagen and tenascin. After treatment, cells showed ribosomal S6 phosphorylation, a translation marker. Wounds showed dermal remodeling by apoptosis and increased cytokeratin 16 in epider. A set of markers was identified to monitor healing by immunohisto. This may help understand delays in some patients.
Researchers studied how mitochondria, the energy-producing structures within cells, move along axons, the long extensions of nerve cells, in living mice.
