Divergence between distantly related species, like humans and rodents, is also negatively correlated with functional and positively with background selection. These patterns persist after accounting for confounding factors. Coalescent models show that selection in the ancestral population can explain a large proportion of variance in divergence, generating the correlations. The study reveals that selection can indirectly affect divergence between both closely and distantly related species, contrary to previous intuition. While direct purifying selection may drive some patterns, it would require more of the genome to be under selection than believed. The findings have implications for understanding genomes and interpreting genetic variation.
Researchers have found that the CK2 kinase plays a crucial role in regulating the stability and activity of the CLOCK (CLK) protein in the fruit fly circadian oscillator. CLK is a key component of the circadian clock that controls the expression of genes involved in daily rhythms. The study shows that CK2 phosphorylates and stabilizes CLK, reducing its activity. This is surprising because CK1, another kinase, promotes CLK degradation. The findings suggest that CK2 and CK1 have opposing effects on CLK, stabilizing and destabilizing it, respectively. This balance is important for proper circadian function. The study also found that downregulating CK activity decreases phosphorylation of CLK and increases expression of PER and TIM, two proteins that inhibit CLK activity. This indicates that CK2 inhibits CLK degradation while reducing its activity. The research identifies CK2 as the first kinase to regulate CLK in Drosila, and suggests it may play a key role in setting the circadian rhythm. The circadian oscillations are found in many organisms and governed by feedback loops of transcription factors that activate their inhibitors. In Drosila, CLK and CY activate PER and TIM at the end of the day, with CLK showing robust oscillations in phosphorylation levels. The study aimed to determine if CK was involved in CLK phosphorylation and its effect on circadian function.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, interacts with its invertebrate host Rhodnius prolix midgut. Researchers investigated whether cruzain, a cystine peptase, plays a role in this interaction. They treated T cruz epastigotes with anti-cruain antibodies and a panel of cystine peid inhibitors and measured adhesion to R. prolix midut ex vivo. All treatments, except CA-OM, decreased adhesion. Cystatin reduced adhesion in a dose-dependent manner. Comparison among T cruz isolates showed G, with low cruzain, adhered less than D28 and Bre. Transgenic epastotes overexpressing endogenous cruzain inhibitor chag, with low cruzain, adhered 73% less than wild-type. Adhesion was partially restored by exogenous cruzain. In vivo experiments, low ch parasites adhered less than wild-type after insect passage. Expression of cruzain increased drastically. This study shows cruzain contributes to T interaction with insect for the first time.
Researchers have identified 20 genes in the nematode worm Caenorhabitis elegans that can suppress a mutant form of a protein called cytoplasm dyin, which is essential for cell division. Cytoplasm dyin is a motor protein that moves along microtubules, helping to separate chromosomes and move to the right place during cell division. It also helps move vesicles and organelles around the cell. The researchers used a technique called RNA interference to reduce the function of many genes in the worm and found 20 that can suppress the mutant cytoplasm dyin. Some of these genes are not essential for the worm's survival, but when reduced, they can prevent the mutant cytoplasm dy from causing problems. The researchers also found that some of these genes, including two light chains of cytopl dy, go to the same places in the cell as the heavy chain of cytopl dy. This suggests they might be part of the same complex. Reducing one of these light chains can also stop the heavy chain from working. The researchers also found 29 genes that, when reduced, can prevent problems not only in cytopl dy but also in other essential processes. They conclude that some non-essential genes can help cytopl function during cell division.
In the ciliate Paramecium tetra, DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) drive programmed genome rearrangements (PGR) during somatic differentiation. The germline nucleus is transmitted to the progeny, but the somatic nucleus, essential for gene expression, is destroyed and a new somatic nucleus differentiates from a copy of the germline. In Paramec tetra, the somatic nucleus development involves massive GR, including the elimination of at least 45,000 germl sequences (Internal Eliminated Sequences, IES). I excision proceeds through a cut-and-close mechanism: domestic transposase PigMac is essential for DNAavage and DSB at excision involves Ligase IV, a component of non-homous endjoining (NHE) pathway. To understand how DNAavage and DSB are coordinated during GR, researchers focused on Ku, the actor of HE-mediated repair. Two Ku70 and Ku80 paralogs are encoded in the genome of P. tetra: Ku70 and Ku80 are produced during sexual processes and localize in developing somatic nucleus. RNA interference shows the development-specific Ku/Ku80 heterodimer is essential for recovery of functional somatic nucleus. Strikingly, PigMac-dependent DNAavage is abolished at IES in cells depleted Ku80, resulting IES retention in somatic genome.
Researchers studied the early stages of prion disease in mice to understand how it affects the brain before symptoms appear. They focused on hippocampal CA1 neurons, which are crucial for memory and learning. They used a technique to isolate these neurons from infected mice and analyzed their gene expression over time. They found that genes in these neurons are dynamic, with distinct phases of activity. A cluster of genes changed early in disease, returning to normal or reversing later. This cluster includes genes related to N-methyl-aspartic acid (NMDA) receptor and neuroprotective pathways. Genes for neuronal and dendrite development also changed, leading to a decline in synaptic proteins. MicroRNAs like mi-132, mi-124, mi-16, mi-26, mi-29, and mi-140 followed similar patterns. This study is the first to describe preclinical response of hippocal neurons to prion. Findings suggest prion stimulates a response, mediated by NMD receptor, promoting survival and remodelling, but terminated before symptoms appear. This points to a critical juncture in disease.
Researchers have created a computer model, called a Petri net, to study how the body's immune response to a parasite called Leishmania donani, which causes a disease called visceral leishiasis. The model simulated how immune cells, called granulomas, form in the liver to fight the parasite and eliminate it. The model was tested with data from experiments on mice and showed it accurately predicted the progression of the disease and changes in the granomas over time. It also revealed a new level of diversity in the granomas' ability to fight the parasite. By simulating the effect of a protein called IL-10, which helps regulate the immune response, the model showed that IL-10 produced by a type of immune cell called Kupffer at the center of the granoma plays a key role in controlling the parasite load. The model doesn't account for IL-10's effects outside the granoma, like on T cell differentiation in other tissues, which could affect the quality and quantity of T cells entering the granoma. Data from mouse studies and human cases of leishias point to a role of T cell cytokines in maintaining balance during disease and granomatous inflammation as a sign of protective immunity. T cells are key to fighting Leish and their depletion in the model led to high parasite burden and non-healing infection, as seen in T-deficient mice.
Researchers have viewed the transcriptional machinery of genes as a computational device with transcription factors as inputs and expression levels as output. They asked what kinds of computations are possible and found that simple kinetic models of transcription regulation can approximate arithmetic operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division, as well as equality and inequality. This contrasts with other studies that emphasize digital notions of computation in biological networks. The accuracy and precision of these approximations depend on different parameters and are tunable. Networks of "arithmetic" genes can be combined to accomplish more complicated computations by designing a network that detects significant elevations in a time-vary signal. Approximating analytic functions can be achieved by allowing multiple transcription factor binding sites on the promoter. This is important for interpreting naturally occurring networks and designing synthetic ones. Theoretical analysis and simulations show that "arithmetic" genes can be combined to compute sophisticated functions. An example is a network that tracks the mean and standard deviation of a time-vary signal and detects when the signal is significantly elevated. A model of a gene regulated by a single transcription factor with multiple binding sites on the promoter is also considered. Simple models demonstrate arithmetic computations at the level of transcription regulation. Other functions like exponentiation, logarithms, and trigonometric functions can be computed by combinations of arithmetic. However, this would be energetically wasteful and require many genes. A more efficient approach is to approximate directly using complicated machinery.
Researchers in Brazil sequenced the genomes of the Chikungunya virus (CHV) from a recent outbreak in the Northeast region and found that two genotypes, Asian/Caribbean and ECSA, are cocirculating in the area. This is the first time these genotypes have been found together in the same region. The study also found evidence of simultaneous infection by both genotypes in six clinical samples, suggesting coinfection might be more common than thought in highly endemic areas. Chikunya virus is an RNA virus from the Togaviridae family transmitted by mosquitoes and causes febrile illness, Chikunya fever, associated with severe outcomes. It arrived in Brazil in 2014 through two introductions: Asian/Caribbean genotype in North and ECS in Northeast. Both genotypes established urban cycle among naive populations, causing outbreaks in Americas. The study used an in-house Next-Generation Sequencing (GS) protocol to detect multiple CHV genotypes from clinical samples. The results show both genotypes expanded their range, reaching cocirculation in Northeast Brazil. Future efforts to understand CHV epidemiology should consider coinfection by different genotypes in population.
Bacteria acquire new DNA from their environment through a process called horizontal gene transfer, which increases their genetic diversity and helps them colonize new niches, including the human host. However, it's unclear how this new DNA interacts with the bacterial cell's regulatory networks. The protein H-NS is a global regulator that targets both horizontally acquired and core genes, silencing their expression in response to external stimuli like osmolarity and temperature. Researchers found that HNS differentially modulates core and horizontally acquired DNA. For example, the plasmid R27-encoded HNS protein evolved to silence horizontally acquired genes without interfering with core regulation. In contrast, chromosomal H requires a helper protein, Hha, to silence horizontally acquired DNA, while core genes are modulated by HNS homomers. The presence of H-like proteins is unique to Enterobacteraceae and conjugative plids encoding HNS variants have only been found in this family. The HNS system in Enterobacteria has unique features, allowing it to selectively modulate core and horizontally DNA. This may help maintain horizontally acquired DNA silent and give bacteria an advantage in adapting to new environments, including host colonization.
Scientists have studied the genetic makeup of three types of Leishmania parasites, which cause different diseases in humans, to understand how they interact with their hosts. They found that most genes are similar across the three species, but a few are different. They looked at which of these different genes are active in the parasite's "intracellular" stage, which causes disease, and if similar genes are active differently in different hosts. Using special microarrays, they confirmed that all different genes are active in the intracellular stage, but only a few are regulated at the RNA level. In a large study of one species, Leish, they found that about 9% of genes are regulated during its life cycle, similar to other Leish species. Comparing gene profiles between species confirmed that Leish undergo little regulation but identified conserved genes are regulated differently in hosts. They also looked if host immunity affects parasite expression by comparing RNA profiles in Leish from normal or immunocompromised mice. While parasite spread is enhanced in immunocompromised mice, RNA profiles are unchanged. This suggests Leish are adapted for intracellular survival and don't change gene expression much. Factors contributing to virulence and pathogenicity may be few different genes or regulation of conserved genes, subject to translation or post-translational controls.
Researchers have developed a new test, called LPhimer, to detect a parasite called Amphimer that causes a disease in humans and animals in tropical areas of Ecuador. The current method to diagnose this disease is by looking for eggs in stool, but it's not very sensitive and can be confused with other parasites. The new test, Limer, targets a specific part of the parasite's DNA and can detect as little as 1 picogram of DNA. It was tested on 44 stool samples from areas where the parasite is common, and was able to detect 25 samples that had the parasite. The test's sensitivity and specificity were 76.67% and 80.77%, respectively. This is the first specific and sensitive test for this parasite in stool samples. It has potential to be used in areas where resources are limited and can help diagnose and monitor the disease.
Researchers have discovered a new role for a protein called Ykt in the process of autophagy in fruit flies. Autophagy is a way cells get rid of damaged or unwanted parts. Ykt is a type of SNARE protein that helps fuse autophagosomes with lysosomes to form autolys. Without Ykt, autophagosomes build up and can't fuse with lysosomes. This leads to problems for the cell. The researchers found that Ykt localizes to lysosomes and autagosomes and forms a complex with Sy17 and Snap. However, V7 can outcompete Y from this complex. Overexpressing V7 rescues the defect caused by Y loss of function. A mutant Y with a change in the zeroionic layer of Y6 retains normal autagic activity and restores viability. Both Y and V are required for autag-lys fusion and are mutually exclusive in the Sy17-Snap complex. This suggests V is involved in membrane fusion and Y acts as a non-conventional SN in this process.
Researchers have studied how the bacterium Haemophilus influenza (NTH) resists the effects of antimicrobial peptides (AMPs) produced by the human body to fight infection. TH is a common inhabitant of the nasal mucosa but can cause infections in the upper and lower respiratory tracts. The bacterium has a protein called Sap that helps it resist AMPs, but the mechanism was unknown. The researchers found that Sap binds to AMP and is necessary for TH to be virulent in the body. They also showed that Sap delivers AMP to the inner membrane for transport into the cytoplasm where they are broken down. This is a new way for TH to avoid the body's defense. AMPs are amphipathic, cationic molecules that target bacterial membranes and cause cell death. TH must defend against AMPs to become a pathogen. The body produces AMP in response to infection and altered expression can affect colonization. The researchers previously showed that β-defin controls TH colonization in a model of disease. They neutralized β-def via antibody to assess AMP contribution to TH levels. Defins and cathelicin are abundant in neutrophils, epithelium, and secreted by lung and trache epithelium. AMP limit bacterial colonization of mucosal surfaces. This is the first evidence that Sap contributes to virulence by protecting from AMP lethality. The researchers monitored Sap-AMP in intact cells and found a new mechanism of inner transport of AMP via Sap to cytoplasm for degradation.
Researchers studied how the protein MarA, a key regulator of antibiotic resistance in E. coli, controls its downstream targets. They found that its short lifespan affects how it coordinates these targets. Mar has a short lifespan of 1-3 minutes due to a protease activity. It regulates 60 genes involved in antibiotic resistance, including efflux pumps and stress proteins. This short lifespan is rare in bacteria, so the researchers wondered why it's useful. They used CRISPR to change Mar's lifespan and found that a longer lifespan increases coordination between genes, but at a slower rate. A shorter lifespan allows for more responsive and agile signaling, but less coordination.
Researchers previously found that mice lacking the enzyme MAP kinase phosphatase 2 (MK-2) were more susceptible to infection with the parasite Leishmania mexicana. This was due to increased Arginase-1 levels and reduced NO activity in their macrophages, as well as a diminished TH1 response. In a new study, mice lacking MK-2 were infected with Leishmania major, a different parasite, and surprisingly showed a similar healing response to wild-type mice in terms of lesion size and parasite numbers. Analysis of immune responses showed a reduced TH1 response in MK- mice with lower parasite-specific IgG levels, lower IFN-γ and TNF-α producing CD4 and CD8 T cells, and lower stimulated spleen IFNγ production. However, MK- mice also had reduced IL-4 levels in spleen and lymph node cells and parasite-specific IgG in serum, indicating a general cell hypo-responsiveness. The TH1/TH balance was unchanged in MK mice compared to wild-type. Although MK- macrophages were more permissive to L growth than wild-type macrophages, LPS/IF-γ was equally effective at controlling growth in MK- and wild-type macroages. No change in disease phenotype was observed in MK mice.
Researchers have studied how the pancreas develops its network of ducts, which carry digestive enzymes to the small intestine. Unlike other glands, the pancreas doesn't follow a typical branching pattern. Instead, its ducts form a mesh, then a treelike structure. This process is not well understood, so the team quantified properties at different stages. They found the pancreas has stereotypic traits at each stage and changes as it matures to optimize delivery to the intestine. Using computer modeling, they broke down development into simple rules, likely conserved in other glands. Early network formation is explained by random connections and new ducts forming. Later, the network prunes based on fluid flow to the intestine.

The pancreas' branches differ between mice, but its structure is stereic at each stage and changes as it matures. Observations were condensed into principles and simulated (Fig 4). The network has stereic properties between E12.5 and E.18.5. The transition from mesh to treel structure is reflected in changing properties. The duct system has stereic traits at each stage and remodeling can be quantified. Modeling deconstructed main steps into simple rules. Early formation from E.10 to E.12.5 is explained by noisy, redundant formation of new ducts. However, how ducts form the network is unclear. Remodeling from plex to treel is less understood. Villenor and colleagues provided insight with anatomical description [12]. They showed the pancreas might be more stereic than believed and identified trends in branches.

This work reveals new features of development. The organ is likely relevant to glands with micumen, like saliv and glands that secrete fluid. Proposed rules differ from deterministic branching or random in mammary.
Researchers have mapped the structural and dynamic features of kines motor proteins, which drive intracellular transport by coupling ATP hydrolysis to conformation changes that mediate movement along microtubules. They analyzed 114 experimental structures and used molecular simulations to identify distinct conformations and their conversion mechanism. Three conformation clusters were found: ATP-like, ADP-like, and Eg5-inhibitor bound. These differ in key elements' orientation, notably microtule binding α-α5, loop subdomain and α2-β-4β-β-7 motor tip. Group membership didn't correlate with nucleotide state, but with necker orientation. Simulations showed all three states sample majorlogically observed conformations, with differences in coupling dist sites. In ATP bound, necker, loop, and α-5 sub display motions absent in AD bound. Dissection indicates communication network between active site, microule interface, and necker via loop and loop 13. Simulations show mutations G325 and G326 in loop reduce flexibility and disrupt couplings. Results indicate ATP and AD conformations are intrinsically accessible regardless of nucleotide, supporting a model where necker docking tightens microule and nucleotide regions. Simulations highlight critical conformation changes and alloster coupling between dist sites.
Researchers have developed a new approach to interpret bioluminescent data from the Lux system, a gene reporter used to measure gene expression. The Lux system is fast, sensitive, and non-destructive, and can be used in various cells, including eukaryotic and whole animals, without euthanasia. However, interpreting biolumines data is limited because biolumcence is different from gene expression due to nonlinear and molecular dynamics of the system. The new approach uses a mathematical model of Lux activity, including LuxAB, LuxC, and Fre, with improved mechanisms for reactions and protein synthesis and turn-over. The model is calibrated with data from Photorhabus lumcens, the source of modern Lux reporters, and literature data for Lux. Importantly, it shows evidence for previously unreported inhibition of the Lux reaction. Simulations show biolumcent profiles can differ from gene expression, with peaks of light output similar to some experimental data. By incorporating the model into a Bayesian scheme, promoter activity can be inferred from biolumcence. Examples show a decrease in biolum would be switching off the promoter, and increase biolum would longer expression. This approach benefits users of Lux technology.
Researchers have discovered the structure of Coxsackievirus A16 (CVA) in complex with a molecule called G3, a potential inhibitor of the virus that causes hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in children. This discovery helps understand how G3 interacts with the virus and how it can block its replication. The team used computer simulations to test two new molecules, NLD and ALD, which also bind to the virus and show promise as potential treatments. They tested these molecules against a range of enteroviruses and found them to be potent and broad-spectrum antiviral. 

The researchers analyzed the structure of CVA with G3 and found key residues involved in the interaction. They used computer simulations to test two new molecules, NLD and AL, which bind to the virus and show potential as treatments. They tested these molecules against a range of enteriruses and found them to be potent and broad-spectrum antiral.
In the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, the serpin Necrot plays a crucial role in regulating the immune response to fungal and Gram-positive bacterial infections. When the fly is infected, a proteolytic cascade is activated through the Toll receptor, leading to the synthesis of antibiotic peptides in the fat body and export to the hemolymph. Necrot is synthesized in the fat body, but its site of degradation was unclear. Researchers used a temperature-sensitive Dynamin mutation to "freeze" endocytosis and found that Necrot is removed from the hemolymph by two types of cells: giant cells and pericardial macrophages. Nec uptake increases rapidly after 30 minutes and peaks at 6-8 hours. The serpin is processed through multivesicular bodies and delivered to the lysosome, co-localizing with ubiquitin protein HRS. It does not co-localize with Rab11, indicating it's not re-exported from macrophages. Mutations blocking late endosome/lysosome fusion cause accumulation of Nec-positive endosomes, even without infection. Knocking down the Drosila ortholog of mammalian LDL receptor Lp1 identifies it as an enhancer of the immune uptake of Nec. Chromosomal deletion of Lp1 blocks uptake of Nec from hemolymph. The study identifies cells and receptor responsible for Nec uptake and degradation in Dophila. Scavenging ser/protein complexes may regulate proteolytic cascades.
In sea urchins, two opposing signals, Nodal and BMP, play a crucial role in establishing left-right (LR) asymmetry. Nodal signaling prevents the formation of the rudiment on the right side, but the opposing pathway to Nodal during LR establishment was unclear. Researchers found that BMP signaling is activated in the left coelomic pouch, specifically in the veg2 lineage, but not in small micromeres. By perturbing BMP activities, they demonstrated that BMP signaling is required for the expression of left-sided genes and formation of left-sided structures. On the other hand, Nodal on the right inhibits BMP signaling and controls asymmetric apoptosis of small miceres. The study shows BMP is a positive signal for left-sided development in seaurchs, suggesting the opposing roles of Nodal and BMP in LR asymmetry are conserved in deuteromes.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a widespread human pathogen that causes serious disease in immunocompromised patients and neonates. The virus exists in a latent, asymptomatic state or undergoes productive replication leading to lysis of the host. Lytic replication starts with the onset of viral early (IE) gene expression. Researchers found that inhibition of cyclin-dependent kinase activity by checkpoint or chemical roscovine restores virus permissiveness in S2 cells. CD inhibition also antagonizes silencing of lytic expression during quiescent, latent infection of undifferentiated NT2 cells, suggesting a link between cell cycle and repression of IE transcription. Data suggest that DNA-dependent release of IE expression removes major obstacle to CM replication from S cells and infection proceeds with normal kinetics from G1 cells. The tumor suppressor p53 governs long-term response to genotoxic by inducing p21 cell arrest or apoptosis. Inhibitory function of CD on CM lytic expression is not restricted to cycle but likely has broader relevance for states of IE expression. Induction of IE by CD inhibition occurs in all cell phases of NT2, though S2 most sensitive at low concentrations. Rescue of CM expression in S relies on p-dependent signalling, induced by genotoxic or replicative stress.
Researchers studied how the immune system fights HIV in people who naturally control the virus without treatment. These individuals, called elite controllers, have strong HIV-specific T cells that keep the virus in check. However, how these cells develop is unclear. Dendritic cells, a type of immune cell, can recognize and help create HIV-specific T cells, but HIV often evades this recognition. The study found that in elite controllers, dendritic cells quickly produce interferons, proteins that fight viruses, and upregulate genes that help fight viruses. This innate response is linked to reduced viral replication and increased T cell death. Blocking this response with drugs or silencing a sensor gene reduced this effect. Importantly, this recognition in dendritic cells from controllers led to stronger HIV-specific T cell responses. The study suggests innate interferon production in dendritic cells is crucial for effective HIV-specific T cells and may aid in preventing or treating HIV.
Scientists have developed a new method to identify genes that control fat storage in fruit fly larvae. They used this method to find 66 genes that make the larvae store more fat, including a gene called Sir2. Sir2 regulates how the body stores and uses carbohydrates and fats by breaking down key proteins. In mammals, Sir2 works differently in different parts of the body, making it hard to understand its role in energy balance. The researchers found that knocking down Sir2 in larvae makes them store more fat. They also showed that Sir2 limits fat storage in individual cells of the body on its own. This suggests Sir2 helps switch from using nutrients to stored fat as energy. Surprisingly, Sir2 mutants survive longer than normal flies when starved of amino acids as long as they have sugar. The study points to a Sir pathway that helps respond to amino acid starvation, regardless of sugar levels. The researchers found that Sir2 regulates metabolic enzymes in mutants, showing a shift from burning to storing fat. They conclude that Sir2 is a key in switching from using nutrients to stored fat as energy.
Researchers studied the first embryonic division of 42 species of nematodes, closely related to Caenorhabditis elegans, to understand how the mitotic spindle behaves during asymmetric cell division. This process is crucial for generating cellular diversity in animals. They recorded the division of 128 strains from 27 Caenorhabis and 15 non-Caenorhabis species and found variations in the degree of cell asymmetry and spindle movements, including oscillation, elongation, and displacement. Notably, these changes occurred without a clear direction in the species' phylogeny, except for spindle oscillations, which evolved at the base of the Caenorhabis genus. These changes were unrelated to embryo size variations. Importantly, elongation, displacement, and oscillation evolved independently. This contrasts with previous studies on C elegans and reveals new changes in spindle mechanics. The study shows that while asymmetric division has been conserved in nemode evolution, spindle parameters can combine in various ways, like other developmental processes.
Researchers studied how two closely related bacteria, Salmonella Typhimium and Escheria coli, respond to acid stress. They found that both have the same protein, Omp, but it's regulated differently in each species. In Salmonella Tyim, Omp is turned on at low pH, while in Escheria, it's not. This is due to differences in the promoter region of the O gene and the Esia O orthologue can be made acid-inducible by introducing sequences from Salmonella. The O regulon in Salmonella overlaps with Esia at 15 genes, including virulence genes Esia doesn't have. O binds to its targets more when DNA is relaxed, which happens in Salmon as a result of acid stress and is needed for virulence genes. Targets of O don't share a strong sequence consensus, suggesting O can recruit genes to its regulon from modest specificity and preference for relaxed DNA.
Researchers have identified a new protein, called N, secreted by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis, that enters the host cells and targets histones in the cell's nucleus. This is the first time a bacterial protein has been found to directly target mammalian histones. The protein, named nuclear effector (N), contains a domain that suggests it functions as a histone methyltransfer, an enzyme that adds methyl groups to histones. Studies showed that N is secreted from the bacterium through a type III secretion mechanism and enters the host cell's nucleus, where it associates with chromatin. Experiments confirmed N is a histone methyltransfer that modifies histones H2, H3, and H4, and even itself, in a process called automethylation. Automethylation seems to enhance N's enzymatic activity, making it more effective at modifying histones. This is the first time a bacterial effector has been found to target mammalian histones. The study suggests N may play a role in Chydia's pathogenicity, but more research is needed to understand its function.
A new study of 35,000 people from 21 different populations found a link between inbreeding and lower height. Inbreeding is when two parents are closely related, like cousins or siblings. The study found that the children of cousins were 3cm shorter on average than children of unrelated parents. This effect remained even after accounting for factors like income and education. However, the effect size of inbreeding on height varied between populations. The study suggests that many rare genetic variants contribute to height, not just a few common ones. The method used in this study can be applied to other heritable traits, like diabetes or heart disease, to understand how inbreeding affects them.
Researchers have identified a distinct type of immune cell in the blood that helps fight off malaria parasites during an infection. This cell, called a monocyte (MO), has different forms and functions that change depending on the body's inflammatory state. The study looked at MO in people with acute malaria and those who had been exposed to malaria but didn't have the disease. They used a technique called flow cytometry to analyze the cells and tested their ability to fight parasites in a lab setting. Results showed that people with high numbers of a specific type of MO, CD14 CCR2CXCR1, had lower parasite levels in their blood compared to those with low numbers of this MO. This suggests a possible link between MO and parasite-fighting activity. The study also found that MO in people with malaria had higher levels of certain markers, such as CCR, CXCR, CD56, TN-α, and IF-γ, which are associated with strong parasite-fighting. Historically, MO have been seen as phagocytic cells, clearing parasites with or opson antibodies. However, this study found differences in MO subsets between people with malaria and healthy controls, with increased inflammatory MO in those with the disease. MO in people with malaria had higher levels of TREM, a marker of inflammation. The study found two groups of patients with different MO phenotypes, one with high CD CCR CXCR and low parasitemia, and the other with low CCR CXCR and high parasia.
A study of 34 HIV-uninfected Ugandan men found that Schistosoma mansoni infection was associated with an increase in HIV-susceptible T cell subsets in the blood, but not the foreskin. Men with S. mansoni infection had higher levels of Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells in their blood compared to those without the infection. Th17 cells in the blood of S mansoni-infected men also produced more cytokines. However, these immune changes were not seen in the foreskin tissue. The study suggests that S mansoni infection may increase HIV susceptibility through the mucosal immune system, but this effect is limited to the blood and does not extend to the foreskin, which is the primary site of HIV acquisition in heterosexual men.
Researchers have found that depleting Wolbachia, a bacteria that live inside filarial nematodes, causes extensive apoptosis, or cell death, in the nemat's reproductive cells and embryos. This is a promising approach to treating filarial diseases, which are caused by these nematodes. The study used whole mount confocal microscopy to observe the effects of Wolia depletion on nemat cells. They found that apoptosis occurs in adult reproductive cells, embryos, and microfilar, and fourth-stage larvae after Wolia depletion. Surprisingly, apoptosis occurs in most embryonic cells that were not infected with Wolia before treatment. Apoptosis does not occur in the hypermal, which has many Wolia, but the hypermal cytoskeleton is disrupted after Wolia depletion. This suggests that Wolia factors in the hypermal cause apoptosis. The pattern of apoptosis matches the nemat tissues affected by Wolia depletion, such as embryogenesis and sterilization, which last for months. The study provides a cellular explanation for reduced microilar loads and interrupted transmission after antibiotic therapy in fil nematodes.
Researchers studied how the malaria-causing parasite Plasium falcum requires a nutrient called pantoate to grow and multiply. They found that the parasite converts pantoate into a molecule called coenzyme A (CoA) using an enzyme called panto kinase (Pan). Some anti-malarial medicines, like panto and CJ-15,801, kill the parasite by targeting CoA production. However, the exact mechanism of action was unknown. The researchers created parasite lines resistant to these medicines by exposing them to panto and CJ-15,801. Whole-genome sequencing revealed mutations in a Pan gene called Pfpan1 in all resistant lines. These mutations altered Pan activity, causing a fitness cost, suggesting Pfpan1 is essential for normal growth. The mutants showed different sensitivity to other anti-mial pantoate analogues, one being hypersensitive. The study suggests different pate classes have different mechanisms: some inhibit Co production while others inhibit using enzymes.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide association study to identify genetic variants associated with the PR interval, a measure of atrial and ventricular conduction time, in African Americans. They analyzed data from 6,247 individuals and found a strong signal in the SCN5A gene, which encodes a cardiac sodium channel, associated with a 2% of PR variability in African Americans. The same variant was also associated with PR in Europeans, but with a smaller effect size and less variability. Further analysis identified additional variants in SCN5, ME1, and TBX5 associated with PR, some of which were also found in European and Asian studies. African ancestry was associated with increased PR duration in one cohort, but not others. The study demonstrates relevance of common variants in African at loci previously associated with PR in European and Asian samples and identifies a signal more strongly associated with PR in Africans than Europeans. The PR interval is a risk factor for atrial fibrillation, heart block, and mortality, with genetic factors explaining 30-50% of variability in European and Asian populations.
Researchers have identified a small GTP-binding protein called ARL8 that plays a crucial role in the replication of Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV), a type of virus that infects plants. To replicate its genetic material, the virus forms complexes on cellular membranes inside the plant cells. Previous studies showed that a protein called TOM is necessary for the virus to multiply efficiently. The study found that ARL, along with TOM, is associated with the virus's replication protein in the membranes of infected tobacco plant cells. When membranes from infected cells expressing ARL were purified, TOM and the virus's replication proteins were also found together. This suggests that a complex of TOM, ARL, and virus proteins forms on membranes in infected cells. In plants, ARL has four family members. Mutations in two ARL genes stopped the virus from multiplying. In a lab experiment, lacking TOM or ARL inhibited the virus's replication. The study suggests TOM and ARL are crucial for the virus's replication process.
Researchers studied the role of inhibitory neurons in the locust's olfactory system to understand how they shape the firing patterns of principal neurons. Two types of inhibitory motifs emerged: feed-forward (FF) and feedback (FB). In the locust, a subset of lateral interneurons (LHNs) provided feed-forward inhibition to Kenyon cells (KCs) to maintain sparse firing, crucial for olfactory learning and memory. However, a single inhibitory cell, the GABAergic neuron (GN), was found to be the main source of inhibition in the mushroom body, mediated by a feedback loop including KCs and GN. A model of the locust olfactory system was used to compare the effects of FF and FB inhibition. Both motifs maintained KC responses and provided optimal odor discrimination, but only FB created a response consistent with in vivo data. This suggests that GN is potentially the primary source of inhibition to KCs. Understanding inhibitory motifs' impact on postsynaptic activity could reveal unknown structures in biological networks.
Researchers have developed a new laboratory test to diagnose rabies, a deadly viral disease that affects animals and humans. The test, called combined real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR), can detect all types of lyssavirus, a group of viruses that includes rabies. It uses two methods: one detects rabies virus (RV) and the other detects other lyaviruses. The test was tested with many animal samples and human samples, including saliva, skin, and brain tissue. It correctly identified 91.5% of rabies cases in skin samples and 54% in saliva. The test was also used in two laboratories in Cambodia and Morocco. This new test is a useful tool for diagnosing rabies in animals and humans and for tracking the virus.
An outbreak of tset-transmitted trypanosomias resulted in over 50% losses of domestic pigs in the Eastern Region of Ghana. To control the disease, a trial was conducted from May to October 2007 to assess the efficacy of insecticide-treated mosquito nets. Two villages were selected, one as control with 14 pigs and one experimental with 24 pigs protected by insecticide-treated nets. The nets were 100 high, 150 denier polyester with 100mg/m deltamethrin and UV protector attached to poles. Bi-monthly monitoring with geo-referenced traps showed a 90% reduction in the protected village within two months, exceeding 95% in subsequent months. The control village tset population remained unaffected, displaying seasonal variations. Fifty pigs from each village were ear-tagged and given curative treatment after blood samples taken. Initial trypan prevalence was 76% and 72 in protected and control, decreasing to 16 and 84 after three months. Six months later, 8% of protected were infected, 60 in control.
A recent survey of 441 biomedical articles published between 2000-2014 found low levels of reproducibility and transparency. Only one study provided a full protocol and none made raw data directly available. Replication studies were rare, with only 4 found in the sample, and 16 had data included in a systematic review or meta-analysis. Most studies didn't mention funding or conflicts of interest. The percentage of articles with no funding statement decreased from 94.4% in 2000 to 34.6% in 2014, while those reporting conflicts increased from 0 in 200 to 15.4% in 201 and no conflicts from 5.6 in 200 to 50 in 201. Articles in clinical medicine journals were more likely to lack funding information and have private funding. The study provides baseline data to track future progress in reproducibility.
Researchers studied how the bacteria Yersinia pestis causes primary pneumonic plague, a deadly disease with a 100% mortality rate. They found that the bacteria first target alveolar macrophages in the lungs, then switch to neutrophils, a type of immune cell. Neutrophils can't stop the bacteria from growing and cause severe inflammation, leading to the disease's lethal phase. The study used a special probe to track proteins delivered by the bacteria's type III secretion system, which is essential for its virulence and has anti-inflammatory effects on mammalian cells. They found that depleting 92% of alolar macroages had little effect on bacterial growth, suggesting they're not crucial in limiting the bacteria's survival. The bacteria create a protective environment in the lungs early stages of the disease, suppressing the host's immune response. The researchers hypothesized the bacteria target immune cells early via type III secretion of effectors. They tracked the fate of macrophages and neutils to understand the progression to the disease's inflammatory phase. This study is the first to identify host cells and population dynamics in the lung during pneumonic plague, showing the bacteria primarily target macroages and neutils in the pre-inflammatory phase.
Researchers conducted a study in Brazil to evaluate the accuracy of enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) using soluble recombinant antigens to detect asymptomatic Leishmaniasis infection. They collected blood samples from 136 participants, 97 of whom were positive and 39 negative by PCR, over a two-year follow-up period. None of the asymptomatic participants progressed to disease. Controls included samples from 22 healthy individuals and 8 patients with kala-azar. Molecular techniques confirmed Leishmania presence in all kala patients and 86% of participants. Kala patients showed high reactivity in ELISA, while asymptomatic individuals showed low reactivity against tested antigens. Compared to molecular methods, L. amazon and L. infant antigens showed higher sensitivity 49.6% and 41% respectively, while r39 had 26.5%. However, r39 had higher specificity 73.7% than L. amazon 52.6 and L. infant 36.8. There was low agreement among different antigens used. Serological tests were inaccurate diagnosing asymptomatic compared to molecular, leading to misclassification in population studies. Studies using serological to estimate prevalence, evaluate programs or identify risk Leish infection may have compromised results.
Researchers have developed a new method to analyze retrotranson expression in mouse embryonic stem cells using Illumina and Affymetrix gene microarray data. This approach allowed them to identify histone deacetylase Hd1 as a component of the retrotranson silencing machinery in these cells. They also found retrotransons that are targets of other silencing mechanisms such as DNA methylation, histone modification, and RingB/E-containing polycomb repressive complexes. The study suggests that multiple silencing mechanisms are independently targeted to retroons in embryonic cells, and different copies of the same retroon can be differentially sensitive to silencing. The researchers used repeat-annotation of microarray data to investigate established mechanisms of retroon silencing and found a complex interplay between DNA methylation and histone modifications regulating expression of repetitive elements in the mouse genome. They identified retroons that are silenced by methylation and histone modifications in embryonic cells and histone deetylase Hd1 as a regulator of retroons in these cells. The study shows that genome-wide silencing of elements can be monitored by extracting information from microarray data, revealing a complex interplay between mechanisms controlling retroon expression in embryonic and germ cells, and differences in behavior of different copies of individual retroons. This approach can generate new insights into retro regulation in mammals and identify components of defense mechanisms protecting the genome from retroposition.
Arabidopsis thaliana cryptochrome 2 (CRY) plays a crucial role in regulating flowering time by controlling the expression of the Flowering Locus T (FT) gene. CRY-interacting bHL1 (C1) interacts with CRY in response to blue light to activate FT transcription. However, in vivo, C1 binds to the chromatin region of the FT promoter, which contains non-canonical E-box sequences, not canonical-box. Researchers found that CRY also interacts with at least C5 in response to blue light, but not in darkness or other wavelengths. Genetic analysis showed that C1, C2, C4, and C5 act redundantly activate FT transcription and are positive regulators of C2-mediated flowering. Importantly, C1 and other C proteins form heterodimers, some of which have higher affinity to non-canonical-box in vitro assays. This explains why C1 and C bind canonical-box with higher affinity in vitro, but are associated with non-canonical-box at FT promoter vivo. Consistent with hypothesis that C play similar roles in C2-mediated blue signaling, C expression is regulated by light. The study shows C redundantly regulate C2 flowering and different C form heterodimers interact non-canonical DNA vivo.
Researchers studied the cost-effectiveness of treating intestinal parasites in US-bound refugees from Asia. Parasites like hookworm, Trichuris, Ascaris, and Strongloides are rare in the US and often misdiagnosed, leading to serious consequences. They compared four options: no treatment, US domestic screening and treatment, overseas presumptive treatment with albendazole and ivermect, and overseas albazole and domestic screening for Stronglo. A model estimated costs and health impacts on 27,700 refugees. The "No" option was the least expensive ($165,923) and least effective (145 cases, 4 hospitalizations, 0 deaths). Overseas albazole and ivermect ($418,824) was less expensive than domestic treatment ($3,832,572) or overseas alb and screening ($2,182,483). The most effective option was overseas alb and iverect, reducing cases and deaths by 80% at a cost of $458,718 per death or $2,219 per QAL gained. Overse presum treatment for US-bound refugees is cost-effective and less expensive than domestic treatment.
Researchers have discovered a new species of microsporidian parasite that infects the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, a worm commonly used in scientific research. This parasite, named Nematida displere, is unique because it can infect and replicate in multiple tissues, including the epidermis, muscle, neurons, and intestine, unlike other related parasites that only infect the intestine. Most of the parasite's replication occurs in the muscle and epider, not the intestine. The genome of Nematida displere is distinct from its relatives, with over 10% of its proteins belonging to a single family of unknown proteins that may help it interact with the host. This discovery provides a new model to study how pathogens grow in different tissues.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called Cockayne syndrome B (CS) plays a crucial role in fixing damaged DNA during transcription, a process called transcription-coupled DNA repair. CS is essential for this process, but mutations in CS lead to Cockayne syndrome, a disease characterized by premature aging, sun sensitivity, and developmental issues. CS belongs to a family of proteins that remodel chromatin, the complex of DNA and proteins that make up chromosomes. However, how CS remodels chromatin and if this activity is used in repair was unknown. The study found that CS repositions nucleosomes, the building blocks of chromatin, in an energy-dependent manner and this is enhanced by N1-like histone chaper, a new partner of CS. By analyzing CS and its derivatives, researchers showed that chromatin remodeling by CS and N1-like chaper is necessary for efficient transcription-cou DNA repair. They also found that chrom remodeling and repair by CS are separate activities. This collaboration between CS and N1 chaper adds to understanding of how chromatin remodelers and chaperons regulate chrom structure. The study provides new insights into CS function in transcription-c DNA repair and mechanisms of Cockayne syndrome.
Researchers have created a detailed map of epigenetic variation in the human genome by studying DNA methylation patterns in five different cell types. They found clusters of CpG sites with high individual variation, called Variably Methyl Regions (VM), which occur at enhancers and 3' untranslated regions. Most VM have heritability, but a subset show low heritability and form co-regulated networks specific to each cell type. These networks are enriched for transcription factor binding sites and biological pathways relevant to each tissue. For example, in T cells, a network of 95 co-regulated VMs is involved in T-cell activation, while in fibroblasts, a network of 34 co-reg VMs controls growth, and in neurons, a network of 18 VMs is involved in synaptic signaling. The researchers also showed that some VM networks are responsive to environment, with methylation levels changing in a coordinated fashion under different conditions. These environmentally-responsive VMs are enriched for imprinted loci, suggesting they are sensitive to environmental conditions. The study provides a map of epigenetic variation in the genome, showing both genetic and environmental causes underlie variation.
Researchers have developed a new rapid test for the dengue virus, called the Panbio Dengue Early, which detects a protein called NS1. This protein is present in the body early stages of infection, typically within 1-9 days of symptoms. The test was evaluated in Vietnam and Malaysia with 198 and 263 laboratory-confirmed samples. The test alone had a sensitivity of 69.2% and 68.9% and specificity of 96% and 96.7 compared to PCR. When combined with a commercial IgM/Ig rapid test, the sensitivity increased to 93%. The study found that using NS1 detection with IgM and Ig serology increased the sensitivity of acute deng diagnosis and extended the detection window to early samples. The test was compared to other NS rapid tests in the same region and showed good performance. The combination of NS1 with IgM and Ig detection resulted in a significant increase in sensitivity compared to individual markers. In Malaysia, the clinical utility of the Dengue Rapid alone and in combination with Dengue Cassette was assessed. The individual sensitivity of Dengue Rapid and Dengue Cassette was 62 and 72.5. The combination of NS1 with Ig detection resulted in a significant increase to 89.
Researchers have developed a new method called Trans to detect conserved helices of functional RNA structures, including transient, pseudo-knotted and alternative structures. These structures are important for understanding how RNA functions in living cells. Current methods assume a unique RNA structure and don't predict features needed for folding in cells. Trans uses evolutionarily related genes to find similar structures in cells. It predicts features of known structures, including pseudo-kotted ones and alternative configurations. It also identifies unstructured sequences bound by molecules and suggests new helices that define folding pathways. This supports the idea that homologous sequences don't just have similar structures, but also fold similarly. Unlike other methods, Trans doesn't predict function over time, but highlights conserved features and doesn't need cellular details. 

The co-transcription folding differs from re-folding in time and structure. Computational methods take kinetics into account, but await testing in cells. A new approach studies folding in cells. Errors in early stages are magnified as folding progresses. Knowing the start of RNA sequence is crucial. Existing methods' performance is on small data. Studying folding experimentally is challenging. Trans predicts novel helices of significance, corresponding to conserved cocription features, supporting homolog sequences fold similarly.
Plants have a built-in defense system to protect themselves from harmful microbes. This system, called immunity, must work even when some of its parts are damaged by the microbes. To be resilient, the system allows different parts to compensate for each other's loss. Scientists studied this system in Arabidopsis, a plant, by taking it apart and reassembling it to understand how it works. They found that the system is made of four main parts: salicylate, jasmon, ethylene, phytoalexin-deficient 4, and salicylate signaling. These parts interact with each other to control the plant's response to an immune trigger, flagellin-22. Some interactions help the system work even when one part is damaged. This is called buffering. The researchers used a new approach, called network reconstitution, to study the system. It involves taking apart and reassembling the system to see how it works. They found that some parts are key to the system even if they don't show changes when one or two are missing. This is because they work together with other parts to keep the system working. The study shows that looking at the system as a whole can help understand how it works, especially when it's resilient to damage.
In the fruit fly Drosila, the nervous system develops from a single layer of cells called neuroepithelial sheets. To create diversity in the nervous system, these sheets are subdivided into domains in a controlled and timely manner. The optic placode, a part of the nervous system, gives rise to the larval eye and optic lobe. The lar eye has two types of photoreceptors: primary and secondary, while the opticobe develops into prominent ganglia during larval and pupal stages. Researchers found a genetic network that controls the balance between eye and opticobe precursors, as well as primary and secondary photoreceptors. The gene proneural factor Aton specifies eye precursors, while the nuclear receptor Tailless is crucial for opticobe precursors. The Hedgehog and Notch signaling pathways act upstream of A and T to coordinate precursor specification. The boundary between A and T controls the number of primary and secondary photore. Notch also controls cell fate, acting in a cascade of transcription interactions to define photore subtype. This study shows how extrinsic and intrinsic factors control neural patterning.
Human beta-defensin 1 (hBD1) is a naturally occurring antimicrobial peptide in the human body that has been shown to have distinct activities in its oxidized and reduced forms. Researchers have explored its mechanisms of action and found that the reduced form of h1 creates a net-like structure around bacteria, trapping them and preventing their migration, but not killing them. This is different from other antimicrobial peptides that primarily kill bacteria. The reduced form of h1 is stable even in the presence of digestive enzymes that break down proteins. In contrast, cysteine, a component of the peptide, is not necessary for net formation. The reduced form of h1 provides additional protection by entrapping bacteria in extracellular structures, preventing invasion. This is a new mechanism of action for h1, different from other defensins like human-defin 6. The study highlights the difference between conventional antibiotics and endogenous host molecules like h1, which have multifunctional activities. The reduced form of h1 forms distinct structures post-translationally, controlled by the local environment. The TR system transforms oxidized h1 into the reduced form. The reduced form of h1 entraps bacteria, a previously unknown function. This mechanism is distinct from human-def 6, indicating a broad spectrum of conserved mechanisms. The presence of h1 in human colonic mucus was previously shown. The multiple strategies of defense might explain why humans have not lost the battle with microbes despite millions of years of exposure. The distinct activities of h1 represent an example of a host peptide using multiple strategies to combat bacteria.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called OCRL is essential for a process called endocytosis in the zebraf pronephric tub, a model of the mammalian kidney. Endocyt is the process by which cells take in substances from outside the body. In Lowe syndrome and Dent disease, caused by mutations in OCRL, patients have low levels of protein in their urine. The study found that OCRL-deficient zebraf embryos have reduced endocyt, with less uptake of fluid and protein from the glomerulate. They also found fewer early endytic compartments and large vacuolar endosomes in proneph cells. Cell polarity in the proneph tub is unaffected in mutant embryos. OCRL-deficient embryos have mild ciliogenesis, but this is not the cause of endocyt defect. Catalytic activity of OCRL is needed for renal endyt and endoc can be rescued by suppressing PIPK. This is the first time OCRL is shown to be needed for endytic in vivo and supports that endytic defects cause renalulopathy in Lowe and Dent disease. PIPK is a potential target for Lowe and Dent disease treatment.
Researchers studied the presence of Rift Valley Fever (RV) in livestock in the Kilom River Valley, Tanzania, a region that experiences annual flooding. They conducted a cross-sectional survey of cattle and sheep from May to August 2011, approximately four years after a 2007 RV outbreak. The study aimed to establish baseline exposure to RV virus and assess relationship between seropositivity and animal and environmental factors. Overall, 11.3% of animals had RV antibodies, with 5.5% born after the 2007 outbreak and 22.7 during the outbreak. There was a linear increase in prevalence in post-epid cohorts. Nine samples were positive for RV IgM antibodies, indicating recent infection. Seropreval exhibited hotspots, with no difference in males and females born after the epidemic, but significant in those during the outbreak. Animals over 15km from the floodplain were more likely to have antibodies than those under 5km. Species, breed, herd composition, and grazing practices were not associated with serositivity. Findings indicate post-epid transmission of RV in the area, with constant exposure and active foci preceding the survey.
Trypanosoma cruz, the parasite responsible for Chagas disease, has a unique contractile vacuole complex (CVC) that helps regulate its osmolarity. As an obligate intracellular pathogen, it also relies on surface proteins to invade hosts. Researchers used genetic and biochemical approaches to study the VC's role in trafficking glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins to the parasite's plasma membrane and host invasion. They found that T. cruzi Rab11 (GFP-TR11) localized to the VC, while a dominant negative mutant (DN) tagged GFP-TR11 localized to the cytosol, and epastigotes expressing this mutant were less responsive to hyposotic and hyperosmotic stress. Mutant parasites still differentiated into metacylic forms and infected cells. GPI-anch transialase (TTS), mucins of 60-200K family, and trypastigote surface antigen (TSS II) co-localized with GFP-TR to VC during intramastigotes transformation into trypastigotes. Parasites expressing GFP-TR11 prevented TS, but not other proteins, from reaching the plasma and were less infective compared to wild type. Incubation with exogenous recombinant active, not inactive TS and sialic acid before infecting cells partially rescued infectivity trypastigotes.
Researchers conducted a phase III clinical trial to compare the effectiveness and safety of a shortened rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) regimen using a purified chick-embryo rabies vaccine (PCV) administered intradermally for 4 times in 1 week, versus the standard 2-site regimen. The study included 443 participants aged 1 year or older, divided into 4 groups to receive intradermal PCV with or without human rabies immunoglobulin (HR) at the first visit. Rabies virus neutralizing antibody (RV) concentrations were measured up to day 365 post-vaccination. The 4-site/1 regimen was noninferior to the 2-site regimen at day 49, with 95% of participants having adequate RV concentrations. Both regimens had similar safety profiles, with no vaccination-related serious events. The study suggests the 4/1 regimen could be an alternative to current recommendations, offering improved efficiency and compliance.
Researchers have studied the brain's ability to detect and respond to important events, focusing on the "salience network" (SN), a group of brain regions including the anterior insula and anterior cingulate cortex. They used high-resolution brain scans from the Human Connectome Project and graph theory to investigate the SN's dynamic organization. The study found that the SN is highly flexible and interacts with other brain networks, such as the frontopetal, cingulateopular, and ventral dorsal attention networks. Its interactions are also highly varied in space and time. The SN acts as a central hub, connecting other networks, and its connections change over time are unique compared to other control systems like the frontopetal and ventral attention networks. The study found that the SN's flexibility is linked to individual differences in cognitive flexibility. The results were consistent in a second test, showing the findings are reliable. This research provides new insights into the SN's dynamic architecture and how it facilitates interactions with multiple brain systems, supporting various cognitive processes.
Scientists have been trying to understand how non-enveloped viruses, like SV40, are released from host cells. These viruses assemble in the nucleus and don't have a membrane, so they must be released without one. A new protein, VP4, is expressed late in the viral cycle and may play a role in this process. To investigate, VP4 was expressed and purified as a fusion protein from bacteria. It was found to bind and disrupt membranes, making them permeable to large molecules. The hydrophobic part of VP is essential for this. It prefers membranes with lipids like those in plasma membranes, not nuclear ones. Phosphatylethanol, a lipid in bacterial membranes, inhibits VP's activity. VP forms pores of 3nm in diameter in mammalian cells, including SV host cells. This suggests VP acts as a viropin to perforate membranes for viral release.
Researchers have developed a DNA vaccine that protects against deng, a serious disease spread in tropical and subtropical areas, by using a protein called NS1. The vaccine, called pcANS, was tested in mice and shown to be effective against the virus. To understand how it works, the researchers looked at the immune response it triggered in the mice. They found that the vaccine induced both antibodies and T cells that fight the virus. The antibodies alone provided some protection, but the combination of both was needed for full protection. The T cells, specifically CD4, played a crucial role in the protection. When these cells were removed, the vaccine no longer worked. Experiments showed that transferring CD4 cells from vaccinated mice to others, along with antibodies, gave the same protection as the vaccine alone. This suggests that CD4 cells and antibodies work together to fight deng. The study provides new insights into how the immune system responds to NS1 and may lead to a vaccine development.
Researchers have studied how the cell-to-cell communication system in Gram-positive bacteria, specifically in Streptococcus, which relies on extracellular peptides to trigger responses. They focused on the RNPP family of proteins, which regulate important processes like sporulation, conjugation, and virulence, and are considered targets for new antibacterial agents. The team elucidated the structure-function of ComR, a new member of the RNPP, which controls natural transformation in Streptoccus. Com is activated by binding to its pheromone X, a mature form of the ComS-inducing peptide. Crystal analysis and mutational assays revealed a mechanism: XIP induces release of the sequestered HTH domain and Com dimerization to DNA binding. This mechanism is conserved in Com orthologs, showing Com is not an R protein but a new RNPP member. Identifying X and Com residues for activation is crucial for designing antagonistic strategies to control gene exchanges in Streptoccus. This is the first report of peptide-mediated control of a transcription regulator by sequestration of its DNA domain. The study proposes a molecular mechanism of Com activation and offers opportunities for controlled peptide-based systems in Strept and Gram bacteria.
Scientists have discovered a way to activate a protein called ELIC, a type of ion channel that helps transmit signals in the nervous system. ELIC is part of a large family of channels that includes receptors for important neurotransmitters like serotonin and acetylcholine. To understand how these channels work, researchers needed to know what activates them. They found that a class of molecules called primary amines, including the neurotransmitter GABA, can activate EL at high concentrations. These molecules bind to a specific site on the protein and cause the channel to open, but the effect wears off over time. The channel allows positively charged ions to pass through, similar to another type of receptor called nicotinic acetylcholine. EL's simple behavior makes it a good model to study how these channels work. Researchers used a library of molecules to find the right activators, located one in a crystal structure, and studied the channel's properties. This helps understand how signals are transmitted in the nervous system.
Researchers have found a link between skin barrier defects and the development of asthma in individuals with a history of eczema/atopic dermatitis (AD). They studied mice with skin-barrier defects and found they developed AD-like inflammation and were susceptible to asthma. A protein called thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSL) expressed by skin cells is the driver of bronial hyperresponsiveness. Mice with keratin-specific deletion of RBP showed high levels of TSL and developed severe asthma after allergen challenge. Eliminating TSL signaling blocked the atopic march, showing high TSL levels sensitize the lung to inflammation. Mice with high TSL without skin pathology developed asthma. Importantly, epidermal T was sufficient to trigger atopic sensitizing lung inhaled allergens without epicutaneous sensitization. The study suggests treating skin-bar defects and inhibiting TSL may prevent asthma in AD patients.
Scientists have developed a new approach to analyze the genetic data of microorganisms by combining multiple types of data with computer tools. This method was used to study the genome of Thermotoga marima, a type of bacteria that thrives in extremely hot environments. The analysis revealed unique features of its genome compared to other bacteria, such as a high number of genes per unit, few non-coding RNAs, and few units with multiple start sites. Transcription regulation is limited by lack of space between units. Many genes are expressed regardless of growth state and there is a strong link between mRNA and protein levels. These properties are thought to be due to its ability to live in hot conditions and could provide insights into life on Earth's evolution.
Researchers investigated how context influences our perception of visual features in images. They presented observers with a display of bars and asked if a target bar was present at the center. Observers were more likely to see the target when the context was weak rather than strong. When the context matched the target, weak bars made observers see the target more, while high-contrast bars made them less likely to see it. A Bayesian model showed that context affects perception in two ways: biasing prior belief in the target's presence and biasing internal model of input caused by the target. This suggests areas beyond primary visual cortex are responsible for inferences.
Researchers have found that the presence of "defectors" in a population can sometimes lead to conditions that rescue cooperation from destruction. Defectors are individuals that consume a common good without contributing to its production, which can lead to the depletion of the good and collapse of cooperation. However, in a structured population, small size can favor cooperation. This is because small size increases variability in cooperator frequency across locations, allowing cooperators to outgrow defectors globally despite defectors outgrowing cooperators in each location. The researchers used an individual-based model to demonstrate three mechanisms by which defectors can lead to conditions that rescue cooperation. First, def-induced population collapse can allow cooperators to grow when defectors go extinct by chance. Second, empty locations created by def-induced extinction can favor cooperation by allowing cooperator but not defector migrants to grow. Third, resource limitation induced by def can select for adaptive mutations to limitation, which can favor cooperation. These factors lead to the counterintuitive result that initial presence of defectors can improve survival of cooperation compared to when def are absent. In a structured population, small sizes precipitated by def provide a "built-in" mechanism for persistence of cooperation.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a type of bacteria that can cause infections in people with weakened immune systems or damaged epithelial barriers. Researchers found that P aerugin sticks to areas where epithelial cells touch each other, specifically at multi-cell junctions, and attaches to dead cells that have been pushed out of the epithelial layer. This attachment is not specific to one type of cell death, as P aerugin also binds to cells that are dying or already dead. The bacteria are then engulfed by surrounding epithelial cells through a process called efferytosis, where they dispose of the dead cells and debris. Inside the cell, the bacteria are in a special sac called an eocytic phagosome that gets lysosomal features and is killed. The study suggests that P aerugin elimination through eocytosis is a defense mechanism used by the body. This could be relevant for studying cystic fibrosis, a disease with high number of dead cells and ineffective eocytosis.
During embryonic development in fruit flies, the gonad is formed from two types of cells: primordial germ cells (PGCs) and somatic gonadal precursor (SG) cells. PGs form at the back of the embryo and are carried inside during gastrulation. To reach SGs, PGs must cross the midgut and migrate through the mesoderm. A combination of repulsive and attractive signals from SGs guide migration. The hedgehog (hh) pathway shifted (sh) gene plays a role in directing PG migration. sh encodes a protein that facilitates long-distance transmission of H through the proteoglycan matrix after released from basolateral membranes of H expressing cells in the wing disc. sh is in the gonadal meserm, loss and gain-function experiments show it's required for PG migration. Previous studies show the hmg-dependent isopoid biosynthetic pathway generates PG attract by SGs and other tissues when hmg is ectically expressed. We show production of PG attract depends on sh and second hh gene g1. Linking PG attract to H, evidence shows ectopic hmg in nervous promotes release of H from cells into the mesermal layer where H can contact PGs. Potentiation of H by hmg depends on cholesterol.
Scientists have been trying to develop a vaccine against HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, for a long time. To make a vaccine work, we need to understand how the body fights off the virus. One way the body fights HIV is with a type of immune cell called CD8 T-cells. These cells can kill infected cells that have HIV. People who control HIV long-term, without getting sick have strong CD8-cells that can kill HIV-infected cells. Researchers tested a vaccine made from a virus called Adenovirus type 5 that carries HIV pieces of the virus. The vaccine did not stop people from getting HIV, but they wanted to see if it made CD8-cells that could kill HIV. They compared people who got the vaccine to those with HIV and those who control the virus long-term. People who got the vaccine had CD8-cells that could kill HIV-infected cells, but not as strong as those who control HIV long-term. However, those with certain genes, called HLA B27, B57, or B58, had stronger CD-cells. These genes are linked to controlling HIV in people with the virus. This suggests that these genes might help make vaccine work better by making stronger CD-cells.
Researchers have long believed that the ability to share intentions, or work together towards a common goal, played a key role in the evolution of humans' unique cognitive abilities. A new study models the co-evolution of intentional behavior and culture, showing that rapid technological advancements go hand-in-hand with the ability to work together. Without opportunities for significant improvement, the ability to work together is selected against. This provides a mechanism for the emergence of shared intentions and collaborative behavior in humans, as well as a reason for species diversity in prevalence of such behavior. The study suggests that early humans' high degree of collaborative behavior compared to other great apes aided development of modern cognitive abilities, known as the shared intention hypothesis or Vygotsian intelligence. The emergence of shared intentions at time of technological advance is consistent with evidence that tool-making and language evolved around the same time, with language facilitating joint behavior. The study formally models the evolution of ability to work together, showing under what conditions it likely emerges. Individuals with ability to share intentions can adjust strategies with neighbors for mutual benefit. Results show effects of joint behavior on speed of technological improvement. The study links technology adoption to evolution of collaboration, providing insight into why humans' ubiquitous ability to work together emerged.
Researchers have identified two microRNAs, miR-34b and mi-449, that play a crucial role in male fertility. These microRNAs are involved in the production of high-quality sperm and their absence leads to oligoasthenatozoospermia, a common cause of male infertility in humans. Oligoastatozoospermia is characterized by low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology. The study found that deletion of miR-34 and mi-449 in mice resulted in oligoastatoospermia, with low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology. The absence of these microRNAs impairs meiosis and final stages of sperm maturation. Analysis of pachene spermatocytes revealed deregulated genes, many of which are targets of mi-34. The study shows that mi-34 family is important for spermatogenesis and its deregulation causes oligoastatoospermia and infertility.
Escherichia coli Nle 191 (Ec) has been used therapeutically for over a century, but the determinants of its probiotic properties remain elusive. Ec produces two siderophore-microins (Mcc) responsible for antagonistic activity against Enterobacteraceae and synthesizes the genotoxin colactin encoded by the p island. Colactin is a virulence and putative pro-cinogenic compound. Researchers aimed to decouple antagonistic activity of Ec from genotoxicity. They found that p-encoded ClP, the peptase that activates colact, is required for antagonistic activity of Ec. Analysis of ClP mutants revealed activity linked to transmembrane helices of ClP not periplasm peptase domain, indicating transmembrane involved in aspect M biosynthesis or secretion. Amino acid substitution in ClP inactivates genotoxic but maintains antagon activity. In vivo salmonelis model, this mutant reduced clinical signs and fecal shedding of Salmonella similarly wild type, ClP deletion could neither protect nor compete pathogen. ClP-dependent antibacterial effect observed with other E coli strains carry truncated form M gene cluster p island.
Cryptococcus neoformans, a fungus that causes meningitis and kills hundreds of thousands annually, relies on glycans for survival and virulence. Glycans are made in the secretory pathway, but precursors are made in the cytos. Nucle sugar transporters solve this problem by exchanging nucleotides for nucleosides. The major virulence factor of C. neoans is its polysacchar capsule, which is also shed to impede the host response. Xylose, a monosacide absent in yeast, is a capsule component. We found two transporters, U1 and U2, specific for xylose donor UDPxy, with distinct localization and kinetic. Both also transport galactose UDPgalactose.
