They analyzed data from 600,000 genetic markers in 69 French-Canadian families and found that recombination rates decrease with age, especially in specific parts of chromosomes near the ends. This may explain why older women are more likely to have extra or missing chromosomes in their eggs, leading to aneuploidy. The study suggests that recombination helps protect against non-disjunction, a process that causes aneuploidy, but this protection becomes less effective with age. The researchers propose a model that reconciles their findings with previous studies on age and aneupidy in trisomies. They also found chromosome-specific effects, which may vary between populations due to genetic differences in recombination regulation. The study supports the idea that different chromosomes are subject to distinct constraints, influencing recombination patterns over generations. The decrease in recombination with age is localized to middle chromosomal arms and subtelomeric regions, where re rates are lower in older mothers compared to younger.
Researchers have found a new way to boost the immune system's first line of defense, the macrophages, to fight off a common opportunistic infection called Cryptococcus neoformans. This fungus is a major threat to people with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS or taking immunosuppressive drugs. Current vaccines are hard to develop because they rely on the body's second line of defense, the adaptive immune system, which is weak in these patients. The scientists used a different approach, priming macrophages with a protein called interferon-gamma (IF-γ) in the body. This made the macroages remember the fungus for at least 70 days and protected against a second infection without the adaptive immune system's help. The team found that this was due to increased activity of a protein called STAT1, which binds to genes that help fight the fungus. This is a new way to make the body's first line of defense remember specific to a pathogen and provide long-lasting protection. This could lead to new vaccines for immunocompromised patients.
Researchers studied how a group of proteins called Polycomb repressive complexes (PCs) control gene expression and development in plants. They found that different combinations of PC members regulate different developmental programs, such as flower and embryo development, in Arabidopsis seedlings. A key protein called CURL LEAF (CL) plays a major role in suppressing flower development by working with other PC members, specifically with a protein called LIKE HETCHROMIN PROTEIN1 (LHP). On the other hand, embryo development is repressed by PC-catalytic subunits AtBMI and AtRING in combination with PC-catal enzymes CL or SWINGER (SW). The role of CL corresponds with changes in H3me3 profiles and is associated with different binding of transcription factors, including MADS and ABA factors. The study suggests that different PC members regulate distinct programs and specificity is modulated by transcription factors. The research used a new method to compare epigenomic data, showing high quality in dissecting epigen modifications in development. They compared genome-wide changes H3me3 and expression in loss-function mutants of PC components in Arabid seedlings. PC are classified into two complexes, PRC1 and P2, participating in transcription repression by catalyzing H3 triethylation and H2 ubiquination, respectively. Depletion of components in plants causes varied defects, raising questions about functional specificity.
Scientists have studied the "loop" or "trigger" part of an enzyme called RNA polymerase II in yeast cells. This enzyme is crucial for copying genetic information from DNA to make proteins. They made many versions of this loop with tiny changes and tested how they affected the enzyme's function. Three types of changes were found: some made the enzyme not work well, some made it work too well, and some had no effect. The changes that made the enzyme not work well were in a special pocket that helps the loop fold into the right shape. This shape is important for the enzyme to copy DNA. Other changes affected how the loop interacts with other parts of the enzyme. This study helps understand how the enzyme works and how it evolved. The method used can be applied to other important proteins in cells. The loop is important for the enzyme to move along DNA and copy genetic information. It also helps the enzyme pause or stop copying at certain points. The loop can fold into different shapes and change between these shapes to do its job. Changes in the loop can make it work better or worse and affect how it moves along DNA. The study found many changes that make the enzyme work better or worse and some that affect how it interacts with other parts.
Researchers studied how the rabies virus (RV) infects the brain. They wanted to know if the virus can spread to the brain through the bloodstream, not just through nerve cells. They infected mice with two types of RV: one from dogs (DOG) and one from silver-haired bats (SB). One group got the virus under the skin (intramuscular) and the other group got it through a vein (intravenous). The mice that got the virus under the skin got sick and died from rabies. But the ones that got it through the vein only got sick if it was from the bat virus. The researchers looked at how the virus spread in the brain and found that the bat virus went straight to the hypothalamus, a part of the brain connected to the pituitary gland. This is a new way the virus can infect the brain. This changes how we think about how to prevent rabies, especially from the bat virus.
Researchers studied the evolutionary history of the H1N1 subtype of the influenza A virus, which has caused significant illness and death in humans since the 1918 pandemic. They analyzed 71 complete genome sequences from 191 to 2006 and found that segment reassortment, a process where parts of the virus swap, played a key role in the virus's evolution. Specifically, they found that an H1 virus from 1947 acquired new genes through reassort, which may explain its sudden change in severity. The 195 epidemic may have also been caused by reassorted H1 viruses. The study suggests reassort is more important in H1's evolution than thought. Reassort between different species can create pandemic viruses, like the 1957 and 68 pandemics. The H1's eight segments generally evolved together, but some reassort events affected specific segments. The study looked at long-term patterns in 71 sequences from 17 countries. Few studies have looked at reassort in H1 viruses. H1 is thought to evolve slower than H2, needing less frequent vaccine updates. H1 caused significant illness from 1917 to 195, then again from 197 to present. The 1918 pandemic killed 20 million, the deadliest event in history.
A new study has shed light on how nicotine affects the brain's reward system, specifically the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which plays a key role in motivation and addiction. Nicotine stimulates nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nACh) in the V, releasing dopamine (DA), a chemical linked to pleasure and reward. Researchers used a computer model of the V's circuitry and ACh function to understand how nicotine works. They found that a type of ACh receptor, αβ2, on either directly stimulates or inhibits DA release, depending on the rate of ACh input. Low ACh input leads to stimulation, while high ACh leads to inhibition. This is due to known properties of α2 ACh receptors. The study also showed that GABA cells, a type of neuron, play a crucial role in nicotine's action. In vitro and in vivo data support these findings. The study suggests that the rate of ACh input determines the response to nicotine, and proposes an ACh dependence for nicotine's rewarding effects.
Researchers conducted a study in Kabul, Afghanistan to find a better way to treat cutaneous leishmanias, a chronic skin disease caused by Leishmania parasites. They tested a new method: high-frequency electrocauterization (EC) followed by moist-wound treatment (MWT) with or without sodium chlorite (DAC-055) on 200 patients with Leish infections. The goal was to prevent superinfections, accelerate wound closure, and improve cosmetic outcome. Patients under 5, with facial lesions, pregnancy, or serious comorbidities were excluded. The primary outcome was time for complete epithelialization. Biops were taken before EC, after closure, and 6 months later. Mean closure time was similar in both groups (43.1 and 42 days). DAC-055 caused faster wound healing in Leish-positive biops (37.2 vs 58.3 days). Superfections occurred at the same rate (8.8%) except in cases with high parasite loads. In vitro, DAC-055 showed lemanicidal effect on amastigotes. EC plus M led to rapid closure, lower relapse rate, and accelerated closure in patients with persistence, warranting future studies on DAC-055.
Researchers conducted a genome-wide RNAi screen in Drosila cells to identify factors impacting RAS-MAP signaling. They found 101 validated hits, most of which were previously known to be associated with the pathway. Epist experiments revealed new factors acting at different steps, including a protein modulating RAF activation. Unexpectedly, most hits worked downstream of ME and influenced MAP expression, mainly through constitutive splicing. This suggests splicing plays a role in establishing MAP levels. Two members of this group were characterized and found to regulate map alternative splicing. This study provides a comprehensive view of factors modulating R-MAP signaling in Dila. It shows pathway output is not solely reliant on classical events like RAF activation, but also MAP regulation. Additionally, splicing components can impact alternative splicing.
Researchers in Thailand studied 498 isolates of the Cryptococcus neoformans and C gatt species to better understand cryptococcosis in the country. They found that 386 were from clinical and 112 from environmental and veterinary sources. Most isolates were from males, aged 37.97 years, with 88.5% of C neoans and 37.5 of gatt from HIV patients. Molecular analysis showed that 94.8% of isolates were C neoans type V, regardless of source, while 2.4% were type II, 0.2 type IV, 0.2 type I, and 2.4 type II. Multilocus Sequence Type (ML) analysis identified 20 types in Thailand, with 5 unique to the country. Most gatt isolates were ST7, identical to the virulent Vancouver outbreak strain, indicating Thailand as a global spread stepping stone. The study found greater diversity and range of molecular types than previously reported. Demographics and HIV status matched previous reports, with neoans common in HIV patients and gatt in immunocompetent. Environmental and veterinary sampling would help fill gaps. Despite treatment, cryptocos remains a major opportunistic infection, further studies are needed for management.
Researchers studied the evolution of a large group of proteins called C2-H2 zinc finger transcription factors (TFs) in fruit flies over 45 million years. They found that a significant number of these TFs have variations that affect their ability to bind to DNA. In addition to losing or gaining C2-Z domains, they also found changes in DNA-contacting residues in 44% of shared domains between species. These changes were conserved across phylogenetic groups and evolved slower than other residues, suggesting they are important. They were rarely found as polymorphisms within a population of flies, indicating rapid fixation. The specificities of these domains changed across phylogen distances, suggesting stepwise evolutionary trajectories for TF divergence. Proteins with conserved C-Z domains were enriched in developmental functions, while varying domains showed no enrichments. The study suggests a subset of dynamic and understudied TFs are a source of variation in flies and other metazoa.
Scientists have developed a new way to quickly and accurately identify two types of bacteria that cause typhoid and paratyoid fevers, Salmonella enterica serotypes Typhi and Paraty A. These bacteria can be hard to diagnose, especially in areas where typing sera is not available. The new method uses a repeated DNA sequence called CRIS (clustered regularly interspaced palindrom repeats) that is specific to each serotype. Researchers created a PCR (polymerase chain reaction) assay that can detect and differentiate between the two serotypes. They tested the assay on 188 Typhi and 74 Paraty A strains from different parts of the world and time periods, and 70 other bacteria that can cause similar symptoms. The results showed 100% sensitivity and specificity, meaning it correctly identified all strains. The new method can be used in many clinical and public health labs with PCR technology. It was tested on cultured isolates, but could be adapted for clinical samples.
Researchers studied the role of Notch receptors in the immune response to Leishmania major, a parasite that causes skin lesions and swelling. They found that Notch1 and Notch2 are necessary for the development of helper T cells that produce IFN, a protein that helps fight the parasite. Mice with both Not1 and Not2 deleted in their T cells were unable to fight the infection and developed large lesions. However, mice with single deletion of Not1 or Not2 were able to fight the parasite and develop a protective immune response. This suggests that Not1 and Not2 are redundant in driving helper cell differentiation. The researchers also found that Notch signaling is required for IF production by helper cells. This effect is independent of a key Notch effector, RBP-J, since mice with R-J deleted in T cells were able to produce IF and fight the parasite. The study shows that Notch plays a crucial role in the development of a protective immune response to Leish major. Understanding how Notch regulates helper cell differentiation and its ligands could lead to new vaccines and treatments for Leish and other infections that require a protective helper response.
Researchers studied whether a parasitic worm infection called Schistosoma mansoni increases the risk of HIV infection in rhes macaques, a type of monkey. They infected some monkeys with the worm and then exposed them to a low doses of a virus that causes AIDS, called SHIV-C. The infected monkeys got sick with the virus at much lower doses than monkeys without the worm. In fact, it took 17 times less virus to infect the monkeys with the worm compared to those without it. The infected monkeys also had higher levels of the virus in their blood and more virus in a type of immune cell called CD4. This is the first study to show that the worm increases the risk of getting AIDS from a virus. Most new HIV infections happen through mucosal transmission, which is when the virus enters the body through the mouth, vagina, rectum, or penis. The worm is common in many parts of the world where HIV is also common. The study suggests that controlling the worm could help reduce the spread of HIV.
Researchers have created a computer model to study how the brain chemical acetylcholine (ACh) affects brain activity during sleep and wakefulness. ACh is a key player in regulating brain excitability and sleep. The model shows how changes in brain activity and structure create three distinct patterns: localized, traveling, asynchronous, and synchronous. These patterns match what's seen in brain activity during slow wave sleep, REM, and waking states. During slow wave sleep, traveling patterns occur in the brain, while in other states, stationary patterns do. The model is made of neurons with a special current regulated by ACh. A's level can change between these patterns. When ACh is low, patterns are localized and easily pinned by network irregularities. When A is high, traveling waves arise. Further decrease in A leads to high synchrony within waves. A also determines how sensitive the network is to irregularities. These patterns may be important, as stationary may encode input and traveling could lead to synaptic regularization.
Researchers studied how genetic mutations in the Toll-like receptor (TLR) pathway affect the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC), a type of cancer. They found that 14.6% of EAC tumors had non-synonymous mutations in the TLR pathway, with TLR4 being the most frequently mutated gene with 5.8% of tumors. These mutations were associated with more proximal and metastatic disease, suggesting clinical significance. The researchers also found TLR mutations in other solid tumors exposed to microbiomes, including uterine endrioid carcinoma, cutaneous melanoma, colorectal adenocarcin, and stomach adenocarcin. TLR mutants had impaired reactivity to bacterial lipopolysaccharide, which may play a role in disease pathogenesis in a subset of patients.
Scientists have long known that the sense of taste is crucial for animal survival, but the process of how taste cells develop has remained a mystery. Researchers used a new approach to study taste development in mice by combining computer analysis and lab experiments. They found that certain molecules called TRMs, which help detect sweet and bitter tastes, are present in developing taste buds on the tongue. To understand how these molecules work, they looked at the DNA sequences that control TRM genes and found a common factor called H1 that might be involved. They studied H1's role in taste development and found that in mice without H1, taste buds had more cells that could detect sweet and bitter tastes than normal mice. This suggests H1 plays a key role in helping taste cells develop in taste buds.
Researchers have investigated the relationship between ethylene and auxin in rice seedling root development. Unlike Arabidopsis, the interaction between ethylene and auxin in rice is not well understood. They found that the activation of OsIL on the expression of Y8RE7 and indole-3-pyric acid (IPA)-dependent auxin biosynthesis is required for ethylene-inhibited root elongation. Using a chemical inhibitor, they showed that ethylene-inhibited primary root elong is dependent on Y-based auxin biosynthesis. They identified a rice mutant, rein-1, which is insensitive to ethylene, and found that YRE7 is truncated at its C-terminus. Mutation in Y7 reduced auxin biosynthesis in rice, while overexpression of Y enhanced eth sensitivity in roots. Y catalyzed the conversion of IPA to IAA, and a truncated version of Y resulted in reduced enzymatic activity, indicating Y is required for IPA-dependent auxin biosynthesis and eth-inhibited elong in early seedlings. Eth induced Y expression and promoted aux accumulation in roots. Low concentrations of IAA rescued the eth response in rein-1, demonstrating eth-in elong depends on IPA-dependent biosynthesis. Genetic studies revealed Y-mediated aux biosynthesis functions downstream of OsIL, which directly activates Y7. The findings reveal a model of interaction between eth and aux in seedling root elong, enhancing understanding eth signaling in rice.
A nationwide study in Saudi Arabia has revealed the challenges of non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NT) diseases, which are increasing globally and unclear in the country. The study collected 527 isolates of NT with clinical and demographical data for 24 months. Primary identification was by probe assays and 16S rRNA, 16-23 ITS, rpo, and h65 genes. The findings were analyzed against demographical and clinical data. 76.5% were Saudi citizens, 34.2% elderly, and 65.3% male. 75.1 isolates were pulmonary with 44.7 clinical significance. 34 NT species, including 17 rare, and 8 undefined were identified. M. simiae 22.6, M. fortuit 18.1, and M. absus 17.8 were predominant. New cases of M. riyense were noticed. Rare events like mycobemia, abscess, peritonitis, and ascites caused by M wol, hatic, duii, and monence. Diabetes and previous TB were risk factors. NT disease and pathogen diversity is a challenge in Saudi. Priorities should be given to NT with diagnostic and management plans.
Yeast cells have a unique way of surviving when they don't have enough food, called quiescence. This state helps them live longer. Scientists wanted to know what makes this happen. They looked at a library of yeast genes and found that three kinases, Rim15, Mck, and Yak, are important for quies. These kinases are like messengers that help cells talk to each other. When yeast don't have food, Rim, Mck, and Yak send signals that help them prepare for quies. They make carbohydrates, like glycogen and trehalose, to store energy. This helps them live longer. When these kinases are missing, yeast can't make these carbohydrates and live shorter. Adding glycogen and treose to the food helps them live longer. Scientists also found that these kinases help control oxygen in the cell, which is important for quies. They think Rim, Mck, and Yak work together to help yeast prepare for quies by making energy and protecting themselves from damage. This helps them live longer.
Researchers have discovered a new way that the influenza A virus evades the immune system by adding sugar molecules to its surface protein, called hemagglutinin (HA). This helps the virus survive even when it has mutations that make it less recognizable to antibodies. The study used a new method to sequence the virus population and found that adding sugar molecules, called N-glycans, to the HA protein increased its ability to bind to receptors, making it more fit and able to spread. This is a new understanding of how the virus stays fit during antigen evolution and shows the power of precise virus sequencing to reveal new mechanisms. 

The virus needs to balance being new and fit to spread, and adding sugar may play a role in this process. The study also found that sugar can increase the fitness of variants that escape antibodies, even without pressure. This suggests that both mechanisms, sugar addition and mutations, contribute to the evolution of sugar in the HA protein. The research used a new method to sequence the virus population and found a new role for sugar in immune evasion. It shows that sugar can compensate for fitness costs of escape mutations, making variants more viable and able to emerge. The study highlights the potential of sequencing to uncover new viral mechanisms through precise genetics.
Researchers analyzed 13 models of ventricular myocytes to understand why some antiarrhythmic drugs don't work well at slow heart rates. These drugs prolong the cardiac action potential (AP), but their effect is stronger at slow rates, making arrhythmia worse at fast rates and better at slow rates. The opposite property, forward dependence, would solve this problem, but forward-dependent antiarrhythmics are rare. The study found that forward dependence is possible in some ionic perturbations of the AP. By simulating myocytes with varying properties and analyzing results, they predicted rate-dependent changes in multiple parameters. They tested 40 parameters and assessed AP at slow and fast rates. The analysis identified forward-dependent ionic perturbations and their mechanisms, such as increased L-type calcium current with indirect changes in delayed potassium current. Inward rectifier potassium and sodium-potassium pump are likely to produce forward prolongation. Models with minimal AP shape changes have little forward potential, while those with large changes have considerable potential. This explains differences between species and ventricular types. The study provides insights into AP duration dependence and a strategy for beneficial antiarrhythmic design.
Researchers have developed a new method to study how genetic variations in people's genes affect their traits, called Phenome-Wide Association Studies (PAS). They applied this method to thiopurine-methyltransferase (TPMT) activity in patients taking thiopine drugs. TPMT is an enzyme that helps break down thiopine, a medication used to treat certain conditions. The study used data from a French hospital's clinical database from 2000 to 2013. They analyzed 442 patient records with 10,252 ICD-10 codes and 7,711 biological test results. The results showed that iron deficiency and diabetes were associated with high TP activity. This is the first study to use ICD-10 codes, not I-9-CM codes, to identify phenotypes. In pharmacogenomics, this method can help identify patients who need personalized treatment.
Researchers conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of studies on the use of stem cells to treat spinal cord injuries in animals. They found that allogenic stem cells, which come from a different individuals, improved motor function by 27.2% and sensory function by 26.3% in animal models of spinal cord injury. However, the quality of the studies varied greatly, with some using different types of stem cells, implantation methods, and delivery routes. The best results were seen when stem cells were differentiated before implantation and delivered intravenously. Female animals did not benefit from stem cell treatment and anesthesia with isoflurane seemed to enhance the effect. A dose-response relationship was also observed. Motor outcomes were less affected by stem cell type, but more by experimental design and outcome measures. Injury location, method, and immunosuppression impacted results. Reporting bias was higher than in other neuroscience studies, but still suboptimal. Studies without blinded outcome assessment overestimated efficacy. The review suggests stem-cell therapies may be promising, but internal validity and bias may lower reported efficacy.
Soil-transmitted helmin (STH) infections, such as Ascaris lumbricoid, hookworm, and Trichuris trura, affect over a billion people worldwide. Preventive chemotherapy, or repeated administration of anthelmint drugs to at-risk populations, is the main control strategy, but does not prevent reinfection. A systematic review and meta-analysis assessed patterns and dynamics of STH reinfection after treatment. 154 studies were identified, 51 included 24 reported STH rates pre- and post-treatment, and 42 determinants of predisposition to reinfection. At 3, 6, and 12 months post-treatment, Ascaris lumicoid prevalence reached 26%, 68%, and 94% of pretreatment levels, respectively. Trichisura reinfection were 36%, 67, and 82, and hookworm 30, 55, 57. Prevalence and intensity of reinfection were correlated with pretreatment status. S reinfections occur rapidly after treatment, particularly Ascaris and Trichis. Frequent anthint drug administrations are needed to maximize preventive benefit. Integrated approaches emphasizing health and sanitation are needed to interrupt transmission.
Researchers have developed a new method called Minimum Enrich Analysis (MiA) to study nonalcoholic liver disease (NAFL) by analyzing metabolic processes at the molecular level. NAFL is a spectrum of diseases from simple steatosis to complex noncoholic stehepatitis. Current methods, such as pathway analysis, use predefined maps of metabolic processes, but these can be biased by different annotations and don't capture complex interactions. MiA generates minimal networks of reactions that can synthesize a target metabolite and applies to genome-scale metabolic networks. The researchers used MiA to investigate deregulated networks in NAFL phenotypes, such as fatty liver and inflammation in humans and mice. They found key deregulations in cholesteryl ester, cholesterol, and hexadecate synthesis in both humans and mice, and regulators of hydrogen peroxide synthesis were different in humans and mice. MiA identified general and specific characteristics of NAFL phenotypes. This method is applicable to any genome and target metabolite, making it flexible for studying metabolism in any disease or organism.
Researchers have found that the brain's sense of smell, or olfactory system, can identify a wide variety of odors despite their intensity by using a method called primacy coding. This method encodes odor identity by the types of receptors that respond first, providing a compact and efficient representation that the brain can interpret. A model of primacy was analyzed using simulations and statistical descriptions, showing that the encoded information depends on the number of receptor types, but not the size of the repertoire. The representation is independent of odor intensity and useful for olfactory tasks, similar to experimentally measured. Interestingly, a smaller receptor repertoire can be advantageous for discriminating odors. The model suggests overly sensitive receptors can dominate and make the array useless, allowing prediction of receptor adaptation to environmental changes. Primacy is more useful than binary coding, as the sparsity is independent of odor statistics, unlike alternatives. It provides an efficient representation independent of intensity, helping identify odors in the olfactory cortex.
Researchers studied the behavior of broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bnMA) against HIV, which are designed to neutralize the virus in the body. They found that some bnMA did not completely neutralize the virus, even at high concentrations. This was seen in both in lab-grown viruses and viruses grown in human cells. The study looked at 278 pseudoviruses and 117 viruses in two different assays, and found that bnMA targeting the V2 of the spike protein and gp41 were most likely to show incomplete neutralization. Conversely, bn targeting the high-mose patch were less likely to show this behavior. CD4 binding antibodies also showed this behavior infrequently. The phenomenon of incomplete neutralization was also seen in viruses grown in human cells. Five bnMA were tested against 18 virus clones produced in cells and assayed in TZ-bl cells, with examples of plateaus at 90% seen. The study suggests that incomplete neutralization and non-sigmoid neutral curves are possible for all bnMA against a wide range of viruses, with implications for use in therapy and vaccine design.
Researchers studied how cancer cells use glucose and glutamine to grow and produce energy. They found that when cells use a lot of glutamine, they make less energy from glucose and more from glutamine. This happens when there's not enough oxygen to fully use all the glucose. A computer model showed that this is the best way for cells to make energy and grow. It involves a special pathway that uses glutamine to make lipids and proteins. This was tested in a cancer cell line and confirmed by computer predictions. The study suggests that how cancer cells change their metabolism to grow. Cancer cells often use glucose to make lactate instead of energy. To understand how they use glutamine, researchers looked at when cells make lactate from glucose in the presence of oxygen. They found that high glutamine use reduces glucose energy production and increases lactate from glutamine. This happens when there's not enough oxygen to use all glucose. A computer model showed this is the best way for cells to make energy and grow. It involves a special pathway that uses glutamine to make lipids and proteins. This was tested in a cancer cell and confirmed by computer predictions. The study shows how cancer cells change their metabolism to grow.
Researchers have been trying to figure out how a protein called Pr, which is linked to a group of deadly brain diseases, changes its shape in the body. To do this, they studied how Pr interacts with other proteins in a lab-grown cells. They also looked at two similar proteins, called Doppel and Shadoo, which are related to Pr. Surprisingly, they found that all three proteins are in the same environment and interact with each other. They also found that Pr interacts with a protein called lamin, which helps cells stick together, and with an enzyme called PDI, which fixes damaged proteins. This helps explain previous findings that said Pr interacts with these proteins separately. Experiments showed that Pr and PDI interact outside of a part of the cell called the endoplasmic reticulum, and might play a new role in Pr's buildup. A theory is proposed that Pr sticks to proteins with immunoglobulin-like domains, which recognize membrane proteins with oliganns. This explains most interactions in healthy cells.
Researchers studied how the immune system responds to influenza virus infection in the lungs. They found that a type of immune cell called group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC) produces a protein called interleukin-5 (IL-5) during infection. IL-5 is important for a type of white blood cell called eosin to mature and leave the bone marrow. The study showed that IL-5 is released into the airways of infected lungs and eosin accumulate in the lungs, especially after the virus is cleared. The source of IL-5 is IL2 cells that enter the lungs during infection. These cells produce more IL-5 when they interact with another type of immune cell called NKT and a type of lung cell called alveolar macrophage. This interaction leads to more IL-5 production and eosin accumulation in lungs during recovery from infection.
Invasive non-typhoidal Salmonella (NT) infections are a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in children and HIV-infected adults in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the epidemiology and clinical manifestations of NT disease in Asia are not well-documented. This study retrospectively identified 102 cases of NT infections in an infectious hospital in Vietnam between 2008 and 2013. Clinical records were accessed to evaluate demographic and clinical factors associated with NT infection and identify risk factors with death. Multi-locus typing and antimicrobial testing was performed on all organisms. 71% of NT patients were HIV-infected, 90% were adults, 71 were male, and 33 reported intravenous use. 26/92 (28) patients had known outcome; HIV was associated with death (p=0.039). Enteridis (ST11) and Typhimium (19,34,154) were most identified serovars. Tyim was more common in HIV-infected (p=0.003). Isolates from HIV-inf patients were more susceptible to trimethoprim-sulfamox than HIV-negative (p=0.037). NT disease is severe in Vietnam with high mortality. In sub-Saharan, HIV was factor for death, majority burden in population HIV-inf adult.
Researchers have developed a new method to identify viral and phage proteins using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs). Phages are viruses that infect bacteria and play a crucial role in their survival and pathogenicity. However, most of their genes have unknown functions, making it hard to understand their impact on microbial communities and human health. The new method uses ANNs to classify protein sequences based on amino acid frequencies and isoelectric points. It correctly identifies a large fraction of test cases with high specificity and sensitivity. The ANNs were also trained to specialize in identifying major capsid and tail proteins, which are more accurate than the general ANNs. To validate the predictions, researchers examined several ORFs with no similarities to known sequences and found they self-assembled into virus-like structures. The ANNs are a new tool to identify phage and prophage proteins that are hard to detect by other methods. They will be useful when sequence data is available but propagation is not practical.
Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSH) is a cancer-causing virus with a large genome that encodes over 85 proteins. One of these proteins is ORF20, a member of the herpesviral UL24 family, but its function is not well understood. OR20 has three uncharacterized isoforms that are mostly found in the nucleus and nucleoli. Researchers used a technique called quantitative purification to mass spectrometry (q-APMS) to find proteins that interact with OR20, including a protein called interferon-stimulated gene (IS) oligoadyl synthase-like (OL). They found that OL and OR20 interacted with each other, and this was true for all OR20 isoforms and OR20 homologs in other herpesviruses. OL is a protein that helps fight viruses, but its role in herpesviruses was unknown. The study found that OL and OR20 worked together with ribosomes, the parts of cells that make proteins, but didn't affect overall protein production. They also found that OR20 helped increase expression of a protein called R-I, which is part of the immune system. OL has antiviral activity against some viruses, but its role in herpesviruses was unknown. The study showed that OL and OR20 were made early in cells that had been infected with SH. Interestingly, OL helped SH infection, but this effect was lost when OR20 was not working. The study found that OL and OR interacted with many proteins, including ribosomal and nucleolar proteins.
A study was conducted to determine the prevalence of Lassa virus disease (LVD) in children with fever and convulsions in an endemic area of Nigeria. Out of 913 children admitted to a hospital, 373 (40.9%) had fever and 108 (29%) had convulsions. The overall prevalence of LVD was 13.5% (95% CI 1.9, 5.7) in febr admissions, 2.8% in children with convuls and 3.8% without convuls. Vomiting and bleeding were associated with increased prevalence of LVD. L is an important cause of undifferentiated fever in children in endemic areas but not associated with convuls. Its prevalence and lack of clinical presentation highlights the importance of high suspicion in diagnosis. Screening febr children with undifferent fever in endemic for L could be a medical and public health measure.
Researchers have identified a new genetic factor that helps plants resist drought, a major cause of crop yield loss worldwide. The factor, called Karri receptor K2 (KAR2), is a protein that responds to a type of chemical called karri found in smoke, which promotes seed germination and plant growth under stressful conditions. They found that a mutation in the K2 gene makes plants more sensitive to water loss, leading to increased water loss, cell damage, and stomatal opening. K2 plants also have reduced anthocyan production and are less responsive to abscisic acid, a hormone involved in stomatal closure and cotyledon opening. A genome-wide analysis of K2 under watered and dehydrated conditions revealed associated genes involved in these changes. The study suggests a connection between K2 and abisic acid signaling in drought response. Comparing K2 to another receptor mutant, strigact14, showed stract also contributes to drought adaptation but not through cuticle development. The findings suggest manipulating K2 and stract signaling may improve drought resistance.
Researchers have investigated the role of insulin receptors in the growth and development of Schistosoma japonicum, a parasite that causes schistosomiasis in humans. They focused on the insulin receptors (SIR) of S. japonicum, which they had previously cloned and characterized. They found that human insulin binds to a specific part of the IR, called the L subdomain, using a technique called biolayer interferometry. They then used a method called RNA interference (RNAi) to reduce the expression of IR in adult S. japon in a lab dish and found that this reduced the transcription of other genes involved in insulin signaling and glucose metabolism. They also saw a decrease in glucose uptake in the IR-knockdown worms compared to controls. In experiments with mice infected with S. japon, they found that the recombinant L domains of IR (rLD1 and rLD2) reduced growth, intestinal worm density, and egg production. These results suggest that the IR could be a target for a vaccine against schistosomiasis, a disease that affects millions in China and the Philippines.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a major cause of disability in the Pacific region, where over 96% of 1.7 million people are at risk of infection. While mass drug administration (MDA) has reduced lymphatic filariasis prevalence, mosquito biology complicates the MD strategy in some areas, making it difficult to attain the goal of elimination. Aedes aegypti, the primary vector in the Pacific, is hard to control with existing methods. Researchers created a new strain of Ae. aegypt, called 'CP', by introducing Wolbachia bacteria from Ae. albopictus, making it incompatible with naturally infected mosquitoes, resulting in female sterility. Laboratory tests showed CP males are competitive, leading to population elimination when introduced into wild Ae. aegpt populations. This strategy is a potential tool to supplement ongoing MD efforts to eliminate LF. The Pacific's geography is ideal for this approach, as Ae.egpt is the primary vector in low microfilaraemic areas and is an obligate host for W. bancfti, a key to breaking the transmission cycle.
African trypanosomiasis, also known as Rhodesian sleeping sickness, is a deadly disease spread by a tsetes fly bites if left untreated. In Tanzania, it's a major health and socio-economic issue in affected communities. This study estimated the disease burden of Rhodesian sleeping sickness in terms of disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) and costs in a highly endemic area of Tanzania. Data from 143 patients admitted in 2004 for treatment at Kali Health Centre in Uram District was used. Direct and indirect costs incurred by patients and health services were calculated. DALs were estimated using the Global Burden Disease method and previous Rhodesian estimates, assuming 45% under-reporting. The DALs for Uram District with and without weighting were 215.7 (95% CI 155.3-287.5) and 281.6 (95 CI 209.1-362.6) respectively. When 45% underreporting was included, results were 622.5 (95 CI 155.3-109.9) and 978.9 (95 CI 201.1-187.8). Treating 143 patients cost $15,514, with patients paying $3,673 and services $11,841. Non-medical indirect costs for 143 patients were $9,781. The study shows sleeping sickness imposes a significant burden on rural communities in Tanzania, highlighting the need for location-specific estimates in countries like Tanzania where many diseases are concentrated.
Researchers studied mice with a genetic mutation in the Ngly gene, which codes for an enzyme that removes sugar molecules from proteins. This mutation causes severe symptoms in humans, but the exact function of the enzyme is unclear. They found that mice with the mutation are born dead in a specific genetic background, but deleting another enzyme, Eng, which also removes sugar molecules, partially rescues the lethality. They also found that changing the genetic background of the mice to a mix of two strains partially rescues the lethality. However, the mice still have severe symptoms similar to humans with the mutation. Deleting Eng in the mixed background also suppresses the symptoms. The study suggests that Ng1 or Ng1/Eng-deficient mice can model human disease and that Eng is a potential target for treatment.
Researchers studied how the gene expression of the hunchback (hb) gene in fruit fly embryos is controlled by a maternal gradient of the Boid (B) protein. They found that gene expression is subject to noise, or variability, which must be constrained for development to be reproducible and coordinated. They identified how noise is controlled by characterizing the dependence of hb mRNA and protein output on promoter structure and transcription dynamics. A model of the hb promoter was created, where the number and strength of B and self-regulatory binding sites can be varied. The model was fit to data from wild-type, self-regulatory mutant, and lacZ reporter constructs using different portions of the promoter. The results indicate that wild-type self-regulatory hb noise is dependent on transcription and translation dynamics, not B fluctuations. Constructs lacking self-regulation show that multiple B binding sites in the promoter play a role in buffering noise. The model is robust to variation in B binding site number across fly species. This study identifies how promoter structure and dynamics reduce noise, features common in many genes, such as multiple sites, cooperativity, and self-feedback, contributing to understanding of reproducibility and determinacy in early development.
Scientists have studied how the genetic material from Neanderthals, an extinct human species, has mixed with modern humans. They found that selection, or natural selection, has removed Neander genes from the human population over time. To understand this, they developed a new method to measure the strength of selection against Neander genes in modern humans. The results show that East Asians have more Neander genes than Europeans, even after accounting for selection. Most selection against Neander genes is due to weak, or slightly bad, genes that were neutral in Neander but became bad in humans. These genes had a big impact on early human-Neander hybrids. The study suggests that population size may play a bigger role in gene mixing than thought. 

The researchers used data on Neander genes in modern humans to test their method. Their work helps understand how selection shaped Neander genes in humans and the nature of human-Neander mixing. There is evidence that selection acted against Neander genes in modern humans. This study is one of the first to measure strength of selection between populations. The method is based on previous work on selection and its effect on neutral genes. The results show patterns of Neander in humans are consistent with selection against weak bad genes. The study suggests selection against Neander may be due to genes that were neutral in Neander but became bad in humans due to larger human population size. These genes had a big impact on early human-Ne hybrids. The study suggests population size and neutral dynamics may be key to gene mixing between species.
Researchers have studied how the HIV virus controls its own gene expression after it has integrated into a host cells. They found that the virus can switch between an active and inactive state, and that this switching may help it hide from the immune system. The virus uses two main elements, Sp1 and NF-κ, to control this switching. Sp1 stabilizes both states, making it harder for the virus to turn on and off, while NFκ has two parts, one that activate and one repress. The team made mutations in these elements and found that Sp1 helps reduce noise in gene expression and makes it harder for the virus to turn on, while NFκ has a stronger activating part that helps the virus turn on. They also found that Sp1 is important for recruiting proteins to the promoter. In cells with mutated Sp1 were more likely to turn on and off the virus. This study helps understand how HIV hides from the immune system and may lead to new treatments.
Accurate genome-wide identification of orthologs is a crucial in comparative genomics, reflected by numerous orthology projects developed in recent years. However, few have compared their accuracy, and several have not been systematically evaluated. Orthology is typically assessed in terms of function, despite phylogeny's original definition by Fitch. This study collected results of nine orthology projects (CO, KOG, Inparan, OrthoCL, Ensembl Com, Homene, Round, EggG, and OMA) and two methods (bidirectional best and reciprocal distance) and compared their predictions to both phylogeny and function using six tests. Phylogen or functional analysis with high specificity, OMA and Homene perform best. At lower specificity but higher coverage, OrthCL outperforms En Com and Inan. Egg provides large coverage for broad grouping but is not specific for phylogen or detailed analyses. Methodologically, En Com's tree/reconciliation approach was outperformed by pairwise, even in phylogen tests. Bidirectional best often outperforms complex projects. This study provides guidance for orth users, introduces methodology, and sets standards for future approaches.
Researchers have developed a new approach to find treatments for schistosomiasis, a disease caused by parasitic worms that infect millions of people in the tropics and sub-tropics. The current treatment, praziquel, has been used for 40 years but is becoming less effective due to resistance. The team used a computational method called drug repurposing to find new targets for the disease. They focused on kinases, proteins that play key roles in parasite's biology, and identified several as potential targets. They also mapped the kinomes of three Schistoma species that infect humans and compared them to the human kinome to find unique targets. This allowed them to suggest existing drugs that could be effective against the parasites, including bosutin, dasatin, and imatinib, as well as new inhibitors vetan, saratin, tideus, alocib, dinlib, and 22 others. The team also identified primary and secondary targets of these drugs in Schoma, enabling the development of new treatments for this neglected disease.
Researchers studied how a protein called CREB binds to a partner protein called CBP to control gene expression. CRE is unstructured when not bound, but becomes structured upon binding. They used computer simulations to predict a folding and binding mechanism, and found that CRE becomes structured after binding, not before. This is different from some models where CRE is structured before binding. Adding more structure to CRE makes it bind slower, like a "fly-casting" process. Including attractive forces between CRE and CBP increases binding speed, but doesn't change mechanism. This study shows how unstructured proteins can help recognize targets. Results match a recent nuclear magnetic resonance study and help understand binding kinetics. CRE's phosphorylated domain (pID) is unstructured when not bound, suggesting folding and binding happen together. Simulations show binding and folding occur together, but pID folds into a helix after binding. The transition state of pID is like the unbound state. Researchers used a G-type model based on pID/CBP structure and analyzed transition states. A recent NMR study suggested pID becomes structured after binding, with transient complexes evolving to a high-affinity. Here, pID changes upon binding, but concepts are relevant. Analysis shows structure forms after binding, making pID binding consistent with induced-fit, where the ligand changes.
A systematic review of schistosomiasis prevalence and intensity in children in Latin America and the Caribbean countries (LAC) was conducted from 1942 to 2014. The study aimed to analyze the progress towards the World Health Assembly's 2012 resolution to eliminate schosomias by 2020. The review included 132 articles with 1242 prevalence and intensity data points, mostly from Brazil (69.7%). High prevalence and intensity were found in Brazil, Venezuela, Suriname, and Saint Lucia, requiring updated epidemiological status to redesign national programs. Antigua and Barbuda, Dominican Republic, Guadeloupe, Martinique, Montserrat, and Puerto Rico may have interrupted transmission, but follow-up is needed to verify status. Heterogeneity in methodologies made cross-national comparisons difficult. The review recommends updating schos status in historically endemic countries and territories to address public health interventions and verify elimination. Improved reporting and standardization of monitoring methodologies are needed using WHO guidelines. Meeting the elimination goal requires additional epidemiological data by age and sex.
Researchers studied how HIV-1, the virus that causes AIDS, is transmitted from one person to another through sex. They looked at 167 full-length HIV-1 genomes and created 40 copies of the virus from 6 couples who transmitted the virus to each other. The goal was to see what makes HIV-1 more likely to be transmitted. They found that the version of the virus that was transmitted, called the "transmitted founder" (TF), didn't have any special traits that made it more likely to be transmitted. It didn't have higher ability to infect cells or replicate in the body's immune system. Also, it wasn't more resistant to a protein called interferon-alpha (IF-α) that helps fight the virus. The study suggests that how the virus adapts to the body's immune system makes it less likely to be transmitted, not the other way around. 

The researchers used a method to get full HIV-1 genomes and made copies of the virus from 6 couples who transmitted to each other. They tested the copies to see how well they could infect and replicate in immune cells and how resistant to IF-α. This study is different from others because it looked at the whole virus, not just one gene, and had copies from both partners. They found that the transmitted virus wasn't more resistant to IF-α than the other versions from the same partner. This means other factors, not IF-α, make the virus more likely to be transmitted. Previous studies found that some versions of HIV-1 were more resistant to IF-α, suggesting the virus adapts to escape the body's immune system. This study looked at 6 couples and found the transmitted virus wasn't more resistant to IFα than other versions.
Researchers studied how filarial parasites, which cause lymphatic filariasis, affect the lymphatic system in the body. They found that in mice without an immune system, lymphatic dilation occurs, but severe lymphedema and elephantiasis require an immune response. To see how parasites directly affect lymphatics, they exposed human lymphatic cells to parasites, antigens, or infected serum. Live parasites and antigens made cells multiply and form tube-like structures. Serum from infected patients and those with chronic lymphatic issues made cells multiply more than uninfected individuals. Tube formation was linked to increased metalloproteases and TIM inhibitors. Comparing gene expression in parasite-exposed and unexposed cells, parasites changed genes involved in organization and junctions, decreasing transport. This suggests parasites induce lymphogenesis and provide insight into filariasis pathology.
Scientists have developed a new way to extract and amplify the genetic material from individual bacteria without growing them in a lab. This is a big deal because most bacteria can't be grown in a lab, making it hard to study them. They used a tiny device to isolate and amplify the DNA from a single E. coli cell in a 60-nanol reaction. The results showed that using smaller reactions reduced errors and gave a more accurate picture of the genome. The quality of the amplified DNA was compared to standard 50-microl reactions and was similar. High-throughput sequencing of single amplicons from both small and large reactions gave good results, making it a straightforward way to sequence single cells. 

The team tested the performance of this method and found that smaller reactions reduced bias and increased specificity. They used a microfluidic chip to isolate and amplify single cells in 60-nanol reactors. Whole genome recovery from single cells helps study ecology and evolution because most microbes can't be cultured. A method called Multiple Displacement Amplification (DA) enables amplification from isolated cells by flow cytometry or dilution. Micromanipulation allowed cells to be selected by fluorescent probes, increasing confidence in single DA reactions.
Researchers studied how viruses from the Orthohant genus, which can cause disease in humans, are transmitted by rodents in the Atlantic Forest, savannas, and wetlands of South America. These rodents shed different viruses, such as the lethal Araraquohantavirus, and factors like population variation may influence transmission within and between populations. They tested if landscape, particularly agricultural and forest remnants, influence rodent havirus hosts in the Atlantic Forest. Using 283 rodent captures and geographically weighted models, they found that havirus proportions were more influenced by landscape diversity than habitat or agricultural type. Small mammal diversity positively influenced pathogenic havirus hosts, indicating habitat quality may be more important than competition with native species. Sugarcane plantations increased rodent hosts, while defaunation did not correlate with potentially pathogenic havirus genotypes. The match between hotspots and human vulnerability was 17%, coldspots 20%. Landscape change influences havirus hosts across the Forest. Findings suggest surveillance in southern and southeastern regions where high host and vulnerability match. Analyses suggest complex rodent dynamics and disease interactions than hypothesized.
Researchers have found that a protein called BCL is crucial for the survival of cells infected with flaviviruses, a family of viruses that includes Japanese encephalitis, Dengue, and Zika viruses. When cells are infected with these viruses, the protein BCL helps to delay apoptosis, or programmed cell death, by suppressing another protein called M1. This delay is important for the virus to spread to neighboring cells and cause disease. The study showed that treatment with BCL inhibitors or lack of the BCL gene leads to apoptosis in infected cells, which reduces viral spread and inflammation. Infection. The researchers also found that BCL is essential for survival of cells infected with flaviruses in the body, and that inhibiting BCL may be a new way to stop the spread of these viruses.
A study estimated the economic impact of rabies in Vietnam from 2005-2014 and found that the total cost of the disease was over $719 million. The largest portion of this cost, 92%, was due to post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) treatments. Canine rabies resulted in 36,560 to 45,700 disability-adjusted life years (DALs) and 914 human deaths over the 10-year period. The cost per dog vaccinated was $1.75. The study suggests that the most effective way to control rabies is through public health campaigns that prevent the disease, not just treating it with P. The results show that Vietnam's rabies burden is similar to other Asian countries, with high P costs and low vaccination investments. The majority of rabies costs in Vietnam are from P, while only a small portion is from dog vaccination. Livestock losses are a small part of the total costs, but may be significant for individual producers. The study found that Vietnam spends more on P than prevention through vaccination, similar to other rabies-endemic countries in Asia.
Scientists have studied the Type II Secretion System (TSS), a molecular machine that helps bacteria secrete proteins across their outer membrane. A key part of this machine is the secretin, a protein that forms a pore in the outer membrane. They found that there are three types of TSS based on the secretin's characteristics. Two types, Klebsella and Vibrio, were compared and found to be different by a protein called pilot that helps assemble the secretin into the membrane. The structure of a new pilot protein, Asp, from Vibrio cholera, was determined. It's similar to other pilots in function but not in structure. Asp binds to a specific sequence in Vibrio secretin and helps assemble the secretin, and is found in many Vibrio and some Escherichia and Shella bacteria.
Researchers have identified a protein called Omp37 on the surface of Leptira bacteria that binds to a protein called elastin found in human skin and blood vessels. This binding is a crucial step in the bacteria's ability to infect the host and cause disease. The study found that Omp37 has a strong affinity for elastin and also binds to other proteins such as fibrinogen, fibronectin, and laminin. This suggests that O37 may play a role in the bacteria's ability to attach to tissues and cause infection. The researchers also found that antibodies in the blood of people infected with leptospi can recognize O37, indicating that the immune system is responding to the protein. Additionally, O37 was found in pathogenic Leptira but not in non-pathogenic Leptira. This suggests that O37 may be a key factor in the bacteria's ability to cause disease. The study suggests that O37 may be involved in the initial stages of infection, allowing the bacteria to attach to the skin through the elastin layer. Further research is needed to understand the role of O37 in the bacteria's lifecycle and how the immune system responds to it.
Researchers have identified two antibodies, 4E and 2F, that can neutralize HIV by binding to a specific regions on the virus called the membrane-proximal external (MP) region of gp41. This region is exposed during the early stages of viral entry into a host cells. To understand how these antibodies work, a model was created to calculate the probability of an antibody disabling gp41 before fusion is complete. The model shows that for these antibodies to be effective, the time to disable the region must be less than 5 minutes. The study also looked at the role of antibody strength in neutralization and found that 2F is more effective than 4. This is because 2 interacts more strongly with the viral membrane. The model was used to determine the factors that allow these antibodies to disable regions and extended to analyze neutralization data. The model shows that a small number of gp41 must be disabled to prevent fusion, but can't determine the exact number from experiments alone.
Researchers conducted a study in Mali and Senegal to see if mass treatment with ivermectin could eliminate onchercias, a disease spread by blackflies, in areas where the disease is common. They gave ivermect to people in three areas for 15 years, every 6 months, and checked for 5 years after to see if it worked. They tested 29,753 people and 49,600 blackflies for the parasite. Results showed a decline in infection and transmission after treatment. In two areas, the parasite was gone 3-4 years later. In the third, where it was high before, it declined to low levels 3-5 years later. The study proved that iverectin can eliminate onchias in some African areas. The findings helped change onchias control to elimination efforts in Africa.
Researchers have studied how a protein called VP4 from the rhinovirus virus, a common cause of the common cold, helps the virus enter cells. Rhinovirus is a type of non-enveloped virus, which means it doesn't have a protective layer around its genetic material. To get inside a cell, the virus needs to deliver its genetic material through the cell membrane without fusing with it. VP4 is a small protein on the virus that helps with this process. Scientists created a version of VP with a tag to study its behavior. They found that VP4 can make holes in model membranes, allowing single-stranded RNA to pass through. The size of the hole matches the size of the virus's genetic material. The team also found that pH affects how well VP4 works and that it's similar to how the real virus works. This study shows how VP4 helps the virus enter cells and suggests it could be a target for new treatments for related viruses like poliovirus and foot-and-mouth disease.
Francisella tularens (Ft) is a highly infectious Gram-negative bacterium that causes tularemia, a disease classified as a class A select agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The bacterium's lipid A structure is similar to that of Francisella novicida (Fn), a pathogen of mice. Researchers identified three enzymes required for lipid carbohydrate modifications: mannose (m1), galactamine (m2), or both (mK). Mutants lacking galactamine (m2) or galos/mannose (m) were attenuated in mice by both pulmonary and subcutaneous routes of infection. Aerosolization of mutants m2 and mK provided protection against wild-type Fn, while subcut administration of mK provided protection from Fn. Infection of alveolar macrophage cells by mK induced higher levels of tumor necrosis-α (TN-α) and macrophage inhibitory-2 (M-2) compared to Fn. Bone marrow-derived macrophages from TLR4 and TLR2 knockout mice infected with m produced higher IL-6 and M-2 than those infected with Fn. However, IL-6 and M-2 were undetectable in MyD−/− mice infected with either strain. My−/− mice were susceptible to m mutant infection. The researchers hypothesize that m's ability to activate pro-inflammatory cytokine/chemine production and innate responses by MyD signaling may be responsible for its attenuation, leading to protective immunity.
Researchers studied the role of Era, a protein involved in ribosome assembly, in Staphylococcus aureus bacteria. Era is a GTPase that acts as a switch to coordinate ribosome assembly and is conserved across all domains of life. However, its function in ribosome assembly is unclear. The study found that Era is not essential for S. aureus growth but important for 30 ribosomal subunit assembly. Era interacts with 16 rRNA enduclease Y and DEAD RNA helicase C, crucial for rRNA processing and growth at low temperatures. Era and C also interact with ppG synthase Rel, impacting Gase activity and helic activity. Era acts as a hub on ribosome, directing enzymes for r processing and assembly. The stringent response, triggered by ppG, inhibits Era activity, contributing to slowed growth. The study suggests Era's role as a guide for ribosome maturation enzymes to their substrates.
Anthrax lethal toxin (LT) causes vascular insufficiency in experimental animals through unknown mechanisms. Researchers investigated the role of neuronal nitric oxide synthase (NOS) in this process. They found that OS-deficient mice are more sensitive to LT, while OS and endothelial OS-deficient mice are not. The increased sensitivity of OS-deficient mice is not due to macrophage sensitivity or cytokine responses, but can be replicated in OSufficient mice through pharmacological inhibition. Histological analysis showed LT-induced changes in heart morphology of OS-def mice, with novel inter-fiber spaces and no cardiomyocyte apoptosis. Electron microscopy revealed pathological changes in hearts of both OS-def and OSufficient mice, varying in severity and timing. Biomarkers of cardiac injury were elevated in LT mice rapidly, indicating cardiac damage. Cardioprotective therapy and allopurin had no effect, but nitric oxide scavenger carbox-PT showed some protection. Echocardiography showed reduced ejection fraction in both OS and OS mice, indicating decreased contractile function. The heart is an early target of LT and OS plays a protective role against cardiac damage.
Scientists have developed a new method to edit genes in parasitic worms that infect over a billion people worldwide. These worms cause some of the most common tropical diseases, but their biology is not well understood due to lack of tools for genetic study. Researchers used a technique called CRISPR-C9 to disrupt a gene in the human parasitic worm Strongyloides steralis, causing severe movement problems in the worms. They also disrupted a similar gene in another parasitic worm, Strongyloides ratti. This shows CRPR-C9 can be used in parasitic worms, making it possible to study their genes and develop new treatments.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to study the effects of ribosome drop on translation and ribosome density along mRNA. Ribosome drop occurs when cells are under stress, such as amino acid starvation or high recombinant protein expression, affecting protein expression efficiency. The model shows ribosome premature termination leads to non-intuitive ribosome profiles, like increased density from 5' to 3' end. Importantly, it predicts rib drop effects on translation are mRNA-specific and quantifies resilience to drop, showing mRNAs with ribosomes are less affected than those without. Among mRN without ribosomes, resilience to drop correlates with elongation rate, fast codons are less affected. Genome-wide analysis in S. cerevisiae reveals mRN coding proteins involved in translation, using fast codons, are resilient to drop. In physiological conditions, mRN coding regulatory stress proteins are less resilient to drop. The model explains variations in translational efficiency by accounting for ribosome behaviors and mRNA variations in rib density from profiling studies.
Researchers are trying to find out if it's possible to stop the spread of soil-transmitted helminths (STH) infections by giving medicine to everyone in a community at the same time. The World Health Organization's current plan is to control STH by giving medicine to school-aged children, but this doesn't stop the spread because there are still infected people and contaminated soil in the environment. Some think giving medicine to everyone at once could speed up stopping the spread, but it's hard to get everyone to take it. A study called DeW3 is testing this idea. It will give medicine for 3 years and then watch for 2 years to see if the spread stops. The researchers want to know if they can tell if the spread is stopped earlier than 2 years. They used a computer model to simulate the study and found that it's hard to tell if the spread is stopped after 1 year unless almost everyone took the medicine. If the spread isn't stopped, it can come back to the same level before medicine was given. Knowing if it's stopped early can save time and money in places where it's unlikely to come back. The study also looked at how much medicine is needed to stop the spread.
Researchers have developed a new vaccine against cholera, a disease caused by Vibrio cholera bacteria. The vaccine is made from a part of the bacteria's outer layer called O-specific polysaccharide (OSP) and a fragment of tetanus toxin. They tested the vaccine in mice and found it was effective in protecting against cholera. The vaccine worked best when given with an adjuvant, a substance that helps the body's immune system respond. Mice that got the vaccine with adju had high levels of antibodies against OSP, a key to fighting cholera. Those that got the vaccine without adju also had some antibodies, but not as many. Mice that got only OSP or adju had no antibodies. The vaccine also triggered memory cells that remember OSP, helping fight cholera. In a test, 95% of mice that got the vaccine with adju survived cholera. The researchers think this vaccine could help young children, who don't respond well to OSP alone. They used a part of tetanus toxin as a carrier, which can be used in other vaccines too. They chose OSP from Vibrio cholera O1 because it's known to be protective in mice. However, infection with O1 doesn't protect against O139 and vice versa, showing OSP is key.
Researchers have discovered that the fungus Candida albicans can inhibit the virulence of the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa by suppressing the production of pyelin and pyoverine, which play a crucial role in iron acquisition and virulence. In a mouse model of gastrointestinal colonization and dissemination, Candida albicans was shown to reduce the virulence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa by inhibiting pyelin and pyd gene expression. Deletion of both pyelin and pyd genes attenuated Pseudas virulence. Heat-killed Candida alb had no effect on Pseud, whereas Candida secreted proteins directly suppressed pyd and pyelin expression and inhibited P vir in mice. Interestingly, suppression or deletion of pyelin and pyd genes had no effect on P's ability to colonize the GI tract but decreased P's cytotoxic effect on colonocytes. Iron supplementation restored P vir in Pseud and Candida colonized mice. The findings provide insight into how bacterial-fungal interactions can modulate virulence in the intestine.
Researchers studied how a type of virus that evades CD8 T cells, a key part of the immune system, affects the outcome of infection. This virus, called EM, is less fit than the normal virus and often reverts back to normal upon transmission to a new host. However, the time it takes for this to happen varies greatly. They infected macaques with a mix of EM and normal virus and found that if the mix contained at least 10% normal virus, the normal virus took over within 7 days. But if the mix had smaller amounts of normal virus, it took weeks for the normal to become dominant. This delay was linked to lower viral loads. The amount of virus in the initial infection determines how quickly it reverts to normal, which in turn affects the outcome of the infection. Delaying the reversion of virus-reducing CD T escape mutations may reduce the severity of HIV in early infection.
Researchers studied yeast populations in Evolution Canyon, Israel, and found that some strains are highly resistant to the heavy metal cadmium. They discovered that this resistance is mainly due to a gene called PCA1, which helps remove cadmium from the cell. Analysis showed that changes in the PCA1's promoter, not its coding region, are responsible for the increased activity. Experiments showed that three specific mutations in the promoter increase PCA's activity, making cells more resistant to cadmium. These mutations are also found in other yeast species, suggesting they're an ancient adaptation. However, they're not present in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, which grows better without cadmium. The study suggests a trade-off between metal resistance and fitness in yeast populations.
Researchers have identified three major cancer-causing pathways in stomach cancer that are linked to patient survival rates. They used a computer-based method to map these pathways in 301 stomach cancer samples, the second leading cause of global cancer deaths. The three pathways, proliferation/stem cell, NF-κ, and Wnt/β-caten, are deregulated in over 70% of stomach cancers. These pathways were validated in a panel of stomach cancer cell lines. Patient stratification by these pathways showed significant differences in survival in multiple groups, suggesting interactions play a role in disease behavior. Stomach cancers can be grouped by pathway activity into biologically and clinically relevant subgroups. Predicting pathway activity by expression allows study of multiple pathways in cancers simultaneously, not achievable by other methods.

A computer method was developed to map pathway levels in tumor profiles and validated using breast cancer examples. This method was applied to stomach cancer to evaluate pathways implicated in carcinogenesis. Eleven pathways were selected, including tumor suppressor and oncogenic, previously implicated in stomach carcinogenesis. A four-step strategy was used to predict pathway activation: defining pathway signatures, mapping onto cancer profiles, validation, and applying to stomach cancer.

Stomach cancer is the second cause of global mortality, prevalent in Asia, most patients diagnosed with advanced disease. Deregulation of pathways such as E, KAS, p, and W/βaten signaling occur in stomach, indicating molecular heterogeneity.
Researchers have developed a method called stress-induced DNA duplex destabilization (SIDD) to identify areas in DNA that are prone to separation under stress. They applied this method to the Escherichia coli genome and found that destabilized sites occur more often in non-coding regions, particularly near known or inferred promoters. The study investigated whether genes in different categories have characteristic S properties in their upstream regions. They found that strong S sites in the E coli genome are significantly associated with the upstream of genes encoding transcription regulators, especially those responding to environmental stimuli. If a gene is controlled by a transcription regulator with a destabilized 5' flank, the genes in that pathway usually have strong S sites in their 5' flanks. This association was observed in 38 free-living bacteria but not in 18 endosymbion or obligate parasitic bacteria. The results suggest that S sites may be involved in transcriptional responses to environmental changes that alter superelicity. The researchers propose that these sites are active participants in superically mediated mechanisms governing gene expression changes in response to physiological or environmental changes.
Researchers studied the role of high-mob group (HMG) proteins in the fungus Podospora anserina, a type of fungus. HMG proteins are DNA-binding proteins that control gene expression. They found 12 HMG genes in P anina, 4 of which control mating and fruit development, and 1 involved in mitochondrial stability. Deleting the remaining 8 uncharacterized HMG genes showed none were essential, but 7 involved in the sexual cycle. Two HMG genes, PaMG5 and Pa9, stood out. Pa5 is an activator of mating genes, while Pa9 represses specific genes in stationary phase. Analyzing HMG genes in deletion strains showed Pa5 is central to a network regulating mating genes. Genetic analysis revealed this network also controls fertility genes not regulated by mating factors. This study highlights HMG's role in sexual reproduction, with 11 of 12 involved in P anina's cycle. Pa5 and Ste11, from Schizoscharomyces pombe, are conserved regulators of mating genes, despite diverging 550 million years ago. Two HMG, SO9 and its regulator S, also play role in sex determination in mammals. Pina and pom mating genes and regulator form an H-box module like SRY/SOX, showing common sex regulation in animals and fungi.
During the 2013-2016 West African Ebola virus epidemic, there was a lack of data on how long the virus persisted in survivors' bodies and the risk of transmission, including sexual transmission. To address this, an observational study was conducted in Sierra Leone during the epidemic response. The study aimed to determine the persistence of Ebola virus in survivors' body fluids and assess the risk of transmission. The study was conducted in two phases. The first phase, initiated within five months of discussions, assessed the persistence of Ebola in semen of 100 men. The second phase assessed the persistence in multiple fluids (semenstrual, vaginal, blood, breast milk, urine, rectal, sweat, saliva, tears) of 120 men and 120 women. Data informed national and global guidelines in real-time, demonstrating the need for semen testing among Ebola survivors. The study accelerated implementation of such programs in virus-affected countries and informed persistence of Zika virus studies. Research is crucial in responding to a poorly understood disease.
Scientists have studied how bacteria, specifically Escherichia coli, detect and respond to chemical signals in their environment. They used a technique called FRET to measure how the bacteria's chemotactic pathway responds to different concentrations of chemicals. By analyzing this data, they predicted the types of chemical gradients the bacteria typically encounter in their natural habitat. The researchers also used information theory and simulations to understand how the bacteria's internal and external noise affect their ability to detect these gradients. They found that the bacteria usually encounter exponential gradients, which lead to a log-normal distribution of stimuli and maximum velocity. This is a step towards understanding the complex environments bacteria live in, like the human intestine.

The study used a multidisciplinary approach, combining FRET measurements, theory, and simulations of bacteria swimming. They found that maximizing information means aligning the bacteria's trajectory with the chemical gradient and increasing their velocity. This suggests the bacteria's pathway has evolved to detect exponential gradients. The Weber-Fech law doesn't predict gradient distribution, but views changes in concentration as useful for the cell. The researchers quantified this view of signaling and characterized the environment in terms of distributions.

The chemotactic system allows bacteria to detect and move towards nutrients or toxins. It's relatively simple with few components and well-understood at the molecular level. It shares design principles with other sensory systems, including Weber's law, Weber-Fech law, and fold detection.
