The study connects these laws with information at the molecular level, unlike previous research.
Scientists have long believed that hematopoietic stem cells (HSC), which produce all blood cells, have an indefinite lifespan due to their ability to self-renew. However, new research suggests that identical HSC differ in lifespan and that lifespan is predetermined and intrinsic to the cell. Lifespan is defined as the time H gives rise to mature blood cells. A new model based on reliability theory explains the diversity of lifespans of Hs. Using experiments and computational modeling, small-scale molecular failures at H population level were tested. The best fit of data is provided by a model where repulation kinetics of H are largely anti-persistent or mean-reverting processes. Failure rates increase during division events are counteracted by repair processes, leading to a crossover from anti-persistent to persistent behavior. This is due to increased failure rate of selfnew leading to clonal extinction. The capacity of Hs is self-limit. Lifespan of each H depends on amplitudes and frequencies of failure kinetics. Short and longer Hs differ in ability to dissipate perturbations. This suggests lifespan is determined by differences in repair capacity.
Antibodies play a crucial role in protecting against chronic helminth infections, which affect one-third of the world's population. Researchers have long known that antibodies and a type of immune cell called macrophages help fight these parasites, but how they work together was unclear. A new study found that helth-specific antibodies trap and prevent damage caused by helmin larvae by changing macroage behavior. Macrophages are a type of immune cell that help fight infection, but can also cause damage if not controlled. The study used mice infected with a common parasite and found that without antibodies, the larvae moved freely and caused tissue damage. With antibodies, the larvae were trapped and macroages expressed a gene that helps heal wounds. This happened without a known signaling pathway, called IL-4α, which is usually involved in macroage activation. The study suggests a new way antibodies activate macroages to fight helmin and prevent tissue damage. This is a step towards understanding how to develop a vaccine or treatment for helmin infections.
Scientists have developed a new way to study how cells repair damaged DNA breaks in their chromosomes without interfering with the process. This is a major threat to the cell's integrity and can lead to cancer or cell death. The new method, called ParBINT, uses small proteins to mark the broken DNA ends, allowing researchers to track its movement in real-time in living cells. They used it to study yeast cells and found that the broken DNA is confined to a small area near the break in the early stages of repair. This is consistent with the idea that the ends need to stay in contact to fix the damage. In some cells with a mutation that affects repair, the process started 10 minutes earlier than normal, showing a key step in the repair process. The new tool can be used to study other processes like gene expression and replication in normal and diseased cells.
Researchers studied how often people in areas with Chagas disease get infected with the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi again. They used computer models to estimate the rate of re-infection and how often it happens during the acute and chronic stages of the disease. The models were based on data from villages in Argentina where 56% of people have mixed infections. The best model predicted 0.032 re-infections per person per year, with 98% happening in the chronic stage. The parasite evades the immune system in 20% of re-infections. This means people have a 14-18% risk of re-infection after 5 years and 21-70% after 30 years, with most getting infected 1-3 times. The low rates are due to weak transmission and not a strong immune response. This is important for vaccine development and understanding disease risk in endemic areas.
Researchers studied blood samples from a group of Thai children who got infected with deng virus (DENV) to understand why some people get sick and others don't. They found that people who got sick had higher levels of certain cytokines, like IL-15 and MCP-1, in their blood before they got infected. People who got sick also had lower levels of other cytokines like IL-12, IL-2, MIP-α, RANT, GM-CSF, and TNα. This suggests there are two types of immune responses to DENV: one that protects and one that makes people sick. The study found higher levels of some cytokines in people who got sick and higher levels of others in people who didn't. This could help us understand how to make better deng vaccines. Previous studies found higher levels of certain cytokines in people with severe deng, like TNα, IFγ, IL18, ILβ, IL6. But this study looked at people before they got infected to see if their immune system could predict if they'd get sick or not. The study had few people who got very sick, so can't say if this profile is linked to severe deng. Also, they only looked at blood 4-7 months before infection, so don't know if other infections or waning immunity changed profiles.
In the fruit fly wing disc, the Hedgehog (H) protein forms a gradient that organizes patterning along the anterior-posterior axis and specifies at least three different domains of gene expression. The prevailing view is that H functions as a classical morphogen, but a direct correspondence between the borders of these patterns and H concentration has not been demonstrated. Researchers found that interpretation of H signaling depends on the history of exposure to H and that a single concentration is sufficient to support multiple outputs. Using mathematical modeling, they predict that at steady state, only two domains can be in response to H, suggesting the boundaries of two or more gene patterns cannot be specified by a static H gradient. Computer simulations suggest a "overshoot" of the H gradient, a transient in which H is expanded compared to H-state. Through examination of H target expression, patterns expand initially and then refine, providing in vivo evidence for overshoot. The H gene architecture suggests overshoot results from H-dependent upregulation of receptor Patched (Ptc). Altering the network such that P is no longer upregulated in response to H-signaling, found patterns of expression, distinct in wild-type discs now overlap.
Researchers have identified a gene called unc-79 in mice that plays a crucial role in how the nervous system responds to ethanol. They found a mutation in this gene, called Lightweight, which makes mice more active and sensitive to ethanol. When exposed to ethanol, Lightweight mice are more likely to die than normal mice. However, mice with one copy of the mutation are more sensitive to ethanol, but not as much as those with two copies. Similar results were seen in a worm called C. elegans, which has a related gene called unc-79. Mice with one copy of the mutation are also more active in new environments and eat more food, but are leaner than normal mice. They also drink more ethanol than normal mice. This suggests a shared pathway in humans and mice that might influence alcohol behavior. The researchers found a mutation in the unc-79 gene in mice, which affects how they respond to ethanol and anesthetics, similar to C. elegans and fruit flies. Mice with one copy of the mutation are more active and sensitive to anesthetics, like isoflurane. They are also more active in new environments and eat more, but are leaner than normal. They drink more ethanol than normal mice. This suggests a shared pathway in humans and mice that might influence alcohol behavior.
Researchers have identified a key immune pathway in the Anopheles gambia mosquito that helps fight off the malaria parasite Plasium falcum, which causes malaria in humans. This pathway, called the Imd, is a powerful defense mechanism that can be used to control malaria transmission. By silencing a gene that regulates the Imd pathway or overexpressing a factor that controls it, mosquitoes become resistant to the parasite. However, more research is needed to understand how to use this mechanism for malaria control. Scientists used RNA interference to silence genes in the Imd pathway and found other genes that work with it to fight the parasite. They found that the Imd is most effective against the parasite's early stage, but also works against other stages. Silencing a key gene in the pathway alone is enough to trigger a strong response against the parasite, even without the mosquito's gut bacteria. The study also found that certain genes in the I pathway, TEP, APL, and LR1, play a role in infection-dependent defense, showing the importance of lab versus natural infection models. These findings highlight considerations for using the I pathway in mosquitoes to limit malaria transmission and reveal nuances in the immune response against the parasite.
Researchers investigated the anti-fibrotic effect of bone-derived mesenchymal stem cells (BSCs) in a mouse model of pulmonary fibrosis caused by the fungus Paroccidiococcus brasiliensis. They found that BSCs did not have an anti-frotic effect and may even worsened the condition by promoting collagen expression and tissue remodeling. Mice were infected with P. brasili and received either BSCs or the antifungal drug itraconazole (TC) alone or in combination. Histological analysis showed increased granulomatous areas and fibrocy count in BSC-treated mice. Soluble collagen and collagen-3, TGF-3, MMP-8, and MMP-15 genes were also increased in those mice. Combined therapy BSC/TC reduced TIM-1 and MMP-13 expression. Human fibroblasts stimulated with lung homogen from infected BSC-transplanted mice showed higher collagen expression. The study suggests that BSC therapy may not be effective against P. brasili infection and could even exacerbate fibrosis.
Researchers studied the seasonal patterns of sand fly species that transmit Leishmaniasis, a disease caused by Leishmania infant, in the Mediterranean region. They collected over 99,000 sand flies from 2011-2013 in 8 countries where the disease was reported. The study found 56,000 flies belonged to 6 species that can transmit Leishias. The flies were active at different times and in different places, with some appearing as early as April and others in June. The density of flies varied, with a peak in July-August and multiple peaks in May-September. A unique pattern was found in Cyprus with 3 peaks. Flies were active from September-November without correlation with temperature. The period of exposure to Leishias was July-September with a peak in July-October. No transmission occurred from December-March. Flies were most active at night, peaking between 11pm-2am. The study found a pattern of behavior that can be used for monitoring. The risk of Leishias transmission was highest June-October, but not evenly distributed, with earlier and more frequent in southern territories.
Scientists have discovered that the bacteria Orientia tsutsamushi, which causes scrub typhus, a disease prevalent in the Asia-Pacific region, can infect and alter the behavior of immune cells called monocytes. Monocytes are a type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in fighting off infections. When exposed to Orientia tsamushi, monocytes changed the expression of over 4,500 genes, including those involved in the production of interferon, a protein that helps fight off viruses and bacteria. The bacteria also induced the expression of genes related to apoptosis, or cell death, in a small percentage of monocytes. Researchers found that the changes in monocytes exposed to Orientia tsam were similar to those found in patients with scrub typhus. This is the first time monocytes have been shown to be polarized, or changed, in response to Orientia tsam in a lab setting. The study sheds light on the pathogenesis of scrub typh, which involves interferon activation of monocytes and their transformation into a specific type called M1. This may lead to new tools for diagnosing patients with typhus.
Scientists have long wondered how ants and other animals navigate complex environments using memory. A key part of the insect brain, called the mushroom body, has been linked to memory, but its function has been mostly studied for simple tasks like recognizing smells. Researchers took a model of the mushroom body developed for fruit flies and applied it to desert ants to see if it could help them learn routes in complex environments. They found that the model worked, allowing ants to quickly learn and remember routes in natural settings. The study suggests the mushroom body can store hundreds of images, or "snapshots," of the environment. 

The researchers used a computer simulation to test the model, feeding it real images of ants' views in their habitat. The model learned to distinguish between on-route and off-route images, showing it can be used for navigation. Notably, the model, made for simple smell recognition, needed little change to work for the more complex task of navigation. Ants and other insects have larger mushroom bodies than flies, which may help with this ability.
Plants have an innate immune system to protect themselves from disease, but they also have unique defense mechanisms like shedding leaves to replace damaged organs. Researchers studied how Arabidopsis thaliana leaves respond to bacterial infection by shedding. They infected Arabidopsis leaves with Pseudomonas syringae, a bacterium that lacks a type III secretion system, and found that it didn't trigger shedding. This suggests shedding is a new form of immunity triggered by bacterial effectors. Genes HAESA/HA2, INFRESC, and NES are needed for shedding to occur. Plants with mutations in genes for bacterial defense and salicylic acid signaling, like phytoalex, disease, and senescence, fail to shed leaves normally. Bacteria touching shedding zones trigger a strong response, but signals are also sent from infected tissue to alert the shedding zone of danger. The researchers propose a model where minor infections are handled by limiting growth, but when out of control, leaves are shed. Salicylic acid regulates both pathogen and drought-triggered shedding. They developed a system to study Pseudas syring pv tomato DC0 in Arabidopsis to understand defense mechanisms. This builds on a well-studied system where non-flowering Arabid leaves are infected with Pseudas syringe. The study defines a model for pathogen-triggered shedding in Arabid and explains genetics. The abission pathway is required for all forms of inducible shedding in Arabid. The response is robust and can be triggered by disease or ET. Disparate pathways regulating defense and shedding are connected, and components are necessary for pathogen-trigger shedding. Salicy acid is necessary for full pathogen and drought shedding.
Researchers studied how starburst amacrine cells (SACs) in the retina detect motion direction. These cells generate larger calcium signals when motion is moving towards their tips than away from them. To understand how this direction selectivity (DS) works, they measured responses to expanding and contracting circular visual stimuli. They found that fundamental and harmonic frequency components were larger for expanding stimuli, suggesting nonlinearity. The relationship between harmonic amplitudes and potential indicates activation of voltage-gated channels. Calcium changes in dendrites due to voltage steps were monitored by two-photon microscopy, showing the distal dendrite is depolarized relative to the soma, due to tonic glutamgic input and high-voltage Ca+ channels. Compartment modeling suggests DS in SACs can be computed by dendrites relying on voltage channels and dendritic gradient, providing spatial asymmetry for discrimination.

Experiments used circular and CP wave stimuli, evoking DS somatic and dendritic Ca+ responses. Dendritic Ca+ responses were seen in a minority of cells, while electrical responses were present in all. Inhibitory blockers showed DS can be generated by a dend-intrinsic mechanism. Blocking GABA and glycine receptors was required to block effects on dendritic Ca signals, indicating GABA and glycine lateral inhibition contributes to DS. Pharmacological data showed DS persists when GABA receptor connections are blocked, suggesting SACs generate DS by themselves. Optical recordings showed strongest Ca+ increases in distal dendrites, near synapses. Dend morphology and low impedance at soma provide electrical isolation, necessary for local processing.
Researchers studied how different types of pathogens, such as bacteria, viruses, and fungi, infect humans and cause harm. They found that the number of pathogens needed to infect a host, called the infective dose, varies greatly between species. The type of molecules pathogens use to infect also plays a role. Those that act locally require fewer pathogens to infect than those that act from a distance. However, pathogens that act from a distance may be more harmful because they can infect many cells at once. The study tested this on 43 human pathogens from various groups and found that locally acting pathogens have lower infect doses but are not more harmful. Instead, harm is linked to the number of pathogens and how they enter the body. Those that enter through skin cause more harm than those inhaled or ingested. The study shows that understanding how pathogens work can explain why some are more infectious and harmful than others.
Researchers studied the role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the development of the parasitic worm Schistosoma mansoni, which causes schistosomiasis, a disease affecting 200 million people worldwide. They analyzed the 3' untranslated regions (3-UTR) of transcripts in juvenile and adult worms and found that the mi-277/498 family was significantly enriched in the transition from juvenile to adult stage. They identified a novel miRNA, sm-mi-498, located near smi-277, suggesting a miRNA cluster, and proposed hairpin structures for both miRNAs compatible with the miRNA pathway. Expression of smi-277/498 was upregulated in adults, while their targets were downregulated in adults but not in immature females. Smi-498 was expressed in tegument cells near the oesophagus and throughout the male body. The study suggests mi-277/498 plays a role in post-transcriptional regulation during development and sexual maturation of schistosomes.
Researchers have discovered a large pool of SARS-related coronaviruses (SARS-CoV) in horseshoe bats in China. These viruses are different from the SARS virus that caused a global outbreak in 2003. The researchers found 11 new SARS-Co viruses in a cave in Yunn Province, China and compared them to previous findings. They found that S-CoVs in this cave are diverse, especially in genes OR3 and OR8. Importantly, some strains are similar to SARS in the hypervar N-terminal (NTD) and receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the S gene. They also found S-Co similar to human SARS in OR3 and split OR8. Additionally, S-Co from this cave are closer to S in non-structural genes OR1 and 1 compared to others. Recombination analysis shows recombination events in the gene and OR8 between S-Co. The researchers think the direct SARS progenitor may have come from recombination of these-Co precursors. Cell studies show three new-Co with different proteins can use human ACE as receptor, close to S-Co. This study gives new insights into SARS origin and importance of preparedness for future S-like diseases.
Researchers are examining the effectiveness of the faecal egg reduction test (FECRT) in detecting drug resistance in human hookworms. The test measures egg output before and after treatment to determine drug efficacy. However, a phenomenon called density-dependent fecundity, where worms increase egg production after treatment, may distort results. This can lead to underestimation of drug efficacy. The degree of underestimation depends on worms' ability to increase egg output, which varies among individuals. Cases with heaviest infections may increase egg output the most. Omitting these cases from FEC may reduce underestimation. Density-dependent fecundity affects the utility of FEC as a resistance tool, highlighting need for new methods like in vitro assays or genotypic changes.
Researchers have discovered that a molecule called heparan sulfate, found on the surface of epithelial cells, plays a crucial role in the development of the lung's tree-like structure. This structure is formed through a process called branching morphogenesis, where the lung grows and divides into smaller branches. The study found that removing heparan sulfate synthase, an enzyme that makes hepar, from epithelial cells, resulted in abnormal lung development. The lung's tips were larger and there were fewer branches, and there was a problem with the development of mesenchymal cells. The researchers also found that a protein called FGF was overexpressed in the mutant lungs, which likely contributed to the abnormal development. Further investigation showed that a protein called SHH, which suppresses FGF, was reduced in the mutant lungs. Reactivating SH in the lungs rescued the abnormal development and reduced FGF activity. The study found that the biologically active form of SH was reduced in the epithelial and surrounding mesenchym cells. This highlights the importance of hepar sulfate in SH signaling for lung development.
Researchers have developed a new technique called paired-end sequencing to detect genetic rearrangements in the genome, which are common in cancer and can create new genes. They wanted to know how much DNA to sequence to detect these rearrangements and where they are in the genome. They created a formula to calculate the probability of a gene fusion in a cancer genome given paired sequences and tested it on breast cancer samples. They found they could predict genes with a small number of large fragments. The ability to detect genes depends on gene length and sequencing parameters, and errors can lead to false positives. This will help future large-scale cancer studies enabled by next-generation sequencing technologies.

Paired-end sequencing is useful for detecting copy-neutral rearrangements like inversions and translocations, which are common in cancer and create new genes. The researchers focused on detecting rearrangement breakpoints, where two non-adjacent coordinates in the genome are adjacent in cancer. They extended this to fusion genes, which are created by rearrangements. Next-generation sequencing will make paired-end of cancer genomes reliable and precise for fusion detection. This will analyze all genomic events leading to cancer and shed light on cancer's genetic and genomic basis.

The probability of detecting genes depends on factors like number and length of sequenced clones, gene length, and errors in localization. They derived and tested formulae for experimental design of current and next-generation technologies. This makes studies more reliable across samples with limited reads. Paired sequencing has errors like artifacts, assembly errors, and mis-mapping, leading to incorrect or false positives. Whole-genome paired sequencing surveys all potential genes and rearrangements in tumors, advantages over transcript or protein studies.
Chemotaxis, the ability of cells to sense and move towards chemical gradients, is a complex process involving motility, gradient sensing, and polarization. Researchers have proposed that these processes are mediated by separate modules that, which, when combined, recreate the behaviors of chemotactic cells. A mathematical model using reaction-diffusion equations and a mechanical model of the cell's cortex demonstrates how these modules work together. The model includes an excitable network for random migration, a local excitation-global inhibition module for direction, and a polarization module linked to the cytoskeleton for persistent movement. By adjusting the strengths of feedback loops, the model replicates behaviors of genetically altered cell lines.

Experiments show that adaptation is not necessary for chemaxis, as cells without it perform less efficiently in uniform stimuli. However, adaptation allows cells to adjust sensitivity in the midpoint of a gradient. Simulations demonstrate that adaptation is not required for chemaxis. Cells can sense direction and respond to chemical gradients by polarizing and migrating towards attractants, a fundamental property of single and multicellular organisms. Experiments suggest chemaxis involves motility, sensing, and polarization.

A previous model, LEG-B, captured some features of chemotactic signaling, is expanded with two modules. A mechanical model simulates cytoskeleton deformations and movements. Polarized and unpolar cells coexist, and can acquire polarity during migration. The LEG-B simulates movement in various scenarios, illustrating complexity of chemactic machinery. Experiments show pathways have redundancy at the biochemical level.
Researchers have discovered a new role for a protein called Tudor domain-containing 6 (TD6) in the development of sperm cells. TD6 is essential for the formation of a structure called the chromatoid body, which is crucial for sperm development and fertility. The study found that TD6 interacts with a protein called protein methyltransferase 5, which helps with RNA splicing. TD6 also interacts with a protein called Sm in the absence of RNA, and this interaction is dependent on a process called arginine methylation. Without TD6, the assembly of a complex called the spliceosome is impaired, leading to increased levels of a type of RNA. In the nucleus, this affects the formation of structures called SM bodies and Cajal bodies, which are involved in RNA maturation. Analysis of TD-deficient sperm cells showed high levels of splicing errors, such as incorrect use of introns and exons and aberrant splicing junctions. This study reveals a new function of TD6 in the maturation of the spliceosome and splicing in early sperm development.
Researchers have studied how bacteria colonize a host and play a crucial role in health, serving as a reservoir for transmitting to other hosts and invasive strains emerging. To understand this, they need to know how bacteria are acquired and cleared from the host. Previous studies have used genetic distance between isolates to determine if they are the same or different, but this approach doesn't account for the diversity within-host population, time between measurements, and uncertainty. A new Bayesian model is presented that calculates the probability of two strains being the same, allowing to determine clearance and acquisition from genomes over time. It models within-host variation using genetic simulation and uses Approximate Bayesian Computation and Markov Chain Monte Carlo for inference. The method is validated with simulations and applied to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus isolates from a clinical study. The model doesn't rely on a fixed distance threshold and provides uncertainty estimates for relevant quantities. It's based on the idea that a "strain" is a population of closely related isolates. The study aims to understand colonization dynamics by inferring if bacteria at different times represent the same or distinct events, enabling calculation of acquisition and clearance rates. Whole-genome sequencing provides genetic distance between isolates, used to infer their relationship.
Plants grow new organs through the activity of stem cells called meristems. The shoot apical meristem creates leaves and flowers, while lateral merist create highly ordered, spiraled or whorled patterns through a process called phyllaxis. The transport of the hormone auxin is thought to play a major role in this process. Current hypotheses propose that hormone transporters of the PIN family create auxin maxima at precise positions, leading to organ initiation. To explain how transporters create flux to regions within the plant, different concepts have been proposed. A major hypothesis, canalization, suggests transporters amplify and stabilize existing flux, which could be initiated by diffusion. This explains organized auxin flux during vein formation, but shoot apical meristem requires a second hypothesis where hormone is transported to areas with highest concentrations. This implies two different mechanisms for PIN in membrane, based on sensing and concentration. Patterning requires interaction of hundreds of cells, making it impossible to estimate if a scenario is plausible. Computational modeling provides a means to test this hypothesis. A computer simulation shows flux-based hypothesis explains auxin at meristem, providing a unifying concept for control in plants. Experiments are needed to distinguish flux-based and other hypotheses.
Researchers have been working to develop a new diagnostic test for visceral leishmaniasis, a disease caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani. They used a combination of lab experiments and computer searches to find potential biomarkers. Previous studies showed that IgG, a part of the immune system, could be used to monitor the disease in rapid tests. However, these tests were not very reliable. The researchers replaced the crude antigen used in these tests with specific ones and found that they were more accurate. They identified proteins from the parasite that IgG reacted with and used computer searches to predict which parts of these proteins were most likely to be recognized by the immune system. They tested these predictions in a small group of patients and found that one was 84% sensitive and 95% specific. This is a promising result for developing more reliable tests to monitor the disease. The team used computer searches to reduce the number of proteins to test, focusing on those with specific features. They predicted which parts of these proteins were likely to be recognized by the immune and tested these in a small group of patients, finding one that was 84% sensitive and 95 specific. This is a proof of concept for developing more reliable tests to monitor the disease. The team used computer searches to reduce the number of proteins to test, focusing on those with specific features. They predicted which parts of these were likely to be recognized by the immune and tested in a small group of patients, finding one that was 84% sensitive and 95 specific. This is a proof of concept for developing more reliable tests to monitor the disease.
Researchers studied 317 cases of cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) from six countries: Syria, Pakistan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Ethiopia, Iran, and others. They found caseating granulomas in 61.5% of cases, which were divided into three types: caseating (25.2%), suppurative (4.6%), and tuberculoid without necrosis (70.2%). Caseating and tuboid granuloma groups were different in terms of geography, with more cases in Saudi Arabia. Histologically, both groups differed in the distribution of Ridley's pattern (RP), with RP3 in caseating granulomas (31%) and RP5 in tuboid granuloma (38%). Time to healing was shorter in tuboid vs case group (4.0 vs 6.2 months). Parasitic index, species, and other variables did not differ between granuloma groups. 18.2% of CL cases had caseating granulomas, suggesting CL should be considered in differential diagnosis in endemic regions. Cases with caseating granulomas showed slower healing, no association with species, possibly due to worse immune response or aggressive leishmania strains.
Researchers have identified a gene that may contribute to the development of type 2 diabetes in mice. The gene, called Zfp69, is a zinc finger transcription factor that helps control the expression of other genes. In mice with a version of the gene that doesn't work properly develop diabetes and obesity. The researchers found that a retrotransposon, a piece of genetic material that can jump from one location to another, disrupted the gene in mice that don't develop diabetes. In contrast, mice with a working version of the gene develop diabetes and obesity. The researchers also found that mice with a working version of the gene on a human gene, ZNF642, had higher levels in fat tissue of people with type 2 diabetes. This suggests that Zfp may play a role in the development of type 2 diabetes. The researchers conclude that Zfp is the most likely cause of the diabetes in mice and that the retrotranson contributes to genetic differences between strains.
Researchers have developed a new model to predict how cells in the vertebrate hematopoietic system differentiate into different types. This system has many branching pathways and cell types, making it a challenging to understand. The model combines regulatory and signalling pathways controlling cell differentiation. It uses a logical approach to analyze extensive data, which is mostly qualitative. To handle the network's size and complexity, a reduction method is used with a state identification algorithm. Simulations were done in various environments to see how they affect cell differentiation. Stable states were found for Th1, Th2, Th17, and Treg subtypes, but also hybrid cells co-expressing Th, Th, Th2, and Treg markers in environment-dependent. The model shows the nature of these types and their relationships with Th subtypes. It can be used to explore new pathways in silico.
Researchers used a mathematical model to study how proteins called transcription factors bind to DNA in fruit fly embryos. These proteins help control which genes are turned on or off during development. They bind to thousands of spots on the genome, but how and where they bind is not well understood. The model predicted where and how five proteins bind based on DNA and protein-DNA affinities, but was only 40% accurate. Adding interactions between proteins and spatial patterns in the nucleus didn't improve accuracy. Many predicted bindings didn't happen in real life, likely due to closed chromatin. Measuring DNA accessibility improved predictions to 60-90% accuracy. The model showed that in open chromatin, binding is mostly determined by protein sequence, not interactions. Combining accessibility data and simple models can predict protein binding with high accuracy.
In the fruit fly Drosila, two proteins called Daughterless (Da) and Extramacchaetea (Em) play a crucial role in regulating cell growth and development. These proteins belong to a family of transcription factors called basic helix-loop-helix (bHL) that control cell proliferation in many animals. Research has shown that these factors are often misregulated in cancer cells. To understand how they work, scientists studied the development of epithelial cells in imaginal discs. They found that Em controls the transition from G2 to M phase and cell division through a protein called Cdc phosphatase string. When Em levels are low or Da are high, string is overexpressed, which rescues proliferative defects. The study also shows Da acts as a transcription repressor of string. This defines a mechanism by which Em controls cell growth by regulating Da, which represses string transcription.
Scientists have developed a new method to study how cells respond to stress by changing the way they grow and divide. They used a technique called phosphoproteomics to look at how proteins in yeast cells change when they are stressed. Phosphroteomics is different from proteomics because it looks at how proteins change, not just what proteins are there. The team created a pipeline to analyze phosphrote data from experiments to find important proteins and how they interact. They used this pipeline to study yeast and found 24 proteins involved in stress response and 9 in growth. Four of these proteins were tested and shown to affect growth, validating the method. This pipeline can be used to study other cells and find new proteins to investigate.
Researchers studied how the regulation of the X chromosome in fruit fly (Drosophila) male germline. They found that the X chromosome does not undergo dosage compensation, which is the equalization of X gene expression in males and females, in most of the male germl. They also found no evidence of meiotic sex chromosome inactivation (MSCI), which is the silencing and heterochromization of the X during meiosis in the male or female germl. The team discovered that the reduced expression of X-linked genes in Doph testes does not reflect a meiosis process, and microarray data show no overall reduced expression of the X in cells for meiosis-stage spermatocytes. They found that the expression of endogenous X-linked genes in Doph test is affected by evolved differences in chromosomal gene content, not dosage compensation or MCI. The study resolves previous conflicting reports and has implications for patterns of genome and speciation in Doph.
Researchers have studied how Citrobacterium, a bacteria that causes diarrhea in mice, infects the gut. They found that the bacteria form colonies on the gut lining of the intestines, called "attachment and effacement" (A/E) lesions. These colonies must constantly renew themselves by re-infecting the rapidly regenerating gut lining. It was unclear if these colonies come from planktonic bacteria in the gut or spread from sessile bacteria without a plankton phase. The study focused on the early stages of infection and found that colonic A/E colonies are clonal populations that depend on local growth to persist. In healthy mice, these colonies are established within 18 hours of infection. These early events shape the severity of infection despite the presence of virulent bacteria. Mechanistically, resistance to A lesion formation is mediated by TLR4/My88/Tr signaling and induced by virulent Citrobium in a gene-dependent manner. The study shows that Citrobium pathogenesis is restricted to a short window that determines disease severity.
Researchers have developed a new method to estimate the overlap between two populations, such as species or genes, when only a fraction of each population is sampled. This is a common problem in fields like ecology and epidemiology, where data is often incomplete. The new method, called Bay-opt estimation, uses Bayesian inference to account for the sampling rates and produces unbiased estimates of overlap. It also calculates the uncertainty of the estimates and can be used to plan future studies by balancing sampling effort and uncertainty.

The method is based on a special case of the diversity problem, where the total number of objects in each population is known. This is different from most existing indices, which assume complete data and lead to bias. The new method can be used for presence-absence data, but requires species abundance data for others. An example is estimating the overlap between two types of malaria parasites, each with 60 types. The goal is to find the true overlap if both were fully sampled. The method can also quantify uncertainty in the estimates.

The method can be improved by incorporating whole-genome data as prior, making it useful for studying Plasium spp. multig antigen families or general diversity in multig families.
Scientists have long known that eukaryotic kinases, a type of enzyme, regulate cellular functions by adding a phosphate group to targeted proteins through a highly conserved catalytic core. However, the interactions that control the active state of this core were not well understood. Researchers used cAMP protein kinase as a model and combined biochemical, biophysical, and computational techniques to identify a set of conserved electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions that harmoniously regulate the mechanics. These include a salt bridge between a lysine from the β-strand and glutamate from α-helix, and electrostatic interaction between phosphorylated loop and α-helix and ensemble of hydrophobic residues of Regulatory Shell. Contrary to previous thought, the conserved lysine in β-str is not required for phosphorylation but essential for active state. The α-phates of ATP interact with conserved lysine in β-strand, forming a bridge with glutamate from α-helix. In absence of bridge and electro interaction, active state can be regulated through Shell. Enhancing hydrophity of from leucine to phenylane connected β-region and α-h through hydro interaction between Sh2 and Sh from β-region and RS from α-h. Results show it's possible to rescue catalytic activity by repositioning lys onto loop. Mutating glutamate to alanine destabilized active conformation associated with Shell, unable to undergo autophosphorylation, transphosphorylation, or catalysis. However, assembly can be partially restored by coexpressing with PDK, introducing interaction between phosphorylated loop and H from α-h. β is not required for phosphorylation but structural sensor facilitating state by coordinating β-region with α-h.
American Samoa conducted seven rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) to eliminate lymphatic filariasis (LF) from 2000-2006. The World Health Organization recommends systematic post-MDA surveillance using Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) for epidemiological assessment of recent transmission. This study compared the effectiveness of two survey designs for post-M surveillance: a school-based survey of children aged 6-7 and community-based survey of people aged 8. In 2016, a school survey was conducted in 29 elementary schools and a cluster survey in 28 villages on two islands. Blood samples were tested for circulating filarial antigen (CA) using Alere Filariasis Strip. The school survey identified 9 antigen-positive children with an overall CA prevalence of 0.7%, while the community survey identified 102-positive people with a prevalence of 6.2%. Prevalence increased with age and was higher in males. The school survey had limited sensitivity and negative predictive value but high specificity and positive value for identifying villages with transmission. The community survey identified antigen individuals of all ages and foci of high prevalence. Both confirmed recrudence of transmission.
Researchers studied how sex is determined in zebraf fish, a common model organism. They found that sex is not just determined by one gene, but by multiple factors that can vary between strains and are influenced by environment. Germ cells, specifically oocytes, are needed for females to develop. But how oocytes control sex and maintain the female state is unknown. The study looked at two oocyte-produced signals, Bmp and Gdf9, and found Bmp plays a role in maintaining female sex in zraf. Females without Bmp develop normally but switch to males during mid-juvenile stage and become fertile. They also found estrogen is needed for female development and Bmp's function is linked to regulating estrogen production in oocytes. 

In the study, researchers tested if G9 and Bmp have a role in sex determination or female differentiation in zraf. They found Bmp females develop normally but switch to males during juvenile stage. Results provide insights into how oocytes regulate sex in zraf. The hypothesis is that o-gon interaction stabilizes c19a1 expression and estrogen by somatic gonad. Consistent, somatic gonad expresses Bmp receptors. c19 functions as a switch to determine female in zraf and medaka, animals without o develop as males, regardless of genotype, and oocytes are needed in adult zraf to maintain sex. This led to hypothesis that oocytes produce a signal to stabilize female expression in somatic gon, promoting ovarian fate. Two genes, c19a and Bmp, are needed for female development and maintenance. These establish a pathway for female development and maintenance inraf likely conserved in other fish.
Scientists have long known that a group of proteins called Hox play a crucial role in shaping the development of an animal bodies by controlling the expression of specific genes along the front-to-back axis. To achieve this precise control, it's thought that H proteins work together with other factors to turn genes on or off in a highly specific way. However, only a few of these factors have been identified. Researchers studied the regulation of a gene called reaper (r) by the H protein Deformed (D) in fruit flies and found that its expression in the front part of the maxillary segment is achieved through a combination of D with eight different transcription regulators on a small enhancer. This suggests that combinations of H proteins and other factors on small modules called H response elements (HRE) are responsible for the correct placement and timing of H targets. The study found that eight regulators, including Apt, Gcm, E, ms, En, Sl1, Br, Doc, and Disco, are needed in addition to D to properly regulate r in a specific cells of the maxillary. Another H target gene, pr, is activated by D in the front of maxillary through four sites in a fragment. Since D is throughout maxillary, but pr is only locally, it's likely other factors contribute to specific D-dependent pr expression. The findings suggest that proper H target regulation is achieved by multiple regulators: H proteins and many diverse factors.
Plants have a built-in defense system to fight off pathogens, using proteins called nucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat (NB-L) sensors. These sensors recognize and respond to pathogen molecules inside and outside the cell. One such sensor, ADR-L2, works with salicylic acid (SA) to trigger defense responses. We studied the genetic requirements for ADR-L2 to function and found it acts as a "helper" to transduce signals from other sensors. ADR2 doesn't need an intact P-loop, but two related proteins do. We created an autoactive ADR2 mutation, A1D484, which leads to dwarf plants with high SA levels and disease resistance. This requires an intact P. We used A1D to define signaling requirements. A1 signaling doesn't need NAD oxidase and is regulated by E1 and At1. Transcription of A1 is linked to its outputs, both SA-dependent and-independent. Requirements resemble those for SA-dependent signal amplification and cell death. Importantly, A1 auto-signaling is controlled by E and SA in separate but linked pathways. This suggests a model for SA feedback regulation, including A2. ADR2 has non-canonical, P-independent helper functions in defense. We defined its canonical P-dependent functions and requirements. Wild-type A2 is required at BTH cell death in lsd mutant. Redundant E and SA in defense by sensor NB functions have been reported. Our results support this, constitutive A1 results in SA-dependent and-independent phenotypes. Plants respond to effectors with highly polymorphic intracellular resistance R proteins. NB-Ls are activated by effectors to trigger robust responses, including hypersensitive death. We created auto A1, A1 plants exhibit dwarf and constitutive defense. This requires an P. We used as proxy for canonical A in epistasis. A model consistent with new and previous analyses. Several NBs work in pairs, one as effector-sensor, the other helper. This may form higher complexes for regulated activation.
Researchers have identified two components of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) pathway in Arabidopsis, SUVH and ID2, which interact with the protein MOR6 to mediate transcriptional silencing. They found that SUV2 and SUV9 can act together with MOR6 or synergistically to silence genes, and ID2 interacts with MOR6 to silence a subset of MOR6 target loci. Other RDM components, including Pol IV, V, R2, and DRM2, are also required for silencing at a subset of MOR6 loci. MOR6 was previously shown to silence genes through heterochrom condensation, and researchers found that the SWI/SNF chrom-remodeling complex interacts with MOR6 and SUV9 to mediate silencing. This suggests that RDM components are involved in both methylation and MOR6-mediated heteroch condensation. The study shows how methylation is linked to heteroch condensation and enhances silencing at methylated regions.
Researchers studied the role of heat shock protein 90 (Hsp) in modifying phenotypes in vertebrates, using zebraf as a model. They found that inhibiting H90 did not induce a heat shock response or perturb phenotype in wild-type strains, but increased the severity of a recessive eye phenotype caused by a p6 mutation, while decreasing the severity of another caused by su mutation. A new spectrum of severe eye malformations, including anophthalmia, microphthalmia, and nanthalmia, was uncovered by limited H90 inhibition. Breeding offspring from unaffected parents led to elevated malformation frequencies, revealing the oligogenic nature of this phenotype. Unlike Drosila, H90 inhibition decreased developmental stability in zraf, indicated by increased asymmetric presentation of anophia, microphthalm, and nanthalm phenotypes. Analysis of p6 mutation suggests a mechanism for buffering by H90. The studies imply that mild perturbation of H90 at developmental stages may underpin variable penetrance and express of anomalies where genotype and environment play a role.
Researchers have identified and studied a common protein modification in living organisms called N-terminal acetylation, where the N-terminus of a protein becomes acetylated after translation. They analyzed proteins from fruit fly cells and found over 1,200 mature N-termini, showing N acylation occurs with similar frequency in insects and humans. A rule, called the X PX rule, determines when acetylation happens, and can be used to genetically engineer proteins to study its importance. By expressing mutated proteins in cells and flies, the researchers created an assay to test N acylation's role. This method can be applied to other species, as the rule seems valid in both simple and complex organisms, allowing the study of N acylation's function.
Researchers studied how an enzyme called RNA polymerase III (RNAP III) helps produce a type of RNA called transfer RNA (tRNA) in cells. tRNA is crucial for cell growth and development and cancer. To understand how RN III works, they looked for mutations that affect its ability to stop and start producing tRNA. They found 122 mutations in the yeast Saccharomyces pombe and mapped them to a 3.9 angstrom structure of RN III. The mutations were in the active center of the enzyme, including the bridge, loop, and pore, and funnel. The pore is where the RNA is cut by the C subunit. They purified RN III from a mutant that didn't stop producing tRNA and found it had a faster elongation rate. This suggests that the rate of producing RNA is inversely related to stopping. Mutants that didn't stop producing tRNA made more of it than normal cells, not just because they produced it faster. This was confirmed with a reporter gene that had a processing defect and strong terminator. They ruled out differences in RNA decay and found that mutants made more tRNA. Mutations didn't affect the III repressor M1. The study shows that parts of the active center, including C, are key to stopping and some activate III for transcription. Similar mutations in cancer suggest a new way III is activated in disease.
Researchers have developed a new method to predict which proteins interact with SH2 domains, a type of protein that binds to phosphopeptides. They used the structure of SH-phosphope complexes and an algorithm called FoldX to make predictions. The approach worked as well as experimentally derived sequences and substitution matrices in predicting known SH2 targets in vitro and in vivo. The team applied the method to a set of human SH domains with known structure and phosphorylation state, providing a list of high-confidence interactions. Predictions were validated using literature-derived SH interactions and a probabilistic score from Bayes integration of coexpression, conservation, interaction in other species, shared partners, and functions. The predictions led to a new hypothesis for SH role in signaling.

The method was tested on nine SH domains and showed applicability for genome-wide predictions. Structure-based prediction of SH-mediated protein-protein interactions has been addressed once before. The team believes future methods should account for both physics and biology of SH domains. They used Fold to predict in vivo interactions for nine SH-containing proteins and annotated with predicted interactions, providing a resource for further testing. Fold performed as well as consensus or substitution matrices in prediction in vitro SH-phope binding and SH-mediated protein interactions. With information on phosphorylation and structure, Fold gave accurate predictions of protein-protein interactions.
Researchers have discovered a protein called cyclophilin 40 (Cy40) that can break down toxic protein clumps called amyloids in the brain, which are a hallmark of neurodegenerative disorders like Alzheimer's disease. These clumps are made of a protein called tau, which is normally helps with cell structure but becomes toxic when misfolded. Cy40 is a type of enzyme that changes the shape of proline, a type of amino acid in tau, which makes it less likely to clump together. In lab tests, Cy40 broke down tau clumps and improved brain health and memory in a mouse model of Alzheimer's. It also interacted with other proteins with prolines and broke them apart. Without its enzyme activity, it couldn't do this. This is the first time a protein has been found to break down amyloids inside cells. The researchers think this could be a new way to treat Alzheimer's and other neurodegenerative diseases.
Researchers have developed a mathematical model to study how cyanobacteria filaments form and sustain heteroc patterns, a type of cellular differentiation in multicellular organisms. The model combines the genetic circuit of a single cyanobacter with the diffusion of nitrogen along the filament, capturing the development and maintenance of heteroc patterns. By simulating the behavior of a single cyanacter under nitrogen deprivation and coupling their genetic circuits via diffusion, the model shows how heteroc patterns can be generated and sustained. Including noise and external conditions in the model reproduces the main features of heteroc formation and sustainment observed in experiments. The model is based on recent results on the genetic network of cyanobacteria and system biology theory, connecting macroscopic and microscopic processes. It captures the dynamical properties of the genetic circuit and diffusion of nitrogen along the filament. The model shows that noise plays a key role in the onset of differentiation, enabling characteristic heteroc patterns for various parameters. This suggests cyanobacteria have an efficient response to environmental conditions. The model consists of a filament of cyanacteria, each with a dynamical circuit, interacting via protein diffusion.
In Cameroon, despite over 15 years of mass treatment, onchocerciasis prevalence remains above the transmission threshold. A study in three districts with high oncherciasis prevalence aimed to explore the association between people's perceptions of onchiasis and the Community Treatment with Ivermect (CTI) program and their adherence to iverectin. The study found that perceptions of the program were the most determinant of adherence toiverin. Those with a positive opinion ofiverect distribution were more compliant than those with a negative opinion (40% vs 55 in Bang, 48 vs 62 in Bafia). Misconceptions about onchias transmission were common, especially in Bafia and Yassi, where people believed it was due to lack of hygiene. In Bang, many believed it was due to high sugar consumption. Perceptions ofiver distribution were strongly associated with adherence. Education and sensitization onchias during CT implementation and community involvement are recommended.
Researchers investigated the relationship between genetic and epigenetic variations and protein biomarkers for cancer and cardiovascular disease by combining DNA methylation and SNP data with protein measurements. They analyzed 121 biomarkers in relation to DNA methylation at 470,000 positions and 10 million SNPs in 698,103 samples. Epigen-wide association study (EWAS) and genome-wide association study (GW) analyses were performed, and biomarker, DNA methylation, and SNP data were integrated. The study found 124 loci with significant effects up to 0.22 units change per 1% methylation and 4 units per allele copy in EW and GW, respectively. Most GW loci were cis-regulatory, while EW were in trans. Eleven EW loci were associated with multiple biomarkers, including NL5 with CX11, CX9, IL-12, and IL-18. EW signals overlapping with GW were driven by genetic variants, while EW were confounded by smoking. Cis-regulatory SNPs for biomarkers had effect on methylation, but not vice versa. The study suggests epigenetic variation has limited direct effect on biomarkers, reflecting genetic, environmental, or secondary effects of disease pathogenesis.
Researchers studied how the varicella zoster virus (VZV) affects natural killer (NK) cells, a type of immune cell that fights off viruses. They found that VV directly impairs NK cells' ability to respond to stimulation, leading to a loss of killing and cytokine production. Not only infected NK cells, but also uninfected cells exposed to VV in culture were affected. This impairment was due to direct contact between NK cells and VV-infected cells. NK cells maintained surface receptor expression but couldn't respond to stimulation, suggesting VV paralysed them from responding. VV also blocked degranulation and cytokine production, including IF-γ and TNF. Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) also infected NK cells and made them unresponsive, but differently affected cytokine production compared to VV. The study reveals a new way VV evades the immune system by paralysing NK cells.
Researchers investigated the neural basis of apparent motion (AM), a phenomenon where two stimuli presented at different locations create the illusion of a moving stimulus between them. They found that AM affects the detection of gratings along the path, with maximum impairment at high contrast levels, and strongest when target orientation matches inducers. A population model of early visual processing, based on contrast normalization, suggests that AM-related activation in visual cortex is too small to cause masking or perceived motion. Instead, it predicts suppression of early responses during AM, consistent with predictive coding theory. Predictive models propose higher-level motion predictions "explain" lower-level responses to expected input. AM evokes responses in V cells tuned to locations and properties of inducers, interfering with actual stimuli perception. However, masking doesn't necessarily imply V1 activation. Predictive coding accounts provide an alternative, considering motion as predictable context. A stimulus on path is predictable when features match moving and appears at consistent time and place. Responses along path are suppressed in V1 when predictable. The study examined AM's effect on low-level processing, investigating detection of gratings along path. AM impairs detection when target matches inducers' orientation. A previous study measured performance at single intensity, but not maximum reduction, linked to uncertainty. The model captures results, but can't rule out effects in other early cortex areas.
Researchers have found that the HTLV-1 oncoprotein Tax plays a key role in transforming CD4 T cells by promoting cell growth and survival, mainly by activating the NF-κB pathway and inducing NF-κ target genes. To understand this process, they studied how Tax activates IK, a key component of the NF-κ pathway, in a cell-free system. They discovered Tax acts as an E3 ubiquitin ligase, working with Ubc2, Ubc5, or U7, to create mixed-link polyubiquitin chains. These chains directly activate IK by binding to its NEM subunit. This biochemical process clarifies how Tax activates IK, using minimal ubiquitination components for NF- activation, resolving confusion on HTL-1-induced IK-NF-κ activation. The study reveals cellular factors hijacked by HT-1 and may lead to new treatments for ATL and TSPAM.
Researchers have studied how the number of individuals introduced to a new population, known as propagule pressure, affects the success of alien species establishment. They analyzed data from various life forms, including invertebrates, plants, and vertebrates, and found a positive relationship between propagule pressure and success. However, success was most dependent on a range of 10-100 individuals. Heterogeneity in effect was mainly due to different analytical approaches, with larger effect sizes in animal introductions than plant introductions. Study scale and methodology did not influence the relationship. The study is the first to quantify the relationship between propag pressure and alien establishment, using meta-analytical methods. It reveals consistency in the form of the relationship between propag pressure and success.
Interleukin-17 (IL-17), a protein involved in chronic and severe inflammation, reduces the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by degrading encoding mRNAs. The degradation of these mRN depends on proteins (AUBs) that target AU-rich elements in the 3'-translated region of mRN, either facilitating decay or stabilization. Researchers found that AUs and mRNAs assemble in a ribonucleoprotein complex in the presence of microRNA (miR16), leading to degradation. Notably, IL-17 reduces miR expression and promotes binding of stabilizing AUs over destabilizing AUs, reducing degradation. This indicates miR independently directs competition between degrading and stabilizing AUs for mRN. Since AUs affect about 8% of the human transcriptome and miR is ubiquitously expressed, IL-17 may affect other cellular processes besides inflammation.

IL-17 changes the contribution of miR and AUs to degrade mRN. Besides IL-17, IL-β also degrades mRN. Epithelial and fibroblast IL-17 with TN-α degrades mRN encoding inflammatory mediators, resulting in hyper production of pro-inflammatory mediators. Researchers found mRN encoding IL-8, IL-6, and G-CS degraded by AMD pathway, depending on AUs and mi16. These findings show modulation of Ap-miR regulation by IL- depends on specific target, mi usage, and AUs participation.

IL-8 degradation was inhibited by AUF in absence mi16. IL-17 reduced mi binding to complex and promoted IL8 to AUF, stabilizing IL8. Similar for other ARE-mRN, AUs compete for binding, balance regulated by IL, via mi. IL-17 inhibition mi and mi using LNA resulted in degradation. Enhancing mi expression with lentiviral constructs promoted degradation.
In Uganda, both chronic and acute forms of sleeping sickness, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense, have been found in different areas of the country. Acute form has spread to new districts, linked to infected cattle movement. Cattle are long-term reservoirs of the parasite, showing few signs of illness but posing significant risk to human health. This study examined the relationship between cattle and human infection in villages in Kaberido and Dokolo districts. Villages with recent sleeping sickness cases had higher odds of cattle infection than those without. Cattle age affected the likelihood of infection, with those 18-36 months and over 36 months old having higher odds than under 18 months. Villages with sleeping sickness had higher detection of Trypanosoma brucei in cattle, with higher likelihood in case villages than non-case villages. A higher average Tryosoma bruce prevalence in a herd was associated with higher likelihood of Tryosoma rhodesense detection. The study found a strong association between high Tryoma bruce and Tryos rhodesense in villages, providing a means to determine risk at village level in districts.
Researchers have studied the role of the NS complex in regulating housekeeping genes in fruit flies. The NS complex is made up of several proteins, including NS1, NS3, MBD2, and MCR2, and is involved in modifying histone H4. They found that 85% of genes bound by the NS complex are constantly expressed across different cell types. These genes have specific histone modifications, such as H4ac, H2, H3, and H9, and a defined nucleosome-free region and broad transcription initiation patterns. The complex is required for efficient recruitment of RNA polymerase II to these genes, and its absence leads to reduced polymerase II and TBP and TFI binding. Genes that lose the most polymerase upon NS knockdown are involved in DNA replication. The study also found that NS targets constitutively expressed genes, or housekeeping genes, across 30 developmental stages of flies. These genes have elevated histone modifications and nucleosome-free regions.
Researchers have created a new mouse model to study a genetic disorder called facioscapulohumeral dystrophy (FD), which causes progressive muscle weakness and wasting. This disorder is caused by a decrease in epigenetic repression of the D4 macrosatellite repeat and ectopic expression of DUX, a gene encoding a transcription factor. People with FD generally have more than 10 repeats in the subtelomeric region of chromosome 4, while the most common form of FD is caused by contraction of the array to fewer than 10, associated with decreased epigen repression and variegated expression of DUX in muscle. The researchers generated transgenic mice carrying D4 arrays from FD allele and a control allele. These mice recapitulate epigen and DUX expression seen in patients and controls, including high DUX levels in germline, incomplete epigen repression in somatic tissue, and FD-specific varieg D4 expression in sporadic muscle associated D4 chromatin. They also show DUX activates similar gene groups in mouse cells as in human cells. These mice represent a valuable model for FD and will help study molecular mechanisms and test therapeutic strategies.
Researchers have been trying to develop a vaccine against malaria, a disease caused by Plasmodium falcum parasite, using a protein called Apical Membrane Antigen-1 (AMA1). However, the current vaccine only protects against strains similar to the one used in the vaccine, not all strains of the parasite. To overcome this problem, scientists need to understand how the vaccine works against different strains. They created a vaccine with four different versions of AMA1 proteins, called Quax or Q, and found it elicited antibodies that inhibited four different strains of the parasite. Comparing these antibodies to ones made by a single-strain vaccine, they found Quax induced higher levels of broadly inhibitory antibodies, associated with conserved domain-3 and reduced domain-2 responses. Monoclonal antibodies against Qu reacted with a cross-reactive epitope on the hydrophobic trough domain-1, which is conserved on AMA1 and includes the 1-loop. These antibodies were 10 times more potent than previous ones and blocked AMA binding to its ligand R2. Another antibody, E, bound to domain-3, was broadly inhibitory and blocked proteolytic processing of AMA. By itself was weakly inhibitory but synergized with another antibody, G, which binds to conserved face and inhibits R2 binding to AMA. Novel susceptible and epitopes identified can improve antigen breadth and inhibitory response of AMA vaccines. Vaccination with diverse proteins may provide universal coverage by redirecting response to conserved epitopes.
Researchers have discovered a mechanism that controls the timing of mitotic spindle displacement in cells, which is crucial for unequal cell division. The mitotic spindle is a structure that separates chromosomes during cell division, and its displacement to one side of the cell is necessary for cells to divide unequally. While some molecular mechanisms of spindle displacement are known, the timing of this process was unclear. A conserved mechanism of mitotic progression, the anaphase-promoting complex (APC), its activator Cdc20/Fizzy, its target cyclin, and cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK), was linked to spindle timing. The researchers found that these components form a timer for spindle displacement in Caenorhabditis zygote. Mitotic spindle displacement begins at a precise time after chromosomes congress to metaphase plate. Reducing function of proteasome, APC, or C20/Fizzy delayed spindle, while inactivating CD in metaphase caused spindle to displace early. Experimentally unlinking spindle from this mechanism resulted in premature displacement of incompletely assembled mitotic components. The study shows that spindle positioning is delayed until APC inactivates CD, ensuring spindle does not move until fully assembled. This is the first demonstration of mitotic timing spindle in animal cell division. The link between cell cycle and asymmetric division might be evolutionarily conserved, as spindle displaced at similar stage of mitosis in diverse systems.
Researchers studied the genetic adaptations of people living in high-altitude regions, specifically the Andean and Tibetan populations, to understand how they cope with low oxygen levels. These populations have developed unique physiological responses to high altitude, but the genetic basis of these adaptations was unknown. A genome scan was conducted to identify genes showing signs of adaptation to low oxygen levels. The study looked at each chromosome for regions with unknown functions related to altitude and examined genes involved in oxygen sensing. Four statistics were used to detect natural selection, identifying candidate genes and regions in both populations. Results showed distinct patterns of adaptation, with different genes and regions selected in each population. One gene, EGLN, important for oxygen sensing, was selected in both groups, but with different variations. Key genes and chromosomal regions were linked to high-altitude adaptation, providing a basis for future studies to confirm the role of selected genes.
Double-strand breaks (DSBs) in DNA are a major source of genetic instability that can result from environmental assaults or DNA replication errors. Efficient repair of DSBs is crucial for cell survival, but faulty repair can lead to genetic instability, making the choice of DSB repair pathway important. Researchers found that inverted DNA repeats (IRs) near DSBs can channel repair into a pathway that leads to gene conversion instead of break-induced replication (BIR) that causes instability. IRs form unusual DNA structures when in single-strand DNA is formed by D-section. They can form two types of structures: inter-molecular single-strand annealing (SSA) leading to inverted dimers and intra-molecular SSA leading to fold-back (FB) structures. Both interfere with accurate DSB repair and channel D into BIR, promoting genomic destabilization. Different protein complexes process FB with short (12-b) versus long (1-k) DNA loops: MR-Sae2 for short and Rad-Rad10 for long. The study uncovers mechanisms of genomic destabilization from DSB repair by IR. Given IRs abundance in the genome, findings may contribute to understanding IR-mediated destabilization with human disease.
Researchers have developed a new animal model to study how the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa causes infections in the fruit fly Drosila melanogaster. Pseudas aerugin is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause both acute and chronic infections in susceptible hosts, and chronic infections are thought to be caused by biofilms. Biofilms are structured, multicellular communities of microbes encased in an extracellular matrix that enable long-term survival in the host. The researchers infected Drosila with P aerugin and found biofilms formed in the fly's crop, with a characteristic structure and extracellular matrix of DNA and exopolysacide. Pugin cells from biofilms had increased resistance to antibiotics compared to planktonic cells. Biofilm formation was dependent on the exopolyside genes, as a mutant failed to form biofilms. The mutant was more virulent than PA1, while a hyperfilm strain demonstrated less virulence than PA1, indicated by fly survival at 14 postinfection. Biofilm formation by PA1 and in the crop was associated with induction of antimicrobial gene expression 24 postin.
Researchers studied the vasopressin 1 receptor 1 (Av1) gene, which plays a key role in social behaviors, and found that its expression varies between and within species. They looked at the 5' flanking region of the gene and a microsatellite element, a repetitive DNA sequence, to see if they contribute to this variation. Using mice, they found that the 5' flanking region contributes to differences in Av receptor distribution in the brain and impacts behavior in a stress test. They also found that the microsatellite structure affects Av expression in the amygdala, thalamus, and hippocampus, mirroring species differences in receptor patterns. This is the first evidence that microsatellites near genes can affect brain expression and contribute to behavior diversity. However, many species-specific patterns are not explained by the 5 flanking region alone. A 4kb of the 5 flanking region contributes to species-specific receptor patterns in the brain. Transgenic mice with the prairie vole Av1 locus show similar receptor patterns to prairie voles and increased affiliative behavior. This shows Av1 expression in the brain contributes to inter and intra-species variability in vasopress behaviors. The Av1 is a model for exploring genomic mechanisms of brain expression and behavior. The findings suggest that microsatellites can enhance evolvability by increasing gene expression.
Researchers have discovered that a protein called Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID) can cause double-strand breaks in the DNA at specific regions of the immunoglobulin genes and the c-MYC gene in yeast cells. These breaks can lead to chromosomal translocations, which are responsible for a type of cancer called Burkitt's lymphoma. The study used yeast cells that are impaired in a complex called TH, which is involved in making ribonucleic acid (RNA), to understand how ID causes instability in the genome. They found that ID induces breaks in the DNA at the immunoglobulin and c-M sequences in TH mutants, which are unable to make RNA. The breaks are then repaired by a process called Non-homous Joining (NHE). The study shows that yeast and human cells have similar ways to process ID-induced breaks into double-strand breaks, which can lead to chromosomal rearrangements. The research provides new insights into the role of RNA in preventing genome rearrangements and the mechanism of ID-mediated instability. It also shows that once cytosine residues produced by ID are processed into double-strand breaks and chromosomal rearrangements by conserved DNA repair functions in yeast and human cells.
Researchers studied how the bacteria E. coli divides its cells when the division plane is not properly aligned with its chromosomes. They used a microscope to track the movement of DNA during cell division and found that a protein called Fts can move up to 80% of the chromosome from one daughter cell to the other at a rate of 1700-800 base pairs per second. This movement happens when the cell is almost fully divided and the division protein ZipA has left the septum. The sept is a narrow channel with a diameter smaller than 250 nanometers, which is necessary for Fts to move the DNA. The study shows that E. coli can reposition its chromosomes even if the division plane is not aligned. This is different from the common view that the division plane must be aligned with the chromosomes for the cell to be viable. The researchers also found that F can move more DNA than previously thought, up to 3.7 megabases, which is the entire chromosome. The movement happens when the sept is small and F can bind to DNA. The study suggests that the sept acts as a checkpoint to prevent the daughters from separating too early.
Researchers have developed a mathematical framework for selecting the optimal set of peptides for epitope-based vaccines, which are used to prevent or treat various diseases, including infectious and cancer. The framework, based on integer linear programming, identifies the best combination of peptides from a given set that will elicit the strongest immune response. This is important because each person's major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules are unique, making a combination effective for one person may not work for another. The framework can incorporate various requirements for a good vaccine, such as covering multiple antigens and avoiding peptides with high mutation rates. It outperforms previous methods and can solve problems in seconds. The approach is flexible and can be applied to personalized vaccines. The goal is to maximize overall immunogenicity while meeting requirements, such as covering all MHC alleles. This is the first framework to find provably optimal solutions for vaccine design. Examples show how immunological requirements can be translated into the framework, yielding optimal sets of peptides. The approach does not suggest a single strategy, but a framework to work with different definitions of a good vaccine. The goal is to maximize immunogenicity while meeting requirements, which can be formulated as an integer program.
Interleukin-7 Facilitates HIV-1 Transmission to Cervico-Vag Tissue

A new study investigated the role of interleukin-7 (IL-7) in HIV-1 transmission to the cervico-vaginal tissue. IL-7 is a cytokine found in semen, and its levels are higher in HIV-1-infected men. Researchers simulated HIV-1 transmission by depositing the virus on cerv-vaginal tissue with IL-7 concentrations similar to those in HIV-1-infected men. They found that IL-7 increased HIV-1 replication in the tissue and in lymphoid explants. Analysis of infected cells showed IL-7 reduced CD4 T cell apoptosis and increased the number of cycling CD4 cells. High IL-7 levels in semen may help HIV-1 survive and spread in the cervag mucosa at the start of infection.

The study is the first to look at IL-7's role in male-to-female HIV transmission. Results show that cervag and lymph tissues exposed to IL-7 at semen levels found in HIV-1-infected men are more susceptible to HIV-1. IL-7 increased HIV-1 in tissues from different donors and even when HIV-1 was low. In lymph tissues, IL-7 increased HIV-infected CD4 cells. The study suggests high IL-7 in semen may make the female genital tract more susceptible to HIV.
Researchers studied how the Zika virus (ZIK) interacts with the RNA response system of Aedes aegypt mosquitoes, which spread the virus. They found that ZIK triggers the production of two types of small RNAs: virus-specific siRNAs and piRNAs. The siRNAs are loaded into a protein called Argonaute 2 (Ago2), but knocking down this protein did not stop the virus from replicating. However, in cells without Ago2, the virus replicated more, suggesting the siRNA pathway helps fight the virus. ZIK-specific piRNAs were detected, but lacked a specific signature and bound to Ago3, not Piwi or Pi6. Silencing these proteins did not enhance virus replication, but Pi4 showed antiv activity. The study also found that ZIK capsid protein increased replication of a different virus, unlike yellow fever protein which blocks siRNA.
In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, a study found that Sporothrix brasiliensis is associated with atypical presentations of sporotrichosis, a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix species.
